Matri filiisque in amore dedicatus。

Matri filiisque in amore dedicatus.

1

1

整体理念

THE MONOLITHIC IDEA

这个想法是杰克·基尔比在盛夏时节想到的，当时大家都在度假，只有他一个人在实验室里。事实证明，这个想法是宇宙级的，教科书中还给这个想法取了一个名字：整体理念。这个想法最终让基尔比获得了诺贝尔物理学奖。这有点奇怪，因为杰克没有接受过任何物理训练；瑞典皇家科学院愿意忽略这个小细节，因为杰克的想法确实让地球上几乎所有人的日常生活变得更好。但这一切都是未来的事情。当基尔比想到这个整体理念时——那是 1958 年 7 月——他只希望老板能让他建立一个模型并尝试一下这个新想法。

The idea occurred to Jack Kilby at the height of summer, when everyone else was on vacation and he had the lab to himself. It was an idea, as events would prove, of literally cosmic dimensions, an idea that would be honored in the textbooks with a name of its own: the monolithic idea. The idea would eventually win Kilby the Nobel Prize in Physics. This was slightly anomalous, because Jack had no training whatsoever in physics; the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences was willing to overlook that minor detail because Jack’s idea did, after all, change the daily life of almost everyone on earth for the better. But all that was in the future. At the time Kilby hit on the monolithic idea—it was July 1958—he only hoped that his boss would let him build a model and give the new idea a try.

老板仍是一个未知数。杰克·基尔比抵达达拉斯，开始在德州仪器公司工作还不到两个月，这位新员工还没有明确自己的定位。当著名的硅片先驱威利斯·阿德科克向杰克提供 TI 半导体研究小组的工作机会时，杰克感到高兴和受宠若惊。这几乎是杰克·基尔比职业生涯中的第一个好运；他将在电子行业最著名的公司之一工作，拥有可以帮助勤奋的年轻工程师解决重要问题的同事和设施。不过，这种喜悦中也有一些疑虑。杰克的妻子芭芭拉和他们的两个年幼的女儿在密尔沃基过得很开心，杰克的事业也在那里蒸蒸日上。在一家名为 Centralab 的小型电子公司工作的十年里，基尔比创造了 12 项可申请专利的发明（包括还原钛酸盐电容器和滑石封装晶体管）。每项专利都能从公司获得一笔小额奖金，并带来巨大的满足感。事实上，杰克后来表示，他在中央实验室最重要的发现就是发明的纯粹乐趣。这其实就是解决问题：你找出问题，研究 5 种、50 种或 500 种可能的方法，找到方法绕过自然界对材料和力的限制，并完善一个可行的解决方案。这是一个紧张而富有创造性的过程，杰克非常热爱它。正是对解决问题的痴迷，让他在 34 岁时冒险在达拉斯找到了一份新工作。德州仪器是一家重要的公司，它让他研究电子领域最重要的问题。

The boss was still an unknown quantity. It had been less than two months since Jack Kilby arrived in Dallas to begin work at Texas Instruments, and the new employee did not yet have a firm sense of where he stood. Jack had been delighted and flattered when Willis Adcock, the famous silicon pioneer, had offered him a job at TI’s semiconductor research group. It was just about the first lucky break of Jack Kilby’s career; he would be working for one of the most prominent firms in electronics, with the kind of colleagues and facilities that could help a hard-working young engineer solve important problems. Still, the pleasure was tempered with some misgivings. Jack’s wife, Barbara, and their two young daughters had been happy in Milwaukee, and Jack’s career had blossomed there. In a decade working at a small electronics firm called Centralab, Kilby had made twelve patentable inventions (including the reduced titanate capacitor and the steatite-packaged transistor). Each patent brought a small financial bonus from the firm and a huge feeling of satisfaction. Indeed, Jack said later that the most important discovery he made at Centralab was the sheer joy of inventing. It was problem solving, really: you identified the problem, worked through 5 or 50 or 500 possible approaches, found ways to circumvent the limits that nature had built into materials and forces, and perfected the one solution that worked. It was an intense, creative process, and Jack loved it with a passion. It was that infatuation with problem solving that had lured him, at the age of thirty-four, to take a chance on the new job in Dallas. Texas Instruments was an important company, and it was putting him to work on the most important problem in electronics.

到 20 世纪 50 年代末，这个问题——技术期刊称之为“互连问题”或“数字障碍”，或者更诗意地说，“数字暴政”——对电子界的物理学家和工程师来说已经很熟悉了。但对世界其他地方来说，这仍然是一个秘密。在 20 世纪 50 年代，在切尔诺贝利事故、挑战者号火箭爆炸、互联网色情或歌剧中途响起的手机出现之前，“技术进步”的概念仍然只有积极的含义。美国人满怀喜悦地期待着不久的将来，从迪克·特雷西的手腕收音机到巴克·罗杰斯的火星空军基地，所有科幻作品都将成为日常生活的事实。早在 1958 年，你就可以从口袋里掏出一台晶体管收音机——口袋里的收音机！——并听到有关一台巨型电子计算机正在接收人造卫星微型发射器以光速发射的信号的消息，该人造卫星以每小时 18,000 英里的速度绕地球运行。谁能责怪人们期待明天出现新的奇迹呢？

By the late 1950s, the problem—the technical journals called it “the interconnections problem” or “the numbers barrier” or, more poetically, “the tyranny of numbers”—was a familiar one to the physicists and engineers who made up the electronics community. But it was still a secret to the rest of the world. In the 1950s, before Chernobyl, before the Challenger rocket blew up, before the advent of Internet porn or cell phones that ring in the middle of the opera, the notion of “technological progress” still had only positive connotations. Americans were looking ahead with happy anticipation to a near future when all the creations of science fiction, from Dick Tracy’s wrist radio to Buck Rogers’s air base on Mars, would become facts of daily life. Already in 1958 you could pull a transistor radio out of your pocket—a radio in your pocket!—and hear news of a giant electronic computer that was receiving signals beamed at the speed of light from a miniaturized transmitter in a man-made satellite orbiting the earth at 18,000 miles per hour. Who could blame people for expecting new miracles tomorrow?

人们对未来新闻有着巨大的兴趣，杂志和报纸乐于满足这种兴趣。生物学、遗传学和医学领域的重大突破还需要几年时间，但在电子学领域，五十年代末几乎每个月都会出现一些惊人的创新。首先是晶体管，这项发明催生了新的电子时代——然后是晶体管、空间晶体管、微电子晶体管和晶闸管。当英国著名杂志《新科学家》预测即将开发一种新设备“神经晶体管”时，这似乎并不奇怪，它将执行人类神经元的所有功能，从而实现终极假体——人工大脑。1956 年末，《生活》杂志的一名记者挖出了五角大楼一项关于新型导弹的秘密计划——一种运兵导弹，可以在美国的一个基地搭载一个排，然后“穿越外太空，在不到 30 分钟的时间内将部队降落在敌后 500 英里的地方。”导弹鼻锥中的计算机将确保此类飞行所需的精确度。鼻锥中装有计算机？这本身就是异想天开。20 世纪 50 年代的计算机是巨型装置，可以占据整个房间——在某些情况下是整栋建筑——并消耗火车头的动力。但这也将让位于进步。UNIVAC 计算机的制造商斯佩里兰德 (Sperry-Rand) 据说正在研发可放在桌面上的计算机。1952 年 11 月 4 日，它在投票结束一小时后预测了德怀特·艾森豪威尔 (Dwight Eisenhower) 的选举胜利，从而一夜成名。而这仅仅是个开始。很快，公文包里、手表里、针头上都会有计算机。

There was an enormous appetite for news about the future, an appetite that magazines and newspapers were happy to feed. The major breakthroughs in biology, genetics, and medicine were still a few years away, but in electronics, the late fifties saw some marvelous innovation almost every month. First came the transistor, the invention that gave birth to the new electronic age—and then there was the tecnetron, the spacistor, the nuvistor, the thyristor. It hardly seemed remarkable when the venerable British journal New Scientist predicted the imminent development of a new device, the “neuristor,” which would perform all the functions of a human neuron and so make possible the ultimate prosthetic device—the artificial brain. Late in 1956 a Life magazine reporter dug out a secret Pentagon plan for a new kind of missile—a troop-carrying missile that could pick up a platoon at a base in the United States and then “loop through outer space and land the troops 500 miles behind enemy lines in less than 30 minutes.” A computer in the missile’s nose cone would assure the pinpoint accuracy required to make such flights possible. A computer in a nose cone? That was a flight of fancy in itself. The computers of the 1950s were enormous contraptions that filled whole rooms—in some cases, whole buildings—and consumed the power of a locomotive. But that, too, would give way to progress. Sperry-Rand, the maker of UNIVAC, the computer that had leaped to overnight fame on November 4, 1952, when it predicted Dwight Eisenhower’s electoral victory one hour after the polls closed, was said to be working on computers that would fit on a desktop. And that would be just the beginning. Soon enough there would be computers in a briefcase, computers in a wristwatch, computers on the head of a pin.

杰克·基尔比和他电子行业的同事们——那些本该让所有这些奇迹变成现实的人——读了这些文章，却觉得既遗憾又好笑。事实上，纸面上确实有实现大众媒体报道的几乎所有幻想的计划；事实上，初步的蓝图远远超出了大众的想象。工程师们已经开始制定他们的第一份粗略计划，用于制造高容量计算机，这种计算机可以驾驶火箭飞向月球，或者将世界上的每个图书馆连接到一个可以从任何办公桌访问的全球网络上。但这一切都只是纸面上的。由于数字的暴政所带来的限制，这一切都不可能实现。互连问题是阻碍电子技术未来所有进步的不可逾越的障碍。

Jack Kilby and his colleagues in the electronics business—the people who were supposed to make all these miracles come true—read the articles with a rueful sense of amusement. There actually were plans on paper to implement just about every fantasy the popular press reported; there were, indeed, preliminary blueprints that went far beyond the popular imagination. Engineers were already making their first rough plans for high-capacity computers that could steer a rocket to the moon or connect every library in the world to a single worldwide web accessible from any desk. But it was all on paper. It was all impossible to produce because of the limitation posed by the tyranny of numbers. The interconnections problem stood as an impassable barrier blocking all future progress in electronics.

现在，在达拉斯一个闷热的夏日，杰克·基尔比有了一个可能打破壁垒的想法。从一开始，他就认为自己可能会做出一些革命性的东西，但他尽力保持职业谨慎。毕竟，许多革命性的想法最终都存在致命缺陷。日复一日，他独自在空荡荡的实验室里工作，反复思考这个想法，在实验室笔记本上画图，画电路图，规划如何建立一个模型。作为一名发明家，杰克知道，如果你过于认真地看待它们，许多壮观的想法都会化为泡影。但这个不同：他研究得越多，寻找缺陷的次数越多，它看起来就越好。

And now, on a muggy summer’s day in Dallas, Jack Kilby had an idea that might break down the barrier. Right from the start, he thought he might be on to something revolutionary, but he did his best to retain a professional caution. A lot of revolutionary ideas, after all, turn out to have fatal flaws. Day after day, working alone in the empty lab, he went over the idea, scratching pictures in his lab notebook, sketching circuits, planning how he might build a model. As an inventor, Jack knew that a lot of spectacular ideas fall to pieces if you look at them too hard. But this one was different: the more he studied it, the more he looked for flaws, the better it looked.

当同事们度假回来时，杰克向威利斯·艾德科克展示了他的笔记本。“他很兴奋，”杰克后来写道，“但持怀疑态度。”艾德科克也记得这件事。“我很感兴趣，”他后来回忆道。“但杰克说，这太麻烦了；你要想把它做出来会很痛苦。”杰克一直坚持要对新想法进行测试。但测试需要一个模型；这可能要花费 10,000 美元，甚至更多。还有其他项目，艾德科克应该继续推进这些项目。

When his colleagues came back from vacation, Jack showed his notebook to Willis Adcock. “He was enthused,” Jack wrote later, “but skeptical.” Adcock remembers it the same way. “I was very interested,” he recalled afterward. “But what Jack was saying, it was pretty damn cumbersome; you would have had a terrible time trying to produce it.” Jack kept pushing for a test of the new idea. But a test would require a model; that could cost $10,000, maybe more. There were other projects around, and Adcock was supposed to move ahead on them.

杰克·基尔比性格温和，随和而从容。他身材瘦长，举止随意，举止朴实，脸上挂着灿烂的笑容。他说话很慢，声音很轻柔，始终带着他出生地堪萨斯州大本德的乡村口音。这种从容不迫的说话方式反映了他谨慎、深思熟虑的思维方式。相比之下，艾德考克则是一个精力充沛的家伙，虽然说了无数遍，但仍然跟不上他飞速发展的思路。不过，那个夏天，基尔比却在努力向前冲刺。毕竟，如果他们不开发这个新想法，别人可能会想到。毕竟，德州仪器并不是世界上唯一一家试图克服数字暴政的公司。

Jack Kilby is a gentle soul, easygoing and unhurried. A lanky, casual, down-home type with a big leathery face that wraps around an enormous smile, he talks slowly, slowly in a quiet voice that has never lost the soft country twang of Great Bend, Kansas, where he grew up. That deliberate mode of speech reflects a careful, deliberate way of thinking. Adcock, in contrast, is a zesty sprite who talks a mileaminute and still can’t keep up with his racing train of thought. That summer, though, it was Kilby who was pushing to race ahead. After all, if they didn’t develop this new idea, somebody else might hit on it. Texas Instruments, after all, was hardly the only place in the world where people were trying to overcome the tyranny of numbers.

罗伯特·诺伊斯在隆冬时节萌生了这个宏大的想法——或者至少是在旧金山湾阳光明媚的山谷中，冬天的微寒季节，如今因这个想法而被称为硅谷。与基尔比不同，鲍勃·诺伊斯在有想法时无需向老板征求意见；31 岁的诺伊斯就是老板。

The monolithic idea occurred to Robert Noyce in the depth of winter—or at least in the mildly chilly season that passes for winter in the sunny valley of San Francisco Bay that is known today, because of that idea, as Silicon Valley. Unlike Kilby, Bob Noyce did not have to check with the boss when he got an idea; at the age of thirty-one, Noyce was the boss.

那是 1959 年 1 月，硅谷仍以农业为主，在无边无际的桃子和梅子果园中，只有少数几家电子公司如雨后春笋般涌现。仙童半导体公司就是其中一家先驱公司，成立于 1957 年末，创始人是一群物理学家和工程师，他们猜想，通过生产改进版的晶体管和其他机械设备，他们可以赚到巨额财富，而事实证明他们猜对了。这个团队机械人才济济，管理技能却很差，但其中一位创始人兼首席执行官兼具这两种技能：鲍勃·诺伊斯。诺伊斯身材瘦削，方下巴，散发着喷气式飞机飞行员的自信，他有着无限的好奇心，这让他在某个时候开始从事从唱牧歌到驾驶水上飞机等各种爱好。诺伊斯的博士学位是物理学，他的技术专长是光刻术，这是一种印刷电路板的奇特工艺，需要最先进的摄影、化学和电路设计知识。和杰克·基尔比一样，诺伊斯喜欢用他强大的智慧来解决需要解决的具体问题，当他找到一种方法来跨越一些困难的技术障碍时，他和基尔比一样兴奋不已。然而，在仙童公司，他也对管理学科着迷，并倾向于担任研发总监一职。在这份工作中，诺伊斯大部分时间都在寻找电子行业面临的问题的有利解决方案。在 20 世纪 50 年代后半期，这意味着他正在思考一些问题，比如双扩散晶体管中基极和发射极触点的最佳合金，或者钝化硅片内结的有效方法。这些都是仙童当时生产的精密元件的具体问题。但诺伊斯在 1958 至 1959 年冬天也思考了一个更广泛的问题：数字暴政。

It was January 1959, and the valley was still largely an agricultural domain, with only a handful of electronics firms sprouting amid the endless peach and prune orchards. One of those pioneering firms, Fairchild Semiconductor, had been started late in 1957 by a group of physicists and engineers who guessed—correctly, as it turned out—that they could become fantastically rich by producing improved versions of transistors and other mechanical devices. The group was long on mechanical talent and short on managerial skills, but one of the founders turned out to have both: Bob Noyce. A slender, square-jawed man who exuded the easy self-assurance of a jet pilot, Noyce had an unbounded curiosity that led him, at one time or another, to take up hobbies ranging from madrigal singing to flying seaplanes. His doctorate was in physics, and his technical specialty was photolithography, an exotic process for printing circuit boards that required state-of-the-art knowledge of photography, chemistry, and circuit design. Like Jack Kilby, Noyce preferred to direct his powerful intelligence at specific problems that needed solving, and he shared with Kilby an intense sense of exhilaration when he found a way to leap over some difficult technical obstacle. At Fairchild, though, he also became fascinated with the discipline of management, and gravitated to the position of director of research and development. In that job, Noyce spent most of his time searching for profitable solutions to the problems facing the electronics industry. In the second half of the 1950s, that meant he was puzzling over things like the optimum alloy to use for base and emitter contacts in double-diffuse transistors, or efficient ways to passivate junctions within the silicon wafer. Those were specific issues involving the precise components Fairchild was producing at the time. But Noyce also gave some thought during the winter of 1958–59 to a much broader concern: the tyranny of numbers.

与安静内向的基尔比不同，基尔比总是独自一人仔细思考问题，才能取得最好的成果；而诺伊斯则是一位外向、健谈、冲动的发明家，他需要有人倾听他的想法，并指出哪些想法不可能奏效。那年冬天，诺伊斯的主要倾听对象是他的朋友戈登·摩尔，他是一位深思熟虑、谨慎的物理化学家，也是仙童半导体公司的另一位联合创始人。诺伊斯会精力充沛、兴奋不已地闯进摩尔的小隔间，开始在黑板上潦草地写着：“如果我们在这里做一个电阻，在那里做一个晶体管，那么也许你可以……”

Unlike the quiet, introverted Kilby, who does his best work alone, thinking carefully through a problem, Noyce was an outgoing, loquacious, impulsive inventor who needed somebody to listen to his ideas and point out the ones that couldn’t possibly work. That winter, Noyce’s main sounding board was his friend Gordon Moore, a thoughtful, cautious physical chemist who was another cofounder of Fairchild Semiconductor. Noyce would barge into Moore’s cubicle, full of energy and excitement, and start scrawling on the blackboard: “If we built a resistor here, and the transistor over here, then maybe you could . . .”

1959 年的头几周，诺伊斯逐渐找到了解决互连问题的方法，这并非突然。他后来回忆说，1 月 23 日，“我脑子里的所有零碎都汇集到了一起。”他拿起笔记本，记下了一个想法。这是一个整体式想法，诺伊斯用与杰克·基尔比六个月前在达拉斯的笔记本中记录的非常相似的文字来表达它：“……最好在一块硅片上制造多个设备，以便能够在制造过程中实现设备之间的互连，从而减轻重量、减小尺寸等，并降低每个有源元件的成本。”

Not suddenly, but gradually, in the first weeks of 1959, Noyce worked out a solution to the interconnections problem. On January 23, he recalled later, “all the bits and pieces came together in my head.” He grabbed his notebook and wrote down an idea. It was the monolithic idea, and Noyce expressed it in words quite similar to those Jack Kilby had entered in a notebook in Dallas six months earlier: “...it would be desirable to make multiple devices on a single piece of silicon, in order to be able to make interconnections between devices as part of the manufacturing process, and thus reduce weight, size, etc. as well as cost per active element.”

和基尔比一样，诺伊斯从一开始就确信自己正在做一件重要的事情。“当时，我们有很大动力去解决数字障碍，”他后来回忆道。“当时的电子行业处于一种境地——例如，一台计算机有数万个组件，数万个互连——制造这些东西几乎是不可能的。而这看起来是一种解决办法。我记得有一天我告诉戈登，我们可能找到了一个真正大问题的解决方案。”

Like Kilby, Noyce felt fairly sure from the beginning that he was on to something important. “There was a tremendous motivation then to do something about the numbers barrier,” he recalled later. “The [electronics] industry was in a situation—for example, in a computer with tens of thousands of components, tens of thousands of interconnections—where things were just about impossible to make. And this looked like a way to deal with that. I can remember telling Gordon one day, we might have here a solution to a real big problem.”

从本质上讲，整体式理念旨在解决的一大问题是人们的期望值过高。这在技术史上并非史无前例的现象：重大突破引发了人们对未来光明新世界的乐观预测，但随后问题不断出现，让这个美好的未来无法实现——直到新的突破解决了新问题。

At its core, the big problem that the monolithic idea was designed to solve was one of heightened expectations. It was hardly an unprecedented phenomenon in technological history: a major breakthrough prompts a burst of optimistic predictions about the bright new world ahead, but then problems crop up that make that rosy future unobtainable—until a new breakthrough solves the new problem.

引发“数字暴政”问题的突破是 1947 年底震惊电子世界的一记惊雷。这是战后科学史上的一次开创性事件，是改变一切的少数发展之一：晶体管的发明。

The breakthrough that gave rise to the problem known as the tyranny of numbers was a thunderbolt that hit the world of electronics at the end of 1947. It was a seminal event of postwar science, one of those rare developments that change everything: the invention of the transistor.

在晶体管出现之前，电子设备，从最简单的调幅收音机到最复杂的大型计算机，都是围绕真空管构建的。任何年龄足够大、在 1964 年之前打开过收音机或电视机的人可能都还记得收音机的真空管：当你打开开关时，你可以透过电视机背面的小孔看到一束橙色的光开始发光——真空管内的灯丝。真空管发光是因为它本质上与灯泡相同；在玻璃灯泡密封的真空中，电流流过金属丝，加热灯丝并发出白炽光。玻璃灯泡内必须是真空的，否则灯丝会因高温而立即烧毁。但事实证明，真空的优势远不止防火。20 世纪初，无线电先驱们在对灯泡进行实验时发现，如果他们在真空灯泡中多接一些电线，它就可以实现两种有用的电子功能。首先，它可以从天线接收微弱的无线电信号，并将其增强或放大到足以驱动扬声器的程度，从而将电子信号转换成足够大的声音来听见。这种“放大”功能使收音机和后来的电视机能够正常工作。其次，正确接线的灯泡或真空管可以在一秒钟内从开切换到关，大约 10,000 次。（由于它能够打开和关闭电流，因此真空管在英国被称为阀门。）这种能力对于数字计算机至关重要；正如我们将在第 6 章中看到的那样，计算机通过各种开和关信号组合做出逻辑决策并执行数学计算。

Until the transistor came along, electronic devices, from the simplest AM radio to the most complex mainframe computer, were all built around vacuum tubes. Anybody old enough to have turned on a radio or television set before, say, 1964, may remember the radio tube: when you turned on the switch, you could look through the holes in the back of the set and see a bunch of orange lights begin to glow—the filaments inside the vacuum tubes. A tube gave off light because it was essentially the same thing as a light bulb; inside a vacuum sealed by a glass bulb, electric current flowed through a wire filament, heating the filament and giving off incandescent light. There has to be a vacuum inside the glass bulb or else the filament will burn up instantly from the heat. But the vacuum turned out to offer advantages that went beyond fire protection. Experimenting with light bulbs at the beginning of the twentieth century, radio pioneers found that if they ran some extra wires into that vacuum bulb, it could perform two useful electronic functions. First, it could pull a weak radio signal from an antenna and strengthen, or amplify, it enough to drive a loudspeaker, thus converting an electronic signal into sound loud enough to hear. This “amplification” function made radio, and later television, workable. Second, a properly wired light bulb, or vacuum tube, could switch—about 10,000 times in a second—from on to off. (Because of its ability to turn current on and off, the radio tube was known in England as a valve.) This capability was essential to digital computers; as we’ll see in Chapter 6, computers make logical decisions and carry out mathematical computations through various combinations of on and off signals.

但真空管体积大、价格昂贵、易碎且耗电，而且会发热。上世纪 30 年代风靡一时的豪华台式收音机都带有警告，告诫用户不要将文件放在收音机的背面，因为这些真空管的热量可能会引发火灾。在更复杂的设备中，真空管需要大量紧密排列在一起，比如计算机或电话交换中心，所有这些发光的灯丝会发出巨大的热量，使昂贵的机器变成燃烧的熔融玻璃和金属块——实际上就是把金子变成铅。我们从灯泡中知道，真空管很容易在错误的时间烧坏，这让人恼火。宾夕法尼亚大学的 ENIAC 是第一台重要的数字计算机，但它从未发挥出其潜力，因为在计算过程中真空管不断烧坏。美国陆军使用 ENIAC 来计算炮弹轨迹，最终在计算机周围的战略要地部署了一排士兵，他们拿着装满真空管的购物篮；这并没有起到什么帮助作用，因为工程师们永远无法确定这台机器的 18,000 个真空管中究竟哪个在某个特定时刻烧坏了。真空管的温热和柔和的光芒也吸引了飞蛾，飞蛾会飞进 ENIAC 的内部并导致短路。从那时起，修复计算机问题的过程就被称为调试。

But vacuum tubes were big, expensive, fragile, and power hungry. They got hot, too. The lavish console radios that became the rage in the 1930s all carried warnings to owners not to leave papers near the back of the set, because the heat of all those tubes might start a fire. In a more complicated device that needed lots of tubes packed in close to each other, like a computer or a telephone switching center, all those glowing filaments gave off such enormous quantities of heat that they transformed expensive machinery into smoldering hunks of molten glass and metal—in effect, turning gold into lead. As we all know from the light bulb, vacuum tubes have an exasperating tendency to burn out at the wrong time. The University of Pennsylvania’s ENIAC, the first important digital computer, never lived up to its potential because tubes kept burning out in the middle of its computations. The Army, which used ENIAC to compute artillery trajectories, finally stationed a platoon of soldiers manning grocery baskets full of tubes at strategic points around the computer; this proved little help, because the engineers could never quite tell which of the machine’s 18,000 vacuum tubes had burned out at any particular time. The warmth and the soft glow of the tubes also attracted moths, which would fly through ENIAC’s innards and cause short circuits. Ever since, the process of fixing computer problems has been known as debugging.

1947 年圣诞节前两天，贝尔实验室的威廉·肖克利、沃尔特·布拉顿和约翰·巴丁发明了晶体管，有望一举消除真空管的所有缺陷。晶体管是一种全新的技术。它基于半导体的物理原理——硅和锗等具有不同寻常电子特性的元素。晶体管通过在半导体材料固体块内沿受控路径移动电子电荷，执行与真空管相同的两项有用任务——放大和快速开关切换。没有玻璃泡，没有真空，没有预热时间，没有热量，没有烧坏的东西；晶体管比它所取代的真空管更轻、更小、更快——即使是最早的型号也能从开到关的速度快大约 20 倍。

The transistor, invented two days before Christmas 1947 by William Shockley, Walter Brattain, and John Bardeen of Bell Labs, promised to eliminate all the bugs of the vacuum tube in one fell swoop. The transistor was something completely new. It was based on the physics of semiconductors—elements like silicon and germanium that have unusual electronic characteristics. The transistor performed the same two useful tasks as the vacuum tube—amplification and rapid on-off switching—by moving electronic charges along controlled paths inside a solid block of semiconductor material. There was no glass bulb, no vacuum, no warm-up time, no heat, nothing to burn out; the transistor was lighter, smaller, and faster—even the earliest models could switch from on to off about twenty times faster—than the tube it replaced.

对于电子行业来说，这简直是天赐之物。到 20 世纪 50 年代中期，固态已成为收音机、助听器和大多数其他电子设备的标准状态。蓬勃发展的计算机行业欣然接受了晶体管，军方也是如此，他们需要小型、低功耗、耐用的部件来制造弹道导弹和新兴的太空计划。晶体管以战后其他技术成就无法比拟的方式吸引了大众的想象力。核裂变、火箭和遗传学等当代科学进展在报纸上引起了轰动，但与日常生活相距甚远。相比之下，晶体管是普通人可以使用的突破。晶体管便携式收音机恰逢 1954 年圣诞节推出，几乎立即成为零售史上最受欢迎的新产品。这部分是协同效应——袖珍收音机问世时，一些先驱唱片骑师正在推广一种名为摇滚乐的新音乐——部分是纯粹的优势。第一台晶体管收音机 Regency 比之前的任何收音机都更小、更节能、更可靠，而且更便宜（49.95 美元）。

To the electronics industry, this was a godsend. By the mid-1950s, solid state was becoming the standard state for radios, hearing aids, and most other electronic devices. The burgeoning computer industry happily embraced the transistor, as did the military, which needed small, low-power, long-lasting parts for ballistic missiles and the nascent space program. The transistor captured the popular imagination in a way no other technological achievement of the postwar era had. Contemporary scientific advances in nuclear fission, rocketry, and genetics made awesome reading in the newspapers, but were remote from daily life. The transistor, in contrast, was a breakthrough that ordinary people could use. The transistorized portable radio, introduced just in time for Christmas 1954, almost instantly became the most popular new product in retail history. It was partly synergy—pocket radios came out when a few pioneering disc jockeys were promoting a new music called rock ’n’ roll—and partly sheer superiority. The first transistor radio, the Regency, was smaller, more power-efficient, far more reliable, and much cheaper ($49.95) than any radio had ever been before.

学术界通常对革命性的新概念持怀疑态度，在沉溺于这种怀疑态度一两年之后，物理学家和电子工程师逐渐对半导体电子学提供的广阔的新可能性产生了兴趣。到 1953 年，《工程索引》（一本技术领域学术专著的年度汇编）列出了 500 多篇有关晶体管和相关半导体器件的论文。一年后，论文数量翻了一番，再一年甚至更多。这些论文的标题反映了新技术推动的学术研究的强度和全球影响力：

After indulging themselves for a year or two in the resentful skepticism with which academia generally greets revolutionary new concepts, physicists and electronics engineers gradually warmed to the expansive new possibilities offered by semiconductor electronics. By 1953, The Engineering Index, an annual compendium of scholarly monographs in technical fields, listed more than 500 papers on transistors and related semiconductor devices. A year later there were twice as many, a year after that even more. The titles reflected the intensity and the global sweep of academic research spurred by the new technology:

“pn 结晶体管中 Alpha 值的解释”

“电路触发器中的晶体管”

“晶体管谐振系数的电路乘法器”

“晶体管谐振系数的张量分析”

“晶体管的磨损、振荡和典型特性”

“Interpretation of Alpha Values in p-n Junction Transistors”

“Le Transistron dans le circuit trigger”

“Circuito Multiplicatore del coefficient di risonanza con transistor”

“Tensoranalysis in Transistor-Rueckkopplungshaltungen”

“Perekhodnaya, chastotnaya, i fazovaya kharakteristika transistora”

 

 

但这些论文也反映出学术界一种相当非学术性的热情：

But the papers reflected as well a quite unscholarly enthusiasm among the academics:

“成功案例——晶体管的可靠性”

“晶体管是电子简化的关键”

“应用于微型化的优化方法”

“神奇的侏儒”

“Success Story—Transistor Reliability”

“Transistors Key to Electronic Simplicity”

“Méthodes d’Optimization Appliquées à la Microminiaturization”

“Fabulous Midget”

 

 

后来，随着设计师们学会了如何利用这个神奇的侏儒的特性，数字的暴政开始显现。热情让位于沮丧，甚至绝望。到了 20 世纪 50 年代后半期，当问题变得尖锐时，《工程索引》中的标题反映了技术界普遍的失望，甚至绝望：

And then, as designers learned how to make use of the fabulous midget’s properties, the tyranny of numbers began to emerge. Enthusiasm gave way to frustration, even desperation. By the second half of the 1950s, when the problem was growing acute, the titles in The Engineering Index reflected a general sense of disappointment, even despair, in the technical community:

“晶体管电路中的开关损耗”

“电子设备 — 飞行器的重量和体积损失”

“评论晶体管制造问题的解决方案”

“半导体元件的设计限制”

“Switching Losses in Transistor Circuits”

“Electronic Equipment—Weight and Volume Penalties to Flight Vehicles”

“Comment a été résolu le problème de la fabrication des transistors”

“Design Limitations of Semiconductor Components”

 

 

最后一个称谓并不准确。“设计限制”并非晶体管或其他元件所固有的；它们源自所有电路的基本设计结构。

That last title was imprecise. The “design limitations” were not inherent in the transistors or other components; they stemmed from the basic design structure of all electric circuits.

构建电路就像构建句子。有一些标准组件（句子中的名词、动词、形容词；电路中的电阻器、电容器、二极管和晶体管）每个都有自己的功能。电阻器是限制电流流动的喷嘴，使电路设计人员可以精确控制任何点的电流。电视机上的音量控制实际上是一种电阻控制。调节音量会调节电阻器；喷嘴收紧，限制流向扬声器的电流，从而降低音量。电容器是一块海绵，可吸收电能并根据需要逐渐或一次性释放。相机内的电容器从小电池中吸收电能，然后突然爆发出足以触发闪光灯的电量。如果您必须等到相机上的指示灯闪烁以告诉您闪光灯已准备好使用，那么您实际上是在等待内部的电容器吸收足够的能量来使它闪光。二极管是一种水坝，它在某些情况下会阻挡电流，而在条件改变时会打开水坝让电流通过。电眼是聚焦在二极管上的一束光。窃贼穿过光束会阻挡进入二极管的光，从而打开水坝让电流通过，发出嘈杂的警报声。晶体管是一种水龙头。它可以打开或关闭电流，从而发送数字信号流经计算机电路，或者增加电流以放大来自收音机的声音。几乎每个电路都是由这些基本部件组成的：喷嘴、海绵、水坝和水龙头，它们的速度和尺寸各不相同。通过以不同的方式连接这些标准组件，可以获得执行不同功能的电路或语句。

Building a circuit is like building a sentence. There are certain standard components—nouns, verbs, adjectives in a sentence; resistors, capacitors, diodes, and transistors in a circuit—each with its own function. A resistor is a nozzle that restricts the flow of electricity, giving the circuit designer precise control of the current flow at any point. The volume control on a TV set is really a resistance control. Adjusting the volume adjusts a resistor; the nozzle tightens, restricting the flow of current to the speaker and thus reducing the sound level. A capacitor is a sponge that absorbs electrical energy and releases it, gradually or all at once, as needed. A capacitor inside a camera soaks up power from a small battery and then dumps it out in a sudden burst forceful enough to fire the flashbulb. If you have to wait until the indicator light on your camera blinks to tell you that the flash is ready to use, you’re really waiting for the capacitor inside to soak up enough energy to make the thing flash. A diode is a dam that blocks current under some conditions and opens it to let electricity flow when the conditions change. An electric eye is a beam of light focused on a diode. A burglar who steps through the beam blocks the light to the diode, opening the dam to let current flow through to a noisy alarm. A transistor is a faucet. It can turn current flow on and off—and thus send digital signals pouring through the circuitry of a computer—or turn up the flow to amplify the sound coming from a radio. Just about every circuit is made of these basic parts—the nozzle, the sponge, the dam, and the faucet—which come in various speeds and sizes. By connecting these standard components in different ways, one can get circuits, or sentences, that perform different functions.

写句子的人被教导要让他们的设计简短而简单。这条规则不适用于电子产品。一些最有用的电路又大又复杂，有数十万个元件连接在一起。在真空管时代，设计师对功率、热量和尺寸限制的内在意识限制了任何电路设计的范围；设计一台在打开后几分钟就会融化成碎片的机器是没有意义的。然而，随着晶体管的出现，这些基本的设计限制消失了。现在，设计师可以制定奇特的通信和计算机电路计划——这些电路可以引导火箭飞向月球或控制全球即时邮件网络。这样的电路可能使用 50,000、500,000 或 500 万个晶体管，以及类似数量的电阻器、二极管和电容器。为什么不呢？你现在可以建立一个这么大的电路，而不必担心热量或功率问题。从理论上讲，这些超级电路的性能可以胜过以前设计的任何电路。你只需找到零件，将它们连接起来，然后……但问题就来了。这就是数字障碍出现的地方。绘图板上的新电路太大太复杂，几乎不可能建造出来。没有人能把这么多不同的零件连接在一起。

Writers of sentences are taught to keep their designs short and simple. This rule does not apply in electronics. Some of the most useful circuits are big and complicated, with hundreds of thousands of components wired together. In the era of vacuum tubes, the designers’ implicit awareness of power, heat, and size restraints set a limit to the scope of any circuit design; there was no point in designing a machine that would melt to shards a few moments after it was turned on. With the transistor, though, these fundamental design limitations disappeared. Now the designers could draw up plans for exotic communications and computer circuits—circuits that could steer a rocket to the moon or control a global network of instant mail. Circuits like that might use 50,000 or 500,000 or 5 million transistors, and similar numbers of resistors, diodes, and capacitors. And why not? You could build a circuit that big now without worrying about heat or power problems. On paper, these supercircuits could outperform anything that had been designed before. All you had to do was get the parts, wire them together, and. . . . But there was the problem. That was where the numbers barrier came in. The new circuits on the drawing boards were so big and so complex it was virtually impossible to build them. Nobody could wire that many different parts together.

电路必须是一条完整、不间断的路径，电流可以沿着这条路径流动。这意味着电路的所有元件都必须连接成一个连续的环路：电阻连接到二极管，二极管连接到晶体管，晶体管连接到其他电阻，等等。每个元件可以与电路的其他部分有两个、十个甚至二十个互连。连接（将部件连接在一起）几乎完全是手工劳动：它既昂贵又耗时，而且本质上不可靠。一个有 100,000 个元件的电路很容易需要 100 万个不同的焊接连接来连接这些元件。唯一能够进行连接的机器就是人手。

An electric circuit has to be a complete, unbroken path along which current can flow. That means that all the components of a circuit must be connected in a continuous loop: resistors wired to diodes, diodes to transistors, transistors to other resistors, and so on. Each component can have two, ten, even twenty interconnections with other parts of the circuit. Making the connections—wiring the parts together—was almost entirely hand labor: it was expensive, time-consuming, and inherently unreliable. A circuit with 100,000 components could easily require 1 million different soldered connections linking the components. The only machine that could make the connections was the human hand.

即使有人（例如五角大楼，在冷战最激烈的时期，价格不是问题）能负担得起那么多的手工劳动，但人类不可能组装出一百万件东西而不产生一些缺陷。到 20 世纪 50 年代末，电子行业已经直面这一无法改变的极限。海军最新的航空母舰有 350,000 个电子元件，需要数百万个手工焊接连接；接线和测试每个连接的人工成本高于元件本身的总成本。第一台“第二代”（即完全晶体管化的）计算机——控制数据 CD 1604，包含 25,000 个晶体管、100,000 个二极管和数十万个电阻器和电容器——的生产严重落后于计划，因为连接零件非常困难。而绘图板上的新计算机将复杂得多。 20 世纪 90 年代末，人们已经开始规划未来引导火箭登陆月球的计算机。但这些计划要求电路包含 1000 万个元件。谁能生产这样的电路？它怎么能装进火箭里？

Even if somebody—the Pentagon, for example, where price, in the depths of the Cold War, was no object—could pay for that much hand labor, there was no way humans could put together a million of anything without turning out a few that were faulty. By the late 1950s, the electronics industry had come head-to-head with this implacable limit. The Navy’s newest aircraft carriers had 350,000 electronic components, requiring millions of hand-soldered connections; the labor cost—for wiring those connections and testing each one—was greater than the total cost of the components themselves. Production of the first “second generation” (i.e., completely transistorized) computer—the Control Data CD 1604, containing 25,000 transistors, 100,000 diodes, and hundreds of thousands of resistors and capacitors—lagged hopelessly behind schedule because of the sheer difficulty of connecting the parts. And new computers on the drawing boards would be far more complex. At the end of the decade, people were already planning the computers that would someday guide a rocket to a landing on the moon. But those plans called for circuits with 10 million components. Who could produce a circuit like that? How could it fit into a rocket?

贝尔实验室副总裁 JA Morton 在一篇庆祝晶体管诞生十周年的文章中写道：“一段时间以来，电子人已经知道如何通过数字传输和处理各种信息来‘从理论上’大大扩展其视觉、触觉和思维能力。然而，所有这些功能都受到所谓的‘数字暴政’的影响。由于其复杂的数字性质，此类系统需要数百、数千甚至数万个电子设备。” Morton 在后来的一篇文章中写道：“每个元件都必须逐个制造、测试、包装、运输、拆包、重新测试和互连，才能形成一个完整的系统。” “如果系统要作为一个整体运行，每个元件及其连接都必须可靠运行……如果我们必须依靠单个分立元件来生产大型系统，那么大型系统的暴政将为未来的进步设置一道数字障碍。”

“For some time now,” wrote J. A. Morton, a vice president of Bell Labs, in an article celebrating the tenth anniversary of the transistor, “electronic man has known how ‘in principle’ to extend greatly his visual, tactile, and mental abilities through the digital transmission and processing of all kinds of information. However, all these functions suffer from what has been called ‘the tyranny of numbers.’ Such systems, because of their complex digital nature, require hundreds, thousands, and sometimes tens of thousands of electron devices.” “Each element must be made, tested, packed, shipped, unpacked, retested, and interconnected one-at-a-time to produce a whole system,” Morton wrote in a later article. “Each element and its connections must operate reliably if the system is to function as a whole. . . . The tyranny of large systems sets up a numbers barrier to future advances if we must rely on individual discrete components for producing large systems.”

从本质上讲，20 世纪 50 年代探索电子前沿的工程师小团体面临的绝望挫折与 16 世纪 90 年代探索航海前沿的海员小团体面临的绝望挫折是一样的。在大西洋最西端，紧邻中美洲海岸，探险者们可以从桅杆顶向西望去，并“带着一种狂野的猜测”看到一片广阔的新海洋，一个全新的世界，在地峡对面向你招手。但是没有办法——除非绕着南美洲的尖端航行，否则没有办法到达那片充满希望的新海域。未来就在眼前，诱人而诱人，但却遥不可及。对于 Jack Kilby、Bob Noyce 和他们的同事来说也是如此。一个广阔的新电子世界就在蓝图上，但却无法实现。于是物理学家和电子工程师踏上了伟大的探索之旅，寻找跨越数字障碍的路线。

In essence, the small community of engineers exploring the frontiers of electronics in the 1950s faced the same abject frustration that had confronted the small community of seamen exploring the frontiers of navigation in the 1590s. At the far western extremity of the Atlantic, hard against the shores of Central America, the explorers could look westward from the masthead and see, “with a wild surmise,” a vast new ocean, a whole new world, beckoning across the isthmus. But there was no way—no way short of the impossibly expensive, time-consuming, and unreliable voyage around the tip of South America—to get to that wonderfully promising new stretch of sea. The future was within sight, tempting, tantalizing, but out of reach. Just so for Jack Kilby, Bob Noyce, and their colleagues. A vast new electronic world was right there on the blueprints, but impossible to achieve. And so physicists and electronics engineers embarked on a great voyage of discovery, searching for a route across the numbers barrier.

这项搜索成为整个发达国家最优先的技术关注点。皇家雷达研究所急于将这一重要成就的荣誉带给英国，早在 1952 年就提出了一个有前途的概念，但未能成功。法国、德国和俄罗斯相互竞争；在美国，陆军、海军和空军的竞争也同样激烈，每个军种都推行自己喜欢的解决方案，互相拒绝对方的想法。私营公司嗅到了金矿的气息，投入了数百万美元和人力。但在 20 世纪 50 年代的大部分时间里，这些努力都没有真正起到作用。德州仪器公司总裁帕特里克·哈格蒂抱怨说，大多数针对数字暴政提出的解决方案“往往会加剧暴政”。

The search became a top-priority technological concern throughout the established world. The Royal Radar Establishment, racing to bring the honor of this important accomplishment to Great Britain, developed a promising concept as early as 1952 but failed to make it work. The French, the Germans, and the Russians competed against one another; in the United States, the Army, the Navy, and the Air Force competed just as fiercely, each service pushing its own preferred solution, each rejecting the ideas of the others. Private firms, sensing a gold mine, poured millions of dollars and man-hours into the effort. But through most of the 1950s none of these endeavors really helped. Patrick Haggerty, the president of Texas Instruments, complained that most of the proposed solutions to the tyranny of numbers “tend to exacerbate the tyranny.”

在技​​术文献中，解决数量问题的多方面努力被归类为“小型化”（或“超小型化”或“微型化”）。这是一个不幸的术语，因为它暗示了一种行不通的解决方案。小型化的基本目的是努力使电子元件变得非常小，从而减小复杂电子设备的整体尺寸和重量。这一目标显然对军方很重要，因为军方必须将无线电、雷达和声纳设备以及计算机塞进导弹和潜艇的角落和缝隙中。首批小型化项目之一是海军资助的名为“Tinkertoy 行动”的行动。但也有民用方面的影响。“在民用设备中，例如计算机，”行业杂志《电子学》指出，“如果要将计算机安置在合理大小的建筑物中，仅元件数量就使得小型化必不可少。”

The multifaceted efforts to deal with the numbers problem were grouped in the technical literature under the general title “miniaturization” (or “subminiaturization,” or “microminiaturization”). It was an unfortunate term because it suggested a solution that could not work. The basic thrust of miniaturization was an effort to make electronic components extremely small, thus reducing the overall size and weight of complex electronic devices. This goal was obviously important to the military, which had to squeeze radios, radar and sonar devices, and computers into the nooks and crannies of missiles and submarines. One of the first miniaturization programs was a Navy-financed effort called Operation Tinkertoy. But there were civilian implications as well. “In civilian equipment, such as computers,” the trade journal Electronics noted, “the number of components alone makes miniaturization essential if the computer is to be housed in a reasonable-sized building.”

但是，以 Tinkertoy 规模生产晶体管、电阻器等产品并没有减少元件和连接的数量。Tinkertoy 业务往往会加剧这种暴政，因为由微小部件组成的电路更难制造，成本也更高。在装配线上，焊接电路的女性（这几乎完全是女性的工作，因为男性的手被认为太大、太笨拙，而且对于如此复杂和耗时的任务来说太昂贵）现在必须用镊子夹起微型元件和极短的电线，然后在放大镜下用牙签大小的焊接工具将它们连接起来。在这种情况下制造的电路更有可能出现连接故障。在许多情况下，即使是一个错误的连接也可能对整个电路造成致命影响，就像一个烧坏的灯泡会使整串圣诞灯熄灭一样。依赖使用“微型”部件的电路的电子设备是出了名的不可靠。

But turning out transistors, resistors, and the like on Tinkertoy scale did nothing to reduce the sheer number of components and connections. The Tinkertoy business tended to exacerbate the tyranny because circuits composed of tiny parts were harder, and costlier, to build. On the assembly lines, the women who soldered circuits together—it was almost entirely women’s work, because male hands were considered too big, too clumsy, and too expensive for such intricate and time-consuming tasks—now had to pick up miniature components and minute lengths of wire with tweezers and join them under a magnifying glass with a soldering tool the size of a toothpick. Circuits made under those conditions were far more likely to end up with faulty connections. In many cases, even a single bad connection could be fatal to the entire circuit, just as a single burnt-out bulb can make an entire string of Christmas lights go dark. Electronic devices that relied on circuitry employing the “microminiature” parts were famously unreliable.

为了提高可靠性，设计人员尝试了冗余。电子公司不再使用一套元件制造收音机（五十年代末期，典型的小型收音机可能使用六个晶体管，连接十几个电阻器、电容器和二极管），而是开始制造内置额外电路的收音机，就像汽车有两个前轴，以防其中一个在路上折断一样。冗余方法往往会加剧这种暴政，因为额外的元件和额外的线路需要更多的互连，从而需要更多的劳动力。更糟糕的是，冗余电路占用了更多空间，这是一件令人讨厌的事情，尤其是对制造计算机的人来说。即使没有冗余，电子电路也已经太大了。大型电路破坏了现代电子设备最重要的资产：速度。

To enhance reliability, the designers tried redundancy. Instead of building a radio with a single set of components (a typical small radio of the late fifties might have used a half dozen transistors wired to a dozen resistors, capacitors, and diodes) the electronics companies started making radios with an extra circuit built right in—like a car built with two front axles just in case one should snap in half on the road. The redundancy approach tended to exacerbate the tyranny because the extra components and extra wire required more interconnections, and thus more labor. Worse, redundant circuitry took up more space, and that was an anathema, particularly to the people who build computers. Even without redundancy, electronic circuits were already too large. Large circuits undermined the single most important asset of modern electronic equipment: speed.

我们将在第 9 章中看到，计算器、计算机、数字时钟、视频游戏（实际上，所有数字电子设备）都是极其愚蠢的工具。但它们的速度极快，极其愚蠢。计算机将每个问题、每个计算、每个决定简化为机器内部电路中最简单的术语（是或否、一或零、真或假）。这两个黑或白状态由开关（晶体管）表示，它们要么打开，要么关闭。天文台中绘制宇宙图的天体物理学家需要计算 arctan 245.6 的 24 次方根；为此，他将问题输入计算机。机器必须完成几百个单独的是或否步骤（即晶体管必须打开和关闭数百次），才能确定有人按下了它的键。要确定按下了哪些键，然后解决问题，还需要 100,000 个步骤，甚至更多。在街机上玩 Super Zaxxon 的孩子需要摧毁敌人的基地；要做到这一点，他需要按下“开火”按钮。机器必须执行数十个单独的“是”或“否”步骤才能确定按下了按钮。要发射导弹并查看它是否击中任何东西，还需要 5,000 个步骤，甚至更多。机器之所以能够以荒谬复杂的方式工作，只是因为晶体管可以快速地从开切换到关，从关切换到开。在每秒一次的切换速度下，计算机是不可能实现的；在每秒 1,000 次的切换速度下，计算机简直是不切实际的。以每秒一百万次的速度切换，计算机变得非常重要。以每秒十亿次的速度——每纳秒完成问题的一步——它们成为席卷全球的革命的基础。

As we’ll see in Chapter 9, calculators, computers, digital clocks, video games—for that matter, all digital electronic devices—are extremely dumb tools. But they are extremely fast extremely dumb tools. A computer reduces every question, every computation, every decision to the simplest possible terms (yes or no, one or zero, true or false) in the machine’s internal circuitry. These two black-or-white states are represented by switches—transistors—that are either on or off. An astrophysicist mapping the universe in the observatory needs to calculate the twenty-fourth root of arctan 245.6; to do it, he types the problem into his computer. The machine has to work through a few hundred separate yes-or-no steps—that is, transistors have to switch on and off hundreds of times—just to figure out that someone has punched its keys. To determine which keys were pushed, and then to solve the problem, will take another 100,000 steps, quite possibly more. A kid playing Super Zaxxon in the arcade needs to destroy an enemy base; to do it, he pushes the “Fire” button. The machine has to work through dozens of separate yes-or-no steps just to figure out that the button was pushed. To fire the missile, and see if it hits anything, will take another 5,000 steps, quite possibly more. The machines can get away with their absurdly convoluted way of doing things only because the transistors switch, from on to off, from off to on, quickly. At a switching speed of once per second, computers would be impossible; at 1,000 times per second, merely impractical. Switching at a million times per second, computers become important. At a billion times per second—completing one step of the problem every nanosecond—they become the foundation of a revolution that has swept the world.

罗伯特·诺伊斯观察到，“一旦你适应了纳秒，计算机操作在概念上就相当简单了。”从这个意义上讲，二十世纪的电子革命是十九世纪生物革命的智力镜像。只有在适应了极长的时间段（足以让一匹雄马变成一头驴的时间）之后，查尔斯·达尔文和他的同时代人才能考虑在不断演变的星球上进化物种。只有在适应了极短的时间段（微秒、纳秒、皮秒）之后，计算机先驱们才能考虑让机器通过打开和关闭开关来解决问题。计算机操作的核心概念是机器的运行速度快得令人难以置信。速度是计算机的秘密武器。如果计算机的运行速度没有现在这么快，那么就没有人能证明建造计算机所需的时间和材料是合理的。以每秒 1,000 次的切换速度，计算机需要整整一秒甚至两秒才能完成 2 加 2 的运算。按照这样的速度，购买这台机器毫无意义。而人脑，这个极其复杂、强大、高效的计算机，每个人都可以免费获得，它可以比这更快地解决问题。

“After you become reconciled to the nanosecond,” Robert Noyce observed, “computer operations are conceptually fairly simple.” In this respect, the electronic revolution of the twentieth century is the intellectual mirror image of the biological revolution of the nineteenth. Only after they became reconciled to enormously long periods of time—enough time for a dynohippus to turn into a donkey—could Charles Darwin and his contemporaries contemplate species evolving on an evolving planet. Only after they became reconciled to enormously short periods of time—microseconds, nanoseconds, picoseconds—could the computer pioneers contemplate machines solving problems by turning switches on and off. The central concept of computer operations is that the machines operate inconceivably fast. Speed is the computer’s secret weapon. If computers did not work as fast as they do, no one could justify the time and materials required to build them. At a switching speed of 1,000 times per second, it would take a whole second, maybe two, for a computer to add 2 and 2. At that rate, it would make no sense to buy the machine. The human brain, the sublimely intricate, powerful, efficient computer that everyone gets for free, can solve the problem faster than that.

电路中的电线会使速度变慢。计算机中的晶体管根据电子信号打开和​​关闭。通过电线传输的电脉冲到达晶体管，晶体管打开；另一个脉冲到来时，晶体管关闭。不管晶体管本身的切换速度有多快，它都无法切换，直到脉冲到达告诉它该做什么。电路中的线路越多，这些信使脉冲必须传播得越远。在 20 世纪 50 年代，限制计算机速度的因素是电子信号在电路中移动的时间。在最大的计算机中，线路长达数英里，脉冲从电路的一端传输到另一端需要很长时间，以至于计算速度严重受损。

The wires in an electric circuit tend to slow things down. The transistors in a computer switch on and off in response to electronic signals. A pulse of electricity moving through a wire reaches the transistor, and the transistor switches on; another pulse comes along, and the transistor switches off. No matter how quickly the transistor itself can switch, it cannot do so until the pulse arrives telling it what to do. The more wiring there is in a circuit, the farther these messenger pulses have to travel. In the 1950s, the limiting factor in computer speed was the travel time for those electronic signals moving through the circuit. In the biggest computers, with literally miles of wiring, it took so long for pulses to travel from one side of the circuit to the other that computation rates were seriously impaired.

乍一看，这个问题似乎有两个可能的解决方案：要么加快信号速度，使它们在大型电路中移动得更快，要么缩小电路。有朝一日，如果相对论被取代，二十世纪的物理学定律被颠倒过来，第一种解决方案可能唾手可得。然而，目前这是违反定律的。电子信号以宇宙速度极限——光速——通过电路移动。如果现代物理学是正确的，那么没有任何东西能移动得更快。那就只剩下第二种解决方案了。为了提高计算速度，必须减少信使脉冲必须传播的距离——也就是说，使电路更小。但电路变小意味着容量减小。结果是一个悖论。用工程师的行话来说，计算机的“能力”既衡量了它处理大问题的能力，也衡量了它解决问题的速度。至少在成本和尺寸不是严重问题的应用中，通过连接更多的晶体管可以提高解决问题的能力。但晶体管和电线越多，电路就越大，计算速度就越慢。因此，增加计算能力的努力反而导致计算能力下降。这相当于技术上的“第 22 条军规”：数字的暴政。

At first blush, it might appear that there were two potential solutions to this problem: either speed up the signals, so they move through a large circuit faster, or shrink the circuits. Someday, if relativity theory is displaced and the laws of twentieth-century physics are stood on their heads, the first solution may be at hand. At present, however, it is against the law. Electronic signals move through a circuit at the universal speed limit—the speed of light. If modern physics is correct, nothing will ever move faster. That leaves the second solution. To increase computing speed, it was necessary to reduce the distance the messenger pulses had to travel—that is, to make the circuits smaller. But smaller circuits meant decreased capacity. The result was a paradox. In the argot of the engineers, a computer’s “power” is a measure of both its capacity to handle big problems and its speed in solving them. It was possible—at least in applications where cost and size were not serious problems—to increase problem-solving capacity by wiring in more transistors. But more transistors and more wire meant a larger circuit, which reduced computing speed. Thus the effort to build in increased computing power led to decreased computing power. It was the technological equivalent of Catch-22: the tyranny of numbers.

“当时的情况很明显，尺寸决定了性能，”鲍勃·诺伊斯回忆道。“不仅仅是性能（从限制计算速度的角度来看），电子电路的尺寸和复杂性还决定了成本、可靠性和实用性。”

“It was a situation where, quite clearly, size dictated performance,” Bob Noyce recalled. “Not just performance, in the sense of limiting computing speed, but the size and complexity of electronic circuits dictated cost, reliability, utility.”

“你可以看到你想要做的事情需要很多晶体管、很多部件，无论从成本角度、尺寸角度还是其他任何角度来看，这都是令人望而却步的，”杰克·基尔比回忆道。

“The things that you could see that you wanted to do were going to take so many transistors, so many parts, that it would just be prohibitive, from a cost standpoint, from a size standpoint, any way you wanted to look at it,” Jack Kilby remembered.

诺伊斯：“技术界的很大一部分人都在寻找解决方案。”

Noyce: “A large segment of the technical community was on the lookout for a solution.”

基尔比：“发生了很多事情……大家都普遍认为这是必须解决的问题。”

Kilby: “There was just an awful lot going on. . . . It was pretty well accepted that this was the problem that had to be solved.”

诺伊斯：“很明显，一个现成的市场正在等待这位成功的发明家。”

Noyce: “It was clear that a ready market awaited the successful inventor.”

碰巧的是，成功的发明者是两位在竞争制造公司工作的工程师。也就是说，这个具有惊天动地意义的全球性技术问题并没有交给科学家。它不是由大学实验室的学术研究人员解决的，而是由生产线尽头的工业实验室的工程师解决的。

As it happened, the successful inventors were a pair of engineers working at competing manufacturing companies. That is to say, this global technological problem of earth-shaking importance was not turned over to scientists. It was not solved by academic researchers in a university laboratory, but rather by engineers at industrial lab benches just down the hall from the production line.

科学家和工程师倾向于将他们的工作分为两大类，有时被称为基础研究和定向研究。现代世界的一些最关键的发明和发现都是通过基础研究产生的，也就是说，这些研究不以任何特定用途为目的。阿尔伯特·爱因斯坦的宇宙图景、亚历山大·弗莱明发现的青霉素、尼尔斯·玻尔的原子核蓝图、沃森-克里克的 DNA“双螺旋”模型——所有这些都具有巨大的实际意义，但它们都来自基础研究。现代生活中的许多基本工具——电灯、电话、维生素药丸、互联网——都是通过明确集中精力解决特定问题而产生的。从某种意义上说，基础研究和定向研究之间的区别包含了科学和工程之间的区别。总的来说，科学家的动力来自对知识的渴望；正如诺贝尔奖获得者理查德·费曼所说，他们的动机是“发现事物的乐趣”。相比之下，工程师的动力是解决方案。他们的乐趣在于让事情顺利进行。

Scientists and engineers tend to divide their work into two large categories, sometimes described as basic research and directed research. Some of the most crucial inventions and discoveries of the modern world have come about through basic research—that is, work that was not directed toward any particular use. Albert Einstein’s picture of the universe, Alexander Fleming’s discovery of penicillin, Niels Bohr’s blueprint of the atomic nucleus, the Watson-Crick “double helix” model of DNA—all these have had enormous practical implications, but they all came out of basic research. There are just as many basic tools of modern life—the electric light, the telephone, vitamin pills, the Internet—that resulted from a clearly focused effort to solve a particular problem. In a sense, this distinction between basic and directed research encompasses the difference between science and engineering. Scientists, on the whole, are driven by the thirst for knowledge; their motivation, as the Nobel laureate Richard Feynman put it, is “the joy of finding things out.” Engineers, in contrast, are solution-driven. Their joy is making things work.

单片机理念是一种工程解决方案。它通过将数字简化为一个来解决数字的暴政问题：一个完整​​的电路只包含一个部分 - 一个单一的（“单片”）半导体材料块，包含最复杂电路设计的所有元件和所有互连。这一理念的有形产品，工程师称之为单片集成电路，全世界称之为半导体芯片，它从根本上改变了世界，就像电话、灯泡和无马马车一样。集成电路是钟表、计算机、照相机和计算器、心脏起搏器和掌上电脑、深空探测器和深海传感器、烤面包机、打字机、手机和互联网服务器的核心。美国国家科学院称集成电路为“第二次工业革命”的先驱。第一次工业革命增强了人类的体力，将人们从繁重的体力劳动中解放出来；芯片引发的革命提高了我们的智力，使人们从枯燥乏味的计算劳动中解放出来。英国物理学家、女王陛下的首席科学顾问 Ieuan Madlock 爵士称集成电路是“人类有史以来最了不起的技术”。加州商人、Advanced Micro Devices, Inc. 创始人 Jerry Sanders 给出了更尖锐的评价：“集成电路是 80 年代的原油。”

The monolithic idea was an engineering solution. It worked around the tyranny of numbers by reducing the numbers to one: a complete circuit would consist of just one part—a single (“monolithic”) block of semiconductor material containing all the components and all the interconnections of the most complex circuit designs. The tangible product of that idea, known to engineers as the monolithic integrated circuit and to the world at large as the semiconductor chip, has changed the world as fundamentally as did the telephone, the light bulb, and the horseless carriage. The integrated circuit is the heart of clocks, computers, cameras, and calculators, of pacemakers and Palm Pilots, of deep-space probes and deep-sea sensors, of toasters, typewriters, cell phones, and Internet servers. The National Academy of Sciences declared the integrated circuit the progenitor of the “Second Industrial Revolution.” The first Industrial Revolution enhanced man’s physical prowess and freed people from the drudgery of backbreaking manual labor; the revolution spawned by the chip enhances our intellectual prowess and frees people from the drudgery of mind-numbing computational labor. A British physicist, Sir Ieuan Madlock, Her Majesty’s Chief Science Advisor, called the integrated circuit “the most remarkable technology ever to hit mankind.” A California businessman, Jerry Sanders, founder of Advanced Micro Devices, Inc., offered a more pointed assessment: “Integrated circuits are the crude oil of the eighties.”

这一切的发生都源于两个美国年轻人提出了一个新想法——或者更确切地说，一个不那么新的想法。事实上，半导体革命背后的原理是电子学中最古老的想法之一。

All this came about because two young Americans came up with a new idea—or, more precisely, a not-so-new idea. In fact, the principle underlying the semiconductor revolution was one of the oldest ideas in electronics.

2

2

思考的意志

THE WILL TO THINK

除了他们为解释自然界的奥秘而制定的定律、规则、常数、原理、公理、理论和假设之外，科学家和工程师还制定了一系列不成文的规则，旨在解释他们行业的奥秘。其中有一条幽默的，或者说有点幽默的原则，有时被称为“最有名的定律”。简而言之，这条自然定律认为，每当一群研究人员做出重要发现时，该群体中最著名的成员将获得所有荣誉。这似乎解释了为什么热电子发射的重要原理被称为爱迪生效应。

In addition to the laws, rules, constants, principles, axioms, theories, and hypotheses they have devised to explain the mysteries of the natural world, scientists and engineers have developed a series of unwritten rules that purport to explain the mysteries of their business. Among the latter is a humorous, or perhaps quasi-humorous, principle sometimes referred to as “the law of the most famous.” Briefly put, this natural law holds that whenever a group of investigators makes an important discovery, the most famous member of the group will get all the credit. And that seems to explain why the important principle of thermionic emission came to be known as the Edison Effect.

1883 年 3 月，托马斯·爱迪生 (Thomas A. Edison) 的门洛帕克实验室首次观测到热电子发射，当时这位发明家和他的同事注意到他的第一个灯泡内部发生了一些奇怪的事情。除了流过碳丝的电流外，似乎还有另一股单独的电流流过玻璃灯泡内的真空——根据当时对电的解释，这是完全不可能的。门洛帕克没有人明白发生了什么（最终发现电流是白热灯丝中沸腾的电子流）。但爱迪生不愿错过机会，他记录了这一发现并为其申请了专利。然后他把它放在一边。这在一定程度上是时间和资源的问题。由于与债权人的纠纷、专利诉讼以及改进留声机、麦克风和白炽灯的令人沮丧的努力，爱迪生每天工作 20 个小时，通常更多。但爱迪生放弃爱迪生效应的主要原因是他看不到未来。那么，如果电流能够流过真空会怎么样呢？那会有什么好处呢？

Thermionic emission was observed for the first time in March 1883 in Thomas A. Edison’s Menlo Park laboratory, when the inventor and his associates noticed something strange going on inside one of his first light bulbs. In addition to the electric current flowing through the carbon filament, there seemed to be another, separate current flowing through the vacuum inside the glass bulb—something quite impossible, under contemporary explanations of electricity. Nobody at Menlo Park understood what was happening (the current was eventually found to be a flow of electrons boiling off the white-hot filament). But Edison, not one to miss a chance, wrote up the discovery and filed a patent for it. Then he set it aside. It was partly a matter of time and resources. Bedeviled by disputes with his creditors, legal battles over his patents, and frustrating efforts to improve his phonograph, microphone, and incandescent lamp, Edison was already working twenty hours a day, often more. But the main reason Edison abandoned the Edison Effect was that he saw no future in it. So what if current could flow through a vacuum? What good would that do?

120 年后，当固态或半导体器件在几乎所有电子设备中都优于真空管时，我们可以看出爱迪生的说法是有道理的。电子科学和工业以真空管内的热电子效应为基础已有 50 多年的历史；今天回想起来，半个世纪以来对真空管的研究基本上是题外话。当爱迪生于 1883 年发现他的同名效应时，埃德蒙·贝克勒尔、费迪南德·布劳恩和迈克尔·法拉第等电气先驱已经发现某些物质（今天称为半导体）具有各种有用的电子特性。如果这些材料的早期研究继续进行，那么现代半导体革命可能会比现在提前半个世纪甚至更早到来，这并不是异想天开。但在发现爱迪生效应后，电子研究朝着新的方向发展，并取得了显著成果。门洛帕克的工作在十四年后促成了被称为“现代物理学的零时”的实验——电子的发现——从此，沿着一条或多或少直线，无线电报、无线电、电视和第一代数字计算机诞生。这一切都是题外话，但却是辉煌的。

Looking back 120 years later, when solid-state, or semiconductor, devices have proven superior to vacuum tubes in just about all electronic equipment, we can see that Edison had a point. The science and industry of electronics was based on the thermionic effect inside a vacuum tube for more than fifty years; today, hindsight suggests that the half century of work on the vacuum tube was basically a digression. By the time Edison discovered his eponymous effect in 1883, electrical pioneers such as Edmond Becquerel, Ferdinand Braun, and Michael Faraday had already found that certain substances—known today as semiconductors—had a variety of useful electronic characteristics. Had the early work on these materials been continued, it is not too great a flight of fancy to suggest that the modern semiconductor revolution might have come a half century or more earlier than it did. But after the discovery of the Edison Effect, electronics research took a new direction—with dramatic results. The work at Menlo Park led, fourteen years later, to the experiment known as “the zero hour of modern physics”—the discovery of the electron—and from there, along a more or less straight line, to wireless telegraphy, radio, television, and the first generation of digital computers. It was all a digression, but a glorious one.

然而，在 1883 年，这一点还远没有那么明显，甚至对爱迪生这样一位杰出的梦想家来说也是如此。起初，爱迪生效应只引起了科学家的兴趣——而科学兴趣对托马斯·爱迪生来说并不是一件很重要的商品。“嗯，我不是科学家，”门洛帕克的奇才说。“我所做的一切都以银元的大小来衡量。如果它达不到这个标准，那我知道它就不好。”

In 1883, however, that point was considerably less than obvious, even to an exceptional visionary like Edison. At first, the Edison Effect held interest only for scientists—and scientific interest was not a commodity of great importance to Thomas A. Edison. “Well, I’m not a scientist,” the Wizard of Menlo Park said. “I measure everything I do by the size of the silver dollar. If it don’t come up to that standard then I know it’s no good.”

这句话是典型的爱迪生风格。他一生都把自己描绘成一个极度务实的人，依靠勤奋和常识为他的同胞创造更好的生活，并在这个过程中致富。这是一幅典型的美国画卷，而且本质上是准确的，因为爱迪生的生活具有经典美国故事的元素。他是一位不常成功的商人的第七个孩子，在俄亥俄州和密歇根州的中等城镇长大。他上了大约四年的学，包括他母亲在家辅导他的时间，12 岁开始发家致富。他在底特律 - 休伦港火车上卖零食。他创办了一份名为Paul Pry 的报纸。他做过很多电报员的工作，也做过很多次，他非常喜欢这个职业，以至于他给自己的前两个孩子取名为 Dot 和 Dash。他不断地摆弄雇主的电报设备，开始设计有用的改进，并从中获利。渐渐地，他发现自己可以靠发明家谋生。到他三十五岁生日时，爱迪生已经是百万富翁、行业领袖，或许也是世界上最有名的人。1878 年初，当他宣布可能尝试完善电灯时，华尔街的照明天然气股票暴跌。当《纽约每日图画报》报道爱迪生发明了一种能用泥土和水旋转食物和葡萄酒的机器时，许多报纸没有注意到 4 月 1 日的日期，而是直接刊登了这个故事——这只是门洛帕克的又一个奇迹。1931 年，爱迪生去世，享年 84 岁，有人提议将世界上所有的灯熄灭两分钟以示纪念。这个想法被否决了，理由是如果没有电灯，世界不可能运转那么久。

That line was classic Edison. All his life he portrayed himself as the supreme pragmatist, relying on hard work and common sense to build a better life for his fellow man—and get rich in the process. It was an archetypal American picture, and essentially an accurate one, for Edison’s life has the elements of the classic American story. The seventh child of an infrequently successful businessman, he grew up in medium-size towns in Ohio and Michigan. He had about four years of school, counting the time his mother tutored him at home, and set out at the age of twelve to make his fortune. He sold snacks on the Detroit–Port Huron train. He started a newspaper called Paul Pry. He fell into and out of numerous jobs as a telegraph operator, a profession he enjoyed so much that he called his first two children Dot and Dash. Tinkering continually with his employers’ telegraphic equipment, he began to design useful improvements, and get paid for them. Gradually, he discovered that he could make a living as an inventor. By his thirty-fifth birthday, Edison was a millionaire, a leader of industry, and probably the best-known man on earth. When he announced early in 1878 that he might try to perfect an electric light, illuminating gas stocks plummeted on Wall Street. When the New York Daily Graphic reported that Edison had invented a machine that spun food and wine from mud and water, many newspapers failed to notice the April 1 dateline and ran the story straight—just one more miracle from Menlo Park. When Edison died, at eighty-four, in 1931, someone proposed that all the lights in the world be turned out for two minutes as a memorial. The idea was dropped on the ground that it would be impossible for the world to function that long without the electric light.

尽管名声显赫，财富滚滚，爱迪生依然是个粗野的乡巴佬，他蔑视清洁、时尚、秩序、宗教和科学。1878 年，一位记者参观了著名的门洛帕克实验室，他这样描述实验室的老板：“头发开始变白，像拖把一样垂在​​额头上。双手沾满酸液，他的衣服是‘现成的’。他看起来像个技工，或者从他那苍白的脸色来看，他像个夜间印刷工。”爱迪生每天工作 40、80 或 100 个小时，偶尔在实验室的长凳下打个盹。他采用了Perseverantia omnia vincit 的座右铭，后来他将其翻译为“天才是 1% 的灵感和 99% 的汗水”。他对这个公式有绝对的信心；他确信只要尝试足够多的解决方案，他就能解决任何问题。当一名助手疲惫地指出门洛帕克团队尝试了 8,000 种不同的配方，却徒劳无功地制造出蓄电池时，这位发明家回答说：“至少我们知道 8,000 种行不通的东西。”为了找到一种有效的白炽灯灯丝，爱迪生决定尝试地球上所有的东西，直到找到一种行得通。他用干草做了一根灯丝，但出了问题。他尝试了铝、铂、钨、树皮、猫肠、马蹄、人的胡须和大约 6,000 种植物，最后在一段碳化的棉线中找到了解决方案。

Despite fame and fortune, Edison remained an uncouth hay-seed who flaunted his disdain for cleanliness, fashion, order, religion, and science. A journalist touring the famous Menlo Park laboratory in 1878 described the proprietor this way: “The hair, beginning to be touched with gray, falls over the forehead in a mop. The hands are stained with acid, his clothing is ‘readymade.’ He has the air of a mechanic, or with his particular pallor, of a night-printer.” Edison worked in 40-, 80-, or 100-hour bursts, catching a few intervals of sleep under a bench in the lab. He adopted the motto Perseverantia omnia vincit, a phrase that he subsequently translated to “Genius is 1 percent inspiration and 99 percent perspiration.” He had absolute confidence in this formula; he was certain he could solve any problem if he just tried enough solutions. After an assistant noted wearily that the Menlo Park team had worked through 8,000 different formulas in a futile effort to build a storage battery, the inventor replied that “at least we know 8,000 things that don’t work.” Struggling to find an efficient filament for his incandescent light, Edison decided to try everything on earth until something worked. He made a filament from dried grass, but that went haywire. He tried aluminum, platinum, tungsten, tree bark, cat’s gut, horse’s hoof, man’s beard, and some 6,000 vegetable growths before finding a solution in a carbonized length of cotton thread.

至少在公开场合，这位伟大的经验主义者与科学家、数学家或任何大学毕业生都毫无来往——“满脑子都是拉丁语、哲学和所有那些傻瓜”。他大张旗鼓地发明了一种“无知测量仪”，以证明知识分子没有常识。当他聘请自己的“科学顾问”——弗朗西斯·厄普顿 (Francis Upton) 时，他是普林斯顿大学的博士学位获得者，也是伟大的德国物理学家赫尔曼·亥姆霍兹 (Hermann Helmholtz) 的学生——爱迪生立即给他起了个名字叫“文化”，这是门洛帕克帮派的嘲笑词。很快，报纸就报道了爱迪生如何要求他的手下文化确定一个空玻璃泡的体积（以立方厘米为单位）。厄普顿开始用一系列复杂的微分方程来完成这项任务，几个小时后，这些方程将得出接近正确数字的近似值。这位务实的发明家微笑着，抓起球泡，装满水，然后将水倒入量杯中——不到一分钟就确定了精确的容量。

Publicly, at least, the great empiricist had no truck with scientists, mathematicians, or any college graduate—“filled up with Latin, philosophy, and all that ninny stuff.” With great fanfare, he invented an “ignorameter” to prove that intellectuals had no common sense. When he hired a “science advisor” of his own—Francis Upton, holder of a Ph.D. from Princeton and student of the great German physicist Hermann Helmholtz—Edison promptly named him “Culture,” a term of derision among the gang at Menlo Park. Soon enough the newspapers were reporting how Edison had asked his man Culture to determine the volume, in cubic centimeters, of an empty glass bulb. Upton set to the task with a complex series of differential equations that would lead, after a few hours, to a close approximation of the correct figure. With a smirk, the pragmatic inventor grabbed the bulb, filled it with water, and poured the water into a measuring cup—determining the precise volume in less than a minute.

文化最终融入了实验室生活，爱迪生也意识到厄普顿的数学和物理技能是一项重要资产。厄普顿设计并制造了发电机（用现代术语来说，就是发电厂），为爱迪生照明系统和爱迪生电力火车提供安全、高效的电力。厄普顿作为观察者和理论家的技能对热电子发射的发现至关重要，因此这种现象可能更确切地被称为厄普顿效应。

Culture eventually became acculturated to life in the lab, and Edison eventually came to realize that Upton’s mathematical and physical skills were an important asset. Upton designed and built the dynamo—in modern terms, the power plant—that provided safe, efficient power for the Edison lighting system and the Edison electric train. Upton’s skills as an observer and theoretician were so central to the discovery of thermionic emission that the phenomenon might more fairly be called the Upton Effect.

爱迪生的电灯当然依赖于透明玻璃灯泡。灯泡内是真空。在真空中，电流通过灯丝使灯丝发出白热光（真空是必需的，因为没有空气，灯丝就不会烧毁）。光辉透过玻璃灯泡发出，并发光。当电灯还在诞生之初，爱迪生和厄普顿注意到，随着时间的推移，透明玻璃灯泡会变黑。这是一个问题，发明家开始用他的标准方法来消除这个问题。他进行了一系列详尽的反复试验，以找出问题所在。与此同时，厄普顿仔细观察了这一现象。1883 年 3 月，他建议在灯泡内放一块小金属板。这并没有起到什么作用（灯泡变暗的问题最终通过使用更纯净的灯丝材料得到解决），但它带来了一个令人着迷的发现。作为科学家，天生好奇的人，他们花了一些时间研究他们失败的想法——即在灯泡内放一块金属板。他们惊讶地发现，金属板中流过电流。这电流究竟从何而来？当然，电流流过灯丝，但灯丝和金属板之间没有任何联系。研究人员天生好奇，于是做了一些测试。他们增加了灯丝中的电流——发现金属板中的电流也相应增加了。显然，电流在真空中从灯丝流向金属板。这非常令人惊讶——至少对于信任科学家的厄普顿来说——因为专家们已经无可辩驳地证实了电流无法穿越真空。现在爱迪生用实验证明他们错了。

Edison’s electric lamp depended, of course, on a clear glass bulb. The bulb enclosed a vacuum. In that vacuum, electricity running through the filament caused the filament to glow with a white heat (the vacuum was necessary because without air, the filament would not burn away). The glow showed through the glass bulb and gave light. When the electric light was still in its birth throes, Edison and Upton noticed that, over time, the clear glass bulb tended to grow black. This was a problem, and the inventor set out in his standard way to eliminate the problem. He launched into an exhaustive series of trial-and-error experiments to find out what was wrong. Upton, meanwhile, made careful observations of the phenomenon. In March 1883 he suggested putting a small metal plate inside the bulb. This didn’t help (the problem of darkening bulbs was eventually solved by using purer materials for the filament), but it led to a fascinating discovery. Being scientists, being naturally curious people, they spent some time looking over their failed idea—that is, the light bulb with a metal plate in it. They found, to their surprise, that electric current was flowing in the metal plate. Where in the world could this current come from? Current was flowing through the filament, of course, but there was no connection whatsoever between the filament and the plate. Being naturally curious people, the researchers tried some tests. They increased the current through the filament—and found that the current in the metal plate increased proportionally. Evidently, electric current was flowing across the vacuum from filament to plate. This was quite astonishing—at least to Upton, who trusted scientists—because the experts had established incontrovertibly that electric current could not traverse a vacuum. Now Edison had proven them wrong.

在接下来的几年里，神秘的真空电流成为大西洋两岸电气展览会上的展品。由于发现者名声显赫，这种不可能的电流很快被称为爱迪生效应。爱迪生英国子公司的科学家约翰·A·弗莱明订购了一些爱迪生效应灯，并尝试了一些实验。爱迪生在工作中一直使用直流电——电流始终沿同一方向流动。1884-85 年冬天，弗莱明尝试了不同的东西。他将灯丝连接到产生交流电的发电机上——这种电流不断改变方向，来回，来回，每秒多达 120 次。他惊讶地发现，即使交流电在灯丝中来回流动，流向金属板的电流仍然是直流电，方向从未改变。灯已将交流电转换为直流电。

Over the next few years, the mysterious current-in-a-vacuum became a prize exhibit at electrical exhibitions on both sides of the Atlantic. Given its famous discoverer, the impossible current was quickly dubbed the Edison Effect. John A. Fleming, a scientist on the staff of Edison’s British subsidiary, ordered some Edison Effect lamps and tried a number of experiments. Edison had always used a direct current of electricity in his work—a current in which the electricity flowed in the same direction all the time. During the winter of 1884–85, Fleming tried something different. He hooked up the filament to a generator that produced alternating current—a current that constantly changes direction, back and forth, back and forth, as often as 120 times per second. He was mystified to see that, even with an alternating current racing back and forth through the filament, the current flowing to the metal plate was still direct current, never changing direction. The lamp had converted alternating current to direct current.

没人能解释这个结果——当然，爱迪生最不能解释，他站在一旁，看着科学家们做着他们的事情，脸上露出笑容。爱迪生在给朋友的信中写道，对爱迪生效应的研究仅仅是美学研究，“我从来没有时间去研究我工作的美学部分……但据我所知，它对萨凡纳世界的凸头兄弟会目前正在制定的一些法律有着非常重要的影响。”

No one could explain this result—least of all Edison, of course, who stood aside and smiled as the scientists did their stuff. Research on the Edison Effect was merely aesthetics, Edison wrote to a friend, and “I have never had time to go into the aesthetic part of my work. . . . But it has, I am told, a very important bearing on some laws now being formulated by the Bulged-headed fraternity of the Savanic world.”

事实确实如此。美国和欧洲的专家们对电流在真空中的流动进行了广泛的实验。进行这项工作的基本设备是一个细长的玻璃管，一端有一块碳或金属，加热——就像爱迪生灯泡里的灯丝一样——直到热能通过真空发射出电流（因此称为“热电子发射”）。发射电流的金属片称为阴极，因此玻璃管被称为阴极射线管。电流会沿着管子射到远端；在光束击中的地方，玻璃会发出磷光或发光。当时，这种奇特的科学仪器只在美国和欧洲最好的实验室里找到。今天，它以电视显像管的形式出现在各地的客厅、地下室和酒吧里。

It did indeed. Savants in the United States and Europe undertook extensive experimentation on the flow of electricity through a vacuum. The basic apparatus for this work was an elongated glass tube with a piece of carbon or metal at one end that was heated—just like the filament in Edison’s light bulb—until the thermal energy emitted an electric current (hence “thermionic emission”) through the vacuum. The piece of metal that emitted the current was called a cathode, so the glass tube was known as a cathode ray tube. The current would beam down the tube to the far end; at the spot where the beam hit, the glass would phosphoresce, or glow. At the time, this exotic piece of scientific apparatus was found only in the finest laboratories in the United States and Europe. Today it is found in living rooms, basements, and bars everywhere, in the form of the television picture tube.

阴极射线管的工作原理。

How a cathode ray tube works.

学者们希望阴极射线管能够清晰地显示阴极射线，从而解释电力。十九世纪末，工程师和科学家之间出现了奇怪的分歧。多亏了工程师和爱迪生等务实的发明家，电力为世界大部分地区供电，让夜晚变得像白天一样明亮。但科学家们仍然不知道这种强大的力量到底是什么。电的奥秘引发了许多相互矛盾的假设。早期研究人员假设电是一种流体（这就是为什么我们今天仍然谈论“电流”和“流动”的原因）。然后，在 19 世纪 80 年代，这种观念让位于一对相互竞争的理论。一种观点认为电是一种波现象，就像声音和光一样；另一种学派认为阴极射线管中的电束是一束粒子流，就像沙粒一样。波还是粒子？物理学界最伟大的头脑们对这个问题进行了思考、辩论和推测。答案最终来自物理学史上最迷人、最强大的智慧之一——约瑟夫·约翰·汤姆森爵士教授。

The savants hoped that the tube would provide a clear enough picture of cathode rays to permit an explanation of the electric force. As the nineteenth century neared an end, there was a curious gap between the engineers and the scientists. Thanks to the engineers and pragmatic inventors like Edison, electricity powered much of the world and made the nights shine as day. But the scientists still didn’t know precisely what this mighty force was. The mystery of electricity had prompted a number of contradictory hypotheses. Early researchers had postulated that electricity was a fluid (which is why we still talk today of “current” and “flow”). Then, in the 1880s, this notion gave way to a pair of competing theories. One view held that electricity was a wave phenomenon, like sound and light; the other school of thought considered the electric beam in the cathode ray tube to be a stream of particles, like grains of sand. Wave or particle? The greatest minds in physics pondered, debated, speculated over the question. The answer finally came from one of the most fascinating and formidable intellects in the history of physics—Professor Sir Joseph John Thomson.

JJ Thomson 出生于 1856 年，父亲是曼彻斯特的一名书商。家里原本计划让 JJ 去当一名当地工程师的学徒，然后从事这一职业。但是，JJ 16 岁时，父亲去世，Thomson 一家无力支付工程师培训学徒的费用。男孩获得了当地一所大学的奖学金，并很快对数学和物理产生了浓厚的兴趣。时机非常完美——Thomson 的职业生涯跨越了艾萨克·牛顿时代以来物理学最丰富的时代——但在他的大学时代，没有人知道这一点。事实恰恰相反：在 19 世纪 70 年代，人们普遍认为物理学最有趣的部分已经结束，剩下的只是改进测量方法。毕竟，每个人都知道所有物质都是由称为原子的不可分割粒子组成的，元素之间的差异是由于原子之间的差异造成的。伟大的理论家詹姆斯克拉克麦克斯韦 (James Clerk Maxwell) 在被提名为剑桥大学卡文迪什教授（实际上是英国桂冠物理学家）的隆重仪式上指出，人们一致认为“再过几年，所有重大的物理限制都将得到近似估计，到那时，科学家们唯一要做的就是将这些测量结果精确到小数点后一位。” 科学家们已经测量了宇宙中最小物体的质量——氢原子，其重量约为 0.00000000000000000000000017 克（也就是说，约为 0.000000000000000000000000006 盎司）。

J. J. Thomson was born in 1856, the son of a bookseller in Manchester. The family’s plan had been that J.J. would be apprenticed to a local engineer and take up that profession. But his father’s death, when J.J. was sixteen, left the Thomsons unable to pay the fees engineers charged for training apprentices. The boy won a scholarship at a local college and quickly came under the spell of mathematics and physics. The timing was perfect—Thomson’s professional career spanned the most fertile era in physics since Isaac Newton’s day—but nobody knew that during his college days. Quite the contrary, in fact: in the 1870s, there was a general sense that the interesting part of physics was over, and all that remained was refining the measurements. After all, everyone knew that all matter was made of indivisible particles called atoms, and that differences among elements were due to differences in their atoms. The great theoretician James Clerk Maxwell, on the august occasion of his nomination as Cavendish professor at Cambridge—in essence, the physicist laureate of England—noted the consensus “that in a few years all the great physical constraints will have been approximately estimated, and that the only occupation which will then be left to men of science will be to carry on those measurements to another place of decimals.” Already scientists had measured the mass of the smallest object in the universe—the hydrogen atom, weighing about .0000000000000000000000017 gram (which is to say, about .00000000000000000000000006 ounce).

1876 年，汤姆森进入剑桥大学，师从伟大的麦克斯韦，并很快崭露头角。他因一项有趣的发现而获得了三一奖，即一滴水即使带上电荷也不会蒸发。在 1881 年的一篇论文中，他提出了运动球体的质量和能量之间存在联系——这个想法在 24 年后由另一位物理学家在方程式 E = MC 2中得以具体化。作为剑桥大学杰出的物理学家，汤姆森于 1884 年接替了麦克斯韦的教席——既是教授职位，也是家具。当时他 28 岁。一位年长的同事抱怨道：“事情已经到了很糟糕的地步，小孩子竟然被任命为教授。”这个小男孩接管了麦克斯韦在卡文迪什实验室的旧办公室，这是一座乳黄色的新哥特式建筑，门上印着卡文迪什家族的座右铭：Cavendo tutus，即“时刻警惕”。

Thomson went to Cambridge in 1876, studied under the great Maxwell, and quickly distinguished himself. He won the Trinity Prize for the interesting discovery that a drop of water would not evaporate if given an electric charge. In an 1881 paper he suggested that there was a connection between the mass and the energy of a moving sphere—an idea that was crystallized by another physicist twenty-four years later in the equation E = MC2. As the preeminent Cambridge physicist, Thomson succeeded in 1884 to the chair—both the professorship and the piece of furniture—that Maxwell had held. He was twenty-eight years old. “Things have come to a pretty pass,” an older colleague groused, “when mere boys are appointed professors.” The mere boy took over Maxwell’s old office in the Cavendish Laboratory, a cream yellow neo-Gothic pile with the Cavendish family’s motto emblazoned over the door: Cavendo tutus, or “Always on the Lookout.”

“JJ 大部分时间都坐在曾属于麦克斯韦的扶手椅上做数学题”，一位学生回忆道。他坐在那里思考、解决问题，因为他对思想的力量有绝对的信心。他确信，借助数学，人类思维可以理解所有的物理现象。但这位教授的好奇心广泛，远远超出了数学和物理的范围。他的工作时间最多从早上十点到晚上六点（中间有下午茶时间），他还经常抽出时间为剑桥大学参加划船和橄榄球比赛加油。他阅读了 AE 豪斯曼的诗歌手稿，并决心从不错过吉尔伯特和沙利文新轻歌剧的首演之夜。他对园艺、高尔夫和美国政治很着迷。他是地地道道的英国人。在回忆录中，他非常自豪地指出，他的 27 名学生（包括他的儿子）被选入皇家艺术学院；顺便说一句，他提到其中有七个（包括他的儿子）也获得了诺贝尔奖。JJ 自己在 1906 年获得的诺贝尔奖似乎比他两年后获得的爵士头衔更让他满意。1940 年，他 84 岁去世，被安葬在威斯敏斯特大教堂艾萨克·牛顿墓旁。

“J.J. spent a good part of most days sitting in the armchair that had belonged to Maxwell, doing mathematics,” a student recalled. He sat there thinking, working out problems, because he had absolute confidence in the power of thought. He was certain that the human mind, aided by mathematics, could comprehend all physical phenomena. But the professor’s wide-ranging curiosity reached far beyond math and physics. His workday ran, at the most, from ten in the morning to six at night (with a break for afternoon tea), and he regularly found time to cheer for Cambridge at crew and rugby matches. He read A. E. Housman’s poetry in manuscript and made it a point never to miss opening night of a new Gilbert and Sullivan operetta. He was fascinated by gardening, golf, and American politics. He was British to the core. In his memoirs he notes with great pride that twenty-seven of his students (including his son) were elected to the Royal Academy; as an aside, he mentions that seven of them (including his son) also picked up Nobel Prizes. J.J.’s own Nobel Prize, in 1906, seems to have satisfied him less than the knighthood he received two years later. When he died, at eighty-four, in 1940, he was buried in Westminster Abbey near the grave of Isaac Newton.

物理学家谈论汤姆森 1897 年的阴极射线实验，就像建筑师谈论毕尔巴鄂的古根海姆博物馆一样。实验方法优雅，结论大胆而令人震惊，实验结果给后来的一切留下了不可磨灭的印记。汤姆森决心找出一切关于射入阴极射线管的电子束的信息。它从何而来？它是由什么构成的？那束纯能量是波还是粒子流？汤姆森决定通过对电子束施加不同的力并尽可能精确地测量结果来确定电子束的性质。他的实验非常漂亮。通过在玻璃管周围放置磁铁，汤姆森可以让阴极射线以完美的螺旋形旋转。由于管内的真空不完全，阴极射线偶尔会撞击杂散气体原子并使其带电。带电原子或离子会发出五彩缤纷的光辉，直到被另一个原子中和或重新结合。结果是如此美好，以至于汤姆森和他的同事们为此写了一首歌，曲调为“克莱门汀”：

Physicists talk about Thomson’s cathode ray experiment of 1897 the way architects talk about the Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao. The approach was elegant, the conclusion bold and stunning, and the result left an indelible mark on everything that came after. Thomson was determined to find out everything he could about that electric beam shooting through the cathode ray tube. Where did it come from? What was it made of? Was that beam of pure energy a wave, or a stream of particles? Thomson decided he could ascertain the nature of the electric beam by subjecting it to different forces and measuring the results as precisely as possible. His experiments were beautiful to watch. By placing magnets around the glass tube, Thomson could make the cathode ray spin in a perfect spiral. Since the vacuum in the tube was not complete, the cathode ray would occasionally strike a stray gas atom and give it an electric charge. The charged atom, or ion, would glow with a colorful splendor until it was neutralized, or recombined, by another atom. So lovely were the results that Thomson and his colleagues wrote a song about it all, to the tune of “Clementine”:

在布满灰尘的实验室里，

在线圈、蜡和麻线中间，

原子在其荣耀中

电离并重新结合。

In the dusty lab’ratory,

’Mid the coils and wax and twine,

There the atoms in their glory

Ionize and recombine.

 

 

合唱：噢，我的爱人！噢，我的爱人！

噢，我的爱人是我的！

你迷失了，永远消失了

，直到你重新结合。

Chorus: Oh my darlings! Oh my darlings!

Oh my darling ions mine!

You are lost and gone forever

When just once you recombine.

 

 

在奇异的磁路中

看看它们如何紧密缠绕，每个离子都围绕着自己的磁力线形成

螺旋。

In the weird magnetic circuit

See how lovingly they twine,

As each ion describes a spiral

Round its own magnetic line.

 

 

合唱

Chorus

在一个完全无电极的管子里，

它们沿着一条线放电，

它们留下的光芒

在一段时间内是相当耀眼的。

In a tube quite electrodeless,

They discharge around a line,

And the glow they leave behind them

Is quite corking for a time.

 

 

合唱

Chorus

起初，汤姆森的研究只带来了混乱；他的发现似乎不符合任何单一理论。电束可以被磁铁或电场弯曲，这一事实强烈表明它是由粒子组成的，因为没有波会受到磁引力的影响。但也有令人信服的证据反对粒子假说。即使使用最精确的测量，也没有迹象表明光束会像任何粒子流一样被重力偏转。此外，光束可以穿过薄薄的金属箔片而不留下孔洞。众所周知，某些能量波可以做到这一点——就像光波穿过窗户而不会在玻璃上留下痕迹一样——但固体粒子似乎不可能做到这一点。为了解决这些矛盾的结果，汤姆森求助于数学。通过一系列巧妙的计算，他确定了移动光束的速度——它行进的速度约为每秒 20,000 英里，比以前发现的任何物体的运动速度都要快得多。利用这一结果，他计算出阴极射线粒子的质量（如果它们确实是粒子的话）。结果简直不可能。每个粒子的质量将小于氢原子大小的千分之一。从物理角度来说，这不可能正确，因为众所周知，氢原子是所有物质中最小的，而且完全不可分割。但从数学角度来说，这不可能错误。此时，汤姆森结束了实验。他别无选择，只能坐在麦克斯韦的扶手椅上仔细思考这个问题。

At first, Thomson’s research produced nothing but confusion; his findings did not seem to fit any single theory. The fact that the electric beam could be bent by a magnet or an electric field strongly suggested that it consisted of particles, for no wave was susceptible to magnetic attraction. But there was also compelling evidence against the particle hypothesis. There was no indication, even with the most exacting measurements, that the beam was deflected by gravity, as any stream of particles should be. Further, the beam could pass through a thin sheet of metal foil without leaving a hole. It was known that certain energy waves did that—just as light waves pass through a window without leaving a mark on the glass—but it seemed impossible for a solid particle to do so. To resolve these contradictory results, Thomson fell back on mathematics. Through a series of ingenious calculations, he determined the velocity of the moving beam—it traveled about 20,000 miles per second, infinitely faster than any object had ever been found to move before. Using that result, he calculated what the mass of the cathode ray particles would be, if indeed they were particles. This produced a result that was simply impossible. The mass of each particle would be less than one one-thousandth the size of a hydrogen atom. As a physical matter, this could not be right, for the hydrogen atom was well known to be the smallest of all material objects, and quite indivisible. As a mathematical matter, though, it could not be wrong. At this point, Thomson ended his experiments. There was nothing left to do but sit down in Maxwell’s armchair and think the matter through.

汤姆森从这项研究中得出的结论在今天看来是如此简单，以至于几乎不可能认识到在 1897 年提出这一结论需要多么巨大的直觉飞跃和纯粹的革命性勇气。他一举分裂了不可分裂的原子，并解释了无法解释的电作用力。四月的一个星期五晚上，他在皇家学会的一次非正式演讲中展示了他对物理世界的全新看法。
