The conclusion Thomson drew from this research is so elementary today that it is almost impossible to appreciate the enormous intuitive leap, the sheer revolutionary daring, that was required to state it in 1897. In one fell swoop, he split the unsplit-table atom and explained the inexplicable force of electricity. He presented his wholly new picture of the physical world in an informal speech to the Royal Institution on a Friday evening in April.

“我最近做了一些有趣的实验，”他开始说道。他接着说，与公认的科学智慧相反，原子并不是不可分割的。他在原子中发现了一种新的粒子——一种至少比任何原子小一千倍的粒子。这些亚原子粒子——汤姆森称之为“微粒”，但最终采用了“电子”一词——是所有物质的普遍组成部分，存在于每个原子中。电子具有磁性并带负电荷，这解释了为什么磁铁或电场会使它们偏离直线路径。它们的质量非常小，以至于重力作用在它们身上是无法察觉的。它们比任何原子都小得多，以至于它们可以穿过金属原子的开放空间——从而穿过一片金属箔而不留痕迹。阴极射线——事实上，任何电流——都是由这些带电粒子流组成的。

“I have lately made some experiments which are interesting,” he began. Contrary to accepted scientific wisdom, he went on, the atom was not indivisible. He had found within the atom a new kind of particle—a particle at least a thousand times smaller than any atom. These subatomic particles—Thomson called them “corpuscles,” but eventually the term “electrons” was adopted instead—are universal constituents of all matter, found in every atom. The electrons are magnetic and carry a negative charge, which explains why a magnet or an electric field made them swerve from their straight path. Their mass is so minute that the force of gravity upon them was undetectable. They are so much smaller than any atom that they could slip through the open spaces in an atom of metal—and thus shoot through a sheet of metal foil without a trace. The cathode ray—for that matter, any electric current—consists of a stream of these charged particles.

在随后的讲座和论文中，汤姆森和他的同事们完善了他们对电子的描述，并假设了其他亚原子粒子。由于电子带负电荷，原子中一定还有另一个带正电的粒子；电子和质子（正粒子后来被称为质子）的数量相等，会使普通原子呈电中性。由于电子质量小，它可以移动。事实上，如果一块金属带上电荷或加热到白炽状态（如爱迪生效应），电子就会大量流出。汤姆森得出结论，这股移动的电子流就是电流。

In subsequent lectures and papers, Thomson and his colleagues refined their picture of the electron and postulated other subatomic particles. Since the electrons carried a negative charge, there must be another, positively charged particle in the atom; equal numbers of electrons and protons (as the positive particles came to be called) would make the ordinary atom electrically neutral. Because of its small mass, the electron can move about. Indeed, if a piece of metal is given an electric charge or heated to incandescence (as in the Edison Effect), electrons will stream away in huge numbers. This stream of moving electrons, Thomson concluded, is an electric current.

和任何令人震惊的发现一样，JJ Thomson 的结论“原子由许多更小的部分组成”一开始也遭到了抵制。但很快，物理学界就逐渐接受了电子和质子的存在，因为这个理论是可行的。它解释了以前人们无法理解的有关原子结构和电的各种事情。它最终将使半导体物理学的全新世界成为可能。这是一个开创性的想法。

As with any shocking discovery, J. J. Thomson’s conclusion that the atom consisted of many smaller parts drew resistance at first. Fairly soon, though, the world of physics grew to accept the existence of the electron and the proton because the theory worked. It explained all sorts of things about atomic structure and about electricity that had not been understood before. It would eventually make possible the whole new world of semiconductor physics. It was a seminal idea.

这个想法诞生的那间乳黄色实验室仍然矗立在剑桥校园里，尽管如今它已经成为政治学家和经济学家的办公场所。剑桥大学在相当远的地方为物理学家和工程师建造了一座漂亮的新卡文迪什实验室。但至少剑桥的董事会成员有历史感。他们在汤姆森旧实验室外的墙上挂了一块纪念匾，纪念汤姆森的重大突破 100 周年：

The cream yellow laboratory where this idea was born still stands on the Cambridge campus, although nowadays it houses political scientists and economists. The university has built a fancy new Cavendish Laboratory for physicists and engineers a fair distance away. But at least the trustees of Cambridge have a sense of history. They marked the 100th anniversary of Thomson’s great breakthrough by mounting a celebratory plaque on the wall, outside his old lab:



1897 年， JJ THOMSON在老卡文迪什实验室

发现了电子，

随后电子被公认为

物理学的第一个基本粒子

，并成为化学键、电子学和计算的基础。

Here in 1897 at the old Cavendish Laboratory

J.J. THOMSON

discovered the electron

subsequently recognized as the

first fundamental particle of physics

and the basis of chemical bonding, electronics, and computing.

 

 

尽管汤姆森的洞察力源自真空电流实验，但他对电流（移动电荷的流动）的解释同样适用于半导体材料块中的电流。如果科学家们重新开始上一代人基本上被搁置的半导体工作，下一个重要发展可能就会出现在该领域。然而，汤姆森的发现首先应用于真空管，真空管成为接下来半个世纪电子设备的核心部件。这要归功于约翰·安布罗斯·弗莱明和李·德·福雷斯特的工作。

Although Thomson’s leap of insight developed from experiments on electric current in a vacuum, his explanation of electric current—a flow of moving charges—is equally valid for current in a block of semiconductor material. If scientists had gone back to the semiconductor work that had largely been laid aside a generation earlier, the next important developments might have come in that field. As it happened, though, Thomson’s discovery was first applied in vacuum tubes—and the tube became the central component of electronic devices for the next half century. This came about because of the work of John Ambrose Fleming and Lee De Forest.

JA 弗莱明是汤姆森的同辈。和汤姆森一样，他在大学学习物理只是因为他的家庭无法支付工程学徒的费用。和汤姆森一样，弗莱明也是一位杰出的教授（在伦敦大学学院任教），也是主要科学协会的成员。与汤姆森不同，弗莱明对从他的工作中赚钱很感兴趣；结果就是，他像爱迪生一样陷入了无休止的专利诉讼。为了获得收入，弗莱明四处巡回演讲，走遍不列颠群岛进行科学演示。弗莱明勤奋、纪律严明、对自己和周围的人要求极高，他决心让自己的演讲完美无缺——他用秒表排练，确保每个单词和手势都恰到好处——因此，他没能看出 1903 年在一次广为宣传的演讲中恶作剧的幽默之处。为了展示无线电报的神奇之处，弗莱明安排在演讲中途接收伟大的古列尔莫·马可尼本人的长途信息。在适当的时候，电报键开始发出嘎嘎声，但信息不是弗莱明为纪念这一历史性时刻选择的有分量的字眼，而是一首下流的打油诗（“有一位意大利年轻人/他非常巧妙地欺骗了公众……”）。原来，听众中一位爱玩的学生，现代黑客的先驱，为了恶作剧而自带了一台发射器，侵入了网络。弗莱明对此感到非常不悦，他给《纽约时报》写了一封措辞严厉的信，谴责这种“科学流氓行为”。

J. A. Fleming was a contemporary of Thomson’s. Like Thomson, he studied physics at college only because his family could not pay for an engineering apprenticeship. Like Thomson, Fleming was a distinguished professor (at University College, London) and a member of the leading scientific societies. Unlike Thomson, Fleming was interested in making money from his work; one result was that, like Edison, he became ensnarled in endless patent litigation. In pursuit of an income, Fleming worked the lecture circuit, traveling all over the British Isles to give scientific demonstrations. Hard-working, highly disciplined, extremely demanding of himself and those around him, Fleming was determined that everything about his lectures should be perfect—he rehearsed with a stopwatch so that every word and gesture would come at the right second—and thus failed to see the humor in a prank perpetrated during a widely advertised talk he gave in 1903. To demonstrate the wonders of wireless telegraphy, Fleming had arranged to receive a long-distance message in mid-lecture from the great Guglielmo Marconi himself. At the appropriate time, the telegraph key began to rattle, but instead of the weighty words Fleming had chosen to mark the historic occasion, the message was an off-color limerick (“There was a young fellow of Italy/ Who diddled the public quite prettily . . .”). It turned out that a playful student in the audience, a precursor of the modern hacker, had brought a transmitter of his own for purposes of mischief and broken into the network. Fleming, thoroughly unamused, wrote a thundering letter to The Times to denounce such “scientific hooliganism.”

弗莱明对金钱的兴趣也使他开创了现代教职员工中常见的一种做法——为工业企业提供咨询。1882 年，他被任命为爱迪生电灯有限公司的“电工”（现代术语为“科学顾问”）。他只担任了几年这个职位，但那几年恰逢爱迪生和厄普顿研究爱迪生效应的时期。正如我们所见，弗莱明在 1884 年发现了一个有趣的现象：爱迪生效应电流（从灯丝流向金属板的电流）从不改变方向，即使交流电通过灯丝也是如此。多年后，在汤姆森确定电流是电子流之后，弗莱明才得以解释其中的原因。从热灯丝中沸腾出来的电子流向金属板。但金属板的温度不足以发射电子，因此没有电流从金属板流回灯丝。因此，爱迪生效应总是产生直流电。

Fleming’s interest in money also led him to pioneer a practice common among modern faculty members—consulting to industrial concerns. In 1882 he was appointed “electrician” (the modern term would be “science advisor”) to the Edison Electric Light Company, Ltd. He held that position only a few years, but they happened to be the years when Edison and Upton were working on the Edison Effect. Fleming, as we have seen, made the interesting discovery in 1884 that the Edison Effect current—the current from the filament to the metal plate—never changed direction, even when alternating current was sent through the filament. Years later, after Thomson had established that the current is a flow of electrons, Fleming was able to explain why. Electrons boiling off the hot filament flowed to the metal plate. But the plate was not hot enough to emit electrons, so no current flowed back from plate to filament. Thus the Edison Effect always produced direct current.

世纪之交，弗莱明又获得了一个顾问职位，这次是在马可尼无线电报有限公司。在那个原始时代，收音机仍然是一种玩具，而不是工具，马可尼公司面临着几个问题。一个是无法将收音机调到特定频率，这一改进可以防止恶作剧者将打油诗当作重要信息发送。对严肃的无线电传输来说，一个更大的障碍是缺乏可靠的整流器。无线电发射器发出的信号以交流电的形式在天空中传播。但将这些信号转换成信息的接收仪器（例如电报键或收音机的扬声器）使用的是直流电。因此，关键需求（缺失的环节）是一种设备，它可以接收发射器发出的交流电并将其转换或整流为直流电，以响应原始信号的脉动。

At the turn of the century Fleming landed another consulting position, this time with Marconi’s Wireless Telegraph Company, Ltd. Radio in this primordial era was still as much a toy as a tool, and there were several problems facing the Marconi firm. One was the inability to tune the radios to a specific frequency, an improvement that could have prevented pranksters from sending limericks in place of important messages. A more significant obstacle to serious radio transmission was the absence of a reliable rectifier. A radio transmitter beams out signals that travel through the sky in the form of alternating current. But the receiving instruments that turn those signals into information—a telegraph key, for example, or a radio’s speaker—operate on direct current. The crucial need, then—the missing link—was a device that could take the alternating current sent by the transmitter and convert, or rectify, it to a direct current that echoed the pulsations in the original signal.

如今被称为半导体的材料具有这种整流特性，而第一台收音机采用半导体晶体来整流信号。这种收音机后来被称为晶体收音机。由于没有人对半导体技术了解太多，晶体收音机似乎只在他们选择的时候才工作，而且对于商业用途来说太反复无常了。如果收音机要对世界产生任何重大影响，就必须有人找到一种可靠的方法将交流无线电信号转换为直流电。这是马可尼交给 JA 弗莱明的任务。

The materials known today as semiconductors have this rectifying quality, and the first radios employed a semiconductor crystal to rectify the signal. Such radios came to be known as crystal sets. Since nobody knew much about semiconductor technology, crystal sets seemed to work only when they chose to, and were too capricious for business use. If radio was to have any serious impact on the world, someone would have to find a dependable way to convert the alternating radio signal into direct current. This was the task Marconi assigned to J. A. Fleming.

弗莱明最初试图从标准晶体中获得可靠的整流作用。然而，1904 年 10 月，他意识到这种方法不会有成效，并开始认真思考其他可以将交流电转换为直流电的设备。什么机制总是产生直流电？突然，他回想起了 20 年前的实验。弗莱明自己描述了发现的时刻：

Fleming initially tried to get reliable rectifying action out of the standard crystal. In October 1904, however, he realized that this approach would not be fruitful and began thinking hard about other devices that could convert an alternating current to direct current. What mechanism always produced direct current? Suddenly, he recalled his experiments of twenty years before. Fleming himself described the moment of discovery:

当我正在思考这个问题的困难时，我的思绪又回到了与爱迪生效应有关的实验。

I was pondering on the difficulties of the problem when my thoughts recurred to my experiments in connection with the Edison Effect.

“为什么不试试灯呢？”我想。

“Why not try the lamps?” I thought.

我走到一个柜子前，拿出一些我以前研究时用过的灯……我开始在主电路中振荡。令我高兴的是，我看到检流计的指针指示出稳定的直流电……我们在这种特殊的电灯中找到了整流高频无线电流的问题的解决方案。无线电中缺失的环节找到了——它就是一盏电灯。

I went to a cabinet and brought out some lamps I had used in my previous investigations. . . . I started the oscillations in the primary circuit. To my delight I saw the needle of the galvanometer indicate a steady direct current. . . . We had in this particular kind of electric lamp a solution to the problem of rectifying high frequency wireless currents. The missing link in wireless was found—and it was an electric lamp.

除了用于无线电之外，弗莱明还指出了另一个重要特性：从灯丝流向极板的电流可以比任何机械开关更快地关闭和打开。“这些小电子非常灵活，”弗莱明写道，“无论我们多么快速地改变电气化……极板电流都会相应地改变，甚至以每秒一百万次的速度改变。”由于这种像水龙头一样打开和关闭电流的能力，弗莱明将改进后的灯泡称为“阀门”。在技术文献中，弗莱明的整流灯被称为二极管，因为它有两个电极——灯丝和极板。

In addition to its usefulness for radio, Fleming noted another important characteristic: the current flowing from filament to plate could switch off and on far more rapidly than any mechanical switch. “So nimble are these little electrons,” Fleming wrote, “that however rapidly we change the electrification . . . the plate current is correspondingly altered, even at the rate of a million times per second.” Because of this capacity to turn current on and off like a faucet, Fleming called the modified light bulb a “valve.” In the technical literature, Fleming’s rectifying lamp is called a diode, because it has two electrodes—the filament and the plate.

弗莱明二极管使可靠的无线电接收器的生产成为可能。但在无线电成为一种实用的远距离信息传送工具之前，还有另一个问题需要解决。无线电波在传播过程中会衰减；信号传播得越远，就越弱。信号传播 30 英里左右后，就太弱了，无法驱动任何类型的麦克风；稍长一点的距离就会使电流减弱，几乎无法移动电报键。接收器中需要一种设备，可以加强或放大传入信号，而不会扭曲其脉动和调制模式。弗莱明发明无线电接收器两年后，在李·德福雷斯特 (Lee De Forest) 杂乱无章的纽约办公室里，这个需求得到了满足。

The Fleming diode made possible the production of dependable radio receivers. But there was still another problem to be resolved before radio became a practical instrument for sending information over any appreciable distance. Radio beams attenuate as they travel; the farther a signal has to go, the weaker it gets. After a signal had traveled 30 miles or so it was too weak to drive any kind of microphone; a slightly longer distance so diminished the current that it could barely move a telegraph key. What was needed was a device in the receiver that could strengthen, or amplify, the incoming signal without distorting its pattern of pulsation and modulation. The need was met, two years after Fleming’s invention, in the cluttered New York office of Lee De Forest.

德·福雷斯特的父亲是公理会牧师，内战结束后不久，他从中西部搬到了阿拉巴马州的塔拉迪加，在那里经营一所黑人学院。年轻的李身为北方人却与黑人生活在一起，在塔拉迪加几乎没有白人朋友，童年时期一直在阅读科学书籍。他确实成为了一名科学家，在撰写了可能是美国第一篇关于无线电波的论文后，他在耶鲁大学获得了博士学位。不过，他身上的爱迪生特质比汤姆逊多得多。德·福雷斯特是一位不知疲倦的自我推销者，他一生都在狂热地工作，以获得他认为应得的财富和名望。这往往是一场艰苦的战斗。德·福雷斯特在专利诉讼中投入了巨额资金，但结果却不尽如人意。 1912 年至 1913 年，在他职业生涯的巅峰时期，他花了两年时间，为联邦邮件欺诈指控辩护，该指控源于他在一封写给潜在投资者的信中预测，人类的声音有一天会传遍大西洋彼岸。检察官宣称，没有人会相信这种“荒谬且故意误导的言论”。陪审团相信了，德·福雷斯特被判无罪。

De Forest was the son of a Congregationalist minister who moved, shortly after the Civil War, from the Midwest to Talladega, Alabama, to run the Negro college there. Stuck with this double whammy—a Yankee who lived with the Negroes—young Lee had few friends among his fellow whites in Talladega and spent his childhood reading science. He did indeed become a scientist; he took a Ph.D. at Yale after writing what was probably the first American dissertation on radio waves. Still, there was considerably more of Edison in him than of Thomson. A tireless self-promoter, De Forest worked feverishly all his life to attain the wealth and fame he felt he deserved. It was often an uphill battle. De Forest spent huge sums, with indifferent results, in legal battles over patents. He spent two years at the height of his career, 1912–13, fighting a federal mail fraud indictment resulting from his prediction, in a letter to potential investors, that the human voice would someday be broadcast across the Atlantic. No one could possibly believe such “absurd and deliberately misleading statements,” the prosecutor declared. The jury did, and De Forest was acquitted.

德·福雷斯特不是胆小鬼，他对自己的科学成就毫不妥协。当被要求在富兰克林研究所讨论他的无线电放大器时，这位发明家向在场的工程师们保证，“工程史上从未有过如此革命性的一步。”德·福雷斯特将他的自传命名为《无线电之父》，这一不谦虚的举动促使艾萨克·阿西莫夫指出，“很少有发明有这么多的创始人。”就在他 85 岁接受精细的癌症手术之前，德·福雷斯特无意中听到医生说可以通过电干燥术切除肿瘤。“俗称热线，”德·福雷斯特在手术台上嘶哑地说。“我在 1907 年发明了它。”

Not a shrinking violet, De Forest yielded to none in his esteem for his own scientific accomplishments. Asked to discuss his radio amplifier before the Franklin Institute, the inventor assured the assembled engineers that “a more revolutionary step was never taken in the history of engineering.” De Forest titled his autobiography Father of Radio, an immodesty that prompted Isaac Asimov to note that “few inventions have had so many fathers.” Just before he underwent delicate cancer surgery at the age of eighty-five, De Forest overheard the doctors saying the tumor would be removed by electrodesiccation. “Commonly known as the hot wire,” De Forest croaked from the operating table. “I invented it in 1907.”

德·福雷斯特最重要的发明是无线电放大器，它基于电学的一个基本原理：同性电荷排斥，异性电荷相吸。带负电荷的物体会被正电荷吸引，就像回形针会被磁铁吸引一样。在暴雨中，当云和地面产生相反的电荷时，吸引力足以将电子闪电拉过间隙。这个原理也解释了狗仔队最喜欢的现象——静电吸附。当这位小明星从豪华轿车中出来时，她裙子的下摆从她的尼龙长袜上擦掉了一些电子。由于这些多余的电子，裙子带上了负电荷，而长袜则带上了正电荷。负电荷的下摆会粘在正电荷的长袜上——如果摄影师运气好的话，大约在大腿中部——当她离开汽车时，一千个闪光灯会闪烁。

De Forest’s most important invention, the radio amplifier, was based on a fundamental principle of electricity: unlike charges attract, and like charges repel. An object carrying a negative charge is attracted toward a positive charge just as a paper clip is pulled toward a magnet. In a rainstorm, when clouds and earth develop opposite charges, the attraction is strong enough to pull a lightning bolt of electrons across the gap. This principle also explains the paparazzi’s favorite phenomenon, static cling. As the starlet scoots over to get out of the limousine, the hem of her dress rubs some electrons off her nylon stockings. With these excess electrons, the dress acquires a negative charge; the stockings become positive. Negative hem clings to positive stocking—at about mid-thigh, if the photographers are lucky—and a thousand flashbulbs pop as she leaves the car.

1906 年，德·福雷斯特在对一些早期整流管进行修补时，在灯丝和金属板之间放置了一个金属丝网。通常，这不会影响爱迪生效应电流，因为电子会直接穿过开口的金属丝网流向金属板。但是，当德·福雷斯特在金属丝网上放置负电荷时，同性电荷会相互排斥：负金属丝网会排斥带负电荷的电子，流向金属板的电流会急剧减少。当他向金属丝网上放置正电荷时，异性电荷会相互吸引：金属丝网会吸引电子，流向金属板的电流会增加。

Tinkering with some early rectifying tubes in 1906, De Forest put a wire screen between the filament and the metal plate. Normally, this did not affect the Edison Effect current because electrons flowed right through the open screen to the plate. But when De Forest put a negative charge on the wire screen, like charges repelled: the negative screen repelled the negatively charged electrons, and current flowing to the plate was sharply reduced. When he sent a positive charge to the screen, unlike charges attracted: the screen attracted electrons, and the current to the plate was increased.

实验表明，金属屏上电荷的微小变化会导致流向金属板的电流发生巨大变化。更重要的是，爱迪生效应电流的变化完全模仿了发送到金属屏的电流的变化。因此，这是一个精确的放大机制。如果来自远距离无线电信号的弱电流被发送到金属屏，它会形成一个更强的电流，与无线电波的波动精确匹配。这种更强的电流可以驱动电报键或扬声器。德福雷斯特将金属屏称为“网格”，并申请了一项名为“放大微弱电流的装置”的专利。

Experiments showed that a small change in the charge on the metal screen caused a big change in the current flowing to the metal plate. More important, the variations in the Edison Effect current exactly mimicked variations in the current sent to the wire screen. Here, then, was a precise amplifying mechanism. If the weak current from a distant radio signal was sent to the wire screen, it shaped a much stronger current that precisely matched the fluctuations of the radio beam. This stronger current could drive a telegraph key or loudspeaker. De Forest called the metal screen a “grid” and filed a patent entitled “Device for Amplifying Feeble Electrical Currents.”

由于德福雷斯特管有三个电极（灯丝、金属板和栅极），因此它在技术上被称为三极管。三极管放大器使无线电成为日常生活中实用的现实。随着进一步的发展（无线电公司最终开发出四极管和五极管），无线电性能得到了极大提高。到 1930 年，无线电已风靡全球（德福雷斯特关于跨大西洋广播的荒谬预言在 1915 年成为现实）。到 40 年代中期，工程师们已经学会了如何使用无线电信号在玻璃管上绘制图像；结果就出现了一种最初被称为图像显示仪、但今天被称为电视的设备。计算机先驱利用电子管的快速切换功能制造了第一代数字计算机。

Since the De Forest tube had three electrodes—the filament, the metal plate, and the grid—it was technically known as a triode. The triode amplifier made radio a practical everyday reality. With further advances—radio companies eventually developed tetrode and pentode tubes—performance was greatly enhanced. By 1930, radio had swept the world (De Forest’s absurd prediction of transatlantic broadcasting came true in 1915). By the mid-forties, engineers had learned how to use radio signals to draw a picture on a glass tube; the result was a device known at first as an iconoscope but today as television. Computer pioneers took advantage of the tube’s rapid switching in building the first generation of digital computers.

真空管本质上只是一个加强版的灯泡，它能够执行整流、放大和快速开关这三种基本功能，是新电子世界的中心。如果将电子技术的发展视为一场技术竞争，真空管已经战胜了晶体收音机等半导体设备，并将其远远甩在身后。但这场战斗尚未结束。

With the capacity to perform three essential functions—rectification, amplification, and rapid switching—the vacuum tube, at heart just a souped-up light bulb, was the hub of a new electronic world. If the development of electronics were viewed as a battle of competing technologies, vacuum tubes had overcome semiconductor devices, like the crystal set, and left them far behind. But this battle was not yet over.

半导体的复兴始于 20 世纪 30 年代末，当时英吉利海峡两岸都担心战争即将爆发。英德两国科学家意识到即将到来的冲突将在很大程度上取决于空中力量，于是竞相开发一种使用无线电技术的预警系统，以发现正在接近的敌机。对于盟军来说幸运的是，英国人首先完善了这一概念。由于他们的系统不仅可以发现飞机，还可以测量飞机与英国之间的距离或射程，英国人将这项发明命名为“无线电探测和测距”。这个名字很快就被缩写为“雷达”。

The renaissance of the semiconductor began in the late 1930s, spurred by growing fear on both sides of the English Channel that war was imminent. Recognizing that the coming conflict would depend largely on airpower, scientists in England and Germany raced to develop an early warning system, using radio techniques, to spot approaching enemy planes. Fortunately for the Allies, the British perfected the concept first. Since their system could not only find planes but also gauge their distance, or range, from England, the British called the invention Radio Detection and Ranging. This name was quickly shortened to the acronym “radar.”

雷达站向空中发射无线电波。只要不碰到任何东西，波束就会以光速直线移动（不列颠之战期间发射的一些雷达波束可能今天仍在太空中移动，距离地球约 61 光年）。但如果信号在半空中击中一块金属（例如德国空军轰炸机），波束就会像网球撞到墙上一样反弹回雷达站。通过标记返回波束的来源并测量其往返时间，英国守军可以告诉他们的战斗机在哪里拦截敌人。

A radar station shot a radio beam into the air. As long as it didn’t run into anything, the beam kept moving in a straight line at the speed of light (some radar beams sent off during the Battle of Britain are presumably still moving out through space today, about 61 light-years from earth). But if the signal hit a piece of metal—say, a Luftwaffe bomber—in midair, the beam would bounce back to the radar station like a tennis ball bouncing off a wall. By marking where the returning beam came from, and measuring how long its round trip had taken, the British defenders could tell their fighters where to intercept the enemy.

起初，英国人希望使用标准无线电设备来发送和接收雷达波束。但这一方法没有奏效，因为真空管整流器无法处理雷达所需的高频信号。工程师们急需其他整流设备，于是他们回顾历史，重新启用了晶体收音机。晶体整流器已经存在了几十年，但由于性能始终不稳定，因此从未发挥过重要作用。然而，到了 20 世纪 30 年代末，人们对这些晶体收音机中的晶体（即半导体元素）有了更多的了解。雷达工程师们利用这一新知识基础，制造出了可靠的晶体接收器。

At first the British had hoped to use standard radio equipment to transmit and receive the radar beams. This didn’t work, because vacuum tube rectifiers could not handle the high-frequency signals required for radar. Desperate for some other rectifying apparatus, the engineers went backward in history and resurrected the crystal set. Crystal rectifiers had been around for decades, but they had never been significant because their performance was always iffy. By the late 1930s, however, much more was known about the crystals in these crystal sets—the elements known as semiconductors. The radar engineers, working from this new base of knowledge, were able to build reliable crystal receivers.

对半导体的深入了解是随机的，几乎是无计划的。与真空管技术的发展不同，真空管技术中每一位新研究人员和每一项新发现似乎都整齐地引领着下一个发现，而科学界对半导体的了解则来自一系列脱节的实验和假设。柏林出版的专著、剑桥的一项有趣实验、巴黎的建议、哥本哈根的反理论——所有这些工作在 20 世纪 30 年代逐渐成为焦点。最终，两条科学工作路线（一条是实验路线，一条是理论路线）合并为半导体物理学的单一理论。

The deeper understanding of semiconductors had come about in a random, almost haphazard, manner. Unlike the development of vacuum tube technology, in which each new researcher and each new discovery seemed to lead neatly ahead to the next, the scientific world’s knowledge of semiconductors grew out of a disjointed series of experiments and hypotheses. A monograph published in Berlin, an interesting experiment in Cambridge, a suggestion from Paris, a countertheory from Copenhagen—all this work gradually came into focus in the 1930s. Eventually, two lines of scientific work, one experimental and one theoretical, merged into a single theory of semiconductor physics.

实验贡献源于商业根源。随着电力成为一种重要的商业商品，销售和使用电力的公司必须知道最有效的传输方式。如果一家公司要铺设一条输电线，那么应该用铜还是棉线铺设？为了回答这个问题，人们进行了实验来测量无数不同材料的电导率。电导率（即电流流过给定材料的难易程度）是物理学家的概念；它与电气工程师的电阻概念相反。电工的电阻单位称为欧姆。因此，一些具有讽刺意味的物理学家决定将电导率的单位称为“姆欧”。

The experimental contribution sprang from commercial roots. As electrical power became a commercially important commodity, the firms that sold and used electricity had to know the most efficient way to transmit it. If a company had to build a power line, should the line be made of copper or cotton? To answer that, experiments were run to measure the conductivity of countless different materials. Conductivity—that is, how easy it is for an electric current to flow through a given material—is a physicist’s concept; it is the opposite of the electrical engineer’s concept of resistance. The electrician’s unit of resistance is called the ohm. Some physicist with a wry humor accordingly decided that the unit of conductivity should be called the “mho.”

在确定数百种材料的姆欧等级的实验中，出现了某些模式。在某些物质中，特别是银、金和铜等金属，电流可以轻松流动。这些材料被称为导体。其他物质——石英、玻璃、橡胶和木材就是突出的例子——阻碍电流流动。它们被称为绝缘体。在这两个极端之间，有一类材料的导电性比绝缘体好，但不如导体。这些半良导体——如硒、锗和硅等元素——被统称为“半导体”。然而，仍然缺乏对为什么某些材料比其他材料更能成为更好的导体的解释。为什么电子如此容易地穿过铜，却如此不情愿地穿过玻璃？硅的什么特性使它介于两者之间？量子力学理论家给出了这个问题的答案，尤其是一位安静、恭敬的丹麦人尼尔斯·亨利克·戴维·玻尔，他研究出了原子的基本结构。

In experiments to determine mho ratings for hundreds of materials, certain patterns emerged. In some substances, particularly metals like silver, gold, and copper, current could flow easily. These materials were labeled conductors. Other substances—quartz, glass, rubber, and wood are prominent examples—blocked current flow. They were called insulators. Between these two extremes was a class of materials that conduct better than insulators but not as well as conductors. These semi-good conductors—elements like selenium, germanium, and silicon—were given the generic label “semiconductors.” Still lacking, though, was an explanation of why some materials made better conductors than others. Why did electrons travel so readily through copper but so reluctantly through glass? And what was it about silicon that made it fall in between? The answer to that question was provided by the theorists of quantum mechanics, particularly by a quiet, deferential Dane, Niels Henrik David Bohr, who worked out the basic architecture of the atom.

尼尔斯·玻尔是二十世纪最伟大的人物之一——他不仅是最有才智的人之一，而且是最慷慨和最仁慈的人之一：“利他主义的化身”，他的朋友 C.P. 斯诺写道。他 1885 年出生于哥本哈根，父母都是杰出的院士，在知识分子氛围浓厚的环境中长大。他的家人广泛阅读了四种语言，并且对音乐和艺术情有独钟。尼尔斯还是一名足球高手，尽管他没有入选丹麦奥林匹克队（他的兄弟在 1908 年入选）。然而，几年后，当玻尔成为物理学家中的佼佼者并在英国工作时，丹麦确实向他发出了邀请。为了吸引玻尔回国，丹麦人在哥本哈根建立了理论物理研究所；就像丹麦几乎总是做的那样，资金来自嘉士伯啤酒厂。在玻尔的领导下，该研究所一度成为量子物理学的世界之都。

Niels Bohr was one of the great people of the twentieth century—not only one of the most powerful intellects but also one of the most generous and humane of men: “the incarnation of altruism,” his friend C. P. Snow wrote. Born in Copenhagen in 1885, the son and grandson of distinguished academicians, he grew up in highly intellectual surroundings. The family read widely in four languages and was steeped in music and the arts. Niels was also a soccer ace, although he was not picked for the Danish Olympic team (his brother snared a spot in 1908). Denmark did come beckoning a few years later, however, when Bohr had emerged in the top ranks of physicists and was working in England. To lure Bohr home, the Danes established an Institute of Theoretical Physics in Copenhagen; as it almost always does in Denmark, the money came from the Carlsberg Brewery. Under Bohr’s direction the institute became, for a while, the world capital of quantum physics.

“他不像爱因斯坦那样对人类冷漠无情，”CP·斯诺在玻尔 1962 年去世后写道。“他只是单纯而真诚地善良。这听起来平淡无奇，但除了智慧之外，他还非常亲切。”他的无私天性在二战期间熠熠生辉。他捐赠了一件无价之宝——他的金质诺贝尔奖奖章——将其熔化，所得款项将用于芬兰战争救济。他冒着巨大的职业和个人危险，直言不讳地反对纳粹，并秘密帮助犹太科学家逃离第三帝国。当他得知他最聪明的前学生维尔纳·海森堡被任命负责德国研制原子弹的研究计划时，玻尔从德国召集了这位年轻的物理学家，告诉他，任何科学家把这种武器交给希特勒都是错误的，在道德上是错误的。 （不管是不是因为玻尔的那番教训，海森堡在纳粹核计划上取得的进展最多也只是很小的进步。）最后，他被迫带着儿子奥格（他和海森堡是同辈，后来也获得了诺贝尔奖）乘一艘小渔船逃离祖国，然后玻尔修建了一条地下铁路，帮助犹太人逃离丹麦。战后，他开始不懈地反对进一步部署核武器。

“He was not, as Einstein was, impersonally kind to the human race,” C. P. Snow wrote after Bohr’s death in 1962. “He was simply and genuinely kind. It sounds insipid, but in addition to wisdom he had much sweetness.” His selfless nature shone through radiantly during World War II. He donated a priceless possession—his gold Nobel Prize medal—to be melted down so that the proceeds could go to Finnish war relief. At considerable professional and personal danger, he spoke out forthrightly against the Nazis and worked secretly to help Jewish scientists escape the Third Reich. When he learned that his most brilliant former student, Werner Heisenberg, had been put in charge of Germany’s research program to develop an atomic bomb, Bohr summoned the younger physicist from Germany and told him that it would be wrong, morally wrong, for any scientist to give Hitler this weapon. (Whether or not that lecture from Bohr was the reason, Heisenberg made minimal progress at best on the Nazi nuclear program.) Finally forced to flee his homeland in a small fishing boat with his son Aage (a chip off the block who was to win a Nobel Prize of his own), Bohr then set up an underground railway to spirit Jews out of Denmark. After the war, he began a tireless campaign against further deployment of nuclear weapons.

在其科学生涯的中期，玻尔做出了一次令人着迷的思想转变。年轻时，他坚信周围的世界有逻辑秩序，自然现象可以用严密的逻辑和理性来解释。他脱离了教会，因为他觉得教会的教义在逻辑上站不住脚。但后来，当他发现世界上有些地方显然不受逻辑支配时，他接受了一幅略显混乱的图景。到 20 世纪 20 年代中期，他提出了“互补原理”，认为物理学足够大，可以容纳一些看似不合逻辑和矛盾的东西。晚年，他设计了一个个人徽章，上面有阴阳符号和座右铭“ Contraria sunt complementa”。

Midway through his scientific career, Bohr made a fascinating intellectual conversion. As a young man, he was convinced that the world around him had a logical order, that natural phenomena could be explained with rigorous logic and reason. He fell away from the church because of his feeling that its doctrines were logically untenable. Later, though, as he discovered parts of the world where logic evidently did not govern, he accepted a somewhat muddier picture. By the mid-1920s, he had developed a “Principle of Complementarity,” which held that physics was large enough to contain some seeming illogic and contradictions. Late in life he designed a personal coat of arms that carried the yin/yang symbol and the motto Contraria sunt complementa.

1911 年，玻尔在哥本哈根获得博士学位，论文主题是当时尚属新概念的电子。随后，他前往剑桥大学，师从 JJ 汤姆森。在那里，他熟悉了汤姆森的原子结构概念，该理论被称为“葡萄干蛋糕原子”，因为它假设了一种海绵蛋糕，电子像葡萄干一样散落​​在各处。接下来，玻尔前往曼彻斯特，与另一位伟大的物理学家欧内斯特·卢瑟福一起工作；在那里，他了解了卢瑟福的“核原子”，该理论假设一个小原子核位于无定形电子云内。然后，在 1913 年，玻尔提出了自己的原子图景，这一假设自此一直盛行，并不断得到改进。

Bohr took his Ph.D. at Copenhagen in 1911, writing his dissertation on the still new concept of the electron, and then headed off to Cambridge to study under J. J. Thomson himself. There he became familiar with Thomson’s conception of the structure of the atom—a theory known as the “raisin cake atom” because it posited a sort of sponge cake with electrons scattered about here and there like raisins. Next Bohr went to Manchester to work with another great physicist, Ernest Rutherford; there he learned of Rutherford’s “nuclear atom,” which posited a small nucleus set inside an amorphous cloud of electrons. Then, in 1913, Bohr set down his own picture of the atom—a hypothesis that has prevailed, with regular refinements, ever since.

“玻尔原子”是当今大多数成年人在高中科学课本上看到的原子：即“太阳系”模型，电子围绕中心原子核在同心轨道上旋转。“在这幅图中，”玻尔在 1922 年的诺贝尔奖演讲中解释道，“我们看到了与行星系统惊人的相似之处，就像我们的太阳系一样。”然而，玻尔图的关键点在于他坚持认为电子不能在任何一个旧位置运行。利用量子力学和一些令人难以置信的数学，玻尔精确地确定了每个轨道应该离原子核多远，以及每个轨道上可以驻留多少个电子。

The “Bohr atom” is the atom that most adults today saw in their high school science books: the “solar system” model, with electrons swirling in concentric orbits around a central nucleus. “In this picture,” Bohr explained in his Nobel Prize address in 1922, “we see a striking resemblance to a planetary system, such as we have in our solar system.” The key point of the Bohr picture, though, was his insistence that electrons could not orbit in just any old spot. Using quantum mechanics and some mind-boggling mathematics, Bohr determined precisely how far from the nucleus each orbit should be, and how many electrons can reside in each orbit.

根据这些规则，距离原子核最远的轨道可以有 1 到 8 个电子。每种元素的电特性由最外层轨道决定——具体来说，由外层轨道中的电子数量决定。如果原子的最远轨道上只有一个电子，那么这个电子就不会与原子核紧密结合；它很容易脱离。但是如果原子的外层轨道上满是电子（8 个电子），电子就会被紧紧地固定在原位。

Under these rules, the orbit that is farthest from the nucleus can have from one to eight electrons. The electrical characteristics of each element are determined by this outermost orbit—specifically, by the number of electrons in the outer orbit. If an atom has only one electron in the farthest orbit, that electron will not be tightly bound to the nucleus; it could break away easily. But in an atom with a full house—eight electrons—in the outer orbit, the electrons will be held tightly in place.

根据这一原子理论，量子物理学家可以预测哪些材料是良好的电流导体。容易释放电子的物质会提供组成电流的自由流动电子；这样的物质应该是良好的导体。在不释放自由电子的材料中，电流不会流动；它将是绝缘体。因此，从理论上讲，任何材料的导电性都由其最外层环中的电子数量决定。

Working from this theory of the atom, quantum physicists could predict which materials would be good conductors of electric current. A substance that easily released electrons would supply the free-flowing electrons that make up electric current; such a substance should be a good conductor. In a material that did not release free electrons, current would not flow; it would be an insulator. Theoretically, then, the conductivity of any material would be determined by the number of electrons in its outermost ring.

没有人见过原子。在我们真正看到原子之前，原子结构的量子图像的某些部分在严格意义上仍将只是理论。然而，由于确定特定材料电导率的实验，可以检验电导率的量子观点。当将这些实验结果与量子理论的预测进行比较时，理论和实验完全吻合。

No one has ever seen an atom. Until we do, parts of the quantum picture of atomic structure will remain, in a strict sense, merely theory. The quantum view of conductivity, however, can be tested, because of the experiments that determined the conductivity of specific materials. When these experimental results are compared with the predictions of quantum theory, theory and experiment match perfectly.

已发现的最佳导体材料——银、铜、金——确实是最外层轨道上只有一个电子的元素。已证明的最佳绝缘体材料确实是那些有八个外层电子的材料。一般来说，外环电子数为三个或更少的元素是导体，而外环电子数为五个或以上的元素是绝缘体。半导体正位于这个连续体的正中央。半导体，如硅和锗，在最外层轨道上有四个电子。

The materials found to be the best conductors—silver, copper, gold—are indeed elements with a single electron in the outermost orbit. Materials that have proven the best insulators are indeed those with eight outer electrons. As a general matter, elements with three or fewer outer-ring electrons are conductors, and those with five or more are insulators. At the precise center of this continuum stand the semiconductors. Semiconductors, such as silicon and germanium, have four electrons in the outermost ring.

半导体材料的这一特性使得它们在电子领域如此有用。半导体处于导体和绝缘体之间的中间位置，正是由于这种介于导体和绝缘体之间的结构，它们才能发挥有价值的电子作用。

It is this special feature of semiconductor materials that makes them so spectacularly useful in electronics. Sitting on the fence, perched midway between the conductors and the insulators, semiconductors can perform valuable electronic service precisely because of their in-between structure.

由于半导体正好处于导体和绝缘体之间的边界，实验者已经找到了改变其导电性的方法。这一过程称为掺杂。其工作原理如下：在纯硅固体块中，各个原子倾向于与相邻原子连接。每个原子都有四个外环电子；它们与隔壁原子的四个最外层元素形成紧密的四角连接。当这种情况发生时，所有八个电子都被牢牢地固定在原位；没有电子可以挣脱，也没有电流流动。但人类已经学会了如何通过在硅中掺杂杂质来欺骗硅原子。他们通过引入微量具有五个外环电子的不同元素（例如砷）来实现这一点。硅原子的四个外部电子将与四个砷电子结合，留下一个额外的砷原子不受束缚，可以自由移动。由于砷掺杂，硅块现在变成了导体。如果引入更多的砷原子，就会产生更多的自由电子，从而产生更多的电流。流经硅的电流（自由电子流）与 JJ Thomson 在他的阴极射线管中看到的流经真空的电流相同。

Because semiconductors are right on the borderline between conductors and insulators, experimenters have found ways to alter their conductivity. This is done by a process called doping. Here’s how it works: In a solid block of pure silicon, the individual atoms tend to link up with their neighbors. Each atom has four outer-ring electrons; they form a tight four-corner connection with the four outermost elements of the atom next door. When that happens, all eight electrons are held tightly in place; no electrons can break free, and no current flows. But humans have learned how to fool the silicon atoms by doping the silicon with impurities. They do it by introducing tiny quantities of a different element—arsenic, for example—that has five outer-ring electrons. The four outside electrons of a silicon atom will bind themselves to four of the arsenic electrons, leaving one extra arsenic atom unbound, free to move. Thanks to the arsenic doping, the block of silicon is now a conductor. If more arsenic atoms are introduced, more free electrons result and more current will flow. The current moving through the silicon—a flow of free electrons—is the same current that J. J. Thomson saw moving through the vacuum in his cathode ray tube.

但是，如果硅中掺杂了某种元素（例如硼），而这种元素的最外层环上只有三个电子，情况会怎样呢？当硅原子试图与硼连接时，排列会少一个电子，从而在第八个电子应该在的位置留下一个空位，即空洞。附近的电子将被拉过来填补这个空洞；这样就会在电子来自的地方留下另一个空洞。另一个电子会移过来填补这个新空洞，在原处留下另一个空洞。结果实际上是硅块上的空洞移动。

But what if the silicon is doped with an element—boron, for example—that has only three electrons in its outermost ring? When silicon atoms try to link up with boron, the arrangement comes up one electron short, leaving a vacant spot—an empty hole—where the eighth electron should be. A nearby electron will be pulled over to fill the hole; this leaves another hole where the electron came from. Another electron moves in to fill this new hole, leaving another hole in its place. The result, effectively, is a movement of holes across the silicon block.

威廉·B·肖克利 (William B. Shockley) 在其经典的半导体物理学著作中，通过将硅块比作停车场来解释这一点。在纯净、未掺杂的晶体中，停车场上的每个空间都已填满，车辆无法通行。如果一辆车被移走，留下一个空位，另一辆车就可以向前移动，从而让另一辆车进入。当然，是汽车在移动，但对于从高楼上不时往下看的观察者来说，空位似乎在停车场上移动。肖克利的书实际上写道，“空置的停车位……可以随着车辆连续进入而移动。”

In his classic text on semiconductor physics, William B. Shockley explains this by comparing a block of silicon to a parking lot. In a pure, undoped crystal, every space on the lot is filled and no traffic can flow. If one car is removed, leaving a vacant slot, another car can move ahead, leaving its place open, in turn, for another car to move into. It is the cars that move, of course, but to an observer looking down every once in a while from a high building it appears that the empty space is migrating across the lot. Effectively, Shockley’s book says, “the vacant parking place . . . can move owing to the successive motion of vehicles into it.”

掺杂过程会产生两种不同类型的硅。硅中如果接收了额外的电子，就会带负电荷，因为电子是负电荷。硅中如果布满空穴（代表缺失的电子），就会带净正电荷。

The doping process results in two different types of silicon. Where the silicon has received extra electrons, it takes on a negative charge, because electrons are negative. Where the silicon is pocked with holes—representing missing electrons—it takes on a net positive charge.

如果空穴现象是在汤姆森时代发现的，那时所有的科学家都对古典学有着深厚的了解，那么这个空缺很可能会被赋予一个希腊语或拉丁语名称，例如“vacutron”或“nihilon”或诸如此类的名字。然而，直到 20 世纪 30 年代，当古典学衰落并且英语成为物理学的通用语言时，空穴的流动才得以牢固确立。因此，带正电的空穴的正式科学名称是一个简单的英文单词：“hole”。（肖克利将他的权威著作命名为《半导体中的电子和空穴 》）。同样简单的是，物理学家决定将掺杂过量电子（因此带负电）的半导体材料称为 N 型半导体。掺杂正电荷（空穴）的半导体块称为 P 型。

If the phenomenon of holes had been discovered in Thomson’s day, when all men of science had a firm grounding in the classics, the vacant spot would most likely have been given a Greek or Latin name, a name like “vacutron” or “nihilon” or some such. The flow of holes was not firmly established, though, until the 1930s, when the classics were in decline and English had become the lingua franca of physics. Consequently, the formal scientific name for the positively charged hole is a simple English word: “hole.” (Shockley titled his definitive text Electrons and Holes in Semiconductors. ) With equivalent simplicity, physicists decided to refer to semiconductor material that had been doped with excess electrons—and is thus negatively charged—as an N-type semiconductor. A semiconductor block doped with positive charge—holes—is called P-type.

到 20 世纪 30 年代末，当所有这些错综复杂的问题都得到解决后，物理学家们对半导体内部的情况有了相当清晰的认识。要将这些知识付诸实践——引发半导体革命——就只剩下人类的智慧了。这一基本要素来自一个由三名美国人组成的团队，该团队的负责人是一位有趣的人物，他曾在不同时期成为现代科学家中最受人尊敬和最受人唾弃的人物之一，他就是威廉·肖克利 (William B. Shockley)。

By the late 1930s, when all these intricacies had been worked out, physicists had a reasonably decent picture of what goes on inside a semiconductor. All that remained to put this knowledge to practical use—to launch the semiconductor revolution—was human ingenuity. This essential ingredient was to come from a team of three Americans headed by an intriguing figure who has been, in different seasons, one of the most respected and most reviled of all modern scientists, William B. Shockley.

肖克利是一对技术型夫妇的独生子，父亲是采矿工程师，母亲是地质学家。肖克利 1910 年出生于伦敦，父亲当时驻扎在那里。他在现在的硅谷北部边缘长大。从加州理工学院毕业后，他在麻省理工学院攻读研究生，研究电子在固体材料中的运动。1936 年，这位刚从学校毕业的年轻博士进入贝尔实验室工作。管理层忽视了他的研究生工作，将他调到真空管部门；肖克利凭借着不懈的坚持，最终进入了半导体实验室。

Shockley was the only child of a technology-oriented couple; his father was a mining engineer, his mother a geologist. Born in London, where his father was stationed, in 1910, he grew up at the northern edge of what is now Silicon Valley. After graduating from Cal Tech he did graduate work at MIT, focusing on the movement of electrons in solid materials. Fresh out of school, the young Ph.D. went to work for Bell Labs in 1936. Management, ignoring his graduate work, shunted him off to the vacuum tube department; by sheer persistence, Shockley eventually worked his way into the semiconductor laboratory.

那是一个丰富而激动人心的时代：半导体物理学刚刚起步，该领域聪明而雄心勃勃的年轻人都认为他们正在见证奇迹的曙光。在这些新潮流的冲击下，肖克利有一天有了一个惊人的想法——一个值得获得诺贝尔奖的想法。那是 1939 年 12 月 29 日，他立即在实验室笔记本上写下了这个想法：“今天我突然想到，使用半导体而不是真空的放大器在原则上是可行的。”十年之内，他将这一原理以晶体管的形式付诸实践，这项发明让肖克利和他的同事沃尔特·布拉顿和约翰·巴丁于 1956 年获得了诺贝尔奖。此后，随着人造卫星的发射，科学被奉为神明，大众媒体将他塑造成了民族英雄。

It was a rich, exciting time to be there: semiconductor physics was just falling into place, and there was a sense among the bright, ambitious young men in the field that they were witnessing the dawn of marvelous things. Buffeted by these currents of the new, Shockley one day had an amazing idea—a Nobel Prize–worthy idea, as it turned out. It was December 29, 1939, and he wrote it down right away in his lab notebook: “It has today occurred to me that an amplifier using semiconductors rather than vacuum is in principle possible.” Within a decade, he had turned that principle into practice in the form of the transistor, an invention that won Shockley and his colleagues, Walter Brattain and John Bardeen, the Nobel Prize in 1956. Thereafter, with the apotheosis of science that followed Sputnik, the mass media made him into a national hero.

除了理论物理学方面的工作外，肖克利还参与了工程（他获得了 90 多项专利）、教学和战略规划（他在二战期间设计了潜艇攻击方法）。他在这些不同知识学科方面的经验促使他对思考进行了大量思考——思考导致好想法的动机和思维过程。他解决任何问题的基本规则都是回归基本原理：“尝试最简单的情况。”

In addition to his work in theoretical physics, Shockley was involved in engineering (he earned more than ninety patents), teaching, and strategic planning (he devised submarine attack methodologies during World War II). His experience in these varied intellectual disciplines prompted him to do a great deal of thinking about thinking—about the motivations and the thought processes that lead to good ideas. His basic rule for solving any problem was to go back to fundamentals: “Try simplest cases.”

肖克利教导说，理解最有可能来自于将情况简化为最简单的元素，然后从那里开始。他那本关于半导体的著名著作遵循了这种模式：在第 1 章中，他将原子结构与停车场进行了比较，并附上了停车场内汽车的小草图以展示交通流量。在第 15 章中，他解释说“空穴波包的波函数 A (φ) 不是价带中 2N-1 个电子的哈密顿量的本征函数。”

Understanding is most likely to result, Shockley taught, from reducing the situation to its simplest elements and proceeding from there. His famous book on semiconductors follows the pattern: In Chapter 1 he sets forth the comparison of atomic structures to parking lots, complete with little sketches of cars in a lot to demonstrate traffic flow. By Chapter 15 he is explaining that “the wave function A (φ) for the hole-wave packet is not an eigenfunction for the Hamiltonian for the 2N-1 electrons in the valence band.”

肖克利认为，对于严肃的思想家来说，动机至少与方法同样重要，他的科学论文中充斥着关于这个评论或那个实验在激励他进行新发现方面所起的作用的旁白。他始终认为，关键的动机问题——事实上，这是任何领域取得成功的基本要素——是“思考的意愿”。这是他在 1940 年从核物理学家恩里科·费米那里学到的一句话，他永远不会忘记。肖克利后来写道：“在这四个词中，[费米] 提炼出了一个非常重要的见解的精髓：一个有能力的思想家不愿意投入繁琐而精确的思考所要求的努力——他将缺乏‘思考的意愿’——除非他确信他的努力成果会做一些有价值的事情。”肖克利说，无论是在获奖实验中，还是在大一物理突击测验中，有效思考的训练在一生中都很重要。在斯坦福大学，他多年来一直教授一门名为“科学思考的思维工具”的新生研讨课。基本内容是教授自己的文章“思考思考可以改善思考”。

Motivation is at least as important as method for the serious thinker, Shockley believed, and his scientific papers are replete with asides about the role of this comment or that experiment in spurring him on to new discoveries. And he always maintained that the crucial motivational issue—in fact, the essential element for successful work in any field—was “the will to think.” This was a phrase he learned from the nuclear physicist Enrico Fermi in 1940, and never forgot. “In these four words,” Shockley wrote later, “[Fermi] distilled the essence of a very significant insight: A competent thinker will be reluctant to commit himself to the effort that tedious and precise thinking demands—he will lack ‘the will to think’—unless he has the conviction that something worthwhile will be done with the results of his efforts.” The discipline of competent thinking is important throughout life, Shockley says, whether on a prize-winning experiment or a pop quiz in freshman physics. For many years at Stanford he taught a freshman seminar called “Mental Tools for Scientific Thinking.” The basic text was the professor’s own essay, “THINKING about THINKING improves THINKING.”

所有这些关于思考的思考，都让肖克利陷入了一场激烈的种族和政治争论。这场争论最初是在 20 世纪 60 年代末期引发的，直到今天，虽然强度有所降低。或许是因为他知道自己发现了本世纪最重要的科学思想之一，因此产生了自信；或许是因为他有某种政治倾向。但无论出于什么原因，这位伟大的物理学家都认为自己也是人类智力领域的专家。在写给美国国家科学院的一封信中，以及随后的一系列演讲和采访中，肖克利敦促详细研究他称之为“劣生学”的问题，并称其为“通过基因残疾的不成比例的繁殖而导致的倒退进化”。用通俗的话说，肖克利声称，黑人平均比白人笨。因此，黑人的高出生率可能导致“我们国家人类素质的下降”。肖克利说：“我的研究让我不可避免地得出这样的观点：美国黑人智力和社交能力低下的主要原因是遗传，并且是种族基因造成的。”肖克利接着提出了一项社会政策来应对这种情况：政府应该努力降低低智商人群的生育率，比如通过自愿绝育的税收减免等计划。

All this THINKING about THINKING thrust Shockley into a furious racial and political controversy that he initially provoked in the late 1960s and that continues, at lower intensity, to this day. Perhaps it was the self-confidence that came from the knowledge that he had hit on one of the most important scientific ideas of the century; perhaps it was some political inclination. For whatever reason, though, the great physicist decided that he was also an expert in the field of human intelligence. In a letter to the National Academy of Sciences, and then in a series of lectures and interviews, Shockley urged detailed study of a problem he named “dysgenics” and defined as “retrogressive evolution through the disproportionate reproduction of the genetically disabled.” In plain English, Shockley was claiming that, on the average, blacks are dumber than whites. Thus high birthrates among blacks could lead to “decline of our nation’s human quality.” “My research leads me inescapably to the opinion,” Shockley said, “that the major cause of American Negroes’ intellectual and social deficits is hereditary and is racially genetic in origin.” Shockley went on to propose a social policy to deal with this situation: government should work to reduce birthrates among low-IQ elements of the population, through programs such as tax breaks for voluntary sterilization.

这一理论是由一位没有接受过遗传学培训的物理学家提出的，并且是在美利坚合众国历史上一个相当动荡的时期提出的，它使肖克利成为美国最受鄙视和诽谤的人之一。他被谴责为伪科学家、狂热分子和法西斯分子。他的肖像在东西海岸都被焚烧，并被剥夺了在美国一些最负盛名的大学演讲的权利，包括哈佛大学、达特茅斯学院和耶鲁大学。他被允许在普林斯顿大学露面，在一个小厅（因为戒备森严而选择在这里）演讲，而数百名愤怒的示威者在外面高声抗议。回到斯坦福大学，一群配备扩音器（晶体管使便携式和非常强大的扬声器成为可能）的学生会聚集在他的办公室窗下高呼“杀掉肖克利”——这让肖克利获得了工程史上可能独一无二的体验，他亲眼目睹自己的发明被用来将对他的处死要求放大了百倍。

This theory, proposed by a physicist with no training in genetics and set forth during a fairly tumultuous period in American history, made Shockley one of the most despised and vilified men in the United States. He was denounced as a pseudoscientist, a fanatic, a fascist. He was burned in effigy on both coasts and denied the right to speak at some of the nation’s most prestigious colleges, including Harvard, Dartmouth, and Yale. He was permitted to appear at Princeton, speaking in a small hall (chosen for its tight security) while hundreds of enraged demonstrators screamed protests outside. Back at Stanford, groups of students equipped with bullhorns, the portable and immensely powerful loudspeakers made possible by the transistor, would gather under his office window to chant “Off Pig Shockley”—affording Shockley the experience, probably unique in engineering history, of watching his own invention used to provide hundredfold amplification of demands for his death.

这位煽动者似乎很享受他所制造的轰动。在一张肖克利的课堂照片中，这位教授平静地站在一旁，双臂交叉，一副漠不关心的样子，这张照片曾被身穿三K党长袍和尖顶帽的示威者扰乱。在斯坦福大学无数次的“反对肖克利”集会中，麦克风出现故障；在场的这位发明家走上前来修好了晶体管设备，以便演讲者可以继续谴责他的想法。无论对他的攻击多么激烈，肖克利从未停止寻找新的论坛来传达他的信息；1982 年，令党内领导人失望的是，他曾短暂地寻求共和党美国参议院的提名。他的政纲呼吁对“劣生学”进行公开调查。也许整个事情最可悲的部分是，关于智力的争论成了肖克利关注的核心；他一直从思考物质世界的奥秘中获得纯粹的乐趣，但这种乐趣被他对政治的沉迷所淹没。当我催促他回忆导致他最伟大发明的思维过程时，他总是把话题引回到智力和种族问题上。1989 年他去世时，他仍然对这个问题念念不忘。

The instigator seemed to relish the stir he had created. A photograph of one of Shockley’s classes that has been disrupted by demonstrators in Ku Klux Klan robes and pointed hats shows the professor standing calmly aside, arms folded, taking in the scene with an appearance of benign unconcern. At one of the countless “Off Shockley” rallies at Stanford, the microphone went on the blink; the inventor, who was present, stepped forward and repaired the transistorized device so that the speakers could continue their denunciation of his ideas. No matter how bitter the attacks on him, Shockley never stopped seeking new forums to convey his message; in 1982, to the dismay of party leaders, he briefly pursued the Republican nomination for the U.S. Senate. His platform called for a public inquiry into “dysgenics.” Perhaps the saddest aspect of the whole thing was that the argument about intelligence became Shockley’s central concern; the sheer pleasure he had always taken in pondering the mysteries of the physical world was overwhelmed by his immersion in politics. When I pushed and pulled at him to get him to remember the thought processes that led to his greatest invention, he kept steering the conversation back to intelligence and race. He was still fixated on that issue when he died in 1989.

这场旷日持久的争论中，讽刺的一点是，肖克利虽然工作热情、意志坚定，但看起来更像是一位和蔼可亲的祖父，而不是公众眼中的恶魔。多年来与他共事的人无一例外地称他“魅力十足”；在科学会议上，他以讲笑话而闻名，甚至在发表论文时还在讲台上表演魔术。他还以能从与他共事的人身上获得最大收获而闻名。二战刚结束后，他在贝尔实验室就做到了这一点，当时他被任命负责一个研究新半导体应用的团队。

One of the ironies of this extended controversy was that Shockley, for all his intensity and determination, seemed much more a pleasant grandfatherly type than a public ogre. Those who worked with him over the years invariably described him as “charming”; at scientific meetings he was known for telling jokes and even performing magic tricks at the podium while delivering his papers. He also had a reputation for getting the most out of the people who worked with him. This he certainly did at Bell Labs when, just after World War II, he was put in charge of a team investigating new semiconductor applications.

团队中资历最深的成员沃尔特·豪瑟·布拉顿在晶体管发明时年仅 45 岁。布拉顿在华盛顿州的家庭牧场长大，后来进入惠特曼学院学习。他在俄勒冈州和明尼苏达州攻读研究生，1929 年获得博士学位后，进入新成立的研究机构贝尔实验室工作。他后来回忆说，当时“真空管和热电子学刚刚萌芽”，他首先开始研究真空管。后来，他进入著名学者 CJ 戴维森的半导体研究领域，并在 1937 年戴维森获得诺贝尔奖的消息传来的那一天在场。一大群记者蜂拥而至，实验室很快就被麦克风、新闻片摄像机和一排排的弧光灯包围了。戴维森注意到年轻助手脸上惊讶的表情，便走到布拉顿身边，低声说道：“别担心，沃尔特，总有一天你会获奖的。”

The senior member of the group, Walter Houser Brattain, was forty-five when the transistor was invented. Brattain grew up on the family ranch in Washington State and went to Whitman College. He did graduate work at Oregon and Minnesota, and upon receiving his Ph.D. in 1929 went to work for the newly organized research institution Bell Labs. It was a time, as he recalled later, when “the vacuum tube and thermionics were just shedding their baby teeth,” and he was first put to work on tubes. Later he moved into semiconductor research under the great scholar C. J. Davisson and was present on the day in 1937 when word arrived that Davisson had won the Nobel Prize. A horde of reporters swarmed onto the premises, and the lab was quickly engulfed in microphones, newsreel cameras, and banks of klieg lights. Davisson, noticing the astonishment on his young assistant’s face, stepped over to Brattain and whispered, “Don’t worry, Walter—you’ll win one some day.”

布拉顿是最谦逊的人，但他似乎对获奖感到尴尬。在瑞典国王古斯塔夫六世向他颁发诺贝尔奖的仪式上，布拉顿说：“当一个人想到自己在正确的时间处于正确的环境中是多么幸运时，他确实需要谦虚地接受这样的奖项。”他对科学家在社会中的角色也同样缺乏自信。布拉顿说，他的工作只是增进我们对物理世界的理解；“然而，我强烈地感觉到，科学家无权决定他的理解如何被运用。”尽管如此，当他回顾晶体管诞生 25 周年时，布拉顿确实发出了一个抱怨：​​“我最痛恨的是摇滚音乐家使用固态电子器件将声音提升到既痛苦又有害的程度。”

The most unassuming of men, Brattain seemed almost embarrassed about winning awards. At the ceremony during which King Gustav VI of Sweden presented him the Nobel Prize, Brattain observed that “one indeed needs to be humble about accepting such an award when he thinks how fortunate he was to be in the right environment at the right time.” He was equally diffident about the scientist’s role in society. His job, Brattain said, was merely to enhance our understanding of the physical world; “I feel strongly, however, that the scientist has no right to dictate how his understanding is used.” Nonetheless, when he took a look back on the twenty-fifth anniversary of the transistor, Brattain did voice one complaint: “The thing I deplore most is the use of solid state electronics by rock and roll musicians to raise the level of sound to where it is both painful and injurious.”

布拉顿是晶体管三人组中的实验者；他对半导体的工作方式有着直觉，正是他将同事的理论变成了工作装置。第一个晶体管是由锗和金属线组成的笨重结构，只有沃尔特·布拉顿才能让它工作，他后来写道，“如果我把它摆弄得恰到好处的话。”

Brattain was the experimentalist of the transistor trio; he had an intuitive feeling for the way semiconductors ought to work, and it was he who turned his colleagues’ theories into working apparatus. The first transistor was an ungainly construct of germanium and wire that could be made to work only by Walter Brattain and only, he wrote later, “if I wiggled it just right.”

晶体管团队的第三位成员是约翰·巴丁。他出生于 1908 年，父亲是威斯康星大学医学院院长。他在麦迪逊长大，在威斯康星大学获得工程学位。他后来在匹兹堡的海湾石油公司工作，但三年后决定，他更喜欢纯科学而不是应用科学。他进入普林斯顿大学，在未来的诺贝尔奖得主尤金·维格纳的指导下学习半导体物理，并于 1936 年获得博士学位。他在明尼苏达州任教，战争期间在海军军械实验室工作，然后于 1946 年同意加入他的朋友肖克利在贝尔实验室工作。1951 年，在完成了晶体管的基本工作后，他建议贝尔从事超导体的研究，即在极低温度下几乎没有电阻的材料。贝尔愚蠢地拒绝了这个建议，理由是超导性太不切实际了，无法实现。巴丁离开实验室后，到伊利诺伊大学任职（一位名叫杰克·基尔比的年轻工程师听了他的讲座）。在那里，巴丁与另外两位物理学家利昂·库珀和约翰·施里弗联手开发了超导的理论基础。他们的方案被称为 BCS 理论，事实证明这一理论可行，并成为几乎所有超导体开发的基础。巴丁凭借这一理论第二次获得了诺贝尔奖。

The third member of the transistor team was John Bardeen. Born in 1908, the son of the dean of the medical school at the University of Wisconsin, he grew up in Madison and took his engineering degree at Wisconsin. He went to work for Gulf Oil in Pittsburgh but decided after three years that he preferred pure to applied science. He enrolled at Princeton, studied semiconductor physics under the future Nobel laureate Eugene Wigner, and took a Ph.D. in 1936. He taught at Minnesota, worked in the Naval Ordnance Laboratory during the war, and then agreed to join his friend Shockley at Bell Labs in 1946. In 1951, with the basic transistor work completed, he suggested that Bell undertake work on superconductors—that is, materials that show almost no electrical resistance at extremely low temperatures. Bell rejected this proposal, foolishly, on the grounds that superconductivity was too pie-in-the-sky to work. Bardeen left the lab and took a position at the University of Illinois (where a young engineer named Jack Kilby heard him lecture). While there, Bardeen joined with two other physicists, Leon Cooper and John Schrieffer, to develop the theoretical basis of superconductivity. Their scheme, known as the BCS theory, has turned out to work and has been the basis for almost all superconductor development. For this theory, Bardeen won a second Nobel Prize.

巴丁是布拉顿的完美搭档。他的强项是理论。在晶体管项目中，布拉顿会进行实验，然后巴丁会仔细检查结果并解释其含义。他不是那种可以恰到好处地摆弄机器并使其运转的人。1972 年，当他第二次获得诺贝尔奖时，伊利诺伊州的公关人员非常自豪地安排了一场新闻发布会，并召集了附近所有科学记者。记者们都来了，但没有巴丁。他后来道了歉，解释说他被困在家里，因为他无法让他的（晶体管化的）车库门开启器工作。

Bardeen was a perfect complement to Brattain. His forte is theory. On the transistor project, Brattain would work his experiments and then Bardeen would sift through the results and explain what they meant. He was not the type of person who could wiggle a piece of machinery just right and make it work. On the day in 1972 when his second Nobel was announced, the public relations people at Illinois, proud as punch, arranged a press conference and summoned every science reporter within traveling distance. The reporters showed up, but not Bardeen. He apologized later, explaining that he had been stuck at home because he couldn’t get his (transistorized) garage door opener to work.

实验物理学家布拉顿、理论物理学家巴丁和理论物理学家肖克利（肖克利兼具理论和实验部分工作，是这个团队的领袖）从 1946 年开始研究两类半导体的不同属性：P 型半导体，即掺杂过量正电荷（空穴）的材料，以及 N 型半导体，即掺杂过量负电荷（电子）的材料。他们研究的是“双极”锗，即一条掺杂了 N 型和 P 型的锗带。他们集中精力研究 N 型和 P 型半导体中心的交汇点。这个交汇点是现代物理学中最重要的交汇点，被称为 PN 结。PN 结可以让奇妙的事情发生。

Brattain the experimentalist, Bardeen the theorist, and Shockley, who did some of both and was clearly the leader of the group, began in 1946 to study the different attributes of the two types of semiconductor: P-type, the material that had been doped with excess positive charges (holes), and N-type, which had excess negative charges (electrons). They worked with “bipolar” germanium—that is, a strip of germanium that had been doped so as to be N-type on one end and P-type at the other. The men focused intensively on the point in the center where N-type and P-type meet. This point, the most important meeting place in modern physics, is called the P-N junction. The P-N junction makes wonderful things happen.

PN 结的工作原理就像您进入地铁或体育场时要经过的旋转栅门：您可以轻松地从一个方向通过，但不能从另一个方向通过。PN 结是电子的单向门；它们可以朝一个方向通过，但不能朝另一个方向通过。当半导体条连接到电流源（例如电池）时，电子可以轻松地从 N 型材料流过 PN 结，到达 P 端。但它们不能从另一个方向穿过结。

The P-N junction works like the turnstile you pass through when you enter the subway or a stadium: you can go through easily in one direction but not the other. The P-N junction is a one-way door for electrons; they can pass through it going one direction, but not the other. When the semiconductor strip is hooked up to a source of current—a battery, for example—electrons can flow easily from the N-type material, across the P-N junction, to the P end. But they can’t cross the junction in the other direction.

只允许电流沿一个方向流动的装置就是整流器，就像约翰·弗莱明发明的真空管整流器一样，正是它让可靠的收音机成为可能。由于双极条的两端就像弗莱明真空管的两个电极，所以半导体整流器和真空管一样被称为二极管。但与弗莱明使用的体积大、发热大、易碎、耗电的真空管不同，这种半导体二极管具有微小的 PN 结，体积小、功耗低、不发热、不易破碎。半导体二极管也不需要真空，因此不需要玻璃泡。电子作用发生在固体内部，因此有“固态”一词。

A device that lets current pass in only one direction—that’s a rectifier, just like John A. Fleming’s vacuum tube rectifier, which made reliable radios possible. Since the two ends of the bipolar strip act like the two electrodes of Fleming’s tube, the semiconductor rectifier, like the tube, is called a diode. But instead of the large, hot, fragile, power-hungry vacuum tube that Fleming used, this semiconductor diode, with its minute P-N junction, is tiny, low-power, unheated, and unbreakable. The semiconductor diode needs no vacuum, either, and thus no glass bulb. The electronic action takes place within the solid; hence the term “solid state.”

1946 年，贝尔实验室团队开始工作时，人们对半导体二极管的工作原理有了相当深入的了解。然而，半导体二极管在电子学中并不重要（除了雷达等高度专业的应用），因为它们不执行放大的基本任务。只要电子设备仍然需要真空管（以及随之而来的高功率、高热量和大尺寸等问题）作为放大器，使用真空管二极管整流器也同样方便。电子学的革命始于肖克利、巴丁和布拉顿经过两年紧张而又经常令人恼火的工作，设计出半导体三极管（一种微型、低功耗、不加热的固态放大器）。这正是肖克利在 1939 年 12 月想到的设备。

By 1946, when the Bell Labs team began its work, the operation of the semiconductor diode was fairly well understood. Semiconductor diodes were not at all important in electronics, however—except for highly specialized applications, like radar—because they did not perform the essential task of amplification. As long as electronic equipment still needed vacuum tubes—with all their attendant problems of high power, heat, and size—as amplifiers, it was just as convenient to use vacuum tube diode rectifiers as well. The revolution in electronics came when Shockley, Bardeen, and Brattain, after two years of intense and frequently exasperating work, devised a semiconductor triode—a tiny, low-power, unheated, solid-state amplifier. This was the very device Shockley had thought of back in December 1939.

世界上第一台固态放大器是由巴丁和布拉顿临时拼凑起来的。它包括两根细导线，它们被精确地放置在一小块锗上的 PN 结处，彼此非常接近。如果导线被放置在正确的位置，并且布拉顿正确地摆动它们，那么流入一根导线的小电流就可以被放大一百倍。

The world’s first solid-state amplifier was a jury-rigged affair put together by Bardeen and Brattain. It involved two fine wires placed extremely close to each other precisely at the P-N junction on a small piece of germanium. If the wires were set at exactly the right spot, and if Brattain wiggled them just right, a small current flowing into one wire could be amplified to a current one hundred times as great.

1947 年 12 月 23 日，发明者向贝尔实验室的高层展示了这一装置。起初，他们用标准电子仪表测量放大率，观察者可以看到仪表上的刻度盘向右摆动很远，显示电流大幅放大。但真正让发明成果大白于天下的测试是，他们将麦克风连接到发明的一端，将扬声器连接到另一端。人们一个接一个地拿起麦克风，低声说“你好”，电路另一端的扬声器则大声喊出“你好！”肖克利有着敏锐的历史感，他意识到了这一时刻的美妙对称性：贝尔实验室又取得了通信领域的重大突破。他后来写道：“听到晶体管放大的语音，是亚历山大·格雷厄姆·贝尔那句著名的‘沃森先生，过来，我要你’的传统。”

The inventors demonstrated this device to the Bell Labs brass on December 23, 1947. At first they measured the amplification with standard electronic meters so that the observers could see the dial on the meter swing far to the right, showing a huge amplification of current. But the test that really brought home what had been achieved came when they hooked up a microphone to one end of their invention and a loudspeaker to the other. One by one, the men picked up the microphone and whispered “Hello”; the loudspeaker at the other end of the circuit shouted “HELLO!” Shockley, with an acute sense of history, realized the nice symmetry of the moment: another major breakthrough in communications had occurred in Bell’s lab. “Hearing speech amplified by the transistor,” he wrote later, “was in the tradition of Alexander Graham Bell’s famous ‘Mr. Watson, come here, I want you.’”

这第一台设备被称为点接触晶体管，是一种笨重、不精确的仪器，本身可能不会产生重大影响。第一台晶体管的真正重要性在于，它启发肖克利完善了改进的固态放大器，这种设备将彻底改变电子学：结型晶体管。肖克利在点接触发明的开发中只发挥了很小的作用。“我对团队成功的喜悦有所缓和……”他后来回忆道。“我感到有些沮丧，因为我的个人努力……没有带来我自己的重大发明贡献。”这种沮丧，加上固态放大器确实可行的认识，让肖克利“有了思考的意愿”。在接下来的五周里，他全身心投入“繁琐而精确的思考所要求的努力”。新年前夜，他独自工作，在实验室笔记本上写下了 19 页的想法和草图。1948 年 1 月 23 日，他在笔记本上写下了结型晶体管的概念。

This first device, known as a point-contact transistor, was a cumbersome, imprecise instrument that of itself would probably not have made a significant impact. The true importance of that first transistor was that it inspired Shockley to perfect an improved solid-state amplifier, the device that would revolutionize electronics: the junction transistor. Shockley had only a small role in the development of the point-contact invention. “My elation with the group’s success was tempered . . . ,” he recalled later. “I experienced some frustration that my personal efforts . . . had not resulted in a significant inventive contribution of my own.” This frustration, coupled with the knowledge that solid-state amplification was indeed possible, gave Shockley “the will to think.” For the next five weeks, he dedicated himself to “the effort that tedious and precise thinking demands.” Working alone on New Year’s Eve, he filled nineteen pages in his lab notebook with ideas and sketches. On January 23, 1948, he set down in his notebook the concept of the junction transistor.

肖克利的想法——当今所有晶体管的基础——是一种半导体三明治结构，即一条有三个不同区域的锗带——一端是 N 型，中间是 P 型，另一端是 N 型。这样就形成了两个背靠背的 PN 结。连接了三根导线——一根连接到每个 N 型区域，一根连接到中间的 P 型区域。现在，如果将电荷发送到中心区域，它将有力地从一个 N 区域吸取电子，穿过中心，从另一端出来。中心区域的电荷越强，它驱动穿过结的电子就越​​多。也就是说，中心部分的电荷可以放大沿带状流动的电流。

Shockley’s idea—the basis of all transistors today—was a semiconductor sandwich, a strip of germanium with three different regions—N-type at one end, P-type in the middle, N-type at the other end. This created two P-N junctions, back-to-back. Three wires were hooked up—one to each N-type region, and one to the P-type in the middle. Now, if a charge was sent to the center region, it would vigorously suck electrons from one N-region, across the center, and out the other end. The stronger the charge on the center region, the more electrons it drove across the junction. That is, the charge in the center section could amplify the flow of current down the strip.

在一种常见类型的晶体管中，第一个 N 型区域称为源极；中间区域为栅极；第二个 N 型区域为漏极。电流从源极流出并流向漏极。电流流过多少由中间的栅极控制。连接到栅极的电流的微小变化会导致从源极到漏极的电流发生巨大变化。更重要的是，栅极电流的变化与流向漏极的电流完全一致。

In one common type of transistor, the first N-type region is called the source; the center region is the gate; the second N-type region the drain. Current flows out of the source and down the drain. How much current flows is controlled by the gate in the middle. A small change in the current hooked to the gate causes a big change in the current from source to drain. More important, variations in the gate current are exactly mimicked in the current flowing to the drain.

这种固态夹层的三个部分类似于李·德·福雷斯特的真空三极管的三个电极。半导体“栅极”的作用类似于真空管的“栅极”。发送到栅极的无线电信号可以形成从源极流向漏极的更强电流。就像在真空管中一样，实际结果是对弱信号的放大再现。除了用作放大器外，固态三极管还可以用作超高速开关。如果设备调整得当，发送到栅极的信号将完全切断漏极电流；另一个信号将打开栅极并重新打开漏极电流。重要的是，在晶体管中，这种开关切换发生在十亿分之一秒内。这比任何真空管的切换速度都要快。这种超高速切换能力使现代计算机及其无数的后代和网络成为可能。

The three sections of this solid-state sandwich are analogous to the three electrodes of Lee De Forest’s vacuum triode. The semiconductor “gate” acts like the vacuum tube “grid.” A radio signal sent to the gate can shape a much stronger current flowing from source to drain. Just as in the vacuum tube, the effective result is an amplified reproduction of the weak signal. In addition to its application as an amplifier, the solid-state triode can serve as an extremely high-speed switch. If the device is adjusted properly, a signal to the gate will cut off the drain current completely; another signal will open the gate and turn the drain current back on. The important thing is that, in a transistor, this on-off switching takes place in billionths of a second. This is faster than any vacuum tube could be made to switch. This capability for ultra-high-speed switching made possible the modern computer and all its myriad offspring and networks.

晶体管比真空管更小、更轻、更快、更灵敏、更可靠，而且更节能，晶体管无疑是一个巨大的成功。贝尔系统的两个重要决定加速了它的发展。贝尔实验室铭记其创始人一生致力于帮助聋人，因此放弃了第一个重要晶体管产品——微型助听器的所有专利使用费。对于所有其他应用，贝尔实验室出于公共服务意识（或许是受到母公司 AT&T 即将提起的反垄断诉讼的影响），设定了 25,000 美元的廉价许可费，并为所有有兴趣生产晶体管的公司开设了培训课程。

Smaller, lighter, faster, more sensitive, more reliable, and far more power-efficient than the vacuum tube, the transistor could not have been anything other than a stupendous success. Two important decisions by the Bell System accelerated its progress. Mindful of its founder’s lifelong interest in helping the deaf, Bell waived all patent royalties on the first important transistor product, the miniature hearing aid. For all other applications, Bell Labs, moved by a sense of public service (and, perhaps, by a pending antitrust action against AT&T, its parent company), established a bargain-basement license fee of $25,000 and ran training programs for all firms interested in producing transistors.

到 50 年代中期，半导体销售额已达 10 亿美元，真空三极管也成了博物馆的藏品。每年都有数百项基于晶体管的有趣新发明问世。大众媒体将这项新技术视为一项真正的奇迹。《时代》杂志在1957 年的一篇典型报道中指出：“对于所有工业需求和大多数人类生理需求，电子魔术师们确信他们掌握了关键。”

By the mid-fifties, semiconductor sales were in the billion-dollar range and the vacuum triode was becoming a museum piece. Each new year brought hundreds of intriguing new inventions based on the transistor. The popular press treated the new technology as a full-fledged miracle. “To all industrial needs, and most human physical needs,” Time magazine noted in a typically breathless report in 1957, “the electronics magicians are sure they have the key.”

还是他们真的做到了？到 1957 年，电子魔术师们只确定他们遇到了一个严重的问题——数字暴政带来的问题。除非能够解决互连难题，否则晶体管化未来的巨大希望可能永远无法实现。这个问题的核心重要性——以及解决该问题将带来的利润——让全球各国政府、研究实验室和制造业企业“愿意思考”解决方案，并愿意投入巨额资金来寻求解决方案。

Or were they? By 1957, the electronic magicians were sure only that they had a serious problem—the problem posed by the tyranny of numbers. Unless the interconnections dilemma could be resolved, the enormous promise of a transistorized future might never be realized. The central importance of the problem—and the profits to be gained from its solution—instilled in governments and research labs and manufacturing concerns around the globe “the will to think” about a solution, and the will to spend large sums in pursuit of it.

走在这项探索前沿的公司之一是德州仪器公司，该公司于 1958 年初启动了一项大规模研究项目，以解决数字问题，并开始从世界各地招募半导体专家。德州仪器聘请的人员中包括一位身材瘦高的 34 岁密尔沃基工程师，名叫杰克·基尔比 (Jack Kilby)。

One of the firms in the forefront of this pursuit was Texas Instruments, which mounted a large-scale research project to deal with the numbers problem early in 1958 and began recruiting semiconductor experts from throughout the world for the task. Among the men TI hired was a lanky thirty-four-year-old engineer from Milwaukee named Jack Kilby.

3

3

一个不明显的解决方案

A NONOBVIOUS SOLUTION

晶体管诞生的那一年，杰克·圣克莱尔·基尔比在电子行业找到了第一份工作，从那时起，他就一直工作在高科技的最前线。他是 20 世纪 50 年代将晶体管从实验室样品发展成工业支柱的一小群先驱者之一。他构思并制造了世界上第一个集成电路或半导体芯片，然后又发明了可能是该芯片最著名的产物——手持计算器。此后，他花了六年时间研究光伏效应，这是一种尚未完全理解的半导体物理现象，旨在建造一个由太阳能驱动的发电站。他获得了无数学术奖项，包括国家科学奖章（相当于技术界的国会荣誉勋章）​​、京都奖（相当于日本的诺贝尔奖）以及诺贝尔奖本身。他的照片悬挂在华盛顿的名人堂中，位于亨利·福特和回旋加速器的发明者欧内斯特·劳伦斯之间。

Jack St. Clair Kilby landed his first job in electronics the year the transistor was born and has been working ever since at the front lines of high technology. He was among a small group of pioneers in the 1950s who developed the transistor from a laboratory specimen to a mainstay of industry. He conceived and built the world’s first integrated circuit, or semiconductor chip, and then proceeded to invent what is probably the chip’s most famous offspring, the handheld calculator. He spent a half dozen years after that working on the photovoltaic effect, an as yet imperfectly understood phenomenon of semiconductor physics, in an effort to construct an electric generating station fueled by the sun. He has won countless scholarly awards, including the National Medal of Science, the technologist’s equivalent of the Congressional Medal of Honor; the Kyoto Prize, Japan’s equivalent of the Nobel Prize; and the Nobel Prize itself. His picture hangs in a hall of fame in Washington between those of Henry Ford and Ernest Lawrence, inventor of the cyclotron.

尽管如此，杰克·基尔比本人似乎与高科技截然相反。基尔比沉着冷静，说话直率，衣着朴素（他在实验室的标准制服是开领运动衫和休闲棉裤），你可能期望看到他安静地坐在乡村商店的门廊上，大脚撑在栏杆上。他身材魁梧，不胖，但在其他方面都很魁梧：六英尺六英寸高，肩膀宽阔，手掌巨大，一张又大又圆、红润的脸，几缕灰白的头发从太阳穴上伸出来，灿烂的笑容准确地表明了他友好、随意、沉着的个性。他性格内向，花了很多时间独自思考、构思；他总是独自完成最具创造性的工作。在谈话中，他并不敏捷。问他一个问题——关于半导体、政治、去机场的最佳路线——他会抽上一口卡尔顿香烟，在绝对沉默中思考片刻，再抽一口，然后轻柔而缓慢地回答。他的回答总是经过深思熟虑，用结构完整的句子表达，从头到尾流畅无离题或绕弯子。

For all that, however, Jack Kilby in person seems the very antithesis of high tech. Calm and quiet, plain-spoken and plainly dressed (his standard uniform in the lab is an open-necked sports shirt and knockabout cotton trousers), Kilby is the kind of person you might expect to find rocking peacefully on the porch of some country store, his large feet propped up on the railing. He is an imposing figure, not fat but big in every other sense: six feet six inches tall, wide shoulders, massive hands, a large, round, ruddy face framed by a few wayward tufts of gray hair poking up from the temples, and an enormous smile that suggests, accurately, a friendly, casual, unruffled personality. An introvert, he spends a good deal of time alone with his thoughts, working through ideas; he has always done his most creative work on his own. In conversation, he is not quick. Ask him a question—about semiconductors, politics, the best route to the airport—and he will take a long puff on a Carlton, think for a moment in absolute silence, take another puff, and then answer, softly, slowly. The answers are invariably thoughtful and delivered in fully structured sentences that flow perfectly from beginning to end without digression or detour.

尽管这位发明家在最现代的技术领域做出了开创性的工作，但他却有老派的一面。他不会戴电子表；他经常仔细考虑数字和模拟（即指针式）钟表之间的区别，并得出结论，老式钟表更能传达时间的无缝流逝。他是达拉斯高科技社区中最后几个拥有个人电脑的人之一，他从未想过用这台机器做任何比尝试将文档附加到电子邮件中更复杂的事情，尽管这种尝试并不总是成功。当 Kilby 在 2000 年 12 月被邀请发表诺贝尔物理学演讲时，瑞典皇家学院的官员提前联系了他，询问他将使用哪种软件程序来准备演讲演示文稿。软件？演示文稿？“天哪，我想我只需要几张幻灯片，”杰克说。尽管他可能是导致计算尺消失的最大责任人，但他仍然将自己最喜欢的 Keuffel & Esser Log-Log Decitrig 放在办公桌中央抽屉中，从某种程度上来说，他更喜欢它，而不是那些让计算尺过时的手持计算器。“它是一种优雅的工具，”他深情地说。他的爱好是摄影（当然是黑白的），三十年来，他一直心满意足地使用同一台可靠的哈苏相机。他倾向于将自己的汽车保养到 100,000 英里以上。“只要它能跑，管他呢，”他解释道。

Despite his pioneering work in the most modern of technologies, the inventor has an old-fashioned streak. He won’t wear a digital watch; characteristically, he has given considerable thought to the difference between digital and analog (i.e., with hands) timepieces and concluded that the older kind better conveys the seamless passage of time. He was one of the last people in the high-tech community in Dallas to get a personal computer, and has never dreamed of doing anything more complicated with the machine than trying, not always successfully, to attach a document to an e-mail. When Kilby was called upon in December 2000 to give the Nobel lecture in physics, functionaries from the Royal Swedish Academy contacted him in advance to find out which software program he would be using to prepare the presentations for his talk. Software? Presentations? “Gosh, I guess I’ll just have a couple of slides,” Jack said. Although he is probably the single person most responsible for the demise of the slide rule, he still keeps his favorite Keuffel & Esser Log-Log Decitrig handy in the center drawer of his desk, and in some ways he prefers it to the handheld calculators that rendered it obsolete. “It’s an elegant tool,” he says affectionately. His hobby is photography (black-and-white, of course), for which he has contentedly used the same trusty Hasselblad for thirty years. He tends to keep his cars well past the 100,000-mile mark. “As long as it runs, what the heck,” he explains.

在行业和公司（他曾断断续续在德州仪器公司工作了近半个世纪），“强硬”和“积极进取”都是极高的赞誉，而这位安静而友善的发明家以好人而闻名。当他穿过德州仪器达拉斯总部蜿蜒的走廊时——他小心翼翼地弯着腰，就像一个经常撞到低矮天花板的人——他叫出每个人的名字，从高层管理人员到信使。公司里的每个人似乎都有一两个关于基尔比善举的故事。我还可以再加一个。当我第一次打电话给基尔比，问我是否可以和他呆一会儿时，他欣然同意了，然后补充说——这是我新闻生涯中的第一次——他会去机场接我，带我四处转转，​​因为“这里打出租车很难。”

In an industry and a company (he has worked at Texas Instruments on and off for almost half a century) where “tough” and “aggressive” are terms of high praise, the quiet but friendly inventor is famous as a nice guy. As he treks through the meandering hallways of Texas Instruments’ Dallas headquarters—walking with the wary, stooped gait of a man who has bumped his head too often on low ceilings—he greets everybody by name, from top management to messenger boys. Everyone at the company seems to have a story or three about some act of kindness on Kilby’s part. To that collection I can add another. When I first called Kilby, out of the blue, to ask if I might spend some time with him, he readily agreed, and then added—it was a first in my journalistic career—that he would pick me up at the airport and shuttle me around because “taxis can be hard as hell to get around here.”

由于量子理论和半导体技术的发展基本同步，基尔比的工作经常使他接近或接近物理学的前沿。这是一个令人困惑的复杂领域；例如，要了解芯片中的电荷流动，必须计算角动量算符的 z 分量的特征值。但基尔比不是科学家。他非常坚定地坚持这一点，用柔和但明确的语气坚持说他是一名工程师。“有一个非常关键的区别，”他说。“科学家的动机是知识；他基本上想解释一些东西。工程师的动力是解决问题，让某样东西发挥作用……这基本上就是我一直想做的事情，解决技术问题。经历这个过程并找到一个可行的解决方案，这让人非常满意，非常满意。”

Because of the more-or-less parallel development of quantum theory and semiconductor technology, Kilby’s work has regularly taken him near or right up to the leading edge of physics. It is a bewilderingly complex field; to understand the flow of charge in a chip, for example, one has to calculate the eigenvalues of the z-component of the angular momentum operator. But Kilby is not a scientist. He is quite firm on the point, insisting, in soft but definite tones, that he is an engineer. “There’s a pretty key difference,” he says. “A scientist is motivated by knowledge; he basically wants to explain something. An engineer’s drive is to solve problems, to make something work. . . . That is basically what I have always wanted to do, to solve technical problems. It is quite satisfying, extremely satisfying, to go through the process and find a solution that works.”

基尔比对这个过程进行了大量的思考，并且，正如他所言，他已经制定出一套解决技术或其他问题艺术的严谨理论。这种方法略微简化，涉及两个层次的集中思考。

Kilby has done a great deal of thinking about that process, and, true to form, he has worked out a careful theory of the art of solving a problem, technical or otherwise. Somewhat simplified, the method involves two levels of concentrated thought.

首先，问题解决者必须用广角镜头审视事物，寻找可能与某种解决方案相关的每一个事实。这需要广泛阅读，包括所有显而易见的技术文献，也包括广泛的其他出版物 — — 书籍、传单、报纸、杂志、演讲、目录，任何东西。基尔比自己每天阅读两三份报纸，每周阅读十几本杂志，不是浏览而是阅读。此外，他还如饥似渴地读书；他的办公室看起来就像一个出版商的仓库，书籍在这里大行其道。多年来，基尔比花时间阅读美国政府颁发的每一项新专利。其中一些发明可以说与他的工作有关：“电解池阳极螺柱涂层”；“电流调节器”。其他一些似乎与之无关：“燃气陶瓷辐射家禽育雏器”；“牙膏封装”；“吉他扩音系统”； “自包装的滑翔机玩具”；“高尔夫推杆辅助器”；“3 或 4 产品表面波声光时间积分相关器”。“没关系，”Kilby 说。“你什么都读——这是工作的一部分。你积累了所有这些琐碎知识，希望有一天，也许其中的百万分之一会派上用场。”为了消遣，Kilby 说，“我读垃圾。”

At first, the problem solver has to look things over with a wide-angle lens, hunting down every fact that might conceivably be related to some kind of solution. This involves extensive reading, including all the obvious technical literature but also a broad range of other publications—books, broadsides, newspapers, magazines, speeches, catalogues, whatever happens into view. Kilby himself reads, not skims but reads, two or three newspapers every day and a dozen magazines or so each week. In addition he devours books; his office looks like a publisher’s warehouse where the books have staged a coup. For years, Kilby took the time to read every new patent issued by the U.S. government. Some of the inventions were arguably related to his work: “anode stud coatings for electrolytic cells”; “electric current regulator.” Others seemed rather far removed: “gas-fired ceramic radiant poultry brooder”; “dentifrice encapsulation”; “guitar amplifying system”; “self-packaged glider toy”; “golf putting aid”; “3- or 4-product surface-wave acousto-optic time-integrating correlator.” “That’s all right,” Kilby says. “You read everything—that’s part of the job. You accumulate all this trivia, and you hope that someday maybe a millionth of it will be useful.” For recreation, Kilby says, “I read trash.”

基尔比体系的下一步要求将关注点转向极其狭窄的领域，严格思考问题，不去理会外界的干扰。首先，这需要对问题进行准确的定义。“问题的定义是创新的重要组成部分，”基尔比写道。“许多解决方案都失败了，”他说，“因为它们解决了错误的问题，而且没有人意识到这一点，直到他们申请了专利并制造出产品。”还必须清楚地了解围绕问题的自然限制；发明家工作的核心是找到一种方法来绕过大自然设置的障碍。“虽然发明被认为是一种创造性的过程，”基尔比曾在一次关于这个主题的演讲中说道，“但它与艺术创造力有很大不同。画家从一张空白的画布开始，作家或诗人从一张白纸开始。他们选择一个图像……他们可以自由地使用任何他们拥有的技术来实现它。技术创造力受到更多限制。自然法则、材料特性…… ……提供非常现实的约束。”

The next step in Kilby’s system requires switching to an extremely narrow focus, thinking strictly about the problem and tuning out the rest of the world. This requires, first of all, an accurate definition of the problem. “The definition of the problem becomes a major part of the innovation,” Kilby has written. “A lot of solutions fail,” he says, “because they’re solving the wrong problem, and nobody realizes that until the patent is filed and they’ve built the thing.” It is also necessary to develop a clear understanding of the natural constraints surrounding the problem; the heart of the inventor’s job is finding a way to slip past the roadblocks erected by nature. “Although invention is considered a creative process,” Kilby said once in a lecture on the subject, “it differs appreciably from creativity in the arts. The painter starts with a blank canvas, the author or poet with a blank sheet of paper. They choose an image . . . and they are free to use any techniques they have to achieve it. Technical creativity is more constrained. The laws of nature, the properties of materials . . . provide very real constraints.”

在集中精力、一心一意地关注手头的问题时，问题解决者还必须排除所有显而易见的解决方案。这是一条关键原则，强调这一点很重要，因为它有点违反直觉。思维倾向于跳到立即显而易见的答案。事实上，这个答案可能是错误的。如果问题很重要，所有显而易见的解决方案都已经被尝试过了。“非显而易见”一词很少出现在词典中，但它是 Kilby 个人词汇的重要组成部分，当他谈论解决问题时，他一次又一次地提到这个概念。他说，历史上一些最重要的创新是如此非显而易见，以至于违反了当时的科学规则。“只有当有人开发出一种其他人已经认定明显错误的方法时，你才会发明出来。”

In this concentrated, single-minded focus on the question at hand, the problem solver must also tune out all the obvious solutions. This is a key principle, important to emphasize because it is somewhat counterintuitive. The mind tends to jump to the answer that is immediately evident. In fact, this answer is probably wrong. If the problem is of any importance, all the obvious solutions have been tried already. The word “nonobvious” appears in few dictionaries, but it is an important part of Kilby’s personal lexicon, a concept he returns to again and again when he gets talking about the business of solving problems. Some of history’s most important innovations, he says, were so nonobvious as to violate the scientific rules of the day. “You only arrived at the invention when somebody developed a method that everyone else had already decided was obviously wrong.”
