此时，如果问题解决者的准备工作已经足够充分，他已经定义了正确的问题，他遵守了物理极限，他富有创造力，而且运气好，他可能会找到一个不太明显的解决方案。但这还不够，至少对于工程问题来说还不够。基尔比说，工程的本质是成本意识。“你可以设计一个核动力婴儿奶瓶加热器，”他说，“它可能会起作用，但它不是一个工程解决方案。从成本角度来看，它没有意义。我爸爸总是喜欢这样说，工程师可以找到一种方法，用一美元做别人花两美元就能做的事情。”

At this point, if the problem solver’s preparation has been broad enough, and he has defined the right problem, and he observes the physical limits, and he’s creative, and he’s lucky, he might hit on a nonobvious solution that works. But that is not enough, at least not for an engineering problem. The essence of engineering, Kilby says, is cost consciousness. “You could design a nuclear-powered baby bottle warmer,” he says, “and it might work, but it’s not an engineering solution. It won’t make sense in terms of cost. The way my dad always liked to put it was that an engineer could find a way to do for one dollar what everybody else could do for two.”

基尔比的父亲是一名电气工程师，曾在美国中西部各地的电力公司工作，最终升任堪萨斯电力公司的总裁。这是一家中型公用事业公司，在堪萨斯州西部各地设有小型发电厂，总部位于大本德，这是一座整洁、繁华的小镇，位于阿肯色河向南拐弯处，汇入密西西比河。杰克于 1923 年出生在密苏里州的杰斐逊城，但他的大部分童年时光都在大本德度过。他在那里的公立学校上学，夏天，他和父亲会开着一辆 1935 年的别克大车穿越平原，在电力公司的每个偏远设施停留。他们会在发电站的工地上爬行，试图找出故障电枢出了什么问题，或者测试新型变压器的效率。

Kilby’s dad was an electrical engineer who worked at electric power companies around the Midwest and eventually rose to the presidency of the Kansas Power Company, a medium-size utility that had small generating plants scattered around the western part of the state and headquarters in Great Bend, a neat, bustling town at the point where the Arkansas River bends south toward the Mississippi. Jack was born in Jefferson City, Missouri, in 1923, but spent most of his childhood in Great Bend. He attended the public schools there, and in the summers he and his father would traverse the plains in a big 1935 Buick, stopping at each of the power company’s remote facilities. They would crawl through the works of the generating stations, trying to find out what had gone wrong with a faulty armature or testing the efficiency of a new-model transformer.

1937 年的暴风雪席卷堪萨斯州，道路被封堵，电话线被击断，老基尔比借用邻居的业余无线电来跟踪客户和远距离业务。自然，好奇的儿子必须看看这个小玩意儿是如何工作的。杰克转动旋钮，把大天线来回转动，把耳机紧紧地贴在头上，这样他就能听清堪萨斯州夜晚中传来的微弱、波动的信号，他很快就迷上了收音机。部分原因是他对这个工具本身的纯粹迷恋，以及对它工作原理的好奇。但这位少年也能体会到人类智慧的力量如何改善了普通人的日常生活。“在我十几岁的时候，一场冰暴，”大约 60 年后，他回忆道，“我第一次看到收音机，以及电子产品如何真正影响人们的生活，让人们了解信息、保持联系，并给他们希望。”一个全新的政府机构——联邦通信委员会，开始要求无线电操作员持有执照。杰克学习了数周，参加了考试，一天放学回家后，发现一封官方信件，上面给他分配了一套自己的呼号：W9GTY。他制作了一套业余无线电装置，改进了它，找来一些零件，又改进了它。到他上大本德高中时，他已经很清楚自己会从事电气工程事业，他把目光投向了工程师的圣地——麻省理工学院。1941 年 6 月的一天，他登上了新英格兰州号列车，这列列车连接了中西部平原和东海岸的学习和商业中心，他乘车前往剑桥。他在那里花了一个月的时间接受培训，准备参加麻省理工学院的入学考试。

When the blizzard of ’37 swept through Kansas, blocking roads and felling telephone lines everywhere, the senior Kilby borrowed a neighbor’s ham radio to keep track of his customers and his far-flung operations. Naturally, the curious son had to see how this gadget worked. Twisting the dials, turning the big antenna this way and that, squeezing the earphones tight against his head so that he could make out the weak, fluctuating signals racing through the Kansas night, Jack was quickly hooked on radio. Partly it was the sheer fascination of the tool itself, and curiosity about why it worked. But the teenager could also appreciate how the power of human ingenuity had improved daily life for ordinary people. “It was during an ice storm in my teens,” he recalled some sixty years later, “that I first saw how radio and, by extension, electronics, could really impact people’s lives by keeping them informed and connected, and giving them hope.” A brand-new government agency, the Federal Communications Commission, began requiring licenses for radio operators. Jack studied for weeks, took the exam, and came home from school one day to find an official letter assigning him his own set of call letters: W9GTY. He built a ham set, improved it, scavenged some parts, improved it again. By the time he got to Great Bend High School it was clear that he would make his career in electrical engineering, and he set his sights on the engineer’s mecca, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. On a June day in 1941 he boarded the New England States, the crack train connecting the midwestern plains with the great centers of learning and commerce on the East Coast, and rode to Cambridge. He spent a month there training to take the entrance exam for MIT.

至此，我们这位发明家的故事开始走下坡路。杰克没通过考试。他被麻省理工学院拒绝了。几十年后，在发起了第二次工业革命、获得了 50 多项专利并赢得了所有领先的工程奖项之后，基尔比仍然感到考试不及格的痛苦。他还记得自己在考试中的分数——497 分，离及格只差三分。当然，从长远来看，一切都会好起来，正如杰克在获得诺贝尔奖那天指出的那样。但当时麻省理工学院的拒绝信是毁灭性的。此外，它还造成了一场实际危机。杰克没有费心申请其他大学。经过一番努力，他被父母的母校伊利诺伊大学录取。他在那里不到四个月，日本就轰炸了珍珠港。大一的基尔比成为下士，被分配到印度东北部茶园陆军前哨的一家无线电维修店。

At this point, our inventor’s story takes a downward turn. Jack failed the test. He was turned down by MIT. Decades later, having launched the Second Industrial Revolution, received more than fifty patents, and won all the leading engineering awards, Kilby still felt the sting of flunking that exam. He could remember his score on the test—he got 497, three points short of passing. Of course, it all worked out for the best in the long run, as Jack pointed out on the day he won the Nobel Prize. But at the time that rejection letter from MIT was devastating. Moreover, it created a practical crisis. Jack had not bothered to apply to any other college. After some scrambling he was admitted to his parents’ alma mater, the University of Illinois. He had been there less than four months when the Japanese bombed Pearl Harbor. Freshman Kilby became Corporal Kilby, assigned to a radio repair shop at an Army outpost on a tea plantation in northeastern India.

在军队中，每个人都能学到一些东西。这位 18 岁的下士了解到，创造性的工程技术可以解决官方宣布无法解决的问题。他的部队是美国最早参与游击战的部队之一。小队士兵将通过空运“越过山丘”——即越过喜马拉雅山——进入缅甸，组织当地抵抗运动，骚扰日本人。美国人使用背在身上的无线电与基地保持联系。他们提供了有史以来最好的“便携式”无线电，但它们重达 60 磅，在丛林作战的压力下经常出现故障。陆军对所有投诉的回应是，他们的发射器，即无线电领域的最先进技术，无法改进。当然，工程师知道任何地方都没有无法改进的机器。基尔比部队的工程师在布满灰尘的小帐篷里设立了一个实验室。他们派基尔比下士到加尔各答在黑市上购买旧收音机零件。随着时间的推移，他们开始生产比官方发布的更轻、更节能的临时发射器。

Everybody learns something in the Army. The eighteen-year-old corporal learned that creative engineering can solve problems that have been officially declared insoluble. His unit was one of the first endeavors of the United States in guerrilla warfare. Small teams of soldiers would be airlifted “over the hump”—that is, across the Himalayas—into Burma to put together indigenous resistance movements to harass the Japanese. The Americans kept in touch with their base using radios they carried on their backs. The best “portable” radios ever made were provided, but they weighed 60 pounds and broke down regularly under the stress of jungle operations. The Army responded to all complaints by saying that its transmitters, the state of the art in radio, could not be improved. An engineer, of course, knows that there is no machine anywhere that cannot be improved. The engineers in Kilby’s unit set up a lab in a dusty pup tent. They sent Corporal Kilby down to Calcutta to buy old radio parts on the black market. Over time, they began turning out ad hoc transmitters that were both lighter and more power-efficient than the official issue.

战后，基尔比回到伊利诺斯州，渴望了解雷达和其他战时电子学的进步。总的来说，他很失望。现在他唯一能回忆起的关于电子学课程的事情是，没有一个实验的结果与老师所说的一样。此外，为工程专业学生提供的零星物理课程并没有涵盖揭示亚原子结构本质的关键二十世纪发展。伊利诺斯州有关于量子物理和半导体现象的课程，但仅限于科学家；“他们不会向头脑简单的工程师介绍这些有趣的东西，”杰克说。基尔比于 1947 年毕业，接受了传统的工程教育，成绩不错但并不出色。他去了密尔沃基的 Centralab 工作，原因很简单，因为这是他所在领域唯一一家向他提供工作机会的公司。

After the war, Kilby went back to Illinois, eager to learn about radar and other wartime advances in electronics. On the whole, he was disappointed. The one thing he can recall now about his electronics classes was that none of the experiments turned out the way the instructors said they would. Further, the smattering of physics classes offered to engineering students didn’t cover the crucial twentieth-century developments revealing the nature of subatomic architectures. There were courses at Illinois on quantum physics and semiconductor phenomena, but they were restricted to scientists; “they weren’t going to expose that funny stuff to simpleminded engineers,” Jack says. Kilby graduated in 1947 with a traditional engineering education and decent but not outstanding grades. He went to work in Milwaukee at Centralab, for the excellent reason that it was the only firm in his field that offered him a job.

事情往往如此，这份工作对这位新手工程师来说是个完美的选择。Centralab 是 Globe-Union Corporation 的一个部门，当时生产助听器、收音机和电视电路的电子零件。这是一个竞争激烈的行业，每千个零件一美元的成本差异——每个零件十分之一美分——就可能赢得或失去大笔合同。“这就像一门速成课程，培养对成本的敏感度，”Kilby 后来回忆道。到 20 世纪 40 年代末，无线电工程师已经确定了每种电子元件的最佳材料；电阻器由碳制成，电容器由金属和瓷制成，连接线由银或铜制成。Centralab 并没有试图通过改进材料来为每个零件多榨出几百分之一美分，而是致力于通过提高生产效率来节省更多成本——通过一次制造操作将电路的所有零件放在一个陶瓷基座上。该公司的成功有好有坏，但是概念的种子 — — 电路元件不需要单独制造 — — 却一直留在 Kilby 心中并结出重要的果实。

As such things often do, the job turned out to be a perfect spot for the neophyte engineer. Centralab, a division of Globe-Union Corporation, was then producing electric parts for hearing-aid, radio, and television circuits. It was an intensely competitive business, where a cost differential of one dollar per thousand parts—a tenth of a penny per part—could win or lose huge contracts. “It was sort of a crash course in sensitivity to cost,” Kilby recalled later. By the late 1940s, radio engineers had already determined the optimum material for each kind of electric component; resistors were made of carbon, capacitors of metal and porcelain, connecting wires of silver or copper. Rather than try to squeeze out a few additional hundredths of a cent per part by improving materials, Centralab was working on the notion that more could be saved by production efficiencies—by placing all the parts of a circuit on a single ceramic base in one manufacturing operation. The firm had only mixed success, but the conceptual seed—that the components of a circuit need not be manufactured separately—was to stay with Kilby and bear important fruit.

在 Centralab 工作的最初几年，Kilby 开始发展自己的问题解决方法。为了全面了解工作中需要解决的问题，他决心学习有关该领域的一切知识。他晚上上研究生课程，仔细阅读技术文献，参加任何可能有趣的讲座。一天晚上，在马凯特大学，他听到一位物理学家——约翰·巴丁 (John Bardeen)——描述了一种新发明，该发明无需真空管即可实现放大和快速开关切换。太神奇了！这种设备的存在似乎挑战了 Jack 在学校学到的所有电路规则。Kilby 开始阅读他能找到的有关这种新型固态设备的所有资料。当时和现在一样，Kilby 的阅读范围远远超出了电子学。有一次，他偶然发现了一本牙科用品目录；其中一页令人不快，他至今仍记得，其中描述了一种使用小型喷砂机清除蛀牙的新技术。

In his early years at Centralab, Kilby began to develop his problem-solving methodology. To acquire the wide-angle picture of the problems he had to solve at work, he was determined to learn everything he could about his field. He took graduate courses at night, plowed through the technical literature, attended any lecture that might be interesting. One night at Marquette University he heard a physicist—it was John Bardeen—describe a new invention that achieved amplification and rapid on-off switching without a vacuum tube. Amazing! The very existence of such a device seemed to challenge all the rules of electric circuits that Jack had learned in school. Kilby set out to read everything he could find about this new solid-state device. Then as now, Kilby’s reading went far beyond electronics. At one point he happened upon a dental supply catalogue; one page, so unpleasant he can still remember it, described a new technique that used small sand-blasters to scour away tooth decay.

Centralab 规模很小，而且非正式，可以让实验室里最年轻的人承担重要的工作。Kilby 立即被派去解决真正的工程问题，随着他逐渐掌握了窍门，他获得了从事创造性工作的人的无价资产：自信。随着时间的推移，杰克意识到，如果他正确地处理问题，长时间地努力，并且不让最初的失败打倒自己，他就能找到解决方案。事实上，他的第一个真正的成功之一解决了 Centralab 单步电路构建过程的主要问题之一——电阻器的可靠性。该过程涉及通过在陶瓷基座上印刷小块碳来制造电阻器。机器不精确，所以没有两个碳片的大小相同。这意味着没有两个电阻器的性能完全相同，这使得构建可靠的电路成为不可能。Kilby 的任务是找到一种方法来使所有电阻器的尺寸相同。老板说，这必须迅速完成，而且杰克想出的任何解决方案都必须 (a) 便宜和 (b) 简单。 Kilby 从对问题的广泛回顾开始，思考了所有可能相关的内容。他突然想到了一些东西，是他在某个地方读到的。那些微型牙科喷砂机——有人用过吗？事实上，这种技术从未在牙医中流行起来，因为他们的病人觉得它令人厌恶。但 Kilby 设法找到了一些精密的设备；果然，它们非常适合雕刻多余的碳并使所有印刷电阻器的尺寸相同。这种不明显的方法最终使 Centralab 的单步流程能够生产出可靠的电路。

Centralab was small and informal enough to let the most junior man in the lab take on important jobs. Kilby was immediately put to work solving real engineering problems, and as he got the hang of it, he acquired a priceless asset for anyone engaged in creative work: confidence. Over time, Jack came to realize that if he approached a problem correctly, worked at it long enough, and refused to let initial failures get him down, he could find a solution. One of his first real successes, in fact, solved one of the major problems with Centralab’s single-step circuit-building process—the reliability of the resistors. The process involved making resistors by printing small patches of carbon on the ceramic base. The machinery was imprecise, so no two carbon patches were the same size. That meant no two resistors performed exactly the same, which made it impossible to build a reliable circuit. Kilby was given the job of finding a way to make all the resistors the same size. It had to be done quickly, the boss said, and whatever solution Jack came up with had to be (a) cheap and (b) simple. Starting off with his wide-angle review of the problem, Kilby pondered everything that might be relevant. Something came to mind, something he had read someplace. Those tiny dental sand-blasters—did anybody use them? As it happened, the technique had never caught on with dentists because their patients found it repulsive. But Kilby managed to track down some of those precise devices; sure enough, they were perfect for carving away excess carbon and making all the printed resistors the same size. It was a nonobvious approach that finally made it possible for Centralab’s single-step process to produce reliable circuits.

1952 年，贝尔实验室宣布将发放其新专利晶体管的生产许可证，Centralab 支付了 25,000 美元的许可费，并派遣 Kilby 参加贝尔为期十天的新技术速成班。在那里，他详细了解了现在电路将摆脱真空管的限制而可能出现的奇妙新世界。他满怀创意回到密尔沃基，这些创意促成了晶体管设备制造和封装的重大进步。然而，他逐渐意识到新电子世界有其自身的局限性。

When Bell Labs announced in 1952 that it would issue licenses for production of its newly patented transistor, Centralab put up the $25,000 license fee and dispatched Kilby to Bell’s ten-day crash course in the new technology. There he got a detailed look at the fantastic new world that would be possible now that circuits would be free of the limitations imposed by vacuum tubes. He came back to Milwaukee full of ideas, ideas that led to important advances in the manufacture and packaging of transistorized equipment. Gradually, however, he came to realize that the new electronic world had a limit of its own.

在一家规模相对较小的公司工作时，工程实验室的电路设计师与工厂经理保持着定期联系，基尔比很快就了解到——可能比业内许多其他人更早——制造过程的现实严重限制了晶体管电路的复杂性。在实验室楼上，基尔比和他的同事可以设计助听器或无线电放大器，将数量空前的元件压缩到极小的空间中。但在工厂里，这些电路无法制造；互连数量太多，人手无法制造。“贝尔实验室的杰克·莫顿认为电子行业正面临‘数字暴政’，”基尔比回忆道，“这是一个完美的术语，因为这些新电路中的零件和连接数量实在太大。简单的事实是，你无法完成工程师想做的所有事情。”

Working in a relatively small firm, where the circuit designers in the engineering lab had regular contact with the plant managers, Kilby soon learned—probably sooner than many other people in the business—that realities of the manufacturing process severely restricted the complexity of transistorized circuitry. Upstairs in the lab, Kilby and his colleagues could design a hearing aid or a radio amplifier that squeezed unheard-of numbers of components into minute spaces. But down in the factory, those circuits could not be built; there were just too many interconnections too close together for the human hand to make them. “Jack Morton at Bell Labs suggested that electronics was facing a ‘tyranny of numbers,’” Kilby recalled, “and that was a perfect term for it because the numbers of parts and connections in some of these new circuits were just too big. The simple fact was that you could not do everything that an engineer would want to do.”

对于 Kilby 来说，认识到这个重大的新问题令人振奋。就在他成为一名工程师、解决问题的高手时，电子世界正面临着一个极为棘手的问题。晶体管的出现提供了巨大的、震撼世界的可能性，但除非有人找到解决数字问题的方法，否则这些可能性永远无法实现。设计和生产之间存在着巨大且不断扩大的差距。与业内其他人一样，Jack Kilby 也开始寻找弥合这一差距的方法。

For Kilby, the recognition of this major new problem was electrifying. Just as he was coming into his own as an engineer, a problem solver, the world of electronics was up against a baffling problem of premier importance. The advent of the transistor offered enormous, world-shaking possibilities, but they would never be realized unless somebody found a way around the problem of numbers. There was a huge and growing gap between design and production. Like everyone else in the industry, Jack Kilby plunged into the search for a way to bridge that gap.

但很明显，解决数字暴政（如果真的能找到解决方案）是一项需要大量资源的任务——远远超过 Centralab 这样的公司所能调动的资源。“我觉得，”Kilby 后来写道，“……资金有限的小团队不可能具有竞争力。我决定离开公司。”1958 年初，他向多家大型公司的工程师发送了简历。由于新兴的电子行业是一个完全精英化的领域，没有麻省理工学院的学位现在已无关紧要。杰克的声誉和他的专利目录使他成为该领域的抢手货。IBM 提出了要约。摩托罗拉也提出了。德州仪器的 Willis Adcock 也来信了。

It was evident, though, that solving the tyranny of numbers, if indeed a solution could be found, was a task that would require large resources—considerably larger than a firm the size of Centralab could muster. “I felt,” Kilby wrote later, “. . . that it would not be possible for very small groups with limited funding to be competitive. I decided to leave the company.” Early in 1958 he sent out his résumé to engineers at a number of larger firms. Because the budding electronics industry was a thoroughly meritocratic universe, the lack of the MIT degree was irrelevant now. Jack’s reputation, and his catalogue of patents, made him a hot commodity in the field. IBM made an offer. Motorola did as well. And there also came a letter from Willis Adcock of Texas Instruments.

如今，德州仪器 (Texas Instruments) 是一家全球半导体巨头，也是全球领先的微电子设备制造商之一，这在很大程度上要归功于杰克·基尔比 (Jack Kilby)。然而，在 1958 年，该公司才刚刚开始在电子行业崭露头角。该公司成立于 20 世纪 20 年代中期，当时名为地球物理研究公司 (Geophysical Research Corporation)；其业务是将声波发送到地底深处以寻找潜在的石油钻探地点。在第二次世界大战期间，同样的深层探测方法被证明可用于定位敌方潜艇，而 GRC 成为了国防承包商。该公司战后的总裁帕特里克·哈格蒂 (Patrick Haggerty) 将政府业务扩展到制造电子仪器比地球物理研究更重要的地步。富有远见的哈格蒂坚信他的小公司将大有作为，因此将公司名称改为通用仪器 (General Instruments) — 这是一个大胆的建议，这个达拉斯的无耻小公司可以与通用电气和其他东部电子巨头并驾齐驱。五角大楼不喜欢这个选择——它有另一家名称相似的供应商——所以哈格蒂不高兴地又回到了地理位置：德州仪器。

Texas Instruments today, largely because of Jack Kilby, is a global semiconductor giant, one of the world’s leading manufacturers of microelectronic devices. In 1958, though, it was just beginning to make a mark in the electronics business. The company had been born in the mid-twenties as the Geophysical Research Corporation; its business was sending sound waves deep into the earth to find potential oil drilling sites. During World War II the same deep-sounding methods proved useful for locating enemy submarines, and GRC became a defense contractor. The firm’s postwar president, Patrick Haggerty, expanded the government business to the point where manufacture of electronic instruments became more important than geophysical research. Convinced that great things were in store for his little firm, the visionary Haggerty changed the company’s name to General Instruments—an audacious suggestion that this impudent pup in Dallas could stand with General Electric and the other eastern electronics giants. The Pentagon didn’t like the choice—it had another supplier with a similar name—so Haggerty unhappily fell back on geography: Texas Instruments.

正是哈格蒂的又一次大胆尝试，让德州仪器走上了称霸之路。1952 年，晶体管还是一种稀奇古怪、不可靠的设备，每个价格为 15 美元甚至更多，哈格蒂聘请了贝尔实验室的物理学家戈登·蒂尔，并命令他开发一种可靠的量产晶体管，售价为 2.5 美元。蒂尔做到了。1954 年，哈格蒂推出了他最著名的计划：将廉价可靠的晶体管放入消费产品——袖珍收音机中。这个想法在市场上大获成功。更重要的是，它使晶体管成为一种常见的家用物品，德州仪器也成为电子行业的一个常见名称。

It was another audacious Haggerty gambit that started TI on its road to dominance. In 1952, when transistors were still exotic, unreliable devices costing $15 or more each, Haggerty hired a Bell Labs physicist named Gordon Teal and ordered him to develop a reliable mass-production transistor that would sell for $2.50. Teal did it. In 1954, Haggerty launched his most famous initiative: he put his cheap, reliable transistors into a consumer product—the pocket radio. The idea was a smash hit in the marketplace. More important, it made the transistor a common household item and Texas Instruments a common name in electronics.

和当时所有的晶体管设备一样，第一批袖珍收音机使用的是锗晶体管。锗是一种易于加工的材料，但由于不能在高温下工作，因此在许多应用中并不令人满意。另一种半导体材料硅可以耐热。但硅几乎无法加工；这种材料易碎且难以纯化，用硅制成的元件在装配线上容易破碎。哈格蒂不是那种会让不可能的制造障碍挡住自己道路的人，他命令戈登·蒂尔和物理化学家威利斯·阿德科克设计硅晶体管。在老板的命令下，该项目在世界上任何间谍机构都会钦佩的安全安排下进行。最终，哈格蒂的雄心和对保密的承诺以惊人的方式得到了回报。1954 年 5 月，蒂尔和阿德科克参加了一场关于晶体管业务制造问题的技术会议。当时的圣杯是用硅制成的晶体管，但会议上的发言者一个接一个地阐述了硅带来的无法克服的问题。最后，蒂尔站起来发言。他说，他饶有兴致地听取了有关硅可行性的悲观预测。他平静地说道：“我们公司目前生产两种硅晶体管……我刚好在外套口袋里有一些。”然后，艾德科克出现了，他拿着一台使用锗晶体管的唱片机。唱片播放时，蒂尔将晶体管浸入一桶沸腾的油中；声音停止了。接下来，蒂尔接上德州仪器的一个新硅晶体管。他把它倒进热油中；乐队继续演奏。会议在一片喧嚣中结束，因为在手机问世之前，蒂尔的演讲引发了东部各大电子公司的销售员和工程师们疯狂地涌向电话亭。《财富》杂志的一名记者无意中听到通用电气的一名销售代表在电话里喊道：“他们有硅晶体管！在德克萨斯州！！”目前尚不清楚这些事实中哪一个更令人震惊。

The first pocket radios, like all transistorized equipment of the day, used transistors made of germanium, a material easy to work with but unsatisfactory for many applications because it could not operate at high temperatures. Another semiconductor material, silicon, could withstand heat. But silicon was almost impossible to work with; the material is brittle and difficult to purify, and components made of silicon tended to shatter on the assembly line. Haggerty, not the type to let impossible manufacturing obstacles stand in his way, ordered Gordon Teal and Willis Adcock, a physical chemist, to devise a silicon transistor. On the boss’s command, the project was pursued under security arrangements that any of the world’s spy agencies would admire. In the end, Haggerty’s ambition and his commitment to secrecy paid off in spectacular fashion. In May 1954, Teal and Adcock attended a technical meeting on manufacturing problems in the transistor business. The holy grail at the time was a transistor made of silicon, but speaker after speaker at the meeting set forth the insuperable problems posed by silicon. Finally, Teal rose to speak. He had listened with interest, he said, to the bleak predictions about silicon’s feasibility. “Our company,” he noted calmly, “now has two types of silicon transistor in production. . . . I just happen to have some here in my coat pocket.” Adcock then appeared, carrying a record player that employed a germanium transistor. As a record played, Teal dunked the transistor in a vat of boiling oil; the sound stopped. Next Teal wired in one of TI’s new silicon transistors. He dumped it into the hot oil; the band played on. The meeting ended in pandemonium, for in those days long before the advent of the cellular phone, Teal’s presentation sparked a mad race to the telephone booths among salesmen and engineers from the major eastern electronics firms. A reporter from Fortune magazine overheard a sales rep from General Electric shouting into the phone: “They’ve got the silicon transistor! In Texas!!” It was not clear which of these facts was the more astounding.

德州仪器公司正在大步前进，德州仪器的工程师们开始制作越来越多雄心勃勃的设计。但很快，达拉斯的人们就意识到了数字的暴政。威利斯·阿德科克被任命负责一项重大研究，以克服电子技术进一步发展的障碍。德州仪器公司研究的首批解决方案之一是“微模块”的概念。其背后的理论是，电路的所有元件都可以以相同的尺寸和形状制造，并将线路内置在每个元件中。然后，这些相同的模块可以像儿童的乐高积木一样拼合在一起，形成即时电路。这个概念对德州仪器公司很重要，并不是因为它的内在优点，而是因为它对美国陆军很重要。每个军种都在寻求自己的互连问题解决方案，陆军迫切希望它的提案能够获得通过；如果德州仪器公司能够实现这一目标，它将成为所有陆军承包官员的宠儿。因此，当杰克·基尔比 (Jack Kilby) 于 1958 年 5 月到达 Adcock 的实验室时，微模块是当时最热门的东西。基尔比从一开始就不喜欢它。

Texas Instruments was on its way, and TI’s triumphant engineers began producing more and more ambitious designs. Soon enough, though, the tyranny of numbers became evident to the people in Dallas. Willis Adcock was placed in charge of a major research effort to surmount this obstacle to further progress in electronics. One of the first solutions TI worked on was an idea called the Micro-Module. The theory behind it was that all the components of a circuit could be manufactured in the same size and shape, with wiring built right into each component. These identical modules could then be snapped together, like a child’s Lego blocks, to make instant circuits. The concept was important to Texas Instruments, not so much because of its intrinsic merits, but because it was important to the U.S. Army. Each of the military services was pursuing its own solution to the interconnections problem, and the Army keenly desired that its proposal should prevail; if TI could deliver, it would become the darling of all Army contracting officers. Thus when Jack Kilby arrived at Adcock’s lab in May 1958, the Micro-Module was the hottest thing going. Kilby disliked it from the start.

这种感觉部分是工程师的直觉；微模块与 Centralab 失败的想法有些相似，Kilby 认为它在达拉斯不会有更好的效果。但对于像 Jack Kilby 这样的系统性问题解决者来说，真正的缺陷更为基本：微模块意味着对问题的错误定义。数字暴政带来的真正问题是数字。微模块对减少复杂电路中大量单个元件毫无作用。没有工程师能够满怀热情地解决错误的问题；想到他放弃了一份好工作，带着家人搬到全国各地，却被安排从事一个根本偏离目标的项目，Kilby 的心就沉了下去。

This feeling was partly an engineer’s intuition; the Micro-Module bore some resemblance to an idea that had flopped at Centralab, and Kilby didn’t think it would work any better in Dallas. To a systematic problem solver like Jack Kilby, though, the real flaw was more basic: the Micro-Module implied the wrong definition of the problem. The real problem posed by the tyranny of numbers was numbers. The Micro-Module did nothing to reduce the huge quantities of individual components in sophisticated circuits. No engineer could work with much enthusiasm on a solution to the wrong problem; Kilby’s heart sank at the thought that he had left a good job and moved his family across the country only to be put to work on a project that was fundamentally off target.

当时，德州仪器实行大规模休假政策；每个人都在 7 月休假几周。基尔比在公司工作的时间还不够长，没有时间休假，因此被独自留在半导体实验室。他的心情很糟糕。“我觉得，”多年后他回忆道，“假期结束后，我很可能会被安排去为微模块计划写一份提案——除非我能很快想出一个好主意。”

Texas Instruments then had a mass vacation policy; everybody took off the same few weeks in July. Kilby, who hadn’t been around long enough to earn vacation time, was left alone in the semiconductor lab. He was in a rotten mood. “I felt it likely,” he recalled years later, “that I would be put to work on a proposal for the Micro-Module program when vacation was over—unless I came up with a good idea very quickly.”

Kilby 以他的广角视角深入研究，尽可能多地了解手头的问题以及德州仪器可能解决该问题的方法。除此之外，他还仔细分析了他的新公司及其运营情况。显而易见的事实是，德州仪器对硅片的重视。为了利用在开发硅晶体管的竞赛中取得的胜利，TI 投资了数百万美元用于净化硅片并用它来制造晶体管的设备和技术。“如果德州仪器要做什么，”Jack 后来解释说，“它可能必须与硅片有关。”这个结论为 Kilby 提供了解决问题的狭隘、集中的注意力。他开始认真思考硅片。你能用硅片做什么？

Kilby plunged in with his wide-angle approach, soaking up every fact he could about the problem at hand and the ways Texas Instruments might solve it. Among much else, he took a close, analytical look at his new firm and its operations. The obvious fact that emerged was Texas Instruments’ heavy commitment to silicon. To capitalize on its victory in the race to develop silicon transistors, TI had invested millions of dollars in equipment and techniques to purify silicon and manufacture transistors with it. “If Texas Instruments was going to do something,” Jack explained later, “it probably had to involve silicon.” This conclusion provided Kilby the focus he needed for the narrow, concentrated phase of problem solving. He began to think, and think hard, about silicon. What could you do with silicon?

杰克·基尔比对这个问题的回答被称为“整体论”。这一想法改变了世界，以至于今天几乎不可能重建他提出这一想法之前的世界——因此几乎不可能认识到这一答案是多么巧妙和大胆。整体论已成为现代科学的基本组成部分，与 JJ 汤姆森大胆提出原子内部有微小带电粒子旋转一样基本和明显。然而，在 1958 年 7 月，基尔比的答案几乎不算基本。

Jack Kilby’s answer to that question has come to be known as the monolithic idea. The idea has so changed the world that it is just about impossible today to reconstruct what things were like before he thought of it—and thus it is almost impossible to appreciate how ingenious, and how daring, the answer was. The monolithic idea has become an elementary part of modern science, as fundamental, and as obvious, as J. J. Thomson’s daring suggestion that there were tiny charged particles swirling around inside the atom. In July 1958, though, Kilby’s answer was hardly elementary.

硅能做什么？早在 1958 年，人们就已经知道，如果硅中掺杂了适当的杂质，使其能够传导电荷，那么标准的半导体器件（二极管和晶体管）就可以由硅制成。但是，如果硅中没有杂质，它的电子就会被束缚在原地。没有电荷会流过这样的硅片；它会像标准电阻一样阻挡电流。Kilby 想了想：硅电阻？为什么不呢？一条未掺杂的硅可以充当电阻。它不如标准碳电阻好，但可以工作。此外，通过利用 PN 结的特性，您还可以用硅制作电容器。坦率地说，它算不上一个电容器——它的性能不如标准的金属和陶瓷电容器——但它可以工作。仔细想想，这个想法将会彻底改变电子技术，如果你能用一种材料制作电路的所有部分，那么你就可以在同一材料的整体块中一次性制造出所有部分。

What could you do with silicon? It was already known in 1958 that the standard semiconductor devices, diodes and transistors, could be made of silicon, if the silicon was doped with the proper impurities to make it conduct electric charges. But if the silicon had no impurities, its electrons would all be bound in place. No charges would flow through such a piece of silicon; it would block current just like a standard resistor. Kilby thought about that: A silicon resistor? Why not? A strip of undoped silicon could act as a resistor. It wouldn’t be as good as a standard carbon resistor, but it would work. For that matter, by taking advantage of the peculiarities of the P-N junction, you could also make a capacitor out of silicon. Not much of a capacitor, to be frank about it—its performance wouldn’t equal that of a standard metal-and-porcelain capacitor—but it would work. And come to think of it—this was the idea that would revolutionize electronics—if you could make all parts of a circuit out of one material, you could manufacture all of them, all at once, in a monolithic block of that material.

基尔比越想越觉得这个想法很有吸引力。如果所有部件都集成在一块硅片上，就不需要用电线连接任何东西了。连接可以在半导体芯片内部完成。无论电路有多复杂，都不需要焊接任何东西。没有电线，没有焊接。数字障碍将不复存在。而且，没有电线或连接，大量的元件可以挤进一个非常小的芯片中。1958 年 7 月 24 日，基尔比打开实验室笔记本，记下了他的整体构想：“可以在一块硅片上制作以下电路元件：电阻器、电容器、分布式电容器、晶体管。”他粗略地绘制了如何通过适当排列 N 型和 P 型半导体材料来实现每个元件的草图。

The more Kilby thought about it, the more appealing this notion became. If all the parts were integrated on a single slice of silicon, you wouldn’t have to wire anything together. Connections could be laid down internally within the semiconductor chip. No matter how complex the circuit was, nobody would have to solder anything together. No wires. No soldering. The numbers barrier would disappear. And without wiring or connections, an awful lot of components could be squeezed into a pretty small chip. On July 24, 1958, Kilby opened his lab notebook and wrote down the monolithic idea: “The following circuit elements could be made on a single slice: resistors, capacitor, distributed capacitor, transistor.” He made rough sketches of how each of the components could be realized by proper arrangements of N-type and P-type semiconductor material.

大约四十年后，当杰克的旧笔记本中的这句话在斯德哥尔摩的诺贝尔奖颁奖典礼上被宣读时，在一块硅片上构建整个电路的想法已经非常普遍，甚至出现在初中教科书中。然而，在 1958 年，这个建议是如此“不明显”，以至于令人震惊。“当时没有人会用半导体材料制造这些元件，”基尔比解释说。“它无法制造出很好的电阻器或电容器，而且半导体材料被认为非常昂贵。用优质半导体制造一分钱的碳电阻器似乎是愚蠢的。”用硅制造电阻器似乎和用黄金制造棚车一样合理；你也许可以做到，但何必呢？即使是基尔比一开始也有点怀疑：“你不能确定这个方案中是否存在一些真正的缺陷。”找出答案的唯一方法是建立这个集成电路的模型并进行测试。要做到这一点，基尔比需要老板的批准。

Some four decades later, when that sentence from Jack’s old notebook was read out at the Nobel Prize ceremony in Stockholm, the idea that a whole circuit could be built on a single microchip of silicon was so common it appeared in junior high textbooks. In 1958, however, this suggestion was so “nonobvious” as to be astonishing. “Nobody would have made these components out of semiconductor material then,” Kilby has explained. “It didn’t make very good resistors or capacitors, and semiconductor materials were considered incredibly expensive. To make a one-cent carbon resistor from good-quality semiconductor seemed foolish.” Building a resistor out of silicon seemed about as sensible as building a boxcar out of gold; you could probably do it, but why bother? Even Kilby was a little skeptical at first: “You couldn’t be sure that there weren’t some real flaws in the scheme somewhere.” The only way to find out was to build a model of this integrated circuit and give it a test. To do that, Kilby would need the boss’s okay.

当大家从假期回来，迫不及待地想要开始研究微模块时，基尔比向威利斯·阿德科克展示了他在笔记本上画的草图。“威利斯并不像我那么看重它，”基尔比后来回忆道。阿德科克对这个想法很感兴趣，但对它的实用性表示怀疑；“它太麻烦了，”他后来说道。它可能值得一试；但另一方面，阿德科克应该制造微模块来让陆军满意。要建立基尔比的模型，他必须从该项目中调出人员，让他们去做以前从未尝试过的任务，即用半导体构建一个完整的电路。阿德科克犹豫了。基尔比坚持了下来。最终，他们达成了一项协议：如果基尔比真的能用不同的硅片制作一个工作电阻和一个工作电容，阿德科克将授权更昂贵的努力，在单个半导体芯片上构建集成电路。基尔比煞费苦心地从一条纯硅片上雕刻出一个电阻。然后他取下一块双极硅片，连接 PN 结，制成电容器。他将这些奇怪的器件连接到测试电路中，结果成功了。阿德科克查看了一下，然后同意在单个芯片上构建完整电路。

When everybody came back from vacation, eager to get cracking on the Micro-Module, Kilby showed his notebook sketches to Willis Adcock. “Willis was not as high on it as I was,” Kilby recalled later. Adcock was intrigued with the idea but had doubts about its practicality; “it was pretty damn cumbersome,” he said afterward. It was probably worth trying; but on the other hand, Adcock was supposed to be making Micro-Modules to keep the Army happy. To build Kilby’s model, he would have to divert people from that project and put them on the previously untried task of building a complete circuit out of semiconductors. Adcock hesitated. Kilby pushed. Eventually, they made a deal: if Kilby could actually make a working resistor and a working capacitor out of separate pieces of silicon, Adcock would authorize the far more costly effort to construct an integrated circuit on a single semiconductor chip. Kilby painstakingly carved a resistor out of a strip of pure silicon. Then he took a bipolar strip of silicon and wired the P-N junction to make the capacitor. He wired these strange devices into a test circuit, and they worked. Adcock looked it over, and then okayed the attempt to construct a complete circuit on a single chip.

Adcock 选择的设计是相移振荡器电路，这是一种用于测试的经典装置，因为它包含所有四种标准电路元件。振荡器与整流器相反，它将直流电转换为交流电。如果振荡器工作，它会将稳定的直流电转换为不断来回改变方向的波动脉冲电能。这种转换清晰地显示在示波器上，示波器是一种测试设备，可以在电视屏幕上以图形方式显示电流。如果你将直流电（例如来自电池的电能）连接到示波器，稳定的电流将在屏幕上显示为一条直线，如下所示：

The design that Adcock chose was a phase-shift oscillator circuit, a classic unit for testing purposes because it involves all four of the standard circuit components. An oscillator is the opposite of a rectifier; it turns direct current into alternating current. If it works, the oscillator transforms a steady, direct current into fluctuating pulses of power that constantly change direction, back and forth, back and forth. The transformation shows up neatly on an oscilloscope, a piece of test equipment that displays electric currents graphically on a television screen. If you hook direct current—for example, from a battery—to the oscilloscope, the steady current will show up as a straight line across the screen, like this:

但是如果你在电池和示波器之间放置一个相移振荡器，振荡电流将显示为一条优美的曲线 - 正弦波 - 在屏幕上起伏，如下所示：

But if you put a phase-shift oscillator between the battery and the oscilloscope, the oscillating current will show up as a gracefully curving line—a sine wave—undulating across the screen, like this:

1958 年 9 月 12 日，杰克·基尔比 (Jack Kilby) 的片上振荡器终于准备就绪，它只有半英寸长，比牙签还窄。杰克把它粘在玻璃载玻片上，这样它就可以平放在桌子上；它上面到处都有电线伸出来。有历史感的人拍了这东西的照片，杰克突然觉得它看起来太粗糙了，有点尴尬。一群德州仪器高管聚集在实验室基尔比的区域，观察这种微小而全新的电路；杰克惊讶地看到公司董事长马克·谢泼德 (Mark Shepherd) 也在围观者之中。他心想，这东西最好能用。当然，从概念上讲，基尔比知道它会的。他已经仔细考虑过这个东西很多次了，不可能有缺陷。或者会有缺陷吗？毕竟，以前从来没有人做过这样的事情。基尔比将电池的电线连接到小型单片电路，再将电路连接到示波器时，他显得异常紧张。他摆弄着示波器上的刻度盘。他检查了连接处。他抬头看了看阿德科克，阿德科克耸耸肩，表示没事。他再次检查了连接处。他深吸了一口气。他按下了开关。立刻，一条明亮的绿色光蛇开始在屏幕上波动，形成完美的、无休止的正弦波。集成电路，即数字暴政的答案，已经起作用了。房间里的人看着正弦波，看着基尔比，看着芯片，再次看着正弦波。然后每个人都露出了灿烂的笑容。电子技术的新时代已经诞生。

On September 12, 1958, Jack Kilby’s oscillator-on-a-chip, half an inch long and narrower than a toothpick, was finally ready. Jack had glued it to a glass slide so that it would sit flat on the table; it had wires sticking out here and there. Somebody with a sense of history took a picture of the thing, and Jack suddenly felt kind of embarrassed about how crude it looked. A group of Texas Instruments executives gathered in Kilby’s area in the lab to observe this tiny and wholly new species of circuit; Jack was surprised to see the chairman of the company, Mark Shepherd, among the onlookers. This thing had better work, he thought to himself. Conceptually, of course, Kilby knew it would. He had thought the thing through so often, there couldn’t be a flaw. Or could there? After all, nobody had ever done anything like this before. Kilby was strangely nervous as he hooked up the wires from the battery to his small monolithic circuit, and from the circuit to the oscilloscope. He fiddled with the dials on the oscilloscope. He checked the connections. He looked up at Adcock, who gave him a here-goes-nothin’ shrug. He checked the connections again. He took a deep breath. He pushed the switch. Immediately a bright green snake of light started undulating across the screen in a perfect, unending sine wave. The integrated circuit, the answer to the tyranny of numbers, had worked. The men in the room looked at the sine wave, looked at Kilby, looked at the chip, looked at the sine wave again. Then everybody broke into broad smiles. A new era in electronics had been born.

4

4

洞察力的飞跃

LEAP OF INSIGHT

小飞机从男孩的手中跳出，射向爱荷华州的蓝天。发动机轰隆隆，机身完美地盘旋着，飞机分分秒秒都飞得更高更远，飞过了镇子的尽头，远远地飞过了玉米地。当它离男孩将近一英里远时，它仍然运行着，但男孩却永远地失去了它的踪影。“那是我的第一次技术灾难，”罗伯特·诺顿·诺伊斯多年后回忆道。“是的，它比我以前造的任何模型都要好，但它不见了。”其实，它并没有不见。六个月后，在收获季节，一位农民在玉米秸中发现了这架玩具飞机，他猜想它可能是牧师儿子的作品，因为他总是喜欢摆弄发动机、小玩意和模型。

The little airplane jumped from the boy’s hand and shot off into the blue Iowa sky, the engine purring, the body spiraling perfectly, the plane racing higher and farther away every second, soaring right past the end of town and far out over the cornfields. It was almost a mile away, still performing beautifully, when he lost sight of it for good. “That was my first technological disaster,” Robert Norton Noyce recalled many years later. “Yeah, it worked a lot better than any model I’d ever built before, but it was gone.” Actually, it wasn’t gone. Six months later, during the harvest, a farmer found the toy plane among the cornstalks and guessed that it was probably the work of the minister’s son, who was always messing around with engines and gadgets and models.

不过，到那时，这个男孩已经转向了其他领域。那架失踪的飞机促使他为他的下一个模型制造了一个无线电控制装置。无线电非常有趣，鲍勃·诺伊斯和一个伙伴组装了一对简陋的收发器来来回回发送信息。这两个男孩都没有获得无线电操作员执照，这使得他们的网络成为联邦犯罪；现在可以安全地报告这一罪行，因为他们违法的诉讼时效在 1942 年左右到期。男孩们对化学产生了兴趣；很快，鲍勃就用火棉和三碘化氮混合了他自己的自制炸药。然后他找到了一个旧洗衣机的马达，并试图让它驱动他的自行车。然后又有了其他的东西，之后又有了其他的东西。“我是一个非常好奇的孩子，”诺伊斯后来回忆道。“我总是想弄清楚一切是如何运作的。”

By then, though, the boy had moved on to other things. That lost airplane had prompted him to build a radio control unit for his next model. Radio proved so interesting that Bob Noyce and a buddy put together a pair of crude transceivers to send messages back and forth. Neither boy obtained a radio operator’s license, making their network a federal offense; the crime can safely be reported now because the statute of limitations for their violation expired about 1942. The boys got interested in chemistry; soon Bob was mixing his own home-brew explosives out of gun cotton and nitrogen tri-iodide. Then he found an old washing machine motor and tried to make it drive his bicycle. Then there was something else, and something else after that. “I was a pretty curious kid,” Noyce said later, looking back. “I was always trying to figure out how everything worked.”

有些事情永远不会改变。罗伯特·诺伊斯（Robert N. Noyce）最引人注目的地方在于他兴趣广泛、活动广泛。直到他去世的那一天，他仍然想知道一切是如何运作的。在他职业生涯的不同阶段，他曾是理论物理学家、发明家、企业首席执行官、风险投资家、说客，最终成为美国半导体行业的资深政治家和主要发言人。他的同事和竞争对手称他为“硅谷市长”，唯一的问题是，在他生命的最后十年左右，他的影响力远远超出了硅谷。他是一名成功的科学家和工程师——他获得了一系列学术和工业奖项，如果他活得足够长，肯定会和杰克·基尔比（Jack Kilby）一起获得诺贝尔奖。但他作为一名企业家更成功——事实上，他为世纪之交的典型现象——高科技千万富翁——树立了榜样。鲍勃·诺伊斯是硅谷人第一个证明聪明的工程师能够将自己的技术才能转化为无限财富的人。到 1990 年，他的净资产估计已接近 10 亿美元，与当时的比尔·盖茨大致相当。工作之余，他修复旧飞机，帮助规划哈佛的未来，滑雪，学习日语，并以最大的精力和决心从事他好奇心所向的一切。

Some things never change. The most striking thing about Robert N. Noyce—the grownup version, that is—was the enormous range of his interests and the breadth of his activities. Until the day he died, he still wanted to know how everything worked. At various stages of his professional career he was a theoretical physicist, an inventor, a corporate chief executive, a venture capitalist, a lobbyist, and eventually, elder statesman and leading spokesman for the American semiconductor industry. His colleagues and competitors called him “the mayor of Silicon Valley,” and the only problem with that title was that his influence reached well beyond Silicon Valley in his last decade or so. He was successful as a scientist and engineer—he won a slew of academic and industrial awards, and surely would have shared the Nobel Prize with Jack Kilby if he had lived long enough. But he was even more successful as an entrepreneur—indeed, he set the mold for that classic turn-of-the-century phenomenon, the high-tech multimillionaire. It was Bob Noyce who first demonstrated to the denizens of Silicon Valley that a clever engineer could turn his technical talent into boundless wealth. By 1990, estimates of his net worth ranged toward the billion-dollar mark, which put him roughly in the same league as Bill Gates at the time. Off the job, he restored old airplanes and helped plan Harvard’s future and skied and studied Japanese and took up, with maximum energy and commitment, whatever else his far-flung curiosity fastened upon.

诺伊斯性格和蔼可亲，生性善于交际，他似乎在从事的大多数事情上都倾向于担任领导职务。20 世纪 80 年代初，他对牧歌演唱产生了兴趣。他学习、练习，并加入了合唱团；很快，他就成为了合唱团的指挥。一位朋友曾带诺伊斯参加奥杜邦协会的会议；很快，他就负责指导一项全球行动，为一种正在减少的纽芬兰海鹦物种寻找新的栖息地。几年前，硅谷的一大群高管认为微电子行业需要一个专业组织，诺伊斯就是其中一员；很快，诺伊斯就成为了半导体行业协会的主席。

An affable, naturally gregarious person, Noyce seemed to gravitate to a leadership position in most things he undertook. In the early 1980s, he got interested in madrigal singing. He studied, practiced, and joined a chorus; soon enough, he became its conductor. A friend once took Noyce to an Audubon Society meeting; soon enough, he was supervising a global effort to find a new habitat for a dwindling species of Newfoundland puffin. He was one member of a large group of Silicon Valley executives who decided a few years back that the microelectronics business needed a professional organization; soon enough, Noyce was chairman of the Semiconductor Industry Association.

诺伊斯身材瘦削，体魄强健，五官棱角分明，一头卷发在 60 多岁时变成了银白色。他举止优雅，自信满满，就像赛车手或喷气式飞机飞行员一样（尽管诺伊斯清楚地记得第一次事故，但他一直对飞机很着迷，驾驶的是一架重建的 Republic Seabee 水上飞机，这是一架二战时期的飞机）。他衣着时尚，戴着银边飞行员眼镜，戴着一枚大金戒指，还有一块白金手表，上面有老式指针和新式数字读数。如果说杰克·基尔比 (Jack Kilby) 看起来像一根多余的绳子，那么诺伊斯则是一根充满活力和热情的弹簧。当《哈佛商业评论》请他描述英特尔 (Intel) 的员工时，诺伊斯的回答可以作为他的自画像。英特尔是他共同创立的一家非常成功的微芯片公司。 “高成就者喜欢被衡量，否则他们就无法向自己证明他们取得了成就。”诺伊斯补充道，在这样的人中，“我认为你不能称之为轻松的氛围。这是一个自信的环境，但并不轻松。”自信但很少放松的高成就者——这个描述非常适合鲍勃·诺伊斯。诺伊斯在英特尔的助手之一安德鲁·格鲁夫在 20 世纪 90 年代接任该公司董事长，他对这种高度紧张的企业文化给出了更令人不寒而栗的描述：“只有偏执狂才能生存。”

A wiry, athletic-looking man with angular features and curly hair that went silvery gray in his sixties, Noyce carried himself with the rakish self-assurance of a racing driver or jet pilot (despite a clear memory of that first disaster, Noyce was always fascinated with airplanes and flew a rebuilt Republic Seabee, a World War II seaplane). A fashionable dresser, he wore silver-rimmed aviator glasses, a large gold ring, and a platinum watch that had both old-style hands and new-style digital readout. If Jack Kilby seems as loose as a spare piece of string, Noyce was a coiled spring of energy and enthusiasm. When the Harvard Business Review asked him to describe the employees of Intel, the massively successful microchip company he cofounded, Noyce responded with an answer that might serve as a self-portrait. “They’re high achievers,” he said. “High achievers love to be measured, when you really come down to it, because otherwise they can’t prove to themselves that they’re achieving.” Among such people, Noyce added, “I don’t think you could call it a relaxed atmosphere. A confident environment, but not a relaxed one.” A confident, but rarely relaxed, high achiever—that description fit Bob Noyce perfectly. One of Noyce’s acolytes at Intel, Andrew Grove, who took over as chairman of the firm in the 1990s, offered a somewhat more chilling description of the high-tension corporate culture: “Only the paranoid survive.”

诺伊斯执掌英特尔期间，英特尔很难放松的一个原因是，公司刻意保持技术领先，始终在寻找新创意。事实上，英特尔仍然以这种方式运营，尽管这位元老已经离开十多年了。罗伯特·诺伊斯喜欢这种方式；他把自己定义为“技术专家”，并将这个词定义为“敢于承担风险的人”。诺伊斯说，这就是技术专家和商人之间的关键区别：“没有商人会开发电话。必须是一个特立独行的人——某个一直与聋人打交道的人，突然想到可以通过电线传送人的声音……商人会出去做市场调查，由于那是一种不存在的产品，他会确凿地证明电话的市场为零。”

One reason it was difficult to relax at Intel when Noyce was running the place was that the firm deliberately kept itself on the leading edge of technology, always looking for the new idea. Actually, that’s the way Intel still operates, more than a dozen years since the patriarch left. That’s the way Robert Noyce liked it; he defined himself as a “technologist,” and defined that term as “the kind of person who is comfortable with risk.” And there lies the key difference between a technologist and a businessman, Noyce said: “No businessman would have developed the telephone. It’s got to be a maverick—some guy who’s been working with the deaf and gets the crazy idea that you could actually send the human voice over a wire. . . . A businessman would have been out taking a market survey, and since it was a nonexistent product, he would have proven conclusively that the market for a telephone was zero.”

同样的描述——“敢于承担风险”——也适用于诺伊斯解决问题的方法。他满怀信心地攻克工程难题，坚信某个地方一定有一个完美的解决方案，人类的大脑一定能找到它。他自己也是一位多产、冲动的解决方案创造者，但他也知道“当你仔细观察时，你会发现我的许多伟大想法都是荒谬的。”因此，诺伊斯从来都不是像杰克·基尔比那样的孤独发明家。他需要与他人合作，讨论事情，提出自己的想法，看看它们是否可行。“你向自己解释了很多事情，”他说，“通过尝试向别人解释它们。然后，要么你自己发现这个想法行不通，要么别人可以发现问题并帮助你找到更好的方法。”

The same description—“comfortable with risk”—applied to Noyce’s approach to problem solving. He attacked engineering problems with absolute confidence that there was a perfectly good solution somewhere, and that the human mind could find it. He was to be a prolific, impulsive producer of solutions himself, but he also knew that “a lot of my great ideas turn out to be ridiculous when you look closely.” For that reason, Noyce was never a solitary inventor like Jack Kilby. He needed to work with others, to talk things over, to launch his ideas and see if they would fly. “You explain a lot of things to yourself,” he said, “by trying to explain them to someone else. And then either you can see for yourself that the idea won’t work, or the other person can spot the problem and help you find a better way.”

诺伊斯在职业生涯早期就得到了另一位著名技术乐观主义者威廉·肖克利的启发，显然他吸收了肖克利解决问题的第一条规则：“尝试最简单的情况。”当被要求描述寻找解决方案的正确方法时，诺伊斯这样说：“我们在任何技术领域取得的所有进步——当然，有一些洞察力的飞跃——但除此之外，它已经将其分解为最简单的元素，可理解的元素，并从最简单的元素重新构建。肖克利具有做出正确简化假设的奇妙能力，可以摆脱数学的束缚，直到您对正在发生的事情有一个基本的视觉形象……好吧，你看，你必须回到最基本的、最简单的画面，然后才能充分理解问题并解决它。”

Early in his career Noyce came into the ken of another famous technical optimist, William B. Shockley, and it is clear that he absorbed Shockley’s first rule for solving problems: “Try simplest cases.” Asked to describe the right way to find a solution, Noyce put it this way: “All of our progress, in any technical field—well, there are a few leaps of insight—but beyond that it has been decomposing it to its simplest elements, to understandable elements, and building it back up from its simplest element. Shockley had this wonderful ability to make the right simplifying assumption, to get the math out of the way until you had a basic visual image of what was happening. . . . Well, you see, you have to get back to the basic, the simplest picture before you can understand a problem well enough to solve it.”

和基尔比一样，诺伊斯往往会立即怀疑任何过于明显的解决方案。“无论是技术问题还是其他问题，很多人都会尝试用与其他人相同的方法来解决问题，这是绝对正确的，”诺伊斯说。“你可能会陷入困境。如果你不走出困境，你就无法解决问题。”能够跳过困境的人——能够成为成功发明家的人——是能够提出“洞察力飞跃”的人。“成功的解决方案之所以出现，是因为有人能够激发自己的想象力并尝试新事物……”诺伊斯补充道。“如果你想实现有价值的东西，你就必须跳出新的想法。”

Like Kilby, Noyce tended to be instantly suspicious of any solution that seemed too obvious. “It’s absolutely true, whether it’s a technical question or anything else, that a lot of people are going to try to approach a problem the same way everybody else has,” Noyce said. “You can just let yourself get in a rut. And if you don’t get out of the rut, you’re not going to solve the problem.” The person who can jump over that rut—that person, the person who can be a successful inventor—is the one who is able to come up with the “leap of insight.” “The successful solution comes about because somebody was able to fire up his imagination and try something new . . . ,” Noyce added. “If you want to achieve something worthwhile, you have to jump to the new idea.”

诺伊斯的整个童年都在追求新思想、新现象和新玩意。他于 1927 年出生在爱荷华州丹麦小镇，父亲是公理会牧师。鲍勃小时候，全家从一个乡村小镇搬到另一个小镇；当他的父亲接管格林内尔教区时，这个安静、迷人的小镇位于得梅因以东 50 英里处，全家就在那里定居了下来。虽然诺伊斯大人对技术没有特别的爱好，但他们鼓励儿子，并饶有兴致地听鲍勃和他的三个兄弟每晚讲解他们最新的实验。为了支付飞机套件、无线电零件、化学品等费用，鲍勃当过保姆和割草工。他的主要客户之一是格林内尔学院物理系主任格兰特·盖尔教授。在盖尔的指导下，诺伊斯爱上了数学和物理。他在高中时学习了大学教材，1945 年入读格林内尔学院时，他从一开始就知道物理和数学将是他的主要兴趣。当然，这不是他唯一的兴趣——鲍勃·诺伊斯的生活方式并非如此。他是格林内尔学院游泳队的明星跳水运动员，在合唱团唱歌，在乐队中演奏双簧管，并在广播肥皂剧中扮演角色。

Noyce spent his entire boyhood pursuing new ideas, new phenomena, new gadgets. He was born in 1927 in the tiny town of Denmark, Iowa, the son of a Congregationalist minister. The family moved from one small rural town to the next when Bob was small; when his father took over the parish in Grinnell, a quiet, attractive town fifty miles east of Des Moines, the family settled there for good. Although the elder Noyces had no particular penchant for technology, they encouraged their sons and listened with interest each night as Bob and his three brothers explained their latest experiments. To pay for his airplane kits, radio parts, chemicals, etc., Bob worked as a baby-sitter and mower of lawns. One of his chief customers was Professor Grant Gale, chairman of the physics department at Grinnell College. Under Gale’s tutelage, Noyce fell in love with math and physics. He studied the college texts while in high school, and when he enrolled at Grinnell in 1945 he knew from the first that physics and math would be his major interests. Not his only interests, of course—that was not the way Bob Noyce lived. He was the star diver on Grinnell’s swimming team, he sang in choral groups, played oboe in a band, and had a continuing role in a radio soap opera.

诺伊斯的人生故事基本上是一个接一个的杰出成功的叙述，但在大学期间，他经历了一次难忘的挫折。1948 年的一个晚上，一群格林内尔男孩决定——当时这显然是合乎逻辑的——他们位于爱荷华平原中部的宿舍真正需要的是一场真正的夏威夷烤猪宴，包括烤全乳猪。任务被分派：鲍勃和另一个运动员被分配去抓猪——他们通过在附近农场的猪圈里偷出一只乳猪来完成这项任务。爱荷华州的烤猪宴取得了巨大的成功。但第二天早上，当悔改的诺伊斯承认他的罪行时，没有人笑。在爱荷华州，偷牲畜可不是件好笑的事。由于他父亲的地位和格兰特·盖尔的干预，猪肉小偷免于刑事判决，只被大学开除一个学期。他在一家保险公司工作。当他在高四期间重返格林内尔学院时，他仍然能够与同班同学一起毕业，并获得最高分并成为美国大学优等生荣誉学会会员。

Noyce’s life story was basically a narrative of one outstanding success after another, but at college he experienced an unforgettable setback. One night in 1948 a group of Grinnell boys decided—it evidently seemed logical at the time—that what their dormitory in the middle of the Iowa plains really needed was a genuine Hawaiian luau, complete with roast whole suckling pig. Tasks were divvied up: Bob and another athletic sort were assigned the job of acquiring the pig—a mission they accomplished by swiping a suckling out of the sty at a nearby farm. The Iowan luau was a great success. But the next morning, when the repentant Noyce confessed his crime, nobody was laughing. In Iowa, theft of livestock is not a humorous matter. Thanks to his father’s stature and Grant Gale’s intervention, the pork thief was spared a criminal sentence and was kicked out of college for only one semester. He spent the time working at an insurance company. When he reentered Grinnell midway through his senior year he was still able to graduate with his class, earning top grades and making Phi Beta Kappa.

诺伊斯在格林内尔学院的物理课上学到的电子学大部分都是标准的真空管——弗莱明整流器、德福雷斯特放大器，以及对这些基本设备的各种改进。然而，有一天，盖尔教授用一个完全不同的消息震惊了全班同学。盖尔曾是约翰·巴丁在威斯康星大学工程学院的同学，因此他能够获得最早的晶体管之一并向他的学生展示。这是一次令学生难忘的讲座。“它就像原子弹一样震撼了我，”诺伊斯四十年后回忆道。“这简直太令人震惊了。整个概念，你可以在没有真空的情况下实现放大。这是那些让你摆脱困境、让你以不同方式思考的想法之一。”

For the most part, the electronics Noyce learned in his physics classes at Grinnell was standard vacuum tube stuff—the Fleming rectifier, the De Forest amplifier, and various improvements to those basic devices. One day, however, Professor Gale astounded the class with news of something totally different. Gale had been a classmate of John Bardeen in the engineering school at the University of Wisconsin, and thus he was able to obtain one of the first transistors and demonstrate it to his students. It was not a lecture the student was to forget. “It hit me like the atom bomb,” Noyce recalled forty years later. “It was simply astonishing. Just the whole concept, that you could get amplification without a vacuum. It was one of those ideas that just jolts you out of the rut, gets you thinking in a different way.”

对于一名物理学学生来说，固态技术是一个全新的世界，一个全新的宇宙。诺伊斯非常聪明，他意识到这必定是未来的发展方向；真空管时代已经一去不复返了。作为一名恰逢其时的物理学学生，诺伊斯决定进入这个令人惊奇的新世界。他申请了麻省理工学院，并被录取攻读物理电子学研究生课程——当然，他被录取了。1953 年，他在那里获得了博士学位，在一长串的工作机会中筛选后，他去了费城的 Philco 公司工作，当时该公司正着手大规模开发和生产改进的晶体管。这份工作让诺伊斯有机会实践严肃的科学研究。他发表了一系列关于半导体器件的专著和论文。在一篇论文中，诺伊斯报告了低能气体放电对铂锗二极管的影响；在另一篇论文中，他证明了“直流晶体管电流放大系数”可以使用以下公式确定：

Solid-state technology was a whole new world, a whole new universe, for a student of physics. Noyce was bright enough to realize that this had to be the future; there would be no going back to the vacuum tube. As a student of physics at precisely the right moment, Noyce decided to enter this astonishing new world. He applied to MIT and was admitted to a graduate course in physical electronics—and was accepted, of course. He took his Ph.D. there in 1953, sifted through a long list of job offers, and went to work in Philadelphia for Philco, which was just embarking on a large-scale effort to develop and produce improved transistors. The job gave Noyce a chance to practice serious science. He turned out a series of monographs and papers on semiconductor devices. In one paper, Noyce reported on the effects of low-energy gas discharges on a platinum-germanium diode; in another, he demonstrated that the “dc transistor current amplification factor” could be determined using this formula:

1955 年末，诺伊斯在美国物理学会发表了一篇关于“基区扩展穿透”的论文。这篇论文引起了美国杰出的半导体专家的关注。

Late in 1955, Noyce gave a paper before the American Physical Society on “base widening punch-through.” That paper caught the eye of the nation’s preeminent semiconductor specialist.

1956 年 1 月的一天，诺伊斯接到了威廉·B·肖克利的电话。肖克利解释说，他要离开贝尔实验室，搬到加利福尼亚创办一家开发高性能晶体管的新公司。诺伊斯有兴趣面试吗？“这就像拿起电话与上帝对话一样，”诺伊斯后来回忆道。“他绝对是半导体电子领域最重要的人物。得到这份工作意味着你肯定会在大联盟中打球。”诺伊斯乘坐横跨全国的火车前往帕洛阿尔托。带着诺伊斯特有的自信，他到达的那天早上在肖克利实验室附近租了一套房子；租完房子后，他去参加面试，看看自己能否得到这份工作。他得到了这份工作，把家人安顿下来，并开始与肖克利合作开发高性能双扩散晶体管。

On a January day in 1956, Noyce received a telephone call from William B. Shockley. Shockley explained that he was leaving Bell Labs and moving to California to start a new company that would develop high-performance transistors. Would Noyce be interested in interviewing for a job? “It was like picking up the phone and talking to God,” Noyce recalled later. “He was absolutely the most important person in semiconductor electronics. Getting that job meant you would definitely be playing in the big leagues.” Noyce took a cross-country train to Palo Alto. With characteristic Noycean confidence, he spent the morning of his arrival renting a house near Shockley’s lab; that done, he went to the interview to see if he could land the job. He got it, settled his family into the new home, and set to work with Shockley on the development of a high-performance double-diffusion transistor.

肖克利设想的晶体管是一种半导体三明治结构，其中薄薄的 P 型硅（即掺杂了杂质的硅，因此含有额外的正电荷）夹在两块 N 型硅（掺杂了过量负电荷的硅）之间。（也有一些不太常见的晶体管采用相反的结构，中间是 N 型材料，两端是 P 型材料。）为了使器件发挥最佳性能，硅片的各个区域应该明确界定，而 PN 结（不同区域相交的点）应该是从 P 型到 N 型材料的急剧过渡。在 20 世纪 50 年代初期，晶体管制造商尝试了几十种不同的技术来实现晶体管可靠工作所需的精确掺杂和清晰界定的结。最终被证明是最好的工艺——至今仍在半导体制造中使用的工艺——是贝尔实验室的一项发现，称为扩散。半导体扩散的工作原理就像烧烤坑，山胡桃烟会渗入肉中，带来独特的风味。在扩散过程中，硅棒在炉中高温下被加热，然后含有适当掺杂杂质（例如硼或砷）的气体被泵入炉中。在 1000 摄氏度左右的温度下，气体中的一些杂质原子会渗入硅棒并掺杂其中，掺杂物要么是过量的电子，要么是带正电的空穴。就像烧烤厨师知道要烤多久排骨才能得到山核桃的正确味道一样，固体物理学家逐渐确定了将精确数量的杂质放在硅块的精确位置所需的适当时间和温度。因此，扩散提供了第一种有效的方法，可以生产出具有清晰界定的 N 型硅和 P 型硅区域的半导体棒。制造晶体管的工艺称为双扩散。

The transistor, as Shockley conceived it, is a semiconductor sandwich in which a thin region of P-type silicon (that is, silicon that has been doped with impurities so that it contains extra positive charges) is sandwiched between two regions of N-type silicon (silicon doped with excess negative charges). (There are also less common transistors that employ the opposite structure, with N-type material in the center and P-type on either end.) To get the best performance characteristics from the device, the separate regions of the silicon chip should be clearly defined, and the P-N junction, the point where the different regions meet, should be a sharp, sudden transition from P-type to N-type material. Through the early 1950s transistor makers tried dozens of different techniques to achieve the precise doping and the sharply defined junctions required for reliable transistor action. The process that eventually proved best—the process still used today in semiconductor manufacture—was a Bell Labs discovery called diffusion. Semiconductor diffusion works like a barbecue pit where hickory smoke seeps into the meat and imparts a distinctive flavor. In the diffusion process, a bar of silicon is cooked in a furnace at high heat, and then a gas containing the appropriate doping impurities—boron, for example, or arsenic—is pumped into the furnace. At temperatures of 1000 degrees centigrade or so, some of the impurity atoms in the gas seep into the silicon bar and dope it, either with excess electrons or with positively charged holes. In the same way that a barbecue chef knows just how long to cook the ribs to get the right taste of hickory, solid-state physicists gradually determined the proper time and temperature needed to put precise amounts of impurities at precise points on the silicon block. Thus diffusion provided the first effective means of producing a semiconductor bar with sharply defined regions of N- and P-type silicon. The process used to make transistors was called double diffusion.

一块圆形硅晶片被放入炉中，其直径约为 45 rpm 唱片的大小，厚度约为本书的五页。两种不同的杂质将分步扩散到晶片上，形成一个三层蛋糕——底部是 N 型，中间是 P 型，顶部是 N 型。然后，可以像切蛋糕一样将晶片切成数十或数十个微小的三层碎片——每个碎片都是一个 NPN 晶体管。

A round wafer of silicon, about the size of a 45 rpm record in diameter and about the thickness of five pages of this book, would be placed in the furnace. Two different kinds of impurities would be diffused onto the wafer in separate steps, leaving a three-layer cake—N-type on the bottom, P-type in the middle, N-type on top. The wafer could then be cut, like a cake, into dozens or scores of tiny three-layer pieces—each one an N-P-N transistor.

双扩散技术首次使大规模生产高精度高性能晶体管成为可能。这项技术有望为任何能够掌握其技术复杂性的组织带来丰厚利润。因此，肖克利辞去了贝尔实验室的工作，在著名科学仪器制造商总裁阿诺德·贝克曼 (Arnold Beckman) 的资金支持下，创办了一家生产双扩散晶体管的公司。这位发明家招募了他能找到的最优秀的年轻人，包括诺伊斯、约翰霍普金斯大学的物理化学家戈登·摩尔 (Gordon Moore) 和擅长理论研究的瑞士物理学家吉恩·霍尔尼 (Jean Hoerni)。肖克利已经在思考人类智力，他让每个招募的人都接受一系列心理测试。测试结果表明诺伊斯是一个内向的人，这个结论太荒谬了，肖克利应该意识到这种测试的价值。1956 年初，肖克利半导体实验室在帕洛阿尔托南部阳光明媚的山谷开业。这是硅谷第一家电子公司。

Double diffusion made possible, for the first time, the mass production of precise, high-performance transistors. The technique promised to be highly profitable for any organization that could master its technical intricacies. Shockley therefore quit Bell Labs and, with financial backing from Arnold Beckman, president of a prestigious maker of scientific instruments, started a company to produce double-diffusion transistors. The inventor recruited the best young minds he could find, including Noyce; Gordon Moore, a physical chemist from Johns Hopkins; and Jean Hoerni, a Swiss-born physicist whose strength was in theory. Already thinking about human intelligence, Shockley made each of his recruits take a battery of psychological tests. The results described Noyce as an introvert, a conclusion so ludicrous that it should have told Shockley something about the value of such tests. Early in 1956, Shockley Semiconductor Laboratories opened for business in the sunny valley south of Palo Alto. It was the first electronics firm in what was to become Silicon Valley.

罗伯特·诺伊斯的办公室里挂着一张黑白照片，照片上是一群兴高采烈的年轻科学家，他们正向面带微笑的威廉·肖克利举起香槟。这张照片拍摄于 1956 年 11 月 1 日，就在肖克利获得诺贝尔奖的消息传到帕洛阿尔托几个小时后。然而，当那张快乐的照片拍摄时，肖克利半导体实验室已经一片混乱，令人极度不快。尽管肖克利拥有丰富的技术专长，但他却被证明不是一位熟练的管理者。他不断地将他的研究人员从一个工作调到另一个工作；他似乎无法确定公司到底想要生产什么。

In Robert Noyce’s office there hung a black-and-white photo that showed a jovial crew of young scientists offering a champagne toast to the smiling William Shockley. The picture was taken on November 1, 1956, a few hours after the news of Shockley’s Nobel Prize had reached Palo Alto. By the time that happy picture was taken, however, Shockley Semiconductor Laboratories was a chaotic and thoroughly unhappy place. For all his technical expertise, Shockley had proven to be an inexpert manager. He was continually shifting his researchers from one job to another; he couldn’t seem to make up his mind what, if anything, the company was trying to produce.

“有一群为肖克利工作的人非常不高兴，”诺伊斯多年后回忆道。“他们找到贝克曼，说，嘿，这行不通……就在那时，肖克利获得了诺贝尔奖。贝克曼进退维谷。他不能解雇刚刚获得这一国际殊荣的肖克利，但他必须更换管理层，否则其他人都会离开。”最后，贝克曼坚持留在肖克利身边——并付出了巨大的代价。

“There was a group that worked for Shockley that was pretty unhappy,” Noyce recalled many years later. “And that group went to Beckman and said, hey, this isn’t working. . . . About that time, Shockley got his Nobel Prize. And Beckman was sort of between the devil and the deep blue sea. He couldn’t fire Shockley, who had just gotten this great international honor, but he had to change the management or else everyone else would leave.” In the end, Beckman stuck with Shockley—and paid a huge price.

困惑和沮丧之下，包括诺伊斯、摩尔和霍尔尼在内的八位年轻科学家决定另谋高就。肖克利称这群人为“叛逆八人”，他们后来成为先驱，因为他们建立了一种模式，此后硅谷一直效仿。他们决定以团队形式向开价最高的雇主投诚。这个不同寻常的提议传到了纽约一位投资银行家的耳中，他提出了一个反建议：这八位科学家不应该为别人工作，而应该自己创办公司。这位银行家知道有一位投资者愿意提供支持，那就是仙童照相机和仪器公司，该公司一直在努力寻找进入晶体管业务的机会。于是双方达成了协议。八位年轻科学家每人拿出 500 美元定金，天使投资人拿出其余全部资金，1957 年初，仙童半导体公司开业，距离肖克利的工厂只有一英里左右。

Confused and frustrated, eight of the young scientists, including Noyce, Moore, and Hoerni, decided to look for another place to work. That first group—Shockley called them “the traitorous eight”—turned out to be pioneers, for they established a pattern that has been followed time and again in Silicon Valley ever since. They decided to offer themselves as a team to whichever employer made the best offer. Word of this unusual proposal reached an investment banker in New York, who offered a counterproposal: Instead of working for somebody else, the eight scientists should start their own firm. The banker knew of an investor who would provide the backing—the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation, which had been looking hard for an entrée to the transistor business. A deal was struck. Each of the eight young scientists put up $500 in earnest money, the corporate angel put up all the rest, and early in 1957 the Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation opened for business, a mile or so down the road from Shockley’s operation.

诺伊斯回忆说，当时他们对于经营自己的企业有些疑虑，但这些疑虑很容易被“第一次意识到有机会赚到比你梦想的更多的钱”所克服。事实上，梦想成真了。即使以高科技标准来看，那 500 美元也是一笔惊人的投资。1968 年，创始人将他们在仙童半导体公司的股份卖回给母公司；诺伊斯的收益——他最初 500 美元投资的回报——达到了 25 万美元。诺伊斯和他的朋友戈登·摩尔当时已经找到了另一位金融支持者，并成立了一家新公司英特尔公司（名称来自英特尔公司和集成电路公司）。英特尔最初生产计算机内存芯片，这项业务迅速发展。英特尔的股票于 1971 年首次公开交易——巧合的是，同一天花花公子企业也上市了。上市第一天，两家公司的股票价格差不多；一年后，英特尔的股价是花花公子的两倍多。“华尔街已经发话了，”一位投资分析师表示。“这是回忆胜过乳房。”如今，英特尔是一家价值数十亿美元的公司，任何持有创始集团在该公司股份的人都已经是亿万富翁了。

Noyce recalled that the group had some slight qualms about running their own business, but these doubts were easily overcome by “the realization, for the first time, that you had a chance at making more money than you ever dreamed of.” The dream, as it happened, came true. Even by high-tech standards, that $500 turned out to be a spectacular investment. In 1968 the founders sold their share of Fairchild Semiconductor back to the parent company; Noyce’s proceeds—the return on his initial $500 investment—came to $250,000. Noyce and his friend Gordon Moore had by then found another financial backer and started a new firm, Intel Corporation (the name is a play on both Intelligence and Integrated Electronics). Intel started out making chips for computer memories, a business that took off like a rocket. Intel’s shares were traded publicly for the first time in 1971—on the same day, coincidentally, that Playboy Enterprises went public. On that first day, stock in the two firms was about equally priced; a year later, Intel’s shares were worth more than twice as much as Playboy’s. “Wall Street has spoken,” an investment analyst observed. “It’s memories over mammaries.” Today, Intel is a multibillion-dollar company, and anybody who held on to the founding group’s stake in the company is a billionaire several times over.

1957 年创办仙童半导体公司的那些人决心制造双扩散晶体管，但他们也希望开发其他可以盈利的产品。诺伊斯作为研发总监，负责发现仙童半导体可能有利可图的重要技术问题。在技术发展史上的这个时刻，不需要天才就能发现电子行业迄今为止面临的最重要问题：数字暴政。整个 1957 年和 1958 年，诺伊斯断断续续地思考着互连问题。他后来回想起来说，单片机的想法应该更早出现。“我们当时在一家工厂里，在一个晶圆上以完美的阵列制造所有这些晶体管，”诺伊斯说，“然后我们将它们切成小块，不得不雇佣数千名拿着镊子的女性将它们捡起并尝试将它们连接在一起。这看起来太愚蠢了。它成本高，不可靠，明显限制了可以构建的电路的复杂性。这是一个严重的问题。答案当然是，一开始就不要把它们分开。但当时没人意识到这一点。”相反，诺伊斯陷入了困境。他致力于将电路元件制作成更小尺寸和统一形状的标准想法。他没有想出任何有价值的东西。

The men who started Fairchild Semiconductor in 1957 were determined to make the double-diffusion transistor, but they were also on the outlook for any other product that could turn a profit. Noyce, as director of research and development, was the man responsible for spotting important technical problems that Fairchild might profitably solve. And it didn’t take a genius, at this point in technological history, to identify the most important problem by far facing the electronics industry: the tyranny of numbers. Off and on, all through 1957 and 1958, Noyce thought about the interconnections problem. In retrospect, he said later, the monolithic idea should have come to him much earlier. “Here we were in a factory that was making all these transistors in a perfect array on a single wafer,” Noyce said, “and then we cut them apart into tiny pieces and had to hire thousands of women with tweezers to pick them up and try to wire them together. It just seemed so stupid. It’s expensive, it’s unreliable, it clearly limits the complexity of the circuits you can build. It was an acute problem. The answer, of course, was, don’t cut them apart in the first place. But nobody realized that then.” Instead, Noyce was stuck in a rut. He worked on standard ideas for making circuit components in smaller sizes and uniform shapes. He came up with nothing worthwhile.

无法摆脱困境的诺伊斯将注意力转向了另一个技术难题。双扩散晶体管（NPN 硅的微型三层芯片）极易受到污染。一粒灰尘、一团杂散电荷、一丝污染气体都会破坏 PN 结并影响晶体管的功能。1958 年的一天，吉恩·霍尔尼 (Jean Hoerni) 向诺伊斯提出了一个理论上的解决方案：他将在 NPN 芯片顶部放置一层氧化硅，就像在三层蛋糕上加糖霜一样。氧化物会牢牢地粘在硅上并保护其免受污染。“这是在二氧化硅茧内建造晶体管，”诺伊斯解释说，“这样它就不会受到污染。这就像在丛林中搭建手术室。你把病人放在一个塑料袋里，在里面做手术，这样就不会有丛林里的所有苍蝇坐在伤口上。”

Unable to get out of the rut, Noyce turned his attention to another technical dilemma. Double-diffusion transistors—the tiny three-layer chips of N-P-N silicon—were highly susceptible to contamination. A piece of dust, a stray electric charge, a minute whiff of contaminating gas would break down the P-N junctions and impair transistor action. One day in 1958, Jean Hoerni came to Noyce with a theoretical solution: He would place a layer of silicon oxide on top of the N-P-N chip, like icing atop the three-layer cake. The oxide would hold fast to the silicon and protect it from contaminants. “It’s building a transistor inside a cocoon of silicon dioxide,” Noyce explained, “so that it never gets contaminated. It’s like setting up your jungle operating room. You put the patient inside a plastic bag and you operate inside of that, and you don’t have all the flies of the jungle sitting on the wound.”

费尔柴尔德公司的人认为霍尔尼的创意（之所以称之为平面工艺，是因为它在硅的顶部留下了一层平坦的氧化物）是晶体管技术的一项重要进步。诺伊斯很快请来公司的专利律师约翰·拉尔斯，让他准备一份专利申请。拉尔斯意识到这个平面创意可能在电子领域有其他应用，因此想用最宽泛的语言来写申请书。他告诉诺伊斯费尔柴尔德公司应该尽可能地让申请书具有广泛的应用范围。每次他们谈到平面专利时，拉尔斯都会提出一个挑战：“你还能用这个想法做什么？”

The people at Fairchild recognized Hoerni’s idea—it was called the planar process because it left a flat plane of oxide atop the silicon—as an important advance in transistor technology. Noyce quickly called in the firm’s patent lawyer, John Ralls, to put together a patent application. Ralls, sensing that this planar idea might have other applications in electronics, wanted to write the application in the broadest language. He told Noyce that Fairchild should make the application as expansive as it possibly could. Every time they talked about the planar patent, Ralls would pose a challenge: “What else can you do with this idea?”

多年后回首往事，诺伊斯清楚地看到，正是律师的问题将他从思维困境中拉了出来，激发了他顿悟的飞跃，并最终形成了这个铁板钉钉的想法。还有什么？你还能做什么？1959 年的头几周，诺伊斯一直在认真思考这个问题，在笔记本上画画，与他沉稳谨慎的朋友戈登·摩尔 (Gordon Moore) 连续几个小时讨论这个问题。

Looking back years later, Noyce could see clearly that it was the lawyer’s question that pushed him out of his mental rut and provoked the leap of insight that became the monolithic idea. What else? What else could you do? In the first weeks of 1959, Noyce was thinking hard about that question, scratching pictures in his notebook, talking things over hour after hour with his sedate, cautious friend Gordon Moore.

当诺伊斯研究霍尔尼的平面设计时，他意识到它还有另一个有用的特性。当时，很难将 NPN 晶体管的各个区域精确地连接到一起，因为与芯片的微小区域相比，导线相对较大。霍尔尼在三层硅片上涂上氧化物糖霜，解决了这个问题。连接导线可以像蛋糕上的蜡烛一样穿过糖霜，并可以插入芯片上需要连接的准确位置。氧化物会将它们牢牢固定住。“记住，我试图让这个 [晶体管] 变得非常小，”诺伊斯解释说。“嗯，我不能把导线连接到那里，因为它太小了。但现在，有了平面涂层，我可以将一根大旧导线连接到氧化物上——大旧导线，你知道，只有四分之一根人类的头发。”

As Noyce looked over Hoerni’s planar idea, he realized that it had another useful property. It was quite difficult in those days to make precise electrical connections to the separate regions of an N-P-N transistor, because wires were relatively large compared to the tiny regions of the chip. Hoerni’s oxide icing, spread atop the three-layer silicon cake, helped solve this problem. Connecting wires could be poked down through the icing like candles on a cake, and they could be inserted at the exact spot on the chip where the connection was needed. The oxide would keep them firmly in place. “Remember, what I’m trying to do is make this [transistor] extremely small,” Noyce explained. “Well, I can’t attach a wire to that, because it’s too small. But now, with the planar coating, I can attach a big old wire—big old wire, this is, you know, a quarter of a human hair—running it on top of the oxide.”

这一认识催生出了一个新想法，甚至更好：根本不需要电线。诺伊斯现在发现，可以将细小的铜线或其他金属线印刷在氧化层顶部，而不是戳穿氧化层。这种方法的优势在于，印刷比对齐和插入细小电线是一种更快的工业工艺。通过将“电线”印刷在氧化涂层顶部，晶体管的所有互连、所有电线都可以在单个制造过程中一次性完成。

And that realization led to a new idea, something that was even better: wires wouldn’t be needed at all. Noyce now saw that tiny lines of copper or some other metal could be printed on top of the oxide layer rather than poked down through. The advantage of this approach was that printing is a faster industrial process than aligning and inserting tiny wires. With the “wires” printed on top of the oxide coating, all the transistor’s interconnections, all the wires, could be made in one fell swoop in a single manufacturing process.

但是等一下，诺伊斯想。我们可以更进一步。如果你能用这些印刷金属线连接单个晶体管的不同区域，那么你就可以在一块硅片上放置两个独立的晶体管，并用印刷线将它们连接起来。为什么只局限于晶体管？如果你能把两个晶体管放在一块硅片上，难道你不能在同一块芯片上制造一些其他电路元件吗？在同一块芯片上内置一个电阻怎么样？在里面放一个电容器怎么样？事实上，难道你不能在一块硅片上建立一个完整的电路、一个集成电路吗？这难道不能克服数字的暴政吗？

But wait a minute, Noyce thought. We can carry this even further. If you could connect the separate regions of a single transistor with these printed metal lines, then you could put two separate transistors on a single piece of silicon and connect them with the printed lines. And why stop with transistors? If you could put two transistors on a single chip of silicon, couldn’t you build some other circuit components on the same chip? How about a resistor built into the same chip? How about a capacitor in there? Couldn’t you, in fact, build a complete circuit, an integrated circuit, all on a single chip of silicon? Wouldn’t that overcome the tyranny of numbers?

“我不记得什么时候突然灵光一闪，整个想法就诞生了，”诺伊斯说。“更像是每天你都会说，好吧，如果我能做这个，那么也许我也能做那个，这样我就能做这个，最终你就有了这个想法。”

“I don’t remember any time when a light bulb went off and the whole thing was there,” Noyce said. “It was more like, every day, you would say, Well, if I could do this, then maybe I could do that, and that would let me do this, and eventually you had the concept.”

有一天，诺伊斯走进摩尔的办公室，在黑板上向他展示了一个硅块中的两个晶体管可以通过氧化层上的印刷铜线连接起来。几天后，他又回到了黑板前，向摩尔展示如何将同一块中未掺杂的硅通道用作电阻器。几天后，他在黑板上画了一个硅电容器。这完全是新东西，但摩尔没有提出任何严重的反对意见。

One day, Noyce walked into Moore’s office and showed him, on the blackboard, that two transistors in a single silicon block could be connected by printed copper lines on the oxide layer. A few days later, he was back at the blackboard, showing Moore how he could use a channel of undoped silicon in the same block as a resistor. A few days later, he was drawing a silicon capacitor on the blackboard. It was all completely new, but Moore raised no serious objections.

诺伊斯对单片集成电路的探索与杰克·基尔比的起点不同，但最终的成果是一样的。基尔比首先想到了一个（疯狂的）想法，将所有电路元件都构建在一个半导体块中；作为这个想法的补充，他意识到各种元件可以通过印在同一块上的“导线”连接起来。另一方面，诺伊斯首先想到了在半导体芯片上印制导线，然后从这个层面开始想到将所有电路元件都放在一个芯片上。这两条路线都导致了单片集成电路的出现。

Noyce’s intellectual journey to the monolithic idea began at a different starting point from Jack Kilby’s, but reached the same destination. Kilby had first hit on the (crazy) idea of building all the circuit elements in a single semiconductor block; as an addendum to that notion, he realized that the various elements could be connected by “wires” printed onto the same block. Noyce, on the other hand, arrived first at the idea of printing the wires on the semiconductor chip, and went from that level to the idea of putting all the circuit elements on a chip. Both routes led to the monolithic integrated circuit.

1959 年 1 月 23 日，“所有零件都组装起来了”，诺伊斯在实验室笔记本上用了四页纸对集成电路进行了极为完整的描述。他写道：“在许多应用中，最好在一块硅片上制造多个设备，以便能够在制造过程中实现设备之间的互连，从而减小尺寸、重量等，并降低每个有源元件的成本。”诺伊斯接着解释了如何在硅片上制造电阻器和电容器，以及如何通过直接印在芯片上的金属触点连接整个单片电路。他还绘制了计算机电路的草图——一个将两个数字相加的基本“加法器”电路——以集成形式实现。杰克·基尔比提出单片想法六个月后，鲍勃·诺伊斯也来到了同一个港口。基尔比的旅程稍快一些，但平面工艺的使用使诺伊斯的路线更加可行。

On January 23, 1959, “all the bits and pieces came together,” and Noyce filled four pages of his lab notebook with a remarkably complete description of an integrated circuit. “In many applications,” he wrote, “it would be desirable to make multiple devices on a single piece of silicon, in order to be able to make interconnections between devices as part of the manufacturing process, and thus reduce size, weight, etc. as well as cost per active element.” Noyce went on to explain how resistors and capacitors could be fabricated on a silicon chip, and how the whole monolithic circuit could be connected by metal contacts printed right onto the chip. He also set forth a rough sketch of a computer circuit—a basic “adder” circuit that would add two numbers—realized in integrated form. Six months after Jack Kilby had arrived at the monolithic idea, Bob Noyce sailed into the same port. Kilby’s journey had been slightly quicker, but the use of the planar process made the Noyce route somewhat more viable.

电子行业的消息传播得很快。到 1959 年春天，有关德州仪器公司一项重大新进展的传闻已经传到了仙童公司。没有人知道德州仪器公司究竟做了什么，但不难猜出这项突破是为了解决什么问题。诺伊斯再次请来约翰·拉尔斯，请这位律师为一个新想法准备一份专利申请——“一个单一的电路结构……便于将众多半导体器件包含在一个单一材料体内”。这一次，拉尔斯决定写一份详细、精确的专利申请，这份文件可以作为保护仙童公司免受德州仪器公司可能采取的任何法律行动的盾牌。这一战略决策将成为一场长达十年、一直打到美国最高法院的激烈法律战的决定性因素。

News travels quickly in the electronics industry. By the spring of 1959, rumors about a major new development at Texas Instruments had reached the people at Fairchild. Nobody knew exactly what TI had done, but it was not impossible to guess which problem this breakthrough was designed to solve. Noyce again called in John Ralls and asked the lawyer to prepare a patent application for a new idea—“a unitary circuit structure . . . to facilitate the inclusion of numerous semiconductor devices within a single body of material.” This time, Ralls decided to write a detailed, precise patent application, a document that could serve as a shield to protect Fairchild against any possible legal action by Texas Instruments. This strategic decision would become the decisive factor in a bitter ten-year legal battle fought all the way to the United States Supreme Court.

5

5

基尔比诉诺伊斯

KILBY V. NOYCE

1959 年 1 月 28 日上午，德州仪器半导体实验室中流传着一个可怕的谣言，但最终发现，几乎所有谣言都是错误的。但就像许多虚假警报一样，它具有吓唬人们采取行动的有益效果。杰克·基尔比成功演示了他的原型集成电路，已经过去了四个多月，但从那时起，这一概念的进一步发展几乎为零。基尔比的上司原本希望在 3 月份推出这款出色的新产品，但截至 1 月底，产品还未面世。唯一存在的集成电路是基尔比为演示而亲手制作的粗糙模型；没有人弄清楚如何生产出生产版本。甚至律师也落后于计划；他们未能采取最基本的步骤来保护德州仪器对新发明的权利。

The terrifying rumor that raced through the semiconductor lab at Texas Instruments on the morning of January 28, 1959, turned out, eventually, to be wrong on almost every count. But like many false alarms, it had the salutary effect of scaring people into action. More than four months had passed since Jack Kilby had successfully demonstrated his prototype integrated circuit, but since then further development of the concept had been almost nil. Kilby’s superiors had been hoping to introduce this fantastic new product in March, but as of the end of January, there really wasn’t any product. The only integrated circuits in existence were the crude models Kilby had built by hand for his demonstration; nobody had figured out yet how to turn out a production version. Even the lawyers were behind schedule; they had failed to take the most basic steps to protect Texas Instruments’ right to the new invention.

这就是谣言如此可怕的原因。在一次技术会议上，德州仪器的某个人以为他听到别人说，有人告诉他，另一家公司已经发明了一种集成电路，可以克服数字的暴政。事实上，这份报告中有一点是真的；就在五天前，鲍勃·诺伊斯在仙童公司的办公室里，在他的笔记本上草拟了第一个关于单片机的粗略概念。但传到达拉斯的谣言与诺伊斯无关。德州仪器的消息是，RCA 的某个人发明了一种集成电路，更糟糕的是，RCA 很快就要申请专利了。当这个令人不安的消息传到德州仪器的高级律师塞缪尔·米姆斯那里时，他毫不犹豫地给莫·莫舍打了个紧急电话。

That’s why the rumor was so frightening. At a technical meeting, somebody from TI thought he heard somebody else saying that he had been told that another company had come up with an integrated semiconductor circuit that would overcome the tyranny of numbers. There was, in fact, a germ of truth in this report; just five days earlier, Bob Noyce, in his office at Fairchild, had scratched his first sketchy concept of the monolithic idea in his notebook. But the rumor that reached Dallas had nothing to do with Noyce. The word at TI was that somebody at RCA had come up with an integrated circuit, and that—even worse—RCA was soon going to file for a patent. When this unsettling news reached Samuel M. Mims, TI’s senior staff lawyer, he didn’t hesitate a second before putting through an emergency call to Mo Mosher.

埃尔斯沃斯·H·莫舍 (Ellsworth H. Mosher) 是华盛顿特区专利律师事务所 Stevens Davis Miller & Mosher (电报地址：INVENTION) 的合伙人，也是专利律师界的资深人士，他立即意识到自己必须迅速采取行动。他派了一名初级律师前往达拉斯，并让米姆斯与基尔比坐下来，确切了解这位发明家认为他的庞大创意有什么用处。通常需要两三个月的时间才能整理好专利申请所需的所有文件、文章和图片；不过，在这种情况下，莫舍承诺在一周内向专利局提交一份完整的申请。

Ellsworth H. Mosher, name partner in the Washington, D.C., patent law firm of Stevens Davis Miller & Mosher (cable address: INVENTION) and an elder statesman of the patent bar, knew immediately that he had to act fast. He dispatched a junior lawyer to Dallas and told Mims to sit down with Kilby and find out precisely what the inventor thought his monolithic idea would be good for. It normally took two or three months to put together all the paperwork, prose, and pictures required for a patent application; in this case, though, Mosher promised to deliver a completed application to the Patent Office within a week.

莫瑟的建议——德州仪器最好尽快申请专利——并不像看上去那么明显。专利律师试图向客户传达的最重要的规则之一是，在某些情况下，最好根本不要申请专利。对于发明家来说，专利是一种浮士德式的交易。

Mosher’s advice—that Texas Instruments had better apply for a patent, and fast—was not quite so obvious as it might appear. One of the most important rules that patent lawyers try to get across to their clients is that, in some cases, it is better not to apply for a patent at all. For an inventor a patent is a sort of Faustian bargain.

专利明确保证发明者在专利有效期 20 年内“有权禁止他人制造、使用或销售”该创意。专利持有者可以选择向他人颁发许可，允许他人制造、使用或销售该创意。许可费可以带来大笔收入。如果有人试图在未获得许可的情况下销售专利产品，发明者可以向联邦法院申请禁令和金钱赔偿。这对发明者来说一点也不坏。然而，为了换取这些好处，专利持有者必须披露他成功的所有秘密。专利法规定，发明者必须“以……完整、清晰、简明和准确的措辞提供发明的书面描述，以及制造和使用发明的方式和过程”。发明者和他的公司可能花费了十二年时间和一亿美元来完善这个想法；一旦获得专利，世界上任何人都可以从专利局以 3 美元的价格获得完整、清晰、简明和准确的计划。

The patent expressly guarantees the inventor “the right to exclude others from making, using, or selling” the idea for the twenty-year life of the patent. The patent holder can, if he chooses, issue licenses to others to make, use, or sell the idea. The license fees can bring in large sums of money. If anybody tries to market the patented product without obtaining a license, the inventor can go into federal court to get an injunction and money damages. Not a bad deal at all for the inventor. In exchange for those benefits, though, the patent holder has to reveal all the secrets of his success. The patent law says that an inventor must provide “a written description of the invention, and of the manner and process of making and using it, in . . . full, clear, concise and exact terms.” The inventor and his company might have expended a dozen years and a hundred million dollars perfecting the idea; once a patent is granted, anybody in the world can acquire the plans—full, clear, concise, and exact—from the Patent Office for $3.

例如，如果约翰·S·彭伯顿在 19 世纪 80 年代中期的某一天，为自己在亚特兰大后院发明的配方申请专利，他发明的产品——一种他命名为可口可乐的软饮料——将在 1903 年专利到期时进入公共领域。从那天起，世界上任何人都可以自由酿造和销售这种饮料，而不必向可口可乐公司支付一分钱。但彭伯顿没有为他的配方申请专利，因此是秘密。即使没有专利，可口可乐也能够根据商业秘密保护法来保护其配方，该法规定故意抄袭他人的商业创意是违法的。

If, for example, John S.
