And both concluded that the logical way to handle data was in the form of binary numbers.

图灵写道，由于计算机计算是通过开关从开到关再从关到开来执行的，因此将值 1 分配给开，将值 0 分配给关，并且仅用这两个数字处理所有数学运算是很自然的。“我们强烈支持在我们的设备中使用二进制系统，”冯·诺依曼报告表示同意。计算机“自然适应二进制系统，因为我们……满足于区分[仅仅]两种状态，”他写道。“然而，二进制系统的主要优点……是可以更简单、更快速地执行基本操作。”

Since computer calculations would be performed by switches flipping from on to off and back again, Turing wrote, it was natural enough to assign the value 1 to on and 0 to off, and handle all mathematics with only those two digits. “We feel strongly in favor of the binary system for our device,” the von Neumann report agreed. The computer “is naturally adapted to the binary system since we . . . are content to distinguish [just] two states,” he wrote. “The main virtue of the binary system . . . is, however, the greater simplicity and speed with which the elementary operations can be performed.”

尽管二进制有诸多优点，但也存在一个问题——数学家称之为“转换问题”。这是一个委婉的说法，因为很少有人理解二进制系统，因此很难将计算机的答案转换成人类可以理解的形式。

For all the virtues of binary, though, there was a problem—something the mathematicians called the “conversion problem.” This was a euphemism for the fact that few humans understand the binary system and thus would find it difficult to convert a computer’s answers into a form intelligible to people.

有人提出了两种解决方案。一种是人类应该放弃十进制，学习更接近二进制的东西。在这种安排下，观看《芝麻街 》的学龄前儿童将接受这样的童谣灌输：

Two solutions were proposed. One was that the human race should drop its decimal system and learn something closer to binary. Under this arrangement, preschoolers watching Sesame Street would be indoctrinated with rhymes like this:

图灵和冯·诺依曼提出了一个更切实可行的想法，避免了人类习惯的这种急剧变化。冯·诺依曼的报告指出：“从人类的角度来看，二进制系统的一个缺点是转换问题。但是，既然人们完全知道如何将数字从一个进制转换为另一个进制……那么计算机本身没有理由不能进行这种转换。”

Such a sharp change in human habits was obviated by a more practicable idea set forth by both Turing and von Neumann. “The one disadvantage of the binary system from the human point of view,” von Neumann’s report noted, “is the conversion problem. Since, however, it is completely known how to convert numbers from one base to another . . . there is no reason why the computer itself cannot carry out this conversion.”

这个建议很快就被采纳，从那时起，所有数字设备都包含一个称为解码器的电路，它可以将十进制数转换成二进制数。当你按下按键将数字 206 输入计算器时，解码器会向八个晶体管组成的链发出电子脉冲，晶体管的排列方式如下：

This suggestion was quickly adopted, and ever since all digital devices have included a piece of circuitry called a decoder, which translates decimal numbers into their binary equivalents. When you punch the keys to put the number 206 into your calculator, the decoder sends out electronic pulses to a chain of eight transistors so that the transistors line up this way:

因此，转换为二进制格式（11001110）后，数字 206 就能够被数字机器理解。

Thus transformed to binary format—11001110—the number 206 becomes comprehensible to a digital machine.

正是冯·诺依曼、图灵等人的天才才弄清了如何使用二进制数和二进制数学将一连串无生命的电子开关变成强大的计算工具。但计算机先驱们并没有止步于此。他们还设计了一个完整的逻辑系统，使机器能够做出决策和比较，从而通过复杂的模式或“程序”来处理文字和数字。这个逻辑系统的美妙之处在于它也是二进制的；它可以由充满晶体管的集成电路来实现，这些晶体管除了打开和关闭之外什么也不做。

It was human genius on the part of von Neumann, Turing, and others like them that figured out how to use binary numbers and binary math to turn an inert chain of electronic switches into a powerful computational tool. But the computer pioneers did not stop there. They also designed a complete system of logic that permits machines to make decisions and comparisons and thus work through complex patterns, or “programs,” for manipulating words and numbers. The beauty of this logic system is that it, too, is binary; it can be implemented by integrated circuits full of transistors that do nothing but switch on and off.

哪位现代高科技天才发明了这种二进制逻辑？没有。当今所有数字设备使用的逻辑方法都是公元前 100 年左右（计算机出现之前）由一位名叫乔治·布尔的英国数学家发明的。

Which modern high-tech genius developed this binary logic? None. The logical methods that all digital devices use today were worked out about 100 years B.C. (before computers) by a British mathematician named George Boole.

1815 年，乔治·布尔出生在林肯郡，父亲是鞋匠，家里生活拮据。由于家庭地位低下，乔治只能从事手工业。他被送往一所职业学校，这所学校甚至没有教授拉丁语，而拉丁语是当时英国年轻人职业前途的必备条件。乔治毫不气馁，课后自学了拉丁语和希腊语。这在 1831 年派上了用场，当时 16 岁的乔治被迫辍学，帮助养家糊口。他找了一份助教的工作，但仍继续自学。17 岁时，乔治经历了两次改变他一生的经历。他阅读了牛顿的《自然哲学的数学原理》，并将注意力从古典语言转移到数学上。不久之后，当乔治独自走在一片空旷的田野上时，他突然“灵光一闪”，使他相信人类的所有心理过程都可以用简单的数学术语来表达。

Boole was born in Lincolnshire in 1815, the son of a cobbler who was always pressed for money. The family’s lowly status dictated that the boy would enter some manual trade; he was sent to a vocational school that did not even attempt to teach Latin, the sine qua non of a professional future for any English lad of that day. Undaunted, George taught himself Latin and Greek after school. This came in handy in 1831, when the sixteen-year-old boy was forced to leave school and help support the family. He took a job as an assistant teacher, but continued to educate himself. In his seventeenth year Boole had two experiences that changed his life. He read Newton’s Principia and transferred his attention from classical languages to math. Shortly afterward, while walking alone through an open field, Boole was suddenly struck with a “flash of psychological insight” that convinced him that all human mental processes could be formulated in straightforward mathematical terms.

很高兴看到，当时布尔毕生致力于阐释这一伟大理念。不幸的是，事情并非如此简单。全家现在都靠乔治供养，而他的工作又让他没有足够的时间从事复杂的数学工作。他精通拉丁语和希腊语，因此有资格成为神职人员，于是他决定接受圣职培训。然而，渐渐地，人们发现布尔的思想过于自由，不适合从事这样的职业；与英国国教不同，他怀疑《圣经》的字面真实性，并相信宗教宽容。事实上，他一生都对神职人员及其灌输思想的行为持怀疑态度。据传记作者威廉·尼尔 (William Kneale) 称，布尔临终前曾请求“不要让他的孩子落入那些通常被认为是宗教人士的手中”。

It would be pleasant to report that Boole then and there dedicated his life to the explication of this great concept. Unfortunately, things were not that easy. The family was now dependent on George for support, and his job left insufficient time for complex mathematical work. His knowledge of Latin and Greek qualified him for the clergy, and he decided to train for ordination. Gradually, though, it became clear that Boole was too much a freethinker for such a career; unlike the Anglican Church, he doubted the literal truth of the Bible and believed in religious tolerance. All his life, in fact, he was suspicious of clergymen and their efforts at indoctrination. On his deathbed, according to a biographer, William Kneale, Boole requested “that his children not be allowed to fall into the hands of those who were commonly thought religious.”

布尔致力于教学，在林肯郡开办了自己的学校，现在有时间从事数学研究。一家新杂志的编辑愿意发表布尔的论文，尽管作者缺乏正规培训。其中一篇引起了数学家奥古斯都·德·摩根的注意，他帮助布尔在爱尔兰皇后学院获得了一个教席。布尔终于有了稳定的收入，有时间去研究他对人类思想的伟大数学综合。1854 年，经过十年的紧张工作，他出版了他的杰作《思维定律，逻辑和 概率的数学理论的基础 》。书中开头写道：“以下论文的目的是研究进行推理的思维操作的基本定律；用微积分的符号语言表达它们；并在此基础上建立逻辑科学……”这篇论文完全是新奇的，甚至对专家来说都有些晦涩难懂，最初并没有产生太大的影响。今天，这本书被公认为确实建立了符号逻辑这门新科学的里程碑。

Committed to teaching, Boole opened his own school in Lincolnshire and now found some time for mathematical work. The editor of a new journal was willing to publish Boole’s papers, despite the author’s lack of formal training. One of them caught the eye of the mathematician Augustus De Morgan, who helped Boole obtain a chair at Queen’s College in Ireland. At last Boole had a secure income and the time to work out his grand mathematical synthesis of human thought. In 1854, after a decade of intense work, he published his masterwork, The Laws of Thought, on Which Are Founded the Mathematical Theories of Logic and Probabilities. “The design of the following treatise,” the book begins, “is to investigate the fundamental laws of those operations of the mind by which reasoning is performed; to give expression to them in the symbolic language of a Calculus; and upon this foundation to establish the science of Logic . . .” Completely new, and somewhat obscure even to the expert, it had little initial impact. Today the book is recognized as a milestone that did indeed establish the new science of symbolic logic.

在爱尔兰，布尔娶了玛丽·埃弗勒斯为妻，她是地理学家乔治·埃弗勒斯爵士的侄女。乔治·埃弗勒斯爵士曾勘测尼泊尔的高山，并将自己的名字留在了最高的山峰上。在他的一生中，他展现了维多利亚时代的非凡活力。除了逻辑学方面的工作外，布尔还出版了两本广泛使用的教科书和无数专著。他抽出时间写诗，包括一首名为《十四行诗致三号》的难懂抒情诗。他是女性忏悔者之家的理事，也是提早结束工作时间协会的官员，该协会致力于将工作日缩短到十小时。从一张照片上看，他是一位专注、深思熟虑的教授，长着一张方脸、一头黑发和一双锐利的眼睛。尽管他在高等数学方面取得了诸多成就，但他从未逃避教师的职责。1864 年 11 月，他在寒冷的雨中走了两英里去上课，穿着湿透的衣服继续讲课。他因此感染了肺炎并去世。他留下了最后一份手稿，这份手稿如此独特、如此神秘，以至于皇家学会的专家们都无法解读。他的遗孀评论道：“没有一个数学家能够理解它，也没有一个神学家愿意去尝试。”

In Ireland, Boole married Mary Everest, niece of Sir George Everest, the geographer who surveyed the high mountains of Nepal and left his name to the highest of all. Throughout his life, he demonstrated the phenomenal energy that characterized the Victorian age. In addition to his work on logic, Boole published two widely used textbooks and countless monographs. He found time for poetry, including a difficult lyric entitled “Sonnet to the Number Three.” He was a trustee of the Female Penitents’ Home and an officer of the Early Closing Association, which strove to reduce the workday to ten hours. A photograph shows him to be an intense, thoughtful professor with a square face, dark hair, and penetrating eyes. For all his achievements in higher math, he never shirked his duties as a teacher. In November 1864 he walked two miles through a cold rain to meet a class and proceeded with the lecture in his sodden clothes. From this he contracted pneumonia and died. He left behind one last manuscript, so singular and so arcane that the experts at the Royal Society could not decipher it. “No mere mathematician can understand it,” his widow observed, “and no theologian cares to try.”

布尔逻辑（也称为布尔代数，因为布尔用代数术语表达逻辑概念）如今已被认为是一门重要学科，学者们已将其笼罩在复杂的术语、符号和公式的面纱之下。但从本质上讲，布尔用数学术语描述的思维定律正是日常生活中的东西。布尔用语言的简单结缔组织来研究日常的心理过程：与、或、非。

Since Boolean logic—also known as Boolean algebra, because Boole expressed logical concepts in algebraic terms—is now recognized as something important, the academicians have draped it in a formidable veil of complicated jargon, symbols, and formulas. At the core, though, the Laws of Thought that Boole described in mathematical terms are the stuff of everyday life. Boole examined everyday mental processes in terms of the simple connective tissue of language: and, or, not.

你从酣睡中醒来。你是想翻个身再睡一会儿，还是必须起床去上班？要做出决定，你需要执行一个基本的布尔运算。如果你的时钟显示“是”，即已过了 8:00，日历也显示“是”，即今天是工作日，那么“是”，你就可以起床去上班。但是，如果其中一个条件为“否”，你就可以继续躺在床上。这一决定如今被称为布尔“与”运算。只有当条件 1 和条件 2 都为“是”时，结果才为“是”。

You wake up from a sound sleep. Can you roll over and sleep some more, or do you have to get up and go to work? To decide, you carry out a fundamental Boolean operation. If your clock says yes, it’s after 8:00, and your calendar says yes, it’s a weekday, then yes, you get up for work. If either of these conditions is a no, however, you can stay in bed. This decision is known today as a Boolean AND operation. The result is yes only if condition 1 AND condition 2 are both yes.

厨房水槽代表了另一种基本的布尔模式。如果没有水龙头打开，水龙头就不会流水。但是，如果热水龙头或冷水龙头打开，或者两者都打开，水就会流出。这种判断的结果为“是”，即如果条件 1 或条件 2 或两者都为“是”，则结果为“是”，这种判断被称为布尔“或”运算。

The kitchen sink represents another basic Boolean pattern. If no faucet is on, no water comes out of the spigot. But if either the hot faucet OR the cold faucet is on, OR if both are on, water will flow. This decision, in which the result is yes if condition 1 OR condition 2 OR both are yes, is known as a Boolean OR operation.

本质上，布尔证明了人类的所有推理都可以归结为一系列是或否的决策。因此，每个决策都可以用代数形式来表示。有时公式简单到x + y − z，有时则更复杂。在《思想定律》中，布尔提出了上帝存在的论证，如下：x (1 − y ) (1 − z ) + y (1 − x ) (1 − z) + z(1 − x) (1 − y) = 1。布尔最重要的代数公式（被他描述为整个是或否结构的核心支柱）是：

In essence, Boole demonstrated that all human reasoning could be reduced to a series of yes-or-no decisions. Each decision could therefore be represented in algebraic terms. Sometimes the formulas were as simple as x + y − z, and sometimes they were more complex; in The Laws of Thought, Boole formulates an argument that God exists, as follows: x(1 − y) (1 − z) + y(1 − x) (1 − z) + z(1 − x) (1 − y) = 1. The most important of Boole’s algebraic formulas—the one he describes as the central pillar of his entire yes-or-no structure—is this:

任何还记得高中代数的年轻人都会发现，这个等式只适用于两个数字：0 和 1。换句话说，布尔将所有人类决策组织成是或否的术语，结果却是一个二进制系统。这位自学成才的维多利亚时代学者比时代早了一个世纪，开发了一种决策方法，事实证明这种方法非常适合数字机器。

Anyone young enough to remember high school algebra will see that this equation holds true for two, and only two, numbers: 0 and 1. In other words, Boole’s organization of all human decisions into yes-or-no terms turned out to be a binary system. A century ahead of time, the self-taught Victorian scholar had developed a decision-making methodology that would prove just right for digital machines.

然而，在数字机器出现之前，布尔的代数学在很大程度上被忽视了，只有他的几位同行逻辑学家才关注。布尔最热心的追随者之一是牛津大学数学教授查尔斯·路特维奇·道奇森 (Charles Lutwidge Dodgson)，他撰写了一系列关于符号逻辑的学术著作，并以笔名刘易斯·卡罗尔 (Lewis Carroll) 在他的《爱丽丝》系列书中多次提到布尔的思想。爱丽丝在镜子外遇到的许多人都用基本的布尔术语看待他们的世界——是或否、真或假、是或否：

Until digital machines came along, however, Boole’s algebra was largely ignored, except by a few of his fellow logicians. One of Boole’s most avid followers was the Oxford don in mathematics Charles Lutwidge Dodgson, who wrote a series of academic works on symbolic logic and who, under his pen name, Lewis Carroll, sprinkled his “Alice” books with allusions to Boole’s ideas. Many of the people Alice meets beyond the looking glass see their world in basic Boolean terms—yes-or-no, true-or-false, does-or-doesn’t:

“你很难过，”骑士焦急地说。“让我唱首歌

安慰你吧。”“这首歌很长吗？”爱丽丝问道，因为她那天

听了很多诗。 “这首歌很长，”骑士说，“但是非常非常美。每个听我唱这首歌的人——要么会流泪，要么——” “要么什么？”…… “要么就不美，你知道。”











“You are sad,” the Knight said in an anxious tone. “Let me sing

you a song to comfort you.”

“Is it very long?” Alice asked, for she had heard a good deal of

poetry that day.

“It’s long,” said the Knight, “but it’s very, very beautiful.

Everybody that hears me sing it—either it brings the tears into

their eyes, or else—”

“Or else what?” . . .

“Or else it doesn’t, you know.”

 

 

伯特兰·罗素也是布尔的崇拜者。在《数学原理》中，罗素和阿尔弗雷德·诺斯·怀特黑德将布尔的原始概念推向了高潮，这是普罗米修斯式的努力，他们一劳永逸地奠定了所有数学的基本逻辑基础。罗素和怀特黑德的论文一丝不苟（作者用了一卷半的篇幅才证明 1 + 1 = 2），只有一小部分专家才能读懂，罗素和怀特黑德的论文似乎提供了进一步的证据（如果需要的话），即布尔将逻辑和代数奇妙地结合起来是一种缺乏实际用途的智力抽象。这几乎不是布尔的本意：“科学的抽象学说，”他在《思维定律》中写道， “应该不仅仅是智力上的满足。”然而，在它问世 50 年后，布尔的伟大著作被认为只是一种学术活动。

Bertrand Russell was another admirer. In Principia Mathematica, the Promethean effort to set down once and for all the fundamental logical basis of all mathematics, Russell and Alfred North Whitehead carried Boole’s original concept to a climactic conclusion. Unstintingly meticulous (it takes the authors one and a half volumes to arrive at their proof that 1 + 1 = 2) and inaccessible to all but a small coterie of experts, the Russell-Whitehead treatise seemed to offer further proof, if any were needed, that Boole’s curious combination of logic and algebra was an intellectual abstraction devoid of practical use. This was hardly what Boole had intended: “The abstract doctrines of science,” he writes in The Laws of Thought, “should minister to more than intellectual gratification.” Fifty years after it appeared, though, Boole’s great work was considered strictly an academic exercise.

现在，故事情节转到 1937 年，大西洋彼岸的马萨诸塞州剑桥，那里的工程师和数学家们正在努力设计数字计算机的第一个原始版本。麻省理工学院的工程师 Vannevar Bush 设计了一台使用十进制数的电子计算机；它由杆、轴和齿轮组成，齿轮旋转十分之一圈（36 度）代表数字 1，旋转十分之二圈（72 度）代表数字 2，依此类推。这种装置虽然在当时具有革命性，但往往不够精确；如果齿轮恰好旋转了 48 度或 55 度，代表的数字是什么？于是，人们的注意力转移到了哈佛，那里的另一位工程师 Howard Aiken 正在思考——就像冯·诺依曼和图灵一样——一种使用简单电子开关的二进制机器。在二进制计算机上，精度不是问题——开关要么打开，要么关闭，没有其他问题——但设计适当的开关组合来执行二进制算术是一项极其复杂的任务。

The narrative now shifts ahead to 1937 and across the Atlantic to Cambridge, Massachusetts, where groups of engineers and mathematicians were struggling to design the first primitive versions of a digital computer. An MIT engineer, Vannevar Bush, had designed an electrical calculating machine that used decimal numbers; it was built of rods, shafts, and gears arranged so that a gear would turn one tenth of a full rotation (36 degrees) to represent the number 1, two tenths (72 degrees) for 2, and so on. This device, although revolutionary for its day, tended to be imprecise; if the gear happened to turn 48 degrees, or 55 degrees, what number was represented? And so attention shifted down the street to Harvard, where another engineer, Howard Aiken, was thinking—as Von Neumann and Turing had been—about a binary machine that would use simple electrical switches. On the binary computer, precision was not a problem—the switches were either on or off, nothing else—but it was a forbiddingly complicated task to design the proper combinations of switches to carry out binary arithmetic.

曾与布什共事的麻省理工学院研究生克劳德·E·香农 (Claude E. Shannon) 正在寻找论文题目，并决定研究设计数字开关电路这一重要但艰巨的问题。在工作过程中，香农突然想到了一个至关重要的想法。

An MIT graduate student, Claude E. Shannon, who had been working with Bush, was looking for a thesis topic and decided to take on the important but formidable problem of designing digital switching circuits. In the course of his work, Shannon hit upon a crucial idea.

如果社会以智力价值为基础来分配名利，克劳德·香农就会像摇滚偶像或足球明星一样富有和出名。1916 年，他出生于密歇根州盖洛德的一个农场社区，1936 年毕业于密歇根大学，随后在麻省理工学院获得电气工程博士学位。1937 年，他的硕士论文展示了如何设计计算机数学电路；这项年轻的工作不仅成为了此后计算机架构的基石，还开创了一门名为交换理论的新学科。十年后，作为贝尔实验室的研究员，香农开始思考电子通信的有效方式（例如，如何通过单根线路发送最多数量的电话通话）。他发表了另一篇开创性的论文“通信的数学理论”，开创了一门更重要的新学科，即信息论；今天，信息论不仅是电子学和计算机科学的基础，也是语言学、社会学和许多其他领域的基础。您可能会说克劳德·香农 (Claude Shannon) 是手机界的亚历山大·格雷厄姆·贝尔 (Alexander Graham Bell)，因为如果没有香农设计的信息论基本公式，移动通信就不可能实现。

If society allocated fame and fortune on the basis of intellectual merit, Claude Shannon would have been as rich and as famous as any rock idol or football star. Born in the farm community of Gay-lord, Michigan, in 1916, he graduated from the University of Michigan in 1936 and went on to take a Ph.D. in electrical engineering at MIT. His master’s thesis, in 1937, demonstrated how computerized mathematical circuits should be designed; this youthful piece of work not only served as the cornerstone of computer architecture from then on, but also launched a new academic discipline known as switching theory. Ten years later, as a researcher at Bell Labs, Shannon got to thinking about efficient means of electronic communications (for example, how to send the largest number of telephone conversations through a single wire). He published another seminal paper, “A Mathematical Theory of Communication,” that launched an even more important new academic discipline known as information theory; today information theory is fundamental not only in electronics and computer science but also in linguistics, sociology, and numerous other fields. You could argue that Claude Shannon was the Alexander Graham Bell of the cellular phone, because mobile communications would be impossible without the basic formulas of information theory that Shannon devised.

1949 年，香农出版了一本专著，这也是第一本关于该主题的专著，名为《编写计算机下棋程序》。书中提出的想法至今仍是所有计算机游戏设计的核心，包括击败国际象棋世界冠军加里·卡斯帕罗夫的程序“深蓝”。和许多数学家一样，香农是游戏和谜题的狂热粉丝；除此之外，他还喜欢研究“全字母句子”——包含字母表中每个字母的句子。他在这个领域的代表作是一个只使用每个字母一次的句子：“Squdgy fez, blank jimp crwth vox！”

In 1949, Shannon published a monograph—once again, the first one ever written on the topic—called “Programming a Computer for Playing Chess.” The ideas set forth there are still central to the design of all computer games, including Deep Blue, the program that defeated world chess champion Garry Kasparov. Like many mathematicians, Shannon was an avid fan of games and puzzles; among other things, he liked to work out “pan-grams”—sentences that contain every letter of the alphabet. His pièce de résistance in this field is a sentence that uses each letter only once: “Squdgy fez, blank jimp crwth vox!”

对于一个在技术最前沿工作的人来说，对语言的痴迷非常有用。新概念需要新术语，而香农对高科技语言做出了多项贡献。为了寻找一个词来表示单个信息单位（用数字术语来说，就是 1 或 0），他首先创造了“二进制数字”这个短语，但很快将其缩短为“比特”。直到今天，计算机和其他数字设备的容量仍然以比特为单位；如果个人计算机的额定容量为 64 兆比特，则意味着它配备了足够的随机存取存储器来存储 6400 万比特或不同的信息。如今，世界各地的数字设计师都在使用这个术语，其中许多人可能从未听说过克劳德·香农。不过，香农并不介意。他不是那种自吹自擂的人。在麻省理工学院教授信息理论的那些年里，他从未提到他是学生所学学科的创始人，当勤奋的学生发现他们的教授才是创始人时，他似乎有些尴尬。 2001 年初，贝尔实验室为纪念香农举办了一场展览，指出他的许多 20 世纪思想已成为新世纪日常生活的一部分。香农没有参加开幕式。几周后，他去世了，几份报纸刊登了简短的讣告。几乎没有人记得他对塑造现代世界有多大的影响。

That fascination with language was useful for a man working at the very front edge of technology. New concepts required new terms, and Shannon made several contributions to the language of high-tech. Looking for a word to mean a single unit of information—in digital terms, a 1 or a 0—he first coined the phrase “binary digit” but quickly shortened that to “bit.” To this day, the capacity of computers and other digital devices is still measured in bits; if a personal computer is rated at 64 megabits, that means it comes with enough random-access memory to store 64 million bits, or distinct pieces of information. The term is now used by digital designers everywhere, many of whom have probably never heard of Claude Shannon. Shannon wouldn’t mind that, though. He was not one to blow his own horn. During the years he taught information theory at MIT, he never mentioned that he was the creator of the academic discipline his students were studying, and seemed somewhat embarrassed when diligent students figured out that their prof was the progenitor. Early in 2001, Bell Labs set up an exhibit in Shannon’s honor, noting how many of his twentieth-century ideas have become part and parcel of daily life in the new century. Shannon stayed away from the opening ceremony. A few weeks later he died, receiving brief obituaries in a few papers. Hardly anybody seemed to remember how influential he had been in shaping the modern world.

1937 年，当香农解决二进制电路设计问题时，数字计算机使用的是磁性开关，即继电器。继电器看起来像一个捕鼠器，一端有一个电磁铁。当电流流向磁铁时，它会吸引捕鼠器的金属棒，金属棒翻转，从而打开开关。一旦电流被切断，磁吸引力就会消失，金属棒就会弹回，关闭继电器。问题是如何设计这些继电器阵列，以便它们能够以正确的顺序打开和关闭以添加二进制数。这被视为一项极其困难的任务，要求设计者考虑如此多不同层次的可能变化，以至于任何人都会为此而发疯。今天，设计计算机架构的繁琐、重复的工作是留给计算机的苦差事。但在 1937 年，还没有计算机。二进制逻辑的设计将由人们来设计。

In 1937, when Shannon tackled the problem of binary circuit design, digital computers used magnetic switches called relays. A relay looks like a mousetrap with an electromagnet on one end. When electricity flows to the magnet, it attracts the metal bar of the mousetrap, which flips over and thus turns the switch on. As soon as the current is cut off, the magnetic attraction stops and the metal bar springs back, turning the relay off. The problem was how to design arrays of these relays so that they would switch on and off in the proper order to add binary numbers. This was seen as an inordinately difficult task, requiring the designer to contemplate so many different levels of possible variations that it would tend to drive anybody crazy. Today, the tedious, repetitive work of designing computer architecture is a chore left to computers. But in 1937 there weren’t any. It would be up to people to figure out the design of binary logic.

就在香农苦思冥想这个问题的时候，他偶然发现了一篇关于布尔逻辑的文章，顿时豁然开朗。布尔的“与”运算、“或”运算和其他逻辑函数方程将决策简化为一组二元性——是或否、0 或 1、真或假。香农认识到，这些对也可以用开关二元性来表示：开或关。简而言之，设计二进制逻辑电路这项极其艰巨的任务已经由乔治·布尔完成了。布尔精心设计的方程可以作为将电子开关连接在一起以执行逻辑运算的路线图。因此，香农写道：“通过继电器电路可以执行复杂的数学运算。数字可以用继电器和步进开关的位置来表示，继电器组之间的互连可以表示各种数学运算。”在论文的最后，香农展示了如何连接一系列用于执行布尔“与”和“或”运算的继电器来实现两个二进制数的相加。

While stewing over this question, Shannon happened upon a text on Boolean logic and something clicked. Boole’s equations for AND operations, OR operations, and other logical functions reduced decision making to a set of dualities—yes or no, 0 or 1, true or false. Shannon recognized that these pairs could be represented just as well by the switching duality: on or off. In short, the dreadfully formidable task of designing binary logic circuits had already been done—by George Boole. Boole’s carefully worked-out equations could serve as road maps for wiring together electric switches to carry out logical operations. Accordingly, Shannon wrote, “It is possible to perform complex mathematical operations by means of relay circuits. Numbers may be represented by the positions of relays and stepping switches, and interconnections between sets of relays can be made to represent various mathematical operations.” At the end of his paper, Shannon showed how a series of relays, arranged to carry out Boolean AND and OR operations, could be wired to add two binary numbers.

香农证明，除了数学运算之外，布尔电路还可以进行比较（数字x是否等于数字y？）并遵循“如果 A，则 B”类别的简单指令。香农写道：“事实上，任何可以用‘如果’、‘或’、‘和’等词语在有限步骤中完整描述的操作，都可以用继电器自动完成。”有了这种决策能力（根据计算结果以不同的方式进行），机器就可以被编程为执行复杂的计算，而无需人类操作员的持续指导。

In addition to mathematical operations, Shannon demonstrated, Boolean circuits could be wired to make comparisons—is number x equal to number y?—and to follow simple directions of the “If A, then B” category. “In fact, any operation that can be completely described in a finite number of steps using the words ‘if,’ ‘or,’ ‘and,’ etc.,” Shannon wrote, “can be done automatically with relays.” With this ability to make decisions—to proceed in different ways depending on the results of its calculations—the machine could be programmed to carry out complicated computations without constant direction from the human operator.

香农论文中提出的技术已被广泛用于数字机器。在现代计算机中，集成电路中嵌入的晶体管已经取代了磁继电器，但二进制开关的原理保持不变。集成电路中内置的晶体管本质上与肖克利团队开发的硅三明治相同：它由一层薄薄的 P 型硅夹在两层稍厚的 N 型硅之间组成。该设备连接起来，电流（电子浪涌）将从一个 N 型层流过中间层，然后从另一个 N 型层流出。该电流由流向中间层的信号脉冲打开和关闭。如果向中心层发送脉冲，电流将从一端流到另一端；晶体管导通。但如果中心没有收到脉冲，它会阻止从 N 到 N 的电流流动；然后开关关闭。

The techniques set forth in Shannon’s thesis have been universally adopted for digital machines. In modern computers transistors embedded in integrated circuits have replaced magnetic relays, but the principles of binary switching remain the same. A transistor built into integrated circuits is essentially the same silicon sandwich developed by Shockley’s team: it consists of a thin layer of P-type silicon sandwiched between two slightly thicker layers of N-type silicon. The device is hooked up so that current—a surge of electrons—will run from one N-type layer, through the middle, and out the other N-type layer. This current flow is switched on and off by signal pulses flowing to the middle layer. If a pulse is sent to the center layer, current will flow from end to end; the transistor is on. But if the center receives no pulse, it blocks current flow from N to N; then the switch is off.

计算机的电路是一个接一个的晶体管链。电路类似于一条长长的灌溉管道，管道内有一系列控制水流的水龙头。如果水龙头 1 打开，水就会流向水龙头 2；如果水龙头 1 打开，水就会流向水龙头 3。通过在正确的时间打开正确的水龙头组合，农民可以将水引到田地的任意位置。在计算机的电子管道中，每个晶体管都充当一个水龙头；如果晶体管 1 开启，电流就会流向晶体管 2，依此类推。通过在正确的时间打开正确的晶体管组合，计算机设计人员可以将电流引向电路中的任意位置。

A computer’s circuitry is a chain of transistors, one after another. The circuit is analogous to a long irrigation pipe with a series of faucets built into it to control the flow of water. If faucet 1 is open, water can flow along to faucet 2; if that one is open, water can flow on to faucet 3. By opening the right combination of faucets at the right time, a farmer can direct water to any point in his field. In a computer’s electronic pipeline, each transistor acts as a faucet; if transistor 1 is on, current can flow on through to transistor 2, and so on. By turning on the right combination of transistors at the right time, computer designers can direct the flow of current to any point in the circuit.

为了设置正确的组合，计算机制造商主要依靠三个基本的布尔电路。根据布尔的“与”运算，最简单的“与”电路由三个晶体管组成，它们排列成行，只有当开关 1 和开关 2 同时打开时，开关 3 才会打开。排列如下：

To set up the right combinations, computer builders rely mainly on three basic Boolean circuits. The simplest AND circuit, in accordance with Boole’s AND operation, consists of three transistors lined up so that switch 3 is on only if both switch 1 AND switch 2 are on. The arrangement looks like this:

如果开关 1 或开关 2 之一关闭，电流将被阻止，开关 3 必须关闭。只有当开关 1 和开关 2 都打开时，电流才会流过并打开开关 3。

If either switch 1 or switch 2 is off, the flow of current will be blocked and switch 3 must be off. Only if both 1 AND 2 are on will current flow through to turn on 3.

一个简单的“或”电路可以用三个按如下方式排列的开关来实现：

A simple OR circuit can be implemented with three switches arranged this way:

如果开关 1 和开关 2 都关闭，电流将被阻断，开关 3 必须关闭。但在这个电路中，电流可以流过开关 1 或开关 2 到达开关 3。因此，如果开关 1 或 2 之一打开，或者如果两个都打开，电流将流过电路以打开 3。

If both switch 1 and switch 2 are off, current flow will be blocked and switch 3 must be off. But in this circuit, current can flow through either switch 1 or switch 2 to get to switch 3. Thus if either 1 OR 2 is on, OR if both are on, current will flow through the circuit to turn on 3.

第三个基本电路称为“非”电路，它由两个开关组成，两个开关的排列方式是，第二个开关与第一个开关处于“非”状态。如果开关 1 处于打开状态，则开关 2 处于关闭状态；如果开关 1 处于关闭状态，则开关 2 处于打开状态。

The third basic circuit, called a NOT circuit, can be wired from two switches arranged so that the second is NOT in the same state as the first. If switch 1 is on, 2 is off; if 1 turns off, 2 switches on.

由于这些开关装置的作用是阻断电流或让电流通过，因此它们通常被称为门。通过将电流送过由不同门组成的迷宫，可以执行逻辑和数学运算。最简单的基本加法电路可以用十几个与门、六个或门和三个非门来实现。将表示要相加的二进制数的脉冲发送到电路中。每个脉冲都以正确的组合打开或关闭选定的晶体管，这样电路末端输出的脉冲将以二进制形式表示输入的两个数字之和。

Because these switch arrangements serve either to block current or to let it pass, they are commonly called gates. Logical and mathematical operations are carried out by sending current through a maze of different gates. A basic addition circuit, in its simplest form, can be implemented with a dozen AND gates, a half dozen OR gates, and three NOT gates. Pulses representing the binary numbers to be added are sent into the circuit. Each of these pulses turns selected transistors on or off in just the right combination so that the pulses coming out at the end of the circuit will represent, in binary, the sum of the two numbers that went in.

数学家喜欢用“优雅”这个词来形容复杂问题的简单解决方案。将两个二进制数字相加的布尔逻辑可谓优雅之极。但在早期的计算机中，这种优雅装置的电子设备却极其笨重。刚刚描述的简单加法电路带有 21 个独立门，需要大约 50 个晶体管、十几个其他元件以及错综复杂的连接线。而且这个电路只能将两个二进制数字相加。如果被加的数字每个都需要 8 个二进制数字（例如十进制数 206，用二进制表示为 11001110），那么该问题就需要通过加法电路 8 次，再加上几十个晶体管来存储每次通过的结果。

Mathematicians like to use the term “elegant” to describe a simple solution to a complex problem. The Boolean logic that adds two binary digits is the height of elegance. In the early computers, though, the electronics of this elegant arrangement were extremely cumbersome. The simple addition circuit just described, with its twenty-one separate gates, requires about fifty transistors, a dozen or so other components, and a labyrinthine spaghetti of connecting wires. And this circuit can add only two binary digits. If the numbers being added require, say, eight binary digits each—like the decimal number 206, which is 11001110 in binary—the problem would require eight separate passes through the addition circuit, plus a few dozen more transistors to store the result of each pass.

这就是为什么计算机如此容易受到数字暴政的威胁。二进制数和二进制逻辑的使用提供了一种精确的计算系统，非常适合电子设备。但这种完美契合是有代价的。代价就是复杂性。数字设备只不过是打开和关闭的开关，但许多开关必须打开和关闭许多次才能执行哪怕是简单的操作。当电子电路必须由单个元件手工连接在一起时，这些大数字在尺寸、速度、成本、功耗和设计难度方面都造成了巨大的损失。

This is why computers were so vulnerable to the tyranny of numbers. The use of binary numbers and binary logic provided a precise computational system that was perfectly suited to electronic devices. But this perfect fit came at a price. The price was complexity. Digital devices are nothing more than switches turning on and turning off, but many, many switches must turn on and off many, many times to perform even simple operations. When electronic circuits had to be hand-wired together from individual components, these large numbers took an enormous toll in size, in speed, in cost, in power consumption, in difficulty of design.

尽管在电子大会上首次亮相并不顺利，但当数字计算机刚刚发展起来时，单片机的构想注定会取得巨大成功。有了集成电路，布尔逻辑的简洁模式就可以直接映射到硅片表面上；现在，整个加法电路占用的空间和功耗都比分立元件时代的单个晶体管要小。随着芯片的出现，数字计算机终于在实践中变得和纸面上一样优雅。

Despite its inauspicious debut at the electronics convention, accordingly, the monolithic idea, conceived just as the digital computer was growing up, was destined to be a spectacular success. With integrated circuitry, the neat patterns of Boolean logic could be mapped directly onto the surface of a silicon chip; an entire addition circuit would now take up less space and consume less power than a single transistor did in the days of discrete components. With the advent of the chip, the digital computer had finally become as elegant in practice as it was on paper.

7

7

升空

BLASTING OFF

第一批集成电路的生产难度极大，以至于在芯片公开亮相后近两年，新设备才开始销售。仙童公司是第一个推出这种芯片的公司；其 1961 年春季的产品目录大力宣传了一条由六种不同的单片电路组成的新系列，并称之为“微逻辑元件”。几周后，德州仪器也推出了一系列类似的“固体电路”。正如这两家公司相当尖锐地指出的那样，新的单片电路比任何由分立部件连接在一起的传统电路更小、更轻、更快、更节能、更可靠。

The first integrated circuits proved so hard to produce that nearly two years passed after the chip’s public debut before the new device was available for sale. Fairchild was first off the block; its catalogue for spring 1961 trumpeted a new line of six different monolithic circuits which it called “Micrologic elements.” A few weeks later Texas Instruments entered the fray with a similar series of “solid circuits.” As the two companies rather stridently pointed out, the new circuit-on-a-chip was smaller, lighter, faster, more power efficient, and more reliable than any conventional circuit wired together from discrete parts.

它也更昂贵。一个“Micrologic”逻辑门电路，包含三到四个晶体管和另外六个二极管和电阻，最初的价格为 120 美元。设备制造商可以用顶级晶体管连接电路，即使算上人工成本，成本也低于这个数字。这就像一家汽车公司设计了一辆时速 500 英里的家庭旅行车，售价为 15 万美元。谁需要它？“人们自然不愿意尝试新事物，”鲍勃·诺伊斯后来回忆道。“再加上价格基本上不经济。所以一开始传统电子产品客户根本不会买。”

It was also more expensive. A “Micrologic” logic gate circuit, containing three or four transistors and another half dozen diodes and resistors, was initially priced at $120. An equipment manufacturer could wire together a circuit using top-of-the-line transistors for less than that, even after labor costs were figured in. It was as if an automobile company had designed a family station wagon that could go 500 miles per hour—and cost $150,000. Who needed it? “There was the natural reluctance to commit to something new,” Bob Noyce recalled later. “And added to that you had a price that was basically uneconomical. So at first the traditional electronics customers just weren’t buying.”

这带来了一个相当严重的问题。与大多数行业相比，电子公司严重依赖一种被称为学习曲线的经济现象。在新产品的早期阶段——当制造商仍在学习如何以合理的成本设计和生产设备时——价格必然很高。随着销售量的增加，生产技术得到改进，价格曲线急剧下降。1961 年初，集成电路停滞在曲线的高端；没有商业市场将其压低。正如诺伊斯回忆的那样，芯片似乎陷入了经典的商业困境。在市场回暖之前，价格将保持高位；但只要价格居高不下，传统电子市场就不会感兴趣。

This posed a fairly serious problem. Even more than most industries, electronics firms rely heavily on an economic phenomenon known as the learning curve. In the early life of a new product—when manufacturers are still learning how to design and produce the device at a reasonable cost—prices are necessarily high. As sales increase, better production techniques are developed, and prices curve sharply downward. The integrated circuit in early 1961 was stalled at the high end of the curve; there was no commercial market to push it down. As Noyce recalled, the chip seemed to be caught in a classic commercial Catch-22. Until the market picked up, the price would remain high; but as long as prices stayed high, the traditional electronics markets weren’t interested.

然后，几乎是在一夜之间，美国总统就创造了一个新的市场。

And then, virtually overnight, the President of the United States created a new market.

1961 年 5 月，正如《纽约时报》所指出的，“华盛顿的‘捉拿俄罗斯’情绪十分强烈”，约翰·肯尼迪在国会联席会议上提出了“一项非凡的挑战”。“我认为我们应该登月，”总统说道。“……我相信这个国家应该致力于实现这个目标，在这个十年内，让人类登上月球并安全返回地球。在这个时期，没有哪个太空项目比这更能震撼人类……而且没有哪个项目比这更难实现或花费更多。”

In May 1961—a time when, as The New York Times noted, “there was a strong catch-the-Russians mood in Washington”—John F. Kennedy went before a joint session of Congress to propose “an extraordinary challenge.” “I believe we should go to the moon,” the president said. “. . . I believe that this nation should commit itself to achieving the goal, before this decade is out, of landing a man on the moon and returning him safely to earth. No single space project in this period will be more impressive to mankind. . . . And none will be so difficult or expensive to accomplish.”

对于一个国家来说，往返月球 48 万英里的旅程确实是一项非凡的挑战，因为该国迄今为止最大的太空成就是艾伦·谢泼德驾驶自由 7 号飞船进行了 15 分钟、302 英里的亚轨道飞行。（第三位进入太空的美国人约翰·格伦直到肯尼迪发表演讲九个月后才进行了三次轨道飞行。）成功的月球之旅需要在火箭、冶金学、通信和其他领域取得重大进展。最困难的问题之一是太空专家称之为 G & N 的问题，即制导和导航。

A 480,000-mile round trip to the moon was indeed a challenge of extraordinary dimensions for a nation whose greatest space achievement so far had been Alan Shepard’s 15-minute, 302-mile suborbital flight in the spacecraft Freedom 7. (John Glenn, the third American in space, did not make his three-orbit trip until nine months after Kennedy’s speech.) A successful lunar voyage would require major advances in rocketry, metallurgy, communications, and other fields. Among the most difficult problems were those the space experts called G & N—that is, guidance and navigation.

要让一艘快速移动的宇宙飞船从一个快速移动的行星穿过两个不同的大气层和两个不同的引力场，然后精确地降落在一颗快速移动的卫星上，需要进行一系列无休止的即时更新计算，这种工作只有计算机才能完成。但宇宙飞船上的计算机必须比现有的任何计算机都更小、更轻、更快、更节能、更可靠。简而言之，有人需要这辆时速 500 英里的旅行车。而且，由于事关国家声誉，高价不是问题。“太空计划迫切需要集成电路能够提供的东西，”基尔比后来说道。“他们非常需要它，以至于他们愿意支付标准电路两倍或三倍的价格来获得它。”

The trick of steering a fast-moving spaceship from a fast-moving planet through two different atmospheres and two different gravitational fields to a precise landing on a fast-moving satellite would require an endless series of instantly updated calculations—the kind of work only a computer could do. But a computer on a spacecraft would have to be smaller, lighter, faster, more power-efficient, and more reliable than any computer in existence. In short, somebody needed that 500-mph station wagon. And with the prestige of the nation at stake, high prices were no problem. “The space program badly needed the things that an integrated circuit could provide,” Kilby said later. “They needed it so badly they were willing to pay two times or three times the price of a standard circuit to get it.”

G & N 系统对登月计划至关重要，因此其开发任务是肯尼迪演讲后授予的第一个主要主要合同。毫无疑问，计算机必须由集成电路制成，仙童公司很快就开始收到大量 Micrologic 芯片订单。到1969 年 7 月 20 日鹰号降落在宁静湾基地时——提前五个月迎接已故总统的挑战——阿波罗计划已经购买了超过一百万块集成电路。

The G & N system was so crucial to the moon shot that the assignment for its development was the first major prime contract awarded after Kennedy’s speech. There was no question that the computer would have to be built from integrated circuits, and Fairchild quickly started receiving large orders for its Micrologic chips. By the time the Eagle had landed at Tranquillity Base on July 20, 1969—meeting the late president’s challenge with five months to spare—the Apollo program had purchased more than a million integrated circuits.

二十年后，当美国半导体行业面临与日本竞争对手的全面竞争时，美国电子公司大声抱怨说，日本公司拥有不公平的优势，因为他们的大部分开发资金是由东京政府提供的。在这一点上，美国制造商住在玻璃房子里。华盛顿的政府——具体来说是美国国家航空航天局和国防部——在美国半导体行业的发展中发挥了至关重要的作用。阿波罗计划是芯片最迷人的早期应用，但还有许多其他火箭和武器计划为芯片提供了研究资金，更重要的是，当芯片仍然过于昂贵而无法与民用应用中的传统电路竞争时，它们提供了巨大的市场。1977 年发表的一项研究报告称，在芯片问世后的前 16 年里，政府提供了美国电子行业投入的所有研发资金的近一半。直到 1964 年，政府销售占据了集成电路市场的 100%，此后几年，联邦政府一直是芯片的最大买家。

Two decades later, when the American semiconductor industry was facing an all-out battle with Japanese competitors, U.S. electronics companies complained loudly that Japanese firms had an unfair advantage because much of their development funds were provided by the government in Tokyo. On this point, the American manufacturers lived in glass houses. The government in Washington—specifically, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the Defense Department—played a crucial role in the development of the American semiconductor industry. The Apollo project was the most glamorous early application of the chip, but there were numerous other rocket and weapons programs that provided research funds and, more important, large markets when the chip was still too expensive to compete against traditional circuits in civilian applications. A study published in 1977 reported that the government provided just under half of all the research and development money spent by the U.S. electronics industry in the first sixteen years of the chip’s existence. Government sales constituted 100 percent of the market for integrated circuits until 1964, and the federal government remained the largest buyer of chips for several years after that.

20 世纪 50 年代初，数字暴政首次出现，军方开始资助新型电路的研究。包含大量单个元件的复杂电路固有的问题在国防应用中尤其严重。这种电路往往又大又重，但军方需要轻便易携的设备。“导弹的一般经验法则是，每增加一磅有效载荷，就需要额外花费 10 万美元的燃料，”诺伊斯回忆道。“运送一台 50 磅重的计算机的运费甚至对五角大楼来说都太高了。”此外，太空时代的武器必须绝对可靠——对于拥有数千个元件和数千个手工焊接连接的电路来说，这一目标极难实现。当空军为第一枚现代洲际弹道导弹民兵一号订购电子设备时，规格要求每个单个元件（不仅是每个无线电装置，而且是每个无线电装置中的每个晶体管和每个电阻器）都有自己的进度表，以便记录生产、安装、检查和重新检查。测试、重新测试、再测试使每个电子零件的成本增加了一倍以上。

The military had started funding research on new types of electric circuits in the early 1950s, when the tyranny of numbers first emerged. The problems inherent in complex circuits containing large numbers of individual components were particularly severe in defense applications. Such circuits tended to be big and heavy, but the services needed equipment that was light and portable. “The general rule of thumb in a missile was that one extra pound of payload cost $100,000 worth of extra fuel,” Noyce recalled. “The shipping cost of sending up a 50-pound computer was too high even for the Pentagon.” Further, space-age weapons had to be absolutely reliable—a goal that was inordinately difficult to achieve in a circuit with several thousand components and several thousand hand-soldered connections. When the Air Force ordered electronic equipment for the Minuteman I, the first modern intercontinental ballistic missile, specifications called for every single component—not just every radio but every transistor and every resistor in every radio—to have its own individual progress chart on which production, installation, checking, and rechecking could be recorded. Testing, retesting, and re-retesting more than doubled the cost of each electronic part.

按照惯例，三个军种从三个不同的方向寻找解决方案。海军专注于“薄膜”电路，其中某些组件可以“印刷”在陶瓷基座上，从而略微降低电路的成本和尺寸；杰克·基尔比在密尔沃基中央实验室工作期间曾研究过这个想法。陆军的攻势围绕着微模块理念 - 乐高积木系统，其中不同的组件可以拼接在一起以构成任何类型的电路。基尔比刚到德州仪器时就花了几天时间研究这个概念。

In classic fashion, the three military services went off in three different directions in the search for a solution. The Navy focused on a “thin-film” circuit in which some components could be “printed” on a ceramic base, somewhat reducing the cost and size of the circuit; Jack Kilby worked on this idea for a while during his years in Milwaukee at Centralab. The Army’s line of attack centered around the Micro-Module idea—the Lego block system in which different components could be snapped together to make any sort of circuit. Kilby worked on that one for a few days when he first arrived at Texas Instruments.

随着导弹数量的不断增长，空军对小型但可靠的电子设备的需求也越来越大，于是空军想出了最激进的策略。空军决定抛弃与传统电路或传统组件有关的一切，重新开始。空军的这个项目被称为“分子电子学”，因为科学家们认为他们可以在分子的基本结构中找到一些东西，可以起到传统电阻器、二极管等的作用。鲍勃·诺伊斯在职业生涯早期就接触过分子电子学。“它的想法是，你铺一层这个，再铺一层那个，也许它就会发挥作用，”诺伊斯后来说道。“这绝对是解决任何问题的错误方法。它不是从可理解的元素构建起来的。它没有从基本原理开始，因为他们拒绝了所有的基本原理。它显然注定要失败。”空军不听。在将军们的强烈游说下，分子电子学最终获得了官僚机构的批准——联邦预算中有一个单独的项目。国会最终拨款约 500 万美元用于研究。但这个想法并未实现。

The Air Force, with a growing fleet of missiles that posed the most acute need for small but reliable electronics, came up with the most drastic strategy of all. It decided to jettison anything having to do with conventional circuits or conventional components and start over. The Air Force program was called “molecular electronics” because the scientists thought they could find something in the basic structure of the molecule that would serve the function of traditional resistors, diodes, etc. Bob Noyce brushed up against molecular electronics early in his career. “The idea of it was, well, you lay down a layer of this and a layer of that and maybe it will serve some function,” Noyce said later. “It was absolutely the wrong way to solve anything. It wasn’t built up from understandable elements. It didn’t start with fundamentals because they were rejecting all the fundamentals. It was pretty clearly destined for failure.” The Air Force wasn’t listening. With strong lobbying from the generals, molecular electronics won the ultimate bureaucratic seal of approval—a line item of its own in the federal budget. Congress eventually appropriated some $5 million in research funds. Nothing came of the idea.

当然，每个军种都渴望看到自己的方法占上风。因此，当 1958 年秋天，当这三个军种得知德州仪器公司一位名叫 Kilby 的家伙已经想出了一个既不属于陆军也不属于海军也不属于空军的数字问题解决方案时，他们有些吃惊。

Each service, naturally, was eager to see its own approach prevail. All three services, consequently, were somewhat taken aback when they learned, in the fall of 1958, that a fellow named Kilby at Texas Instruments had worked up a solution to the numbers problem that was neither Army nor Navy nor Air Force.

德州仪器的工作人员测试了第一块芯片并发现它能正常工作后，军方立即获悉了 Kilby 的新单片电路。“德州仪器一直遵循让五角大楼帮助开发项目的策略，”Kilby 后来解释道。“因此，在 1958 年秋天的某个时候，Willis [Adcock] 和我开始向军方介绍我们拥有的东西。”海军对此不感兴趣。陆军同意提供资金，但只要求证明 Kilby 的新集成电路与微模块“完全兼容”。“嗯，它根本不是微模块，”Kilby 回忆道。“但那没关系。它给了我们一些资金，我们不在乎他们怎么称呼它。如果他们想要绿色，我们就会把它漆成绿色。”为了补充陆军的微薄拨款，Adcock 和 Kilby 与空军进行了交谈。“他们不感兴趣，”Kilby 后来说道。 “我们的电路有传统的元件、电阻等，而他们的方法不会有任何传统的爵士风格。”尽管最初遭到拒绝，但阿德科克并没有放弃。他为自己的案子辩护了几个月，最终找到了一位上校，这位上校开始对分子电子学这个珍贵的概念失去信心。1959 年 6 月，美国空军同意提供一点帮助。空军有些不情愿地为芯片的开发工作支付了 100 多万美元，对于一个重大的新电子项目来说，这只是一笔微不足道的钱。（多年后，空军的公共关系部门出版了一本关于微电子的书：“集成电路的发展在很大程度上是美国空军富有想象力和进取心的领导力的故事。”）

The military services learned of Kilby’s new monolithic circuit as soon as the people at Texas Instruments had tested the first chip and found that it worked. “TI had always followed a strategy of getting the Pentagon to help with development projects,” Kilby explained later. “So sometime in the fall of 1958, Willis [Adcock] and I started telling the services what we had.” The Navy wasn’t interested. The Army agreed to provide funding, but only to prove that Kilby’s new integrated circuit was “fully compatible” with the Micro-Module. “Well, it wasn’t a Micro-Module at all,” Kilby recalled. “But that was okay. It gave us some money to work with, and we didn’t care what they called it. If they wanted it green, we’d paint it green.” Hoping to supplement the modest Army grant, Adcock and Kilby spoke to the Air Force. “They weren’t interested,” Kilby said later. “Our circuit had the traditional components, resistors, and the like, and their approach wasn’t going to have any of that traditional jazz.” Despite the initial rejection, Adcock wouldn’t give up. For months he argued his case, and eventually he found a colonel who was starting to lose faith in the cherished notion of molecular electronics. In June 1959 the Air Force agreed to help out, a little bit. Somewhat grudgingly, the service coughed up just over $1 million for developmental work on the chip, a piddling amount for a major new electronics project. (Years later, the Air Force’s public relations wing put out a book on microelectronics: “The development of integrated circuits is, in large part, the story of imaginative and aggressive leadership by the U.S. Air Force.”)

费尔柴尔德公司的事件发展则有所不同，这主要是因为鲍勃·诺伊斯对五角大楼资助的研究有不同的看法。诺伊斯在菲尔科公司担任年轻工程师时曾参与过一些国防研究和开发项目，那段经历给他留下了永远挥之不去的不快。他认为，让一位能力出众、富有创造力的工程师在一位对电子产品一知半解的陆军军官的监督下工作是不公平的，这“几乎是一种侮辱”。诺伊斯强烈认为，私营部门开展研究的正确方式是使用私人资金。如果这项研究恰好产生了对军方有用的东西，那很好，但诺伊斯不希望他的工程师局限于军事研究或受国防开发合同的限制。

Events followed a different course at Fairchild, largely because Bob Noyce had different ideas about Pentagon-funded research. Noyce had worked on some defense research and development projects when he was a young engineer at Philco, and the experience left a sour taste that never went away. It wasn’t fair, he thought—it was “almost an insult”—to ask a competent, creative engineer to work under the supervision of an Army officer who had at best a passing familiarity with electronics. The right way for the private sector to carry out research, Noyce felt strongly, was with private money. If this research happened to produce something useful for the military, fine, but Noyce did not want his engineers restricted to military research or bound by the confines of a defense development contract.

于是，仙童公司利用自己的资金将这一整体理念开发成可销售的商品。不过，诺伊斯欣然承认，公司之所以愿意这样做，很大程度上是因为其可能面向军事市场销售。“导弹计划和太空竞赛正在升温，”诺伊斯说。“这意味着先进设备市场存在，而且价格不经济……因此，人们有很大动力来生产这种产品。”

And so Fairchild developed the monolithic idea into a marketable commodity using its own funds. Noyce readily conceded, though, that the company was willing to do so in considerable part because of potential sales to the military market. “The missile program and the space race were heating up,” Noyce said. “What that meant was there was a market for advanced devices at uneconomic prices . . . so there was a lot of motivation to produce this thing.”

除了阿波罗计划，几种新型核导弹也为集成电路制导计算机提供了巨大的早期市场。第二代洲际弹道导弹民兵二号的设计者于 1962 年决定改用芯片。这一决定带来了未来三年价值 2400 万美元的电子合同，集成电路由此一飞冲天。德州仪器很快就每月向民兵计划出售 4,000 块芯片，仙童公司也获得了重要的民兵计划合同。此后不久，海军开始为其第一枚潜射洲际导弹北极星购买集成电路。到 60 年代中期，芯片已成为各种军用电子设备规格的常规要求 — — 不仅是 G & N 计算机，还有遥测编码器、红外跟踪器、罗兰接收器、航空电子仪器等等。美国宇航局于 1963 年底发射的 IMP 卫星是第一艘使用集成电子器件的太空飞行器，此后芯片成为卫星和其他太空事业的首选电路。1963 年售出了约 50 万块集成电路；第二年销量翻了两番，第三年又翻了两番，第三年又翻了两番。

In addition to the Apollo program, several new families of nuclear missiles provided large early markets for integrated-circuit guidance computers. The designers of Minuteman II, the second-generation ICBM, decided in 1962 to switch to the chip. With that decision, which led to $24 million in electronics contracts over the next three years, the integrated circuit took off. Texas Instruments was soon selling 4,000 chips per month to the Minuteman program, and Fairchild, too, landed important Minuteman contracts. Soon thereafter the Navy began buying integrated circuits for its first submarine-launched intercontinental missile, the Polaris. By the mid-sixties, chips were routinely called for in specifications for a large variety of military electronic gear—not only G & N computers but also telemetry encoders, infrared trackers, loran receivers, avionics instruments, and much more. NASA’s IMP satellite, launched late in 1963, was the first space vehicle to use integrated electronics, and thereafter chips became the circuits of choice in satellites and other space endeavors. About 500,000 integrated circuits were sold in 1963; sales quadrupled the next year, quadrupled again the year after that, and quadrupled again the year after that.

政府销售的蓬勃发展不仅为芯片制造商带来了利润，还带来了声誉。“从市场营销角度来看，阿波罗和民兵是理想的客户，”基尔比说。“当他们决定可以使用这些固态电路时，这对许多购买电子设备的人产生了相当大的影响。这两个项目都被认为是杰出的工程操作，如果集成电路对他们来说足够好，那么，这意味着它对许多其他人来说也足够好。”

The burgeoning government sales not only provided profits for the chip makers but also conferred respectability. “From a marketing standpoint, Apollo and the Minuteman were ideal customers,” Kilby said. “When they decided that they could use these solid circuits, that had quite an impact on a lot of people who bought electronic equipment. Both of those projects were recognized as outstanding engineering operations, and if the integrated circuit was good enough for them, well, that meant it was good enough for a lot of other people.”

职业经济学家的主要消遣之一就是无休止地争论军方资助的研究是促进还是损害了民用经济。一般来说，双方似乎都有足够多的论据，足以让辩论者在未来几年里滔滔不绝。然而，在集成电路的具体案例中，毫无疑问，五角大楼的资金为民用电子业务和民用消费者带来了真正的好处。与装甲运兵车、核炮或零重力食物管不同，太空和军事计划使用的电子逻辑门、收音机等很容易转换为地面民用应用。第一款面向商业市场销售的芯片——用于 1964 年上市的 Zenith 助听器——与 IMP 卫星中使用的集成放大器电路相同。对于民兵二号导弹，德州仪器必须设计和生产 22 种相当标准的集成电路；这些芯片中的每一个都很容易适用于民用计算机、无线电发射器等。微电子革命中许多最为人们所熟悉的产品，从忙碌商人的袖珍传呼机到 Action News Minicam（“十一点电影”），都直接源自太空和军事开发合同。

One of the major pastimes among professional economists is an apparently endless debate as to whether military-funded research helps or hurts the civilian economy. As a general matter, there seem to be enough arguments on both sides to keep the debaters fruitfully occupied for years to come. In the specific case of the integrated circuit, however, there is no doubt that the Pentagon’s money produced real benefits for the civilian electronics business—and for civilian consumers. Unlike armored personnel carriers or nuclear cannon or zero-gravity food tubes, the electronic logic gates, radios, etc., that space and military programs use are fairly easily converted to earthbound civilian applications. The first chip sold for the commercial market—used in a Zenith hearing aid that went on sale in 1964—was the same integrated amplifier circuit used in the IMP satellite. For the Minuteman II missile, Texas Instruments had to design and produce twenty-two fairly standard types of circuits in integrated form; every one of those chips was readily adaptable to civilian computers, radio transmitters, and the like. A large number of the most familiar products of the microelectronic revolution, from the busy businessman’s pocket beeper to the Action News Minicam (“film at eleven”), resulted directly from space and military development contracts.

政府愿意以高价大量购买芯片，这为半导体公司提供了资金，使他们能够磨练设计和生产单片电路的技能。仙童、德州仪器和越来越多的其他公司利用国防和航天销售的利润，开发出精密的制造设施和精确的芯片制造新技术。随着经验的积累，人们找到了解决最常见生产问题的方法，制造芯片的成本开始下降。到 1964 年，最初的制造基地已经到位，集成电路开始以重返月球火箭的速度沿着学习曲线飞速发展。1963 年，芯片的平均价格约为 32 美元。一年后，平均价格为 18.50 美元，再一年为 8.33 美元。到 1971 年，即芯片进入市场十周年，平均价格为 1.27 美元。到 2000 年，具有 1971 年型号容量的芯片售价将低于 5 美分。

The government’s willingness to buy chips in quantity at premium prices provided the money the semiconductor firms needed to hone their skills in designing and producing monolithic circuits. With their earnings from defense and space sales, Fairchild, Texas Instruments, and a rapidly growing list of other companies developed elaborate manufacturing facilities and precise new techniques for making chips. As experience taught ways to solve the most common production problems, the cost of making a chip began to fall. By 1964 the initial manufacturing base was in place, and the integrated circuit started flying down the learning curve with the speed of a lunar rocket in reentry. In 1963 the price of an average chip was about $32. A year later the average price was $18.50, a year after that $8.33. By 1971, the tenth anniversary of the chip’s arrival in the marketplace, the average price was $1.27. By the year 2000, a chip with the capacity of those 1971 models would sell for a nickel or less.

价格下降的同时，能力却飞速提升。年复一年，集成电路的买家用更少的钱买到了更多的产品。制造商学会了如何在单个芯片上塞入越来越多的元件。这一成就部分是设计问题；复杂的电路必须布置在微小的硅片上，以便每个单独的元件都能发挥其功能，而不会干扰挤在一起的其他元件。然而，高密度芯片的主要技术障碍是产量。芯片上印刷的元件越多，其中一个元件出现缺陷的可能性就越大。一个有缺陷的晶体管可能会导致整个集成电路一文不值。“与高密度电路中的元件相比，一粒灰尘就显得太大了，”鲍勃·诺伊斯说。“一粒灰尘很容易毁掉整个电路。所以你必须在绝对没有灰尘的房间里生产产品。你必须内置数千条比人的头发还细的[连接]引线，每一条都必须没有任何缺陷。那么，如何建造一个没有灰尘的房间？如何打印出几乎完美的引线？我们必须慢慢学会如何做这样的事情。”随着时间的推移，该行业开发了“负压”制造室——用稳定的吸力将空气和灰尘从房间中抽出。工厂工人为防止污染而穿着的白色尼龙“兔子服”已经成为微芯片行业的象征。而将电路“打印”到 CD 大小的硅“晶圆”上的机器非常复杂和精确，以至于一台光刻机的成本高达数千万美元。

While prices were falling, capability soared. Year after year, buyers of integrated circuits got more product for less money. Manufacturers learned how to cram more and more components onto a single chip. This achievement was partly a matter of design; complex circuits had to be laid out on the tiny flake of silicon so that each individual component could perform its function without interfering with any of the other components squeezed alongside. The chief technical obstacle to high-density chips, though, was production yield. The more components printed on a chip, the greater the chance that one of those components would have a defect. One defective transistor could render the entire integrated circuit worthless. “A single speck of dust is huge compared to the components in a high-density circuit,” Bob Noyce said. “One dust particle will easily kill a whole circuit. So you’ve got to produce the thing in a room that is absolutely free of dust. You’ve got to build in thousands of [connecting] leads that are finer than a human hair, and every one of them has to be free of any defect. Well, how do you build a room that’s free of dust? And how do you print a lead that is essentially perfect? We had to learn over time how to do things like that.” Over time, the industry developed the “negative pressure” fabrication room—with a steady suction taking air, and dust, out of the room. The white nylon “bunny suit” that fab workers wear to prevent contamination has become a symbol of the microchip industry. And the machinery that “prints” circuitry onto CD-size “wafers” of silicon is so complex and so precise that a single photolithography unit costs tens of millions of dollars.

但随着该行业学会了如何在越来越小的尺寸下运作，它发现自己处于一个令人愉快的位置。一个包含 10,000 个组件的芯片所需的硅片和劳动力并不比只有 5,000 个组件的芯片多多少。这就像一个快餐摊找到了一种方法，用以前做汉堡所需的肉和面包的量来制作两个汉堡。半导体行业找到了一次又一次将产能翻番的方法。1964 年，当最先进的芯片包含大约 60 个组件时，诺伊斯的朋友兼同事戈登·摩尔被要求预测该行业在未来十年将取得多大进展。“我开玩笑地说，”摩尔后来回忆道。“我只是注意到芯片上的晶体管数量在过去三年中每年都翻了一番，所以我说这个速度会持续下去。”令他沮丧的是，这个即兴的预测被广泛引用，并很快被称为摩尔定律。几十年来，这一工业“定律”已演变成各种变体，但最常见的形式是摩尔定律，即最先进的集成电路上的晶体管数量将每隔 18 个月左右翻一番。令摩尔惊讶的是，这条定律一直沿用到 21 世纪。

But as the industry learned how to operate at ever-tinier dimensions, it found itself in a delightful position. A chip containing 10,000 components required no more silicon, and not much more labor, than one with only 5,000 components. It was as if a fast-food stand had found a way to turn out two burgers using the same amount of meat and bread that it had previously used for one. The semiconductor industry found ways to double capacity over and over again. Noyce’s friend and colleague Gordon Moore was asked in 1964, when the most advanced chips contained about 60 components, to predict how far the industry would advance in the next decade. “I did it sort of tongue-in-cheek,” Moore recalled later. “I just noticed that the number of transistors on a chip had doubled for each of the last three years, so I said that rate would continue.” To his dismay, that off-the-cuff prediction was widely quoted and soon came to be known as Moore’s Law. This industrial “law” has developed all sorts of variants through the decades, but in its most common form, Moore’s Law holds that the number of transistors on the most advanced integrated circuit will double every eighteen months or so. To Moore’s astonishment, the law has held true all the way to the twenty-first century.

“我当时说这句话的时候，根本没想过有人会指望我们在接下来的 10 年里继续将 [容量] 翻一番，”近 40 年后，摩尔解释道。“如果从那时往后推 10 年，到 1975 年，那就意味着一块集成电路上会有 65,000 个晶体管。这简直太荒谬了。”到 1975 年，业界生产出了一系列包含 65,536 个晶体管的新型存储芯片。大约需要四个分立晶体管来存储一位信息，因此 65,000 个晶体管的存储芯片可存储 16,000 位信息。大约三年后，这款 16K 芯片让位于 64K 存储芯片，后者拥有大约 258,000 个晶体管。此后，在芯片上放置越来越多元件的进程一直紧跟摩尔定律，一路上只出现了少数小问题。到 21 世纪初，内存领域的最先进技术是 256M 芯片，可容纳 2.56 亿比特信息。256M 电路包含超过 10 亿个晶体管，全部堆叠在一块不大于本页上“CHIP”字样的硅片上。

“At the time I said it, I had no idea that anybody would expect us to keep doubling [capacity] for even ten more years,” Moore explained nearly four decades later. “If you extrapolated out ten years from then, to 1975, that would mean we’d have 65,000 transistors on a single integrated circuit. It just seemed ridiculous.” By 1975 the industry was producing a new series of memory chips that contained 65,536 transistors. It takes roughly four discrete transistors to store one bit of information, so the 65,000-transistor memory chip stored 16,000 bits. This 16K chip gave way about three years later to the 64K memory chip, with some 258,000 transistors. With only a few hiccups along the way, progress in placing more and more components on a chip has closely followed Moore’s Law ever since. By the first years of the twenty-first century, the state of the art in memory was a 256M chip, which held 256 million bits of information. The 256M circuit contains just over 1 billion transistors, all stacked on a sliver of silicon no bigger than the word “CHIP” on this page.

内存芯片往往是所有集成电路中最拥挤的，因为这些芯片上的晶体管可以整齐地排列成相同的元件阵列。其他类型的电路密度稍低一些，因为它们的设计不需要那么紧凑的布局。但这些逻辑芯片也大致遵循摩尔定律，元件数量大约每 18 个月翻一番。戈登·摩尔做出预测时上市的英特尔 8080 微处理器包含大约 4,000 个元件。四分之一世纪后，8080 的曾孙，即奔腾 IV，在大小大致相同的芯片上拥有一万倍的元件——超过 4000 万个晶体管。

Memory chips tend to be the most crowded of all integrated circuits, because the transistors on those chips can be laid out in neat arrays of identical components. Other types of circuits are a little less heavily populated because their design requires less compact layouts. But these logic chips, too, have roughly followed Moore’s Law, with the number of components doubling at roughly eighteen-month intervals. The Intel 8080 microprocessor that was coming to market about the time Gordon Moore made his prediction contained about 4,000 components. A quarter century later, the 8080’s great-great-great-great-grandson, known as Pentium IV, had ten thousand times as many components—something over 40 million transistors—on a chip roughly the same size.

在杰克·基尔比因微芯片获得诺贝尔奖的时候，戈登·摩尔回顾了这项发明的历史，承认他仍然对自己的预测仍然正确感到惊讶。“我仍然很难相信我们能制造出这些东西，”他说。“我从一开始就在那里，我知道从技术上讲，在一个芯片上安装十亿个晶体管是可行的。天哪，我们正在做！但我们能走到今天这一步仍然令人惊讶。”

Around the time Jack Kilby won the Nobel Prize for the microchip, Gordon Moore took a long look back at the history of the invention and admitted that he is still amazed his own prediction continues to hold. “I still have a tough time believing that we can make these things,” he said. “I’m a person who has been there literally since the beginning, and I know as a technical matter that a billion transistors on a chip is doable. Hell, we’re doing it! But it is still astonishing we have come this far.”

随着制造厂生产出数百万个芯片，每个芯片包含数千万甚至数亿个晶体管，摩尔——已从英特尔退休但仍在董事会任职——在退休后花了一些时间来计算一年生产了多少个晶体管。他得出的比较主要表明了想象所涉及的数字有多么困难。摩尔曾一度估计晶体管的数量大于加州平均每年降雨量的数量。另一项计算得出的结论是，半导体行业每年为地球上每只蚂蚁生产 10 个晶体管。

As fabrication plants turn out millions of chips that contain tens or hundreds of millions of transistors each, Moore—retired from active service at Intel, but still on the board—has spent some of his retirement time calculating just how many transistors are produced in a year. The comparisons he came up with demonstrate mainly how hard it is to imagine the numbers involved. At one point, Moore estimated that the number of transistors was greater than the number of raindrops that fall on California in an average year. Another calculation concluded that the semiconductor industry makes ten transistors per year for every ant on the earth.

自微芯片诞生以来，半导体行业的价格稳步下降，产能急剧上升，创造了美国工业史上最大的生产率增长。一张比较芯片诞生前四十年的价格和产能的图表几乎呈现出一个完美的X形：价格曲线随着时间的推移急剧下降，而产能曲线则直线上升。在20世纪50年代初的第一代“固态电路”中，芯片非常简单，价格昂贵，买家每个晶体管的价格约为10美元。到2000年，10美元可以买到两个6400万位的内存芯片，大约有50万个晶体管。显然，价格降低50万倍是一件很特别的事情，因此将芯片与其他工业产品进行比较可能不公平。然而，这种诱惑很难抵挡，人们经常进行比较。在一个典型的版本中，戈登·摩尔提出了一个典型的例子，即如果汽车行业的生产率与半导体行业相当，会发生什么。 “我们可以以每小时 100,000 英里的速度舒适地驾驶汽车，每加仑汽油可行驶 50,000 英里，”摩尔说。“我们会发现，扔掉我们的劳斯莱斯并重新购买比把它停在市中心过夜更便宜。……我们可以把它传给几代人，而不需要任何维修。”

With the steady decline in prices and the steep ascent in capacity since the birth of the microchip, the semiconductor industry has produced the greatest productivity gains in American industrial history. A graph comparing prices and capacity during the first forty years of the chip’s existence makes a nearly perfect X: the price curve angles sharply downward over time, and the capacity curve angles straight up. In the first generation of “solid circuits” back in the early 1950s, the chips were so simple and the prices so high that buyers were paying about $10 per transistor. By the year 2000, $10 would buy two 64-million-bit memory chips, with about half a million transistors. Clearly a 500,000-fold reduction in price is something special, and consequently it is probably unfair to compare the chip to other industrial products. The temptation is hard to resist, though, and the comparison is frequently made. In a typical version, Gordon Moore suggested what would have happened if the automobile industry had matched the semiconductor business for productivity. “We would cruise comfortably in our cars at 100,000 mph, getting 50,000 miles per gallon of gasoline,” Moore said. “We would find it cheaper to throw away our Rolls-Royce and replace it than to park it downtown for the evening. . . . We could pass it down through several generations without any requirement for repair.”

另一个对此感到难以置信的感兴趣的人是鲍勃·诺伊斯。他写道：“即使对我们这些一直密切参与不断发展的技术的人来说，进步是惊人的。”

Another interested party who found this history hard to believe was Bob Noyce. “Progress has been astonishing, even to those of us who have been intimately engaged in the evolving technology,” he wrote.

如今，一块面积约为四分之一平方英寸的芯片上单个集成电路所能容纳的电子元件比 1950 年所能制造的最复杂电子设备还要多。如今的微型计算机（芯片上）成本仅为 300 美元，但计算能力却比第一台大型电子计算机 ENIAC 更强。它的速度快 20 倍，内存更大，可靠性高出数千倍，消耗的电量相当于一个灯泡而不是火车头的电量，体积只有后者的 1/30,000，而价格只有后者的 1/10,000。您可以通过邮购或在当地的业余爱好商店购买。

An individual integrated circuit on a chip perhaps a quarter of an inch square now can embrace more electronic elements than the most complex piece of electronic equipment that could be built in 1950. Today’s microcomputer [on a chip], at a cost of $300, has more computing capacity than the first large electronic computer, ENIAC. It is 20 times faster, has a larger memory, is thousands of times more reliable, consumes the power of a light bulb rather than that of a locomotive, occupies 1⁄30,000 the volume and costs 1⁄10,000 as much. It is available by mail order or at your local hobby shop.

诺伊斯在 1977 年写下了这段话。当然，这段话现在已经过时了。今天的芯片微型计算机比诺伊斯设想的模型强大得多，而且成本要低得多。

Noyce wrote that in 1977. Naturally, the passage is seriously out of date now. Today’s microcomputer on a chip is vastly more powerful than the model Noyce had in mind, and costs considerably less.

芯片容量的大幅提升也提高了电路性能。芯片密度越高，元件之间的空间就越小。空间越小，信号脉冲从一个元件传输到另一个元件的时间就越短，因此电路越小，电路速度就越快。同样，电路越小，所需的功率就越小。因此，芯片制造商年复一年地提供更低的价格、更高的容量和更好的性能。20 世纪 60 年代后半期，这一成就引起了商业市场的关注，例如计算机和工业设备制造商，而当芯片于 1961 年首次出现时，这些制造商对芯片不屑一顾。到 20 世纪 70 年代初，政府不再是芯片的主要消费者；这一地位已被计算机行业所取代。

The dramatic increase in the capacity of a chip also improved circuit performance. Higher-density chips meant less space between components. Less space meant less travel time for signal pulses running from one component to the next, so a smaller circuit was a faster circuit. Similarly, a smaller circuit required less power. Thus the chip makers were offering lower prices, higher capacity, and better performance year after year. In the second half of the 1960s that achievement caught the attention of commercial markets, such as producers of computers and industrial equipment, which had spurned the chip when it first appeared in 1961. By the early 1970s, the government was no longer the leading consumer of chips; that position had been taken over by the computer industry.

回想起来，很容易看出集成电路非常适合数字计算机，但当芯片首次上市时，计算机制造商并不那么明显。在微型计算机和微型计算机出现之前，计算机的价格通常高达数十万美元，开发一款新机型对制造商而言意味着巨大的投资。交货时间很长；1961 年做出的决定将决定四年后上市的机器的生产。因此，计算机设计是一门保守的科学。在 20 世纪 60 年代初期，没有计算机制造商愿意冒险尝试一种全新的电路类型。

In retrospect, it is easy to see that the integrated circuit was perfectly suited to the digital computer, but the point was less than obvious to computer manufacturers when the chip first came on the market. In the days before the mini- and microcomputer, when computers routinely cost hundreds of thousands of dollars, the development of a new model represented an enormous investment on the manufacturer’s part. Lead times were long; a decision made in 1961 would govern the production of machines that came on the market four years later. As a result, computer design was a conservative science. In the early 1960s no computer builder was willing to take a chance on a completely new type of circuit.

因此，当 IBM 于 1964 年推出一系列重要的新计算机 System 360 时，这款新机器并未使用集成电路。尽管如此，System 360 仍包含一个革命性的概念 — — 它是一系列不同尺寸和价格的计算机，它们共享相同的指令代码或软件，因此可以相互通信 — — 这使得所有现有机器都过时了。为了反击，竞争对手必须想出自己的新东西。他们转向集成逻辑电路。使用这种芯片，Univac、Burroughs 和 RCA 制造出了与 IBM 系统一样强大的机器，但体积更小、速度更快、价格更便宜。像 Digital Equipment 和 Data General 这样的新贵带着一个新概念 — — 称为微型计算机的完全集成设备 — — 进入市场。它大约相当于高级管理人员的办公桌大小，价格不到 100,000 美元，但计算能力却与 IBM 的一些大型机相当。1969 年，IBM 屈服于不可避免的现实，开始在其计算机的所有逻辑电路中使用芯片。现在，芯片制造商拥有了一个比航天和国防业务还要庞大的市场。到 1970 年，美国有超过 20 家公司生产集成电路；当年他们销售了 3 亿块芯片。两年后，芯片销量达到 6 亿块。

Thus when IBM brought out a major new line of computers, the System 360, in 1964, the new machine did not use integrated circuits. Still, the System 360 involved a revolutionary concept—it was a family of computers in various sizes and prices that shared the same instruction code, or software, and could thus communicate with one another—which rendered all existing machines obsolete. To fight back, competitors had to come up with something new of their own. They turned to integrated logic circuits. Using the chip, Univac, Burroughs, and RCA turned out machines that were as powerful as the IBM systems but smaller, faster, and cheaper. Brash upstarts like Digital Equipment and Data General entered the market with a new concept—the fully integrated device called the minicomputer. It was about the size of a senior executive’s desk and cost less than $100,000 but matched some of IBM’s big mainframes in computing power. In 1969, IBM bowed to the inevitable and began using chips for all logic circuitry in its computers. Now the chip makers had a market that would dwarf the space and defense business. By 1970, there were more than two dozen American firms turning out integrated circuits; they sold 300 million chips that year. Two years later 600 million chips were sold.

然而，逻辑电路仅代表了潜在计算机市场的一部分。数字机器需要逻辑门来处理数据，但它们也需要内存单元来保存数据。20 世纪 60 年代的计算机使用一种巧妙而简单的技术（称为磁芯存储器）以二进制数字的形式存储数据。磁芯存储器看起来像由细线制成的网球网；无论两根电线交叉在哪里，交叉处都会挂上一个小铁环（磁芯）。通过沿着正确的一对电线发送电子脉冲，每个单独的铁芯都可以磁化或消磁。磁化磁芯代表二进制 1；消磁磁芯代表二进制 0。磁芯存储器相当笨重；需要大约 10 平方英尺的金属网来存储 1,000 位信息（“位”是克劳德·香农 (Claude Shannon) 的术语，表示单个二进制数字，即 1 或 0）。但它可靠、易于制造且价格低廉。导线和铁芯非常便宜，一个完整的内存单元只需要几个晶体管就能发出所需的脉冲。核心内存最昂贵的部分是将所有铁环串在网上的人工成本。这项工作是手工完成的，最终外包给了香港和墨西哥等地，因此核心内存的价格一直很低。

Logic circuitry, however, represented only one part of the potential computer market. Digital machines need logic gates to manipulate data, but they also need memory units to hold the data. The computers of the 1960s stored data, in the form of binary digits, using an ingeniously simple technique called magnetic core memory. A core memory looks like a tennis net made of fine wires; wherever two wires cross, a small iron wedding ring—the core—is hooked over the intersection. By sending electronic pulses along the right pair of wires, each individual iron core could be magnetized or demagnetized. A magnetized core represented a binary 1; demagnetized, it stood for binary 0. Core memory was fairly bulky; it took about 10 square feet of wire net to store 1,000 bits of information (“bit” is Claude Shannon’s term for a single binary digit, a 1 or a 0). But it was reliable, easy to make, and inexpensive. The wires and the iron cores were dirt cheap, and a complete memory unit needed only a handful of transistors to send out the needed pulses. The most expensive thing about core memory was the labor cost for stringing all those iron rings on the net. This job, done by hand, was eventually farmed out to places like Hong Kong and Mexico, so prices for core memory remained low.

一些有远见的半导体工程师看到了将内存放到芯片上的可能性。毕竟，集成电路是存储二进制数字的完美媒介。芯片由大量开关（晶体管）组成，任何开关都有内存。墙上的电灯开关就是一个存储单元；它会记住你对它所做的最后一件事，并保持这种状态（打开或关闭），直到你更改设置。由于各种技术原因，半导体存储器通常使用多个晶体管来存储每个二进制数字。在一种标准存储器设计中，使用四个晶体管的块来存储每个位。如果信号脉冲打开该块，则它代表 1；如果晶体管块关闭，则代表 0。

Some farsighted semiconductor engineers could see the possibility of putting memory onto a chip. The integrated circuit, after all, was a perfect medium for storing binary digits. A chip comprised a large array of switches (transistors), and any switch has memory. The light switch on the wall is a memory unit; it remembers the last thing you did to it, and stays that way—either on or off—until you change the setting. For various technical reasons, semiconductor memories often used more than one transistor to store each binary digit. In one standard memory design, a block of four transistors was used to store each bit. If a signal pulse turned the block on, it stood for 1; if the block of transistors was off, it stood for 0.

半导体存储芯片比同等大小的磁芯存储单元小 10 倍，由于信号脉冲的传输距离更短，因此速度更快。但在 20 世纪 60 年代的大部分时间里，半导体存储芯片的价格也比同等大小的磁芯存储单元贵两到三倍。1967 年，仙童公司的工程师们创造了一项奇迹，将 1,024 个晶体管集成到一块集成电路中。如果每个比特有四个晶体管，那么这样的电路可以存储 256 位信息。但 256 位存储芯片的价格仍是同等大小的铁芯存储芯片的两倍多。仙童芯片在实验室中备受推崇，但在市场上却无人问津。

A semiconductor memory chip was ten times smaller than the equivalent core memory unit; since the signal pulses had shorter distances to travel, it was much faster. Through most of the 1960s, however, it was also two or three times more expensive. In 1967 engineers at Fairchild performed the prodigious feat of squeezing 1,024 transistors onto a single integrated circuit. At four transistors per bit, such a circuit could provide storage for 256 bits of information. But a 256-bit memory chip was still more than twice as expensive as a comparable amount of iron core memory. The Fairchild chip was admired in the laboratories but ignored in the market.

1968 年， 《电气和电子工程师学会会刊》 上刊登了一篇专著，其中详尽阐述了内存行业的经济状况，令人沮丧。该书称，为了接近核心内存的价格，半导体行业人士必须制造出 1,000 位内存芯片。直到有人开发出 4,000 位芯片，半导体内存才会真正便宜下来。一块芯片上有 4,000 位？大多数业内人士看到这些数据后，认为最明智的做法是放弃内存。仙童公司的两位工程师——鲍勃·诺伊斯和他的朋友戈登·摩尔——看到同样的数据后，决定尝试一下。

A monograph that appeared in the Proceedings of the Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers in 1968 set forth in discouraging detail the economics of the memory business. Just to approach the price of core memory, it said, the semiconductor people would have to come up with a 1,000-bit memory chip. Semiconductor memory would not actually become cheaper until somebody developed a 4,000-bit chip. Four thousand bits on a single chip? Most of the industry looked at those figures and decided that the wisest course would be to forget memory. A pair of engineers at Fairchild—Bob Noyce and his friend Gordon Moore—looked at the same numbers and decided to give it a try.

到 1968 年，创立仙童半导体公司的那些人对他们在东部仙童照相机和仪器公司的上司施加的控制感到不满。诺伊斯、摩尔和他们的同事比仙童的任何董事都更了解半导体行业，无论是技术方面还是营销方面，但他们经常被迫遵守看似完全愚蠢的公司法令。此外，在 1967 年，母公司经历了一段动荡时期，两名首席执行官在六个月内被聘用和解雇。对于加州的“仙童”来说，领导公司的合适人选似乎是他们自己的领导人鲍勃·诺伊斯。但当这个建议被传达到公司董事会时，董事们无法将他们已建立的传统公司委托给加州牛仔。当诺伊斯被忽略时，加州人聚集在一起，一致认为是时候继续前进了。

By 1968, the men who had formed Fairchild Semiconductor were chafing at the controls imposed by their corporate superiors back east at the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation. Noyce, Moore, and their colleagues knew more about the semiconductor industry, both the technical and the marketing side, than any of the Fairchild directors, but they were constantly forced to follow corporate decrees that seemed downright foolish. During 1967, moreover, the parent company went through a period of turmoil that saw two CEOs hired and fired within six months. To the “Fairchildren” out in California, it seemed obvious that the right man to lead the corporation was their own leader, Bob Noyce. But when this suggestion was passed to the corporate board, the directors could not bring themselves to entrust their established and traditional corporation to a California cowboy. When Noyce was passed over, the Californians gathered and agreed it was time to move on.

1968 年，诺伊斯、摩尔、安德鲁·格罗夫和其他几位科学家离开仙童公司，创办了一家专门生产半导体存储器的新公司。他们当时押注，制造密度极高的存储器芯片比制造传统的逻辑芯片更容易。逻辑电路有各种门和通路，需要以复杂的方式布置各种元件，并以错综复杂的引线方式连接各部件。相比之下，存储器芯片大部分由相同的晶体管组成，这些晶体管以相同的块状排列，一个接一个，就像莱维顿郊区一排排相同的房屋一样。连接可以通过简单的平行引线网络提供，就像郊区街道纵横交错的整齐网格一样。每个晶体管块，就像莱维顿的每栋房子一样，都可以分配一个唯一的地址。因此，存储器电路将允许随机访问 - 也就是说，逻辑电路可以将数据发送到 1,000 个存储位置中的任何一个或从中提取数据，而不会干扰其他 999 个。

When Noyce, Moore, Andrew Grove, and several others left Fairchild in 1968 to start a new company specializing in semiconductor memories, they were gambling that a memory chip would be easier to make in extremely high densities than the traditional logic chip. A logic circuit, with its assorted gates and pathways, requires a variety of components laid out in complex patterns and a byzantine pattern of leads to connect the parts. A memory chip, in contrast, consisted for the most part of identical transistors lined up in identical blocks, one after another, like blocks of identical tract houses in suburban Levittown. Connections could be provided by a simple network of parallel leads, just like a neat grid of crisscrossing suburban streets. Each block of transistors, like each house in Levittown, could be assigned a unique address. Consequently, the memory circuit would permit random access—that is, the logic circuits could send data to or extract it from any one of 1,000 memory locations without disturbing the other 999.

诺伊斯、摩尔等人创立的新公司英特尔公司于 1968 年底推出了第一款高密度内存电路。它可容纳 1,024 位数据。使用 1,000 的标准工程缩写字母“K”，这种随机存取存储器芯片被称为 1K RAM。英特尔第一年的销售额总计为 2,672 美元。到 1973 年，当 4K RAM 上市时，该公司的销售额突破了 6000 万美元，德州仪器和其他几家公司也纷纷涉足内存业务。

The new firm that Noyce, Moore, and the others founded, Intel Corporation, turned out its first high-density memory circuit late in 1968. It held 1,024 bits of data. Using the standard engineering shorthand for 1,000, the letter “K,” this random-access memory chip was called a 1K RAM. Intel rang up a grand total of $2,672 in sales that first year. By 1973, when the 4K RAM came to market, the firm’s sales topped $60 million, and Texas Instruments and several other firms had jumped into the memory business as well.

与人类其他大多数领域一样，计算机世界也有自己的帕金森定律。有时用纯粹的帕金森术语来表述——“数据会不断膨胀，直到填满可用的内存”——有时用更直白的语言来表述——“内存永远不够用”。对于计算机爱好者来说，使用一组内存就像吃一颗花生。事实证明，计算机行业对廉价、快速的随机存取存储器有着极大的需求，半导体行业也做好了准备来满足这种需求。部分原因是由于通常使用每位四个晶体管的存储配置，内存芯片往往会增长四倍。16K RAM 于 1975 年上市。64K RAM 五年后上市。根据摩尔定律，这种增长一直持续到 21 世纪初的 256M RAM 芯片。

Like most other fields of human endeavor, the computer world has its own version of Parkinson’s Law. It is sometimes stated in pure Parkinsonian terms—“Data expands to fill the memory available to hold it”—and sometimes in plainer language—“There’s no such thing as enough memory.” For computer buffs, using one bank of memory is like eating one peanut. The computer business turned out to have a voracious appetite for cheap, fast random-access memory, and the semiconductor business geared up to meet the need. Partly because of the commonly used four-transistor-per-bit storage configuration, memory chips tended to grow by factors of four. A 16K RAM came on the market in 1975. The 64K RAM went on sale five years later. In accordance with Moore’s Law, this growth has continued up to a 256M RAM chip at the start of the twenty-first century.

除了两种数字电路（逻辑和内存）之外，20 世纪 60 年代末还见证了另一种芯片的首次重大发展，即线性或模拟集成电路。线性芯片复制了许多传统电子电路的功能，如定时器、无线电发射器、音频放大器等。这些应用将集成电路引入了许多非计算机电子设备中。有些是传统的，如第一台集成电路无线电接收器于 1966 年上市，而有些则是全新的，如心脏起搏器，一种以精确间隔发出小电脉冲的微型电路，于 1967 年首次植入人体胸部。最终，集成电子器件取代了从电梯到 Osterizers 等各种设备中的传统电路。

In addition to the two types of digital circuits—logic and memory—the late sixties also saw the first significant development of another species of chip, called a linear, or analog, integrated circuit. The linear chips replicated the functions of many traditional electronic circuits—timers, radio transmitters, audio amplifiers, and the like. Such applications put the integrated circuit into a number of noncomputer electronic devices. Some were traditional—the first integrated circuit radio receiver went on the market in 1966—and some wholly new—the cardiac pacemaker, a tiny circuit that gives off small electric pulses at precise intervals, was implanted in a human chest for the first time in 1967. Eventually, integrated electronics were replacing traditional circuitry in everything from elevators to Osterizers.

集成电路的应用正在迅速增加，但速度却赶不上半导体公司生产高密度集成电路的速度。戈登·摩尔后来表示：“我们达到了可以生产出比我们能使用的更复杂的产品的地步。”那些花时间从资产负债表中抬起头来思考未来的行业高管可以看到，电子电路的供应增长速度快于需求。此外，在工业产品中，集成电路几乎是唯一一次性销售的产品。它不会损坏，也不会磨损活动部件。一旦芯片通过了初步检查，它就可以使用一辈子；几乎没有或根本没有替代市场。

Applications for integrated circuits were multiplying rapidly, but not as rapidly as the semiconductor companies were turning out densely integrated new circuits. “We reached a point where we could produce more complexity than we could use,” Gordon Moore said later. Those industry executives who took time to look up from their balance sheets and think about the future could see that supply of electronic circuits was increasing faster than demand. Almost alone among industrial products, moreover, the integrated circuit was a one-time-only sale. There was nothing to break, no moving parts to wear out. Once a chip passed its initial inspection, it would last a lifetime; there was little or no replacement market.

全国商学院时不时会出现一道考试题，假设有人发明了一种永不磨损的普通产品。著名的原型是亚历克·吉尼斯在伟大电影《白衣人》中发明的神奇面料——一种永远不会变脏、起皱或磨损的布料。在电影中，新产品最初受到热烈欢迎；然后世界各地的干洗店、西装制造商和百货公司都想知道这一突破会给他们带来什么。最后，神奇面料被悄悄埋没了。但如果这样的产品在现实生活中出现——例如终身灯泡或永久剃须刀片？剃须刀片行业应该如何应对？一个答案是，制造商应该通过销售终身刀片迅速赚钱，直到所有传统刀片都被替换——然后倒闭。然而，大多数商学院都不接受这个答案，因为它们宣扬需要永无止境的增长。正确的答案是，行业应该利用其独创性来创造终身剃须刀片的新用途，并满足不断扩大的市场。

An exam question that pops up now and then in the nation’s business schools postulates a situation where somebody invents a common product that will never wear out. The famous prototype is the miracle fabric that Alec Guinness invents in the great film The Man in the White Suit—a cloth that never gets dirty, wrinkles, or wears out. In the movie, the new product is at first welcomed with joy; then the dry cleaners, suit makers, and department stores of the world figure out what this breakthrough would do to them. In the end, the miracle fabric is quietly buried. But what if such a product came along in real life—a lifetime light bulb, for example, or permanent razor blade? How should the razor blade industry react? One answer is that the manufacturers should make a quick killing selling the lifetime blade until all conventional blades are replaced—and then go out of business. This answer is not an acceptable one, however, at most business schools, which preach the need for unending growth. The right answer is that the industry should use its ingenuity to create new uses for lifetime razor blades, and cater to a continually expanding market.

面对不断扩大的终身产品供应，20 世纪 60 年代末的半导体行业做出了正确的选择。他们要做的事情就是为集成电路寻找新的应用和新的市场。由于当时芯片几乎只供政府和工业使用，因此显然要瞄准的新市场是最大的市场——消费者。为了保持爆炸式的增长率，美国半导体行业必须将其革命性的新产品带入美国家庭。
