Faced with an ever-expanding supply of a lifetime product, the semiconductor industry at the end of the 1960s picked the right answer. The thing to do was to find new applications and new markets for integrated circuits. Since the chip, up to then, had been sold almost exclusively for government and industrial uses, the obvious new market to shoot for was the largest market of all—the consumer. To maintain its explosive rate of growth, the American semiconductor industry would have to take its revolutionary new product into the American home.

但如何实现呢？大多数美国人所了解的芯片都是用土豆制成的；“半导体”这个词对公众来说完全陌生。有多少家庭真的需要星际制导和导航系统或价值 50,000 美元的计算机？将微电子革命推广到普通消费者是一个艰巨的问题。为了解决这个问题，该行业向其首屈一指的问题解决者之一 Jack Kilby 求助。

But how? The only chips that most Americans knew much about were made from potatoes; the very word “semiconductor” was completely alien to the general public. How many homes really needed an interplanetary guidance and navigation system or a $50,000 computer? Extending the microelectronic revolution down to the average consumer loomed as a formidable problem. To solve it, the industry turned to one of its premier problem solvers—Jack Kilby.

8

8

内爆

THE IMPLOSION

让芯片走进千家万户、让“芯片”——微电子意义上的“芯片”——成为家喻户晓的词汇的决定，与十年前让芯片的直接祖先晶体管做出同样决定​​的决定如出一辙。这两个案例的决策者都是德州仪器公司远见卓识、勇敢无畏的首席执行官帕特里克·哈格蒂。20 世纪 50 年代初，当晶体管开始成为一种廉价、可靠的量产产品时，哈格蒂对微电子应该在现代社会中发挥普遍作用的想法产生了浓厚的兴趣，甚至到了痴迷的程度。他开始相信，微电子设备将取代现有电子设备中的标准电路；所有由传统齿轮、弹簧或定时器控制的工具和器具都将配备芯片；低成本、低功耗、高可靠性微型元件的出现将创造以前未知的整个市场。“普遍性”就像哈格蒂演讲和著作中的一个固定观念。他坚信微电子设备将逐渐渗透到生活的各个方面，这一信念是他做出许多商业决策的根本原因。

The decision that brought the chip into every household, and made “chip,” in its microelectronic sense, a household word, was a carbon copy of the decision a decade earlier that had done the same things for the chip’s immediate ancestor, the transistor. The decision maker in both cases was Patrick Haggerty, the farsighted and plucky chief executive of Texas Instruments. In the early 1950s, when the transistor was starting to become a cheap, reliable mass-production item, Haggerty developed a fascination, almost an obsession, with the notion that microelectronics should play a pervasive role in modern society. He came to believe that microelectronic devices would replace standard circuitry in existing electronic gear; that all tools and appliances controlled by traditional gears, springs, or timers would be fitted with chips; and that the availability of low-cost, low-power, high-reliability miniature components would create entire markets unknown before. “Pervasiveness” occurs like an idée fixe in Haggerty’s speeches and writings. The conviction that microelectronic devices would gradually pervade every aspect of life was at the root of many of his business decisions.

1954 年，哈格蒂首次将这一原则付诸实践，当时德州仪器还是一家小型区域电子零件制造商，却发现它在晶体管开发方面领先于其他所有公司。“我们知道我们在半导体领域做得很好，”哈格蒂 25 年后回忆道，“[但] 我们面对的是一个充满怀疑的世界……在我看来，德州仪器必须进行某种引人注目的展示，证明可靠的晶体管确实可以大批量生产且价格适中，而且德州仪器既准备好又能够生产它们。”事实上，哈格蒂心中有一个特别引人注目的展示项目。

Haggerty first put the principle into practice in 1954, when Texas Instruments, then a small regional manufacturer of electronic parts, discovered that it was ahead of everybody else in transistor development. “We knew we were doing pretty well in our semiconductor endeavor,” Haggerty recalled twenty-five years later, “[but] we were facing a world that was pretty skeptical. . . . It seemed to me that it was imperative for T.I. to generate some kind of dramatic demonstration that reliable transistors really were available in mass production quantities and at moderate prices, and that T.I. was both ready and able to produce them.” In fact, Haggerty had a particularly dramatic demonstration project in mind.

他召集了工程师，让他们生产一种全新的产品——一种便携式收音机，完全晶体管化，由笔形电池供电，小到可以放在口袋里或安装在仪表盘上。哈格蒂试图说服几家大型收音机公司销售这种设备。他们都拒绝了，认为袖珍收音机没有市场——这是一个准确的说法，因为从来没有过袖珍收音机。1954 年的“收音机”往往是一种放在桌面上的大木头玩意；它放不进手提箱，更不用说放在口袋里了。但哈格蒂坚持己见，最终找到了一家小公司 Regency，该公司在 1954 年圣诞节销售旺季之前推出了袖珍收音机。第一年，Regency 便携式收音机的销量超过 100,000 台，此后袖珍收音机的销量呈天文数字增长。该产品对 TI 和 Regency 来说都同样成功，因为它让晶体管成为全世界熟悉的物品。德州仪器的一些员工说，哈格蒂耗资数百万美元将晶体管引入消费产品的紧急计划实际上针对的是单个消费者——IBM 负责人托马斯·沃森 (Thomas Watson Jr.)。如果哈格蒂的目标就是这个，那他可真是一击即中。沃森购买了 100 台 Regency 收音机，并将它们分发给他的工程师；据 IBM 的一位高管称，沃森告诉他的员工，“如果德克萨斯州的那个小公司能够让这些收音机正常工作……他们就能制造出让我们的计算机正常工作的晶体管。”哈格蒂本人对此的描述再好不过了。1957 年，沃森签署了一份采购订单，使德州仪器成为 IBM 的主要供应商，并为 TI 的晶体管提供了一个巨大的新市场。

He had called in his engineers and told them to produce something wholly new—a portable radio, completely transistorized, powered by penlight batteries, and small enough to carry in a pocket or install in a dashboard. Haggerty tried to persuade several major radio firms to sell the device. They all demurred, arguing that there was no market for a pocket radio—an accurate assertion, since there had never been a pocket radio. A “radio” in 1954 tended to be a big wooden tabletop thing; it wouldn’t fit in a suitcase, much less a pocket. But Haggerty persisted, and eventually found a small company, Regency, which introduced the pocket radio just in time for the Christmas sales rush in 1954. More than 100,000 Regency portables were sold the first year, and pocket radio sales increased astronomically thereafter. The product was as successful for TI as for Regency, because it made the transistor a familiar object throughout the world. Some Texas Instruments people say Haggerty’s multimillion-dollar crash program to put the transistor into a consumer product was actually aimed at a single consumer—Thomas Watson Jr., the head of IBM. If that was Haggerty’s aim, he hit a bull’s-eye. Watson bought a hundred Regency radios and distributed them among his engineers; according to an IBM executive, Watson told his people that “if that little outfit down in Texas can make these radios work . . . they can make transistors that will make our computers work, too.” Haggerty himself couldn’t have put it better. In 1957, Watson signed a purchase order that made Texas Instruments a key IBM supplier and provided a huge new market for TI’s transistors.

在推出收音机 11 年后，哈格蒂开始思考集成电路的未来。这种芯片在军事和工业市场中赢得了一席之地，但尚未打入计算机行业，甚至在消费市场也未取得丝毫进展。哈格蒂和他的工程师都知道，这种芯片代表着技术的革命性进步，而且产品的可靠性、容量和价值每年都在提高——但全世界并不知道这一点。哈格蒂决定，需要的是戏剧性地展示单片电路可以提供的好处。他心中有一个特别戏剧性的演示项目。

Eleven years after he had launched the radio, Haggerty got to thinking about the future of the integrated circuit. The chip was winning itself a niche in military and industrial markets but had yet to crack the computer industry or make even the smallest dent in the consumer market. Haggerty knew, and his engineers knew, that the chip represented a revolutionary advance in technology and that the product’s reliability, capacity, and value were increasing every year—but the world at large did not know that. What was needed, Haggerty decided, was a dramatic demonstration of the benefits that monolithic circuitry could provide. And he had a particularly dramatic demonstration project in mind.

1965 年秋天，哈格蒂与一位工程师一起乘飞机旅行，哈格蒂开始谈论他的信念：微型、廉价但复杂的集成电路将带来新的普及维度。他说，总有一天，芯片将被嵌入到各种消费产品中——到那时，每个家庭都会有集成电路。事实上，他一直在考虑一种消费产品，它可以完美地承载单片电路。飞机降落前，哈格蒂命令这位工程师发明一种全新的东西：一种可以放在手掌中的微型计算器——比以前任何计算机器都轻得多、小得多、便宜得多。

On an airplane trip with one of his engineers in the fall of 1965, Haggerty started talking about his belief that tiny, inexpensive, but complex circuits in integrated form would lead to new dimensions of pervasiveness. Why, the day would come, he said, when the chip would be built into a wide range of consumer products—when there would be integrated circuits in every home. As a matter of fact, he had been thinking about a consumer product that would be a perfect vehicle for the monolithic circuit. Before the plane landed, Haggerty had ordered the engineer to invent something wholly new: a miniature calculator that would fit in the palm of a hand—much lighter, much smaller, and much cheaper than any calculating machine that had ever been thought of before.

接到这个命令的人是公司最受尊敬、晋升最快的工程师之一——杰克·基尔比。自从他在德州仪器公司工作的第一个月发明了集成电路以来，基尔比获得了一系列的加薪和晋升，这很符合他作为员工在单片技术前沿的坚定地位。在一个头衔非常重要的公司里，基尔比从简单的“工程师”晋升为“工程经理”，再到“集成电路开发经理”，最后到“半导体研发实验室副主任”。最重要的是，从基尔比的角度来看，公司基本上让他独自去做他最喜欢的工作——解决技术问题。当哈格蒂提出制造袖珍计算器这个艰巨的问题时，杰克·基尔比显然是接手这个任务的人选。

The man on the receiving end of that order was one of the most respected and fastest-rising engineers in the company—Jack Kilby. Since his invention of the integrated circuit during his first month at Texas Instruments, Kilby had received a series of raises and promotions befitting an employee who had given the company a firm position on the leading edge of monolithic technology. In a company where titles really mattered, Kilby had progressed from simply “Engineer” to “Manager of Engineering” to “Manager, Integrated Circuits Development” to “Deputy Director, Semiconductor Research and Development Laboratory.” Best of all, from Kilby’s point of view, the company had essentially left him alone to do the kind of work he liked best—solving technical problems. When Haggerty came up with the formidable problem of building a pocket calculator, Jack Kilby was the obvious person to take it on.

“我大致将 Haggerty 的目标定义为可以装进外套口袋、售价不到 100 美元的东西，”Kilby 回忆道。“它必须能够进行加、减、除、乘，甚至可能还要进行平方根运算，它必须使用某种电池作为电源，以便于携带，并且不能比一本相当小的平装书重太多。”这是一个艰巨的任务。当然，今天 Kilby 描述的计算器已经非常常见，但在 1965 年，它却是前所未有的。当时有计算机可用，但没有一台计算机能达到 Haggerty 的条件。标准的电子台式计算器和全尺寸办公室打字机一样大、一样重。它包含一架又一架的电子零件和数十英尺长的电线。它使用 120 伏电压，成本约为 1,200 美元——大约是家用汽车价格的一半。

“I sort of defined Haggerty’s goal to mean something that would fit in a coat pocket and sell for less than $100,” Kilby recalled. “It would have to add, subtract, divide, and multiply, and maybe do a square root, it would have to use some sort of battery as a power supply, to make it portable, and it couldn’t be too much heavier than a fairly small paperback book.” It was a tall order. Today, of course, the calculator Kilby described is utterly commonplace, but in 1965 it was something quite unprecedented. There were calculating machines available then, but none came close to meeting Haggerty’s terms. The standard electronic desk calculator was as large and as heavy as a full-size office typewriter. It contained racks and racks of electronic parts and dozens of feet of wire. It ran on 120 volts of electricity and cost roughly $1,200—about half the price of a family car.

总统本人的创意自然成了德州仪器的优先事项。这家在保密方面绝不向中情局让步的公司将基尔比安排在一间隐蔽的办公室里，并告诉他在提到他的新项目时一定要使用代号。德州仪器之前的一个研究项目被称为 MIT 项目，因此基尔比采取了合乎逻辑的下一步行动，将他的研究项目命名为加州理工学院项目。基尔比后来回忆道：“这是一个糟糕的选择。任何听到这个名字的人都会知道，我们正在进行一个关于计算器技术的速成项目。”无论如何，加州理工学院很快就发展成为一个团队。基尔比开始在半导体实验室里寻找那些不会被发明一种新型计算器所涉及的巨大技术问题所吓倒的工程师。在众多人中，他选中了一位友好、随和的年轻德克萨斯人，名叫杰瑞·梅里曼。

The president’s own brainchild naturally became a matter of some priority at Texas Instruments. The company, which yields nothing to the CIA when it comes to secrecy, put Kilby in a shrouded office and told him always to refer to his new project by a code name. An earlier TI research program had been called Project MIT, so Kilby took the logical next step and named his effort Project Cal Tech. “It was a miserable choice,” Kilby recalled afterward. “Anybody who heard it would have figured out that we had a crash project going on calculator technology.” In any case, Cal Tech soon grew into a team effort. Kilby started looking around the semiconductor lab for engineers who would not be daunted by the sizable technical problems involved in inventing a new species of calculator. Among others, he settled on a friendly, easygoing young Texan named Jerry Merryman.

两年前，31 岁的梅里曼来到德州仪器公司，他代表了高科技行业中正在消失的一类人——自学成才的工程师。在德克萨斯州赫恩的乡村小镇完成高中教育后，他在德州农工大学四处奔波了几年，但从未在原地停留足够长的时间，无法确定专业，更不用说获得学位了。相反，他通过打零工学习电气工程，对电路几乎有一种直觉。“他是那种会花一两分钟时间研究电路，然后说，‘好吧，也许我们可以把那根绿线放在那里’的人，”基尔比说。和基尔比一样，梅里曼也坚信任何技术问题都可以解决。“我只知道，”他说，“只要你好好思考，你就会找到答案。最终答案会来。很多发明都是在工作中产生的。”

Merryman, who had come to Texas Instruments two years earlier at the age of thirty-one, represents a vanishing breed in the high-tech industry—the self-taught engineer. After finishing high school in the country town of Hearne, Texas, he floated around and through Texas A&M for a few years but never stayed in place long enough to establish a major, much less earn a degree. Instead, he learned electrical engineering on odd jobs here and there and developed an almost intuitive sense for circuitry. “He’s one of these guys who looks inside for a minute or two and then says, ‘Well, maybe if we put that green wire over there,’” Kilby said. Like Kilby, Merryman has a fundamental confidence that any technical problem can be solved. “I just know,” he said, “that you’re going to find an answer if you think about it right. Eventually it’ll come. A lot of inventions just happen on the way to work.”

1965 年，相信可以将电子计算器的尺寸、重量和成本降低十倍以上几乎是一种信仰。Kilby 意识到的第一件事就是，拆开现有的加法机来查看它们的工作原理（这一过程称为逆向工程）几乎毫无帮助，因为这种口袋大小的设备的基本架构必须是全新的。因此，团队从零开始，确定了计算器所需的基本元件。

It was almost an act of faith in 1965 to believe that you could reduce the size, weight, and cost of an electronic calculator by factors of ten or more. One of the first things Kilby realized was that tearing apart existing adding machines to see how they worked—a process known as reverse engineering—would offer little, if any, help, because the basic architecture of this pocket-size device would have to be completely new. And so the team started at ground zero, setting down the fundamental elements that their calculator would require.

按照阿兰·图灵和约翰·冯·诺依曼制定的架构，所有数字设备，从最强大的大型超级计算机到最简单的手持电子游戏，都可以分为四个基本部分，服务于四个基本功能：

In accordance with the architecture worked out by Alan Turing and John von Neumann, all digital devices, from the most powerful mainframe supercomputer to the simplest handheld electronic game, can be divided into four basic parts serving four essential functions:

输入：从操作员、传感设备或其他计算机接收信息并将其传送到处理单元的单元。对于计算器来说，这意味着键盘。

Input: The unit that receives information from a human operator, a sensory device, or another computer and delivers it to the processing unit. For the calculator, this meant a keyboard.

内存：保存数据（数字、字或指令代码）的单元，直到处理单元准备好接收它。

Memory: The unit that holds data—numbers, words, or instruction code—until the processing unit is ready to receive it.

处理器：将数据传送至各个内存段或从各个内存段传送数据并处理数据的中央控制电路。在计算器中，处理器执行算术运算。

Processor: The central control circuit that transfers data to and from various memory segments and manipulates the data. In a calculator, the processor performs the arithmetic.

输出：显示各次计算结果的显示单元。

Output: The display unit that shows the results of each calculation.

除了这四个基本部分之外，Kilby 还必须担心非便携式电子设备上不存在的问题——电源。打算放在口袋中随身携带并在任何地方使用的计算器不能设计为使用墙上插座提供的 120 伏电源。相反，计算器必须使用电池供电；电压被限制在 5 伏左右。

In addition to these four basic sections, Kilby had to worry about something that is no problem on nonportable electronic devices—a power supply. A calculator meant to be carried in a pocket and used anywhere could not be designed for the 120 volts of power available from a wall socket. Instead, the calculator would have to operate from a battery; it would be limited to about 5 volts.

因为哈格蒂很着急，而基尔比对完成这项工作有基本的信心，所以团队决定全面出击：团队将同时解决所有问题，并希望最终一切顺利。输入部分（基本上就是设计一个小型、节能的键盘）被分配给了一位名叫詹姆斯·范塔塞尔的工程师。基尔比自己负责输出部分和电源。内存和中央处理器（计算器的电子内部部件）是梅里曼的职责。

Because Haggerty was in a hurry, and because Kilby had a basic confidence that the job could be done, the team decided on an all-points attack: the group would work on all their problems at once and hope that everything came together in the end. The input section—basically, the design of a small, power-efficient keyboard—was assigned to an engineer named James Van Tassel. Kilby himself took on the output section and the power supply. The memory and central processor—the calculator’s electronic innards—were Merryman’s responsibility.

“基本规则是，所有东西都必须比你想象的要小，”梅里曼后来说道。“现在，我们做了一件事，将整个内存缩减为一个寄存器。[“寄存器”在计算机术语中是指可以存储十几个二进制数字的短晶体管链。] 唯一的问题是，你需要很多电线进入该寄存器，而机箱内部没有足够的空间容纳这么多电线。” 为了解决这个问题，梅里曼设计了一个特殊的“移位寄存器”——一种布局类似于大型礼堂的存储电路，只有一个狭窄的过道供人们进出。 “这样，所有的位都可以进入那里，以单列行进，而且由于它们一次只进入一个，所以只用一根电线就可以输入很多数字。” 不过，梅里曼最严重的问题是逻辑电路。当时的台式电子计算器使用数千个逻辑门——AND、OR 和 NOT 电路——来执行二进制计算。 “我们试图仅用三条硅条来构建整个电路，”梅里曼说（“硅条”是工程师对硅片的俚语）。“这样一共就剩下大约 400 个门了——可能是 4,000 个晶体管。我设计出了一个只需要 400 个门的处理单元。它也几乎成功了——只是它始终无法弄清楚如何将小数点放在正确的位置。这需要一大堆额外的门。”最后，团队不得不采用四芯片设计，总共有 535 个逻辑门。

“The basic rule was, everything had to be smaller than you’d ever thought you could make it,” Merryman said later. “Now, one thing we did, we reduced the whole memory down to a single register. [“Register” is computerese for a short chain of transistors that can store a dozen or so binary digits.] The only problem with that was you’d need a lot of wires coming into that register, and there wasn’t much room inside that case for a lot of wires.” To solve that, Merryman designed a special “shift register”—a storage circuit that is laid out something like a large auditorium with only a single narrow aisle for people to come in and out. “That way, all the bits could come in there, sort of march in single file, and since they come in one at a time you get a lot of numbers in with just one wire.” Merryman’s most serious problem, though, was with the logic circuitry. The desktop electronic calculators of that time employed thousands of logic gates—AND, OR, and NOT circuits—to carry out binary calculations. “We were trying to build this whole circuit with only three bars,” Merryman said (“bar” is the engineer’s slang term for a silicon chip). “That left me about 400 gates in all—maybe 4,000 transistors. And I worked out a processing unit that only needed 400 gates. It almost worked, too—except it never could figure out how to get the decimal point in the right place. That took a whole bunch of extra gates.” In the end, the team had to settle for a four-chip design with a total of 535 logic gates.

与此同时，范塔塞尔开发了键盘的可行模型，基尔比找到了一块可充电电池，可以让设备运行三个小时，然后才会耗尽电量。内存、处理器、输入和电源都完好无损。只剩下一个问题——用于显示答案的输出单元。但事实证明，这是一个异常棘手的问题。

Meanwhile, Van Tassel had developed a working model for the keyboard, and Kilby had found a rechargeable battery that would run the device for three hours before running down. Memory, processor, input, and power supply were in good shape. That left only one problem—the output unit, for displaying the answer. But this proved to be an unusually thorny problem.

当时的台式计算器使用阴极射线管（一种微型电视机）进行显示，但这种系统对于便携式机器来说太重、太脆弱、太耗电。有一段时间，Kilby 曾希望使用一排微型霓虹灯来显示答案。结果发现，该系统至少需要 40 伏电压，这是不可能的。就在加州理工学院团队所在的走廊另一头，一位 TI 研究人员正在研究一种新的电子设备——发光二极管（LED），当微小电流通过时，它会发出明亮的彩色光。事实上，几年后，这项技术确实成为计算器和手表的标准显示技术；不过，在 1965 年，二极管还没有发出太多的光。

Contemporary desk calculators used a cathode ray tube—a miniature television set—for display, but such a system was far too heavy, fragile, and power-hungry for a portable machine. For a while, Kilby had hoped to use a row of tiny neon lights to display the answers. As it turned out, that system required at least 40 volts—out of the question. Just down the hall from the Cal Tech team, a TI researcher was working on a new electronic device—a light-emitting diode, or LED—that was supposed to shine with a bright colored light when a minute current passed through it. This technology did, in fact, become the standard display technique for calculators and watches a few years later; in 1965, though, the diodes were not yet emitting much light.

别无选择，只能发明新东西。因此，Kilby 开发了一种热敏打印技术，其中低功耗打印头会将图像“刻录”到热敏纸上；这个想法非常完美，而且该工艺至今仍在低成本、节能的打印机中广泛使用。

There was nothing to do but invent something new. So Kilby developed a thermal printing technique, in which a low-power printing head would “burn” images into heat-sensitive paper; the idea worked perfectly, and the process is still widely used in low-cost, power-efficient printers.

所有这些活动只用了十二个多月的时间。1966 年末的一天，Merryman 回忆道，“这东西被放在桌子上，就像一个人躺在手术台上一样，整个身体都裂开了，电线到处都是，我们输入了一个问题，它就成功了！” 静静地，几乎是瞬间，正确的答案就从机器的一条纸带上旋转出来了。加州理工学院的团队把他们的原型带给了 Haggerty，Haggerty 满意地点了点头，然后打电话给专利律师。又过了一年，设计才得以完善，并提交了专利申请——“微型电子计算器”。尽管从那时起，手持计算器已经取得了长足的进步，但加州理工学院团队的架构仍然是所有此类设备的核心；即使在今天，许多 TI 型号仍带有原始 Kilby–Merryman–Van Tassel 专利的编号：3,819,921。

All this activity consumed a little more than twelve months. One day late in 1966, Merryman recalled, “the thing was all laid out on the table like a person spread out on an operating table, all split open, wire running all over, and we punched in a problem, and it worked!” Silently, and almost instantaneously, the right answer came spinning out of the machine on a strip of paper tape. The Cal Tech group took their prototype in to Haggerty, who nodded with satisfaction—and called in the patent lawyers. It took another year before the design was perfected and the patent application—for a “Miniature Electronic Calculator”—could be filed. Although handheld calculators have come a long, long way since then, the Cal Tech team’s architecture is still the gist of all such devices; even today many TI models carry the number of the original Kilby–Merryman–Van Tassel patent: 3,819,921.

新设备的电子元件非常超前，以至于花了数年时间才生产出最初的量产型号。世界上第一台袖珍计算器 Pocketronic 直到 1971 年 4 月（确切地说是 4 月 14 日）才推出（营销人员认为它们可能会引起纳税人在 1040 表格上加班的注意）。按照今天的标准，第一款型号已经过时了——它是一款四功能（加、减、乘、除）计算器，重量为 2.5 磅，售价约为 150 美元。但它的销量却非常火爆。

The electronics of the new device were so far ahead of their time that it took years to turn out the initial production models. The world’s first pocket calculator, the Pocketronic, was not introduced until April 1971—April 14, to be exact (the marketing people thought they might win the attention of taxpayers working late on Form 1040). By today’s standards, that first model was a dinosaur —a four-function (add, subtract, multiply, divide) calculator that weighed 2½ pounds and cost about $150. But it sold like crazy.

您需要一台性能相当强大的计算器才能知道接下来发生的事情。1972 年，美国售出了 500 万台袖珍计算器。随着新功能的增加和价格暴跌，销量逐年翻番。借用帕特里克·哈格蒂的话来说，袖珍计算器变得无处不在。第一台袖珍计算器在美国销售后的十年内，该国的计算器数量超过了人口数量。正如哈格蒂所预测的那样，这种新的微电子器件创造了一个以前根本不存在的市场。数千万从未考虑过购买加法机或计算尺的人决定拥有一台袖珍计算器。“有多少家庭主妇真的需要知道一个数字的平方根？”分析这一现象的两位英国学者 Ernest Braun 和 Stuart MacDonald 写道。“但是，这项技术便宜得可笑。只需花费一周家务费用的一小部分，就可以永久获得任何数字的平方根。”

You would need a fairly high-powered calculator to keep track of what happened next. Five million pocket calculators were sold in the United States in 1972. As new features were added and prices plummeted sales doubled year after year. To borrow a word from Patrick Haggerty, the pocket calculator became pervasive. Within a decade after the first pocket calculator was sold in the United States, the country had more calculators than people. As Haggerty had predicted, the new microelectronic gadget created a market that had simply not existed before. Tens of millions of people who never considered purchasing an adding machine or a slide rule decided they wanted to own a pocket calculator. “How many housewives actually need to know the square root of a number?” wrote Ernest Braun and Stuart MacDonald, two English scholars who analyzed the phenomenon. “But then, the technology is ridiculously cheap. For a fraction of the cost of one week’s housekeeping, one can have permanent access to any number’s square root.”

如今，四功能计算器（业界称之为“普通计算器”）的售价约为 3.95 美元，美国市场已基本饱和。然而，美国人每年仍会购买 2600 万到 3000 万台替换计算器，包括股票经纪人、会计师、纳税申报员、债券交易员、牧场主、自行车赛车手、厨师以及销售人员能想到的任何其他细分市场专用型号。全球计算器市场每年的销售额达 10 亿美元，每年的销售额接近 1 亿台计算器。在日本，卡西欧制造了内置计算器的算盘。有些人仍然使用古老的计数器来检查计算器显示屏上弹出的结果。

Today, with a four-function calculator—a model the industry calls “plain vanilla”—available for $3.95 or so, the U.S. market is virtually saturated. Yet Americans still buy between 26 million and 30 million replacement calculators each year, including specialized models for stockbrokers, accountants, tax return preparers, bond traders, cattle ranchers, bicycle racers, cooks, and any other market niche the salespeople can dream up. Worldwide, the calculator market is a billion-dollar-per-year business, with sales approaching 100 million calculators each year. In Japan, Casio makes an abacus with a built-in calculator. Some people still use the ancient counter to check the results that pop up on the calculator’s display screen.

芯片的另一个消费应用是电子或数字手表，它与手持计算器诞生于同一年，现在同样“普及”。从技术角度来看，数字手表比计算机容易制造。它基于一种名为晶体振荡的便捷自然现象，物理学家称其为某些元素的纯晶体在连接到电流源（例如小电池）时会振荡或来回振动。振动频率取决于元素的原子结构；但对于给定材料，振动频率永远不会变化。例如，某些常见矿物石英晶体每秒会精确地来回振动 3,579,545 次。

Another consumer application of the chip, born the same year as the handheld calculator and just as “pervasive” now, was the electronic, or digital, wristwatch. As a technical matter, the digital watch is markedly easier to make than a calculating machine. It is based on a convenient natural phenomenon called crystal oscillation, which is the physicist’s way of saying that pure crystals of certain elements will oscillate, or vibrate back and forth, when connected to a source of electric current (e.g., a small battery). The rate of vibration depends on the atomic structure of the element; for a given material, though, the rate never varies. Certain crystals of the common mineral quartz, for example, will vibrate back and forth, back-and-forth, precisely 3,579,545 times each second.

精密的振荡器是任何钟表的核心，无论是落地钟的 5 英尺黄铜摆锤还是手表的 0.5 厘米石英片。钟表匠所需要的只是一种计数来回振荡的机制，计数是二进制逻辑门可以执行的简单任务之一。在数字手表中，称为 JK 触发器的逻辑门会计数晶体的振动。每当计数达到 3,579,545 时，门就会向显示单元发送一个脉冲，手表就会记录下一秒的流逝。同一芯片上的另一组门计数 60 秒并更新分钟显示；另一组门计数分钟以更新小时。如果你拆开你的数字手表（为什么不呢？你可以花 5 美元买一块新的），你会发现，传统钟表的齿轮、弹簧、轴承和衬套只剩下四个部件：电池、晶体、芯片和显示单元。

A precise oscillator, be it the 5-foot brass pendulum of a grandfather clock or the .5-cm flake of quartz in a wristwatch, is the heart of any timepiece. All the watchmaker needs is a mechanism to count the back-and-forth oscillations—and counting is one of the simple tasks that binary logic gates can perform. In the digital watch a logic gate called a JK flip-flop counts the vibrations of the crystal. Every time the count hits 3,579,545, the gate sends a pulse to the display unit and the watch records the passage of another second. Another set of gates on the same chip counts 60 seconds and updates the minute display; another counts minutes to update the hour. If you tore apart your digital watch (why not? you can get a new one for five bucks), you would find, in place of the gears, springs, bearings, and bushings of a traditional timepiece, only four parts: a battery, a crystal, a chip, and the display unit.

尽管如此，第一款电子手表——由一家美国公司以 Pulsar 品牌生产，并于 1971 年秋季推出——被定位为高端产品。24 克拉黄金 Pulsar 售价 2,000 美元；不锈钢款售价 275 美元。随着电子手表的改进——变得更小、更易读、更省电——其价格也随之下降。

Nonetheless, the first digital watch—produced by an American firm under the Pulsar brand name and introduced in the fall of 1971—was marketed as a decidedly high-bracket item. The 24-karat gold Pulsar was priced at $2,000; a stainless steel model cost $275. Characteristically, as the electronic watch improved—getting smaller, easier to read, more power-efficient—its price fell.

美国读者可能已经从这段历史中发现了沙文主义的正当借口。尽管索尼、精工、佳能和卡西欧等品牌占据主导地位，但微电子时代的主要消费产品都是纯粹的美国佬的独创性的结果，而使这些进步成为可能的根本性突破——整体理念——也是如此。民意调查显示，许多美国人认为微电子革命只是从日本进口的又一个产品——日本技术和营销天才的又一个体现。事实上，天才的流动方向却相反。微电子的历史就是日本公司——以及世界各地的其他公司——向美国创新者学习的历史。这种熟悉的模式再次在微处理器——一种使微电子在普及道路上走得比以往更远的设备——的发展中上演。

The American reader may have spotted in this history a perfectly legitimate excuse for chauvinism. Despite the predominance of names like Sony and Seiko, Canon and Casio, the major consumer products of the microelectronic age all resulted from pure Yankee ingenuity, as did the fundamental breakthrough—the monolithic idea—that made such advances possible in the first place. Polls show that many Americans consider the microelectronic revolution just another import from Japan—one more manifestation of the Japanese genius for technology and marketing. In fact, the flow of genius has gone in the other direction. The history of microelectronics has been a history of Japanese firms—and other companies around the world—learning at the feet of American innovators. This familiar pattern was played out once again with the development of the device that has taken microelectronics further than ever down the path of pervasiveness—the microprocessor.

微处理器的故事始于东京，但场景迅速转移到硅谷。1969 年，日本商用机器制造商 Busicom 计划生产一系列新的台式打印机计算器，但在日本找不到能够设计这些机器所需的复杂集成电路的工程师。Busicom 向鲍勃·诺伊斯寻求帮助，当时他仍在组建新公司英特尔。这家日本公司与英特尔签订了一项合同，要求为新系列机器设计和生产 12 个互连芯片。Busicom 派出一组工程师前往英特尔监督这项工作。与此同时，诺伊斯将问题交给了一个单人团队——马西安·E·“泰德”·霍夫，一位 34 岁的博士，他被更广阔的工业前景所吸引，放弃了斯坦福的教职。尽管霍夫是微电路专家，但他真正的野心更大。他一直想设计自己的电脑。

The story of the microprocessor begins in Tokyo, but the scene shifts rapidly to Silicon Valley. In 1969 a Japanese business-machine manufacturer, Busicom, was planning a new family of desktop printer calculators but could find no engineers in Japan capable of designing the complex set of integrated circuits the machines would require. Busicom sought help—from Bob Noyce, who was still putting together his new company, Intel. The Japanese signed a contract with Intel calling for the design and production of twelve interlinked chips for the new line of machines. Busicom sent a team of engineers to Intel to oversee the work. Noyce, meanwhile, handed the problem to a one-man team—Marcian E. “Ted” Hoff, a thirty-four-year-old Ph.D. who had been lured away from a teaching job at Stanford by the prospect of broader horizons in industry. Although Hoff was an expert on microcircuits, his real ambitions were somewhat larger. He had always wanted to design his own computer.

当 Busicom 工程师向霍夫展示他们所需的 12 块芯片的初步方案时，这位美国人大吃一惊。这种安排极其复杂 — — 一些最简单的功能需要将同一个数字传入和传出两个或三个不同的内存寄存器 — — 而且不可能以可接受的价格实现。更糟糕的是，在霍夫看来，这种设计不够优雅。花费数十个人年去设计一套只能在一小组机器上使用的专用电路，简直是浪费。

When the Busicom engineers showed Hoff their tentative plans for the twelve chips they needed, the American was appalled. The arrangement was outrageously complex—some of the simplest functions would require sending the same number into and out of two or three different memory registers—and could not possibly be implemented at an acceptable price. Even worse, in Hoff’s eyes, the design was inelegant. It was downright wasteful to put dozens of man-years into designing a set of specialized circuits that could be used in only one small group of machines.

最后这点对诺伊斯来说也很重要。到 60 年代末，诺伊斯担心各种集成电路的迅速普及，每种集成电路都有其特殊用途。每个想要为其产品配备芯片的客户都要求专门为该产品设计芯片。“如果这种情况持续下去，”诺伊斯和霍夫后来写道，“所需电路的数量将超过电路设计师的数量。与此同时，每个电路的相对使用率将下降……设计成本增加和使用率减少将使制造商无法在大量用户群体中摊销成本，并会削弱学习曲线的优势。”

This last concern was important to Noyce as well. By the end of the sixties, Noyce was worried about the rapid proliferation of different integrated circuits, each designed for its own special purpose. Every customer who wanted a chip for his product was demanding a custom-designed chip just for that product. “If this continued,” Noyce and Hoff wrote later, “the number of circuits needed would proliferate beyond the number of circuit designers. At the same time, the relative usage of each circuit would fall. . . . Increased design cost and diminished usage would prevent manufacturers from amortizing costs over a large user population and would cut off the advantages of the learning curve.”

展望未来，诺伊斯认为解决专用集成电路泛滥问题的办法是开发通用芯片，这种芯片可以大批量生产，并可针对特定应用进行调整（“编程”）。霍夫对这个概念很感兴趣，坦率地说，他在寻找尝试的机会。当 Busicom 的任务落到他头上时，他抓住了这个机会。这位设计师放弃了 Busicom 的想法，为日本人提出了一个惊人的新设计：一种通用处理器电路，可以为各种工作进行编程，包括执行 Busicom 机器的算术运算。霍夫指出，这种方法可以实现比这家日本公司建议的简单得多的电路。事实上，到 1971 年夏天，霍夫已经能够将计算器中央处理器 (CPU) 的所有逻辑电路放在一个芯片上。CPU 可以与一个用于内存的芯片、一个用于存储寄存器的芯片和一个用于保存程序的芯片耦合；整个计算器系列只需要四块集成电路。事实上，在电路设计师的工作中，霍夫实现了自己的梦想：他设计了自己的通用计算机。

Looking ahead, Noyce saw that the solution to proliferation of special-purpose integrated circuits would be the development of general-purpose chips that could be manufactured in huge quantities and adapted (“programmed”) for specific applications. Hoff had been intrigued by this concept and was frankly looking for an opportunity to give it a try. When the Busicom assignment landed in his lap, he grabbed the chance. Scrapping Busicom’s ideas, the designer came up with a strikingly new design for the Japanese: a general-purpose processor circuit that could be programmed for a variety of jobs, including the performance of arithmetic in Busicom’s machines. As Hoff pointed out, this approach would permit much simpler circuitry than the Japanese firm had suggested. Indeed, by the summer of 1971, Hoff was able to put all the logic circuitry of a calculator’s central processor unit, or CPU, on a single chip. The CPU could be coupled with one chip for memory, one for storage registers, and one to hold the program; the entire family of calculators would require only four integrated circuits. In his job as a circuit designer, Hoff had, in fact, fulfilled his personal dream: he had designed his own general-purpose computer.

然而，到了 1971 年夏天，计算器行业正处于巨大变革的阵痛之中。那年春天，杰克·基尔比 (Jack Kilby) 推出了一款售价 150 美元的手持计算器，彻底改变了规则；像 Busicom 这样拥有 1,000 美元重磅计算器的公司陷入了巨大的困境。因此，Busicom 告诉英特尔，它不能再按照最初商定的价格购买新芯片。随后进行了谈判。Busicom 获得了较低的价格，但作为回报，它放弃了几乎无价的东西：对芯片的独家使用权。英特尔现在可以自由地向任何人出售 Hoff 的通用片上 CPU。

By the summer of 1971, though, the calculator industry was in the throes of great change. The introduction of Jack Kilby’s $150 handheld calculator that spring had completely changed the rules; companies like Busicom with their heavyweight $1,000 machines were in big trouble. Accordingly, Busicom told Intel it could no longer pay the price originally agreed upon for the new chips. Negotiations ensued. Busicom got its lower price, but gave up something in return that turned out to be almost priceless: its exclusive right to the chips. Intel was now free to sell Hoff’s general-purpose CPU-on-a-chip to anybody.

但会有人买吗？这个问题在英特尔内部引发了激烈的争论。营销人员认为单芯片 CPU 毫无价值。充其量，几家小型计算机公司每年可能会购买几千块芯片；这甚至还不够支付广告费。一些董事担心新电路与英特尔的实际业务相差太远。毕竟，英特尔是一家电路制造商；霍夫的新芯片虽然只是一个电路，但它实际上相当于一个完整的系统——几乎是一整台计算机。诺伊斯和霍夫后来写道，他们面临着强大的压力，要求放弃整个项目。

But would anybody buy it? That question spurred furious debate at Intel. The marketing people could see no value in a one-chip CPU. At best, a few minicomputer firms might buy a few thousand of the chips each year; that wouldn’t even pay for the advertising. Some directors were worried that the new circuit was too far afield from Intel’s real business. Intel, after all, was a circuit maker; Hoff’s new chip was a single circuit, all right, but it really amounted to a complete system—almost a whole computer. There was strong pressure, Noyce and Hoff wrote later, to drop the whole thing.

英特尔当时刚聘请了一位新的营销经理，艾德·盖尔巴赫，他来到公司时正值这场争议。碰巧的是，盖尔巴赫最初在德州仪器从事半导体业务；和德州仪器的其他人一样，他深受帕特里克·哈格蒂的世界观的影响。盖尔巴赫立即意识到，英特尔通过生产通用芯片扭转了行业的发展方向。盖尔巴赫认为，“通用”只是“普及”的另一种说法。他说，新设备的真正市场将是全新的市场。有了这种单芯片中央处理器（如今称为微处理器），集成电路可以“首次将智能融入许多产品中”。

Intel had recently hired a new marketing manager, Ed Gelbach, and he arrived at the company in the midst of this controversy. As it happened, Gelbach had started in the semiconductor business at Texas Instruments; like everyone else at TI, he was steeped in Patrick Haggerty’s view of the world. Gelbach realized immediately that Intel had reversed the course of the industry by producing a general-purpose chip. “General purpose,” Gelbach saw, was just another way of saying “pervasive.” The real markets for the new device, he said, would be completely new markets. With this one-chip central processor—known today as a microprocessor—the integrated circuit could “insert intelligence into many products for the first time.”

于是，英特尔的新款“4004”集成电路于 1971 年底以 200 美元的价格开始销售。英特尔略带夸张地将该设备宣传为“芯片上的计算机”。渐渐地，随着人们意识到它真的可以在任何地方工作，微处理器开始出现在几乎任何地方。一个典型的应用是世界上第一个“智能”交通信号灯。它可以通过声音和光传感器告知高峰时间何时开始、高峰或结束；微型 CPU 会根据情况改变红绿灯的时间，以最大限度地提高交通流量。很快就出现了智能电梯、智能屠夫秤、智能加油泵、智能牲畜喂食器、智能静脉注射针头，以及令人眼花缭乱的其他“智能”设备。K2 滑雪板中的微处理器会对振动做出反应，并使滑雪板横向变硬，减少滑行时的弹跳。网球拍中的微处理器可以感知球击中球拍的位置，并立即调整弦的张力，使该点成为球拍此次击球的“最佳击球点”。

And so Intel’s new “4004” integrated circuit went on sale for $200 late in 1971. With mild hyperbole, Intel advertised the device as a “computer on a chip.” Gradually, as people realized that it really could work just about anywhere, the microprocessor started showing up just about everywhere. A typical application was the world’s first “smart” traffic light. It could tell, through sound and light sensors, when rush hour was starting, peaking, or running down; the tiny CPU would alter the timing of red and green in response to conditions to maximize traffic flow. Soon there was a smart elevator, a smart butcher’s scale, a smart gas pump, a smart cattle feeder, a smart intravenous needle, and a bewildering array of other “smart” devices. A microprocessor in a K2 ski would react to vibrations and stiffen the ski laterally, reducing bounce on the run. A microprocessor in a tennis racket senses where the ball has hit the racket and instantly adjusts string tension to make that very point the racket’s “sweet spot” for that one shot.

当然，德州仪器公司并不乐意让其劲敌在如此重要的新战场上抢占先机。在为客户签订合同时，客户需要“智能”数据终端电路（一种可以与远方大型计算机通信的键盘屏幕组合），德州仪器公司的一位工程师 Gary Boone 开发了一款略有不同的单芯片处理器单元。Boone 的版本称为 TMS 1000，获得了微处理器的第一项专利。随后，在 1971 年底，Boone 和另一位德州仪器工程师 Michael Cochran 制作了第一个集成电路原型，这实际上是一个芯片上的计算机。单个单片电路包含计算机的所有四个基本部分：输入电路、内存、可以处理数据的中央处理器和输出电路。一年后，英特尔推出了第二代微处理器；由于它的容量大约是原 4004 芯片的两倍，新设备被称为 8008。介绍价格为 200 美元。后来，8080、8086 逐渐演化为一系列功能越来越强大的处理器芯片，这些芯片为功能越来越强大的个人计算机提供动力：80286、80386、80486、奔腾、奔腾 ​​Pro、奔腾 III 和奔腾 IV。奔腾 IV 芯片的运行速度比 8008 快五百倍左右，价格也差不多。

Texas Instruments, of course, was hardly pleased to let its arch-rival steal a march on such an important new battleground. Working on a contract for a customer who wanted circuitry for a “smart” data terminal—a keyboard-screen combination that could communicate with large computers far away—a TI engineer named Gary Boone developed a slightly different version of a single-chip processor unit. Boone’s version, called the TMS 1000, received the first patent awarded for a microprocessor. Then, at the end of 1971, Boone and another Texas Instruments engineer, Michael Cochran, produced the first prototype of an integrated circuit that actually was a computer on a chip. The single monolithic circuit contained all four basic parts of a computer: input circuits, memory, a central processor that could manipulate data, and output circuits. A year later, Intel came out with a second-generation microprocessor; since it had roughly twice the capacity of the original 4004 chip, the new device was called the 8008. The introductory price was $200. That morphed into the 8080, the 8086, and then a series of progressively more powerful processor chips that powered progressively more powerful personal computers: the 80286, 80386, 80486, Pentium, Pentium Pro, Pentium III, and Pentium IV. The Pentium IV chip operated at a speed about five hundred times faster than the 8008; the price was about the same.

正是微处理器和一组称为传感器的设备的结合，才最终将微电子技术带入了每个家庭、学校和企业。传感器是一种能量转换器，它将一种形式的能量转换成另一种形式的能量。电话听筒是一种传感器，它将你的声音转换成通过电线传输的电脉冲。计算器上的键盘将手指的物理压力转换成中央处理器可以理解的脉冲。其他传感器可以将声音、热量、光线、湿度和化学刺激转换成电子脉冲。这些信息可以发送到微处理器，微处理器根据预编程的指令决定如何对环境变化作出反应。

It was the marriage of the microprocessor and a group of devices called transducers that finally brought microelectronics into every home, school, and business. A transducer is an energy translator; it converts one form of energy into another. A telephone receiver is a transducer, changing your voice into electrical pulses that travel through the wire. The keyboard on a calculator converts physical pressure from a finger into pulses that the central processor can understand. Other sensors can turn sound, heat, light, moisture, and chemical stimuli into electronic impulses. This information can be sent to a microprocessor that decides, according to preprogrammed directions, how to react to changes in its environment.

热敏传感器可以判断汽车发动机是否以最高效率燃烧燃料；如果不是，传感器就会向微处理器中的逻辑门发送脉冲，逻辑门会调整化油器以获得最佳的燃油和空气混合物。收银台的光敏传感器（我们熟悉的电眼）会读取牛奶盒上的通用产品代码，并向收银机内的微处理器发送二进制脉冲流。中央处理器查询内存以找出今天分配给特定产品代码的价格，将该价格添加到总账单中，然后耐心等待（这一切都花了千分之三秒）传感器读取下一个产品代码。干衣机内的湿度传感器和热量传感器不断测量湿衣服并调整机器，以便洗衣在最短的时间内完成。

A heat-sensitive transducer can tell whether a car’s engine is burning fuel at peak efficiency; if it is not, the transducer sends a pulse to logic gates in a microprocessor that adjust the carburetor to get the optimum mixture of fuel and air. A light-sensitive transducer—the familiar electric eye—at the checkout stand reads the Universal Product Code on a carton of milk and sends a stream of binary pulses to a microprocessor inside the cash register. The central processor queries memory to find out the price assigned to that specific product code today, adds that price to the total bill, and waits patiently (this has all taken three thousandths of a second) for the transducer to read the next product code. A moisture sensor and a heat sensor inside the clothes dryer constantly measure the wet clothes and adjust the machinery so that the laundry will be finished in the shortest possible time.

微电子技术在人体内发挥作用。控制语音合成芯片的微处理器可以连接到手掌大小的键盘，让哑巴也能说话。目前正在开发的芯片可能能够将声音转换成大脑可以理解的脉冲——不仅仅是电子助听器，还是可以取代有缺陷的有机耳的电子耳。其他实验表明，盲人可以植入导盲眼芯片——一种与微处理器相连的光敏传感器，可以向大脑发送可理解的脉冲。

Microelectronics is at work inside the human body. A microprocessor that controls a speech-synthesizing chip can be connected to a palm-size keyboard that permits the mute to speak. Now under development is a chip that may be able to turn sound into impulses the brain can understand—not just an electronic hearing aid, but an electronic ear that can replace a faulty organic version. Other experiments suggest the possibility of an implantable seeing-eye chip for the blind—a light-sensitive transducer connected to a microprocessor that sends intelligible impulses to the brain.

在人们为片上计算机设想的无数新应用中，计算机是其中之一——一种全新的计算机，其设计目的不是大公司或强大的官僚机构，而是普通人。个人计算机始于 1975 年 1 月出版的《大众 电子》杂志，这是一本深受业余无线电爱好者和电子爱好者喜爱的杂志。该期杂志的封面大肆宣扬“项目突破！世界上第一款微型计算机套件可与商用机型相媲美”。在封面中，读者可以看到自制“微型计算机”的计划，其中英特尔 8080 微处理器取代了当时标准办公计算机中的数百个独立逻辑芯片。《大众电子》套件非常简陋，但它让任何会使用烙铁的人都有机会拥有一台计算机——总投资约为 800 美元。在当时，最小的商用机型售价约为 30,000 美元，这确实是一个突破。成千上万的读者寄来了这本杂志。其他电子杂志也开始提供自己的电脑套件。一年之内，成千上万的美国人开始摆弄自己的基于微处理器的个人电脑。

Among the countless new applications that people dreamed up for the computer-on-a-chip was, of all things, a computer—a completely new computer designed, not for big corporations or mighty bureaucracies, but rather for ordinary people. The personal computer got its start in the January 1975 issue of Popular Electronics magazine, a journal widely read among ham radio buffs and electronics hobbyists. The cover of that issue trumpeted a “Project Breakthrough! World’s First Minicomputer Kit to Rival Commercial Models.” Inside, the reader found plans for a homemade “microcomputer” in which the Intel 8080 microprocessor replaced hundreds of individual logic chips found in the standard office computer of the day. The Popular Electronics kit was strictly bare-bones, but it gave anybody who was handy with a soldering iron the chance to have a computer—for a total investment of about $800. At a time when the smallest available commercial model sold for some $30,000, that was indeed a breakthrough. Readers sent in by the thousands. The other electronics magazines started offering computer kits of their own. Within a year thousands of Americans were tinkering with their own microprocessor-based personal computers.

在那个开创性的日子里，个人计算机社区就像一个全国性的合作社，每个新计算机用户都热切地与其他人分享技术和程序。这是一个遵循列宁主义古老格言的社区，即“各尽所能，按需分配”。如果你需要一个程序来让你的自制计算机计算平方根，而我有能力编写一个程序来做到这一点，我会自豪地与你分享我的杰作——免费。但第一批开始编写基于《大众电子》 8080 的计算机的人中，有一位哈佛本科生有不同的想法。20 世纪 70 年代末，他为基于 8080 的 PC 编写了第一个真正有用的程序，即 BASIC 编程语言的简单版本。然后他做了一件了不起的事情：他为此收费。为此，这位年轻的程序员遭到了许多同行的攻击和诽谤。然而，有人愿意为 BASIC 程序支付 50 美元。销售额增长如此之快，以至于这位大学生在父母失望的情况下辍学，并创办了一家销售新一代“微型计算机”软件的小公司。比尔·盖茨将自己的公司命名为微软。

The personal computer community in those pioneering days was a sort of national cooperative, with each new computer user eagerly sharing techniques and programs with everybody else. It was a community that lived by the old Leninist maxim, “From each according to his ability, to each according to his need.” If you needed a program that would make your homebrew computer compute square roots, and if I had the ability to write a program to do just that, I would proudly share my handiwork with you—for free. But among the first to start programming the Popular Electronics 8080-based computer was a Harvard undergraduate who had a different idea. In the late 1970s he wrote the first genuinely useful program for 8080-based PCs, a simple version of the BASIC programming language. And then he did an amazing thing: he charged money for it. For this, the young programmer was attacked and vilified by many of his fellow buffs. And yet there were people willing to pay $50 for the BASIC program. Sales grew so fast that the undergraduate dropped out of college, to the despair of his parents, and started a tiny business selling software for the new breed of “microcomputers.” Bill Gates named his company Microsoft.

这些早期的计算机爱好者——“瘾君子”可能是一个更贴切的描述性术语——开始组建俱乐部，在那里他们可以聚在一起无休止地争论位图图形的最佳方法、软盘的正确接口或 8080、6502 和 Z80 微处理器的相对优点。在硅谷的一个名为“家酿计算机俱乐部”的组织中，两位年轻的计算机爱好者史蒂文·乔布斯和斯蒂芬·沃兹尼亚克坚信个人计算机的市场肯定比相对较小的电子修补匠世界更大。他们决定采用的策略是设计一款外观漂亮、使用简单的机器。重要的是个人计算机不能令人生畏；甚至机器的名称也必须听起来很亲切。最终，乔布斯选择了他能想到的最友好的词——“苹果”。它与计算机或电子产品无关，但这正是重点所在。两人创办了一家名为苹果的计算机公司。

These early computer buffs—“addicts” might be a more descriptive term—began forming clubs where they could get together for endless debates about the best approach to bit-mapped graphics or the proper interface for a floppy disk or the relative merits of the 8080, 6502, and Z80 microprocessors. At one such organization in Silicon Valley, a group called the Homebrew Computer Club, two young computer-philes, Steven Jobs and Stephen Wozniak, convinced themselves that there had to be a larger market for personal computers than the relatively small world of electronics tinkerers. The gimmick, they decided, was to design a machine that was pretty to look at and simple to use. The important thing was that the personal computer could not be intimidating; even the name of the machine would have to sound congenial. Eventually, Jobs settled on the friendliest word he could think of—“apple.” It had nothing to do with computers or electronics, but then that was the whole point. The two started a computer company called Apple.

曾经有一段时间，计算机体积巨大、价格高昂，甚至连专家都望而生畏。社会学专家经常警告说，普通人可能会成为少数买得起并懂计算机的企业和政府老大哥手中的棋子。将权力集中在计算机控制者手中是奥威尔《1984》的基本原则。但到了真正的 1984 年，微电子技术的大规模普及导致了计算能力的大规模分散。在真正的 1984 年，数百万普通人可以一点一点地匹敌政府或企业计算机。在真正的 1984 年，典型的计算机用户已经成为坐在键盘前写七年级科学报告的小弟弟。

There was a time—when computers were huge, impossibly expensive, and daunting even to experts—when the sociological savants regularly warned that ordinary people could become pawns at the hands of the few corporate and governmental Big Brothers that could afford and understand computers. This centralization of power in the hands of the computer’s controllers was a basic precept of Orwell’s 1984. But by the time the real 1984 rolled around, the mass distribution of microelectronics had spawned a massive decentralization of computing power. In the real 1984, millions of ordinary people could match the governmental or corporate computer bit for bit. In the real 1984, the stereotypical computer user had become a Little Brother seated at the keyboard to write his seventh-grade science report.

帕特里克·哈格蒂曾预言芯片将“无处不在”，事实证明他是正确的。到 21 世纪，微电子技术确实渗透到了社会的几乎每个方面，取代了人们熟悉的设备中的传统控制手段，并创造了以前未知的人类活动的新方面。计算机从房间大小的 ENIAC 缩小到针头大小的微处理器，已经深入到日常生活的基本结构中。

Patrick Haggerty, the visionary who had predicted that the chip would become “pervasive,” had been proven right. By the twenty-first century, microelectronics did pervade nearly every aspect of society, replacing traditional means of control in familiar devices and creating new aspects of human activity that were previously unknown. By shrinking from the room-size ENIAC to the pinhead-size microprocessor, the computer had imploded into the basic fabric of daily life.

哈格蒂活到了 1980 年，这一年他见证了他的预言开始成真，但未能确定其影响。他的继任者们努力解决这个问题。在那些对微电子对人类社会的影响着迷的人中，罗伯特·诺伊斯是其中一位元老。“显然，一个拥有数亿台计算机的世界将是一个不同的世界，”他在生命的尽头说道。“但结果会怎样？谁能使用所有这些智能？你会用它们做什么？这是技术无法回答的问题。”

Haggerty lived until 1980, long enough to see his prediction starting to come true, but not to determine what the impact would be. His successors struggled to grapple with that issue. Prominent among those who were fascinated with the effect of microelectronics on human society was one of the patriarchs, Robert Noyce. “Clearly, a world with hundreds of millions of computers is going to be a different world,” he said near the end of his life. “But what will come of it? Who can use all that intelligence? What will you use it for? That’s a question technology can’t answer.”

9

9

暗淡

DIM- I

1976 年夏日，美国工业界一个规模虽小但值得关注的部门因竞争原因而消亡，在华盛顿特区正式安葬。安葬仪式在史密森尼学会举行，非常悲伤。历史悠久的精密仪器制造商 Keuffel & Esser 公司向博物馆赠送了最后一把 Keuffel & Esser 计算尺，以及该公司多年来为学生、科学家、建筑师和工程师生产数百万把计算尺的铣床。计算尺诞生 300 周年后不久——计算尺由 17 世纪英国学者 William Oughtred 发明，他对数学的另一个伟大贡献是首次使用符号“×”表示乘法——计算尺已成为微电子进步的牺牲品。

A small but noteworthy segment of American industry, dead of competitive causes, was formally laid to rest in Washington, D.C., on a summer day in 1976. The rite of internment was a fittingly sad ceremony at the Smithsonian Institution. Keuffel & Esser Company, the venerable manufacturer of precision instruments, presented the museum with the last Keuffel & Esser slide rule, together with the milling machine the company had used to turn out millions of slide rules over the years for students, scientists, architects, and engineers. Shortly past its 300th birthday—the rule was invented by the seventeenth-century British scholar William Oughtred, whose other great contribution to mathematics was the first use of the symbol “×” for multiplication—the slide rule had become a martyr to microelectronic progress.

这里的“进步”指的是杰克·基尔比的手持计算器。在小型电子计算器首次进入市场后的五年里，全球最大、最著名的计算尺制造商 K & E 的销量从每月约 20,000 把计算尺下降到每年仅 1,000 把。到了最后，计算尺销售的主要来源之一是怀旧情绪，因为博物馆、收藏家和摄影师认为计算尺很快就会消失，于是纷纷购买这些遗物。到了 70 年代中期，可以说手写体出现在屏幕上，甚至 Keuffel & Esser 也开始销售自有品牌的电子计算器。麻省理工学院的一位教授在 1976 年告诉《 纽约时报》：“现在这里 100% 的人都在使用计算器。”这句话实际上是计算尺的讣告。

“Progress,” in this case, meant Jack Kilby’s handheld calculator. In the five years after the small electronic calculator first hit the market, K & E, the largest and most famous slide rule maker in the world, had watched sales fall from about 20,000 rules per month to barely 1,000 each year. Toward the end, one of the major sources of slide rule sales was nostalgia, as museums, collectors, and photographers bought up the relics on the theory that the slide rule would soon disappear. By the mid-seventies, the handwriting was on the screen, so to speak, and even Keuffel & Esser was selling its own brand of electronic calculator. “Calculator usage is now 100 percent here,” an MIT professor told The New York Times in 1976, and that statement was essentially the obituary of the slide rule.

K & E 的最后一把计算尺最终被存放在史密森尼美国国家历史博物馆的储物架上。也许有一天，它会被掸去灰尘，拿出来展出；目前，要看这件遗物，必须提前预约。馆长说，几乎没有人会费心。然而，计算尺仍然存在，在整整一代科学家和工程师的深情回忆中（并且经常在办公桌抽屉里杂乱无章地放着），杰克·基尔比也在其中。2000 年秋天，当杰克获得诺贝尔奖的消息传来时，来到他办公室的摄影师坚持要基尔比拿着他的旧计算尺拍照，这大致相当于让亨利·福特骑在马背上拍照。基尔比和他那个年代的其他工程师今天回忆起这把计算尺时，就像老高尔夫球手对山胡桃木柄的 mashie niblick 或汽车迷对 1964 年原版福特野马的喜爱一样。在《技术评论》发表的计算尺悼词中，亨利·佩特罗斯基教授回忆说，他在 20 世纪 50 年代读本科时购买的 Keuffel & Esser Log-Log Duplex Decitrig 成为了他最宝贵的财富。“那台无声的计算伙伴是我整个大学时期和早期工程生涯的忠实伙伴。”

K & E’s last slide rule was eventually deposited in a bin on a storage shelf at the Smithsonian’s National Museum of American History. Someday it may be dusted off and put on display; at present, a special appointment must be made to view the relic. The curator says almost nobody ever bothers. Still, the slide rule lives on, in the affectionate memory (and frequently, amid the clutter in the desk drawers) of a whole generation of scientists and engineers, Jack Kilby among them. When word came in the fall of 2000 that Jack had won the Nobel Prize, the photographers who showed up at his office insisted that Kilby pose with his old slide rule, roughly the equivalent of asking Henry Ford to pose on horseback. Kilby and other engineers of his vintage recall the slide rule today with the same fond regard that an old golfer might have for a hickory-shafted mashie niblick or an auto buff reserves for the original 1964 Ford Mustang. In a requiem for the slide rule published in Technology Review, Professor Henry Petroski recalled that the Keuffel & Esser Log-Log Duplex Decitrig he bought as an undergraduate in the 1950s became his most valuable possession. “That silent computational partner [was] my constant companion throughout college and my early engineering career.”

但从实用角度来看，计算尺和计算器之间的竞争从一开始就是完全一边倒的。计算尺本质上是一种复杂的尺子。最常见的形式是长十英寸的长方形，由象牙、木头或塑料制成，上面标有三个不同的数字刻度——一个在上边缘，一个在下边缘，还有一个在中间。中间部分可以在顶部和底部之间左右滑动。尺子以相等的增量标记——1 英寸、2 英寸、3 英寸，每个整数正好相隔一英寸——而计算尺则以整数的对数来校准。“对数”是数学魔法的一小部分。通过滑动一块标有对数的塑料片，你可以对任何数字进行乘法、除法、平方、立方或求平方根。因此，三个世纪以来，计算尺一直充当着一种简单的计算器。

From a practical viewpoint, though, the competition between the slide rule and the calculator was completely one-sided from the beginning. The slide rule was essentially a complicated ruler. In the most common form, it was a ten-inch-long rectangle made of ivory, wood, or plastic with three different numerical scales marked along it—one on the top edge, a different on the bottom edge, and another in the middle. The middle section could slide right and left between the top and bottom. While a ruler is marked off in equal increments—1 inch, 2 inches, 3 inches, with each whole number exactly an inch apart—a slide rule was calibrated in the logarithms of the whole numbers. A “logarithm” is a tiny bit of mathematical magic. By sliding a piece of plastic marked in logarithms, you can multiply, divide, square, cube, or find the square root of any number. So the slide rule, for three centuries, served as a simple calculator.

缺点是计算尺只能给出近似答案；例如，如果你用它计算 470 的平方根，它会告诉你答案在 21.6 或 21.7 左右，但不会更接近。而且它对解决一些比较棘手的计算问题（确定数量级和将小数放在正确的位置）毫无帮助。相比之下，最原始的 3.99 美元计算器可以精确地解决问题，精确到小数点后一位，其速度和准确性是任何计算尺都无法比拟的。470 的平方根？按两个按钮，答案就会跳到显示屏上：21.67948338868。今天，在记忆的朦胧余辉中，工程师们倾向于从计算尺的缺点中看到优点。 “没有小数点，”佩特罗斯基教授写道，“意味着工程师总是必须独立于计算工具进行快速心算，以确定这项工作是否需要 2.35 码、23.5 码或 235 码的混凝土。通过这种方式，工程师很早就学会了直观地了解数值。现在，小数点在电子设备的显示屏上漂浮在扩展数字中，这些数字经常被不加思考地抄下来。”当然，他有道理；工程师或承包商培养“直观地了解数值”显然是一个好主意。另一方面，计算尺的这一功能对于突然发现自己的工地上有 200 吨多余的混凝土正在硬化的建筑工头来说可能并不那么有吸引力。

The downside was that the slide rule gave only approximate answers; if you used it, for example, to calculate the square root of 470, it could tell you that the answer is somewhere around 21.6 or 21.7, but couldn’t get much closer. And it offered no help at all in solving some of the trickier aspects of calculation—determining the order of magnitude and putting the decimal in the right place. The most primitive $3.99 calculator, in contrast, can solve problems precisely, down to the last decimal with a speed and accuracy that no slide rule could match. The square root of 470? Push two buttons and the answer leaps to the display screen: 21.67948338868. Today, in the hazy afterglow of memory, engineers tend to look on the slide rule’s drawbacks and see virtues. “The absence of a decimal point,” Professor Petroski wrote, “meant that the engineer always had to make a quick mental calculation independent of the calculating instrument to establish whether the job required 2.35, 23.5, or 235 yards of concrete. In this way, engineers learned early an intuitive appreciation of magnitudes. Now the decimal point floats across the display of an electronic device among extended digits that are too often copied down without thought.” He has a point, of course; it’s obviously a good idea for engineers or contractors to develop an “intuitive appreciation of magnitudes.” On the other hand, this feature of the slide rule probably didn’t seem so charming to a construction foreman who suddenly found himself with 200 excess tons of concrete hardening on his job site.

计算尺是一种简单的工具（至少，如果你知道对数的工作原理的话）。工程师们说，这种简单性是其吸引力的一部分。“它有一种诚实的感觉，”杰克·基尔比有一天告诉我，他伸手到办公桌的抽屉里，拿出他的旧 K & E。“计算尺没有隐藏部件。没有黑匣子。没有任何事情不在桌子上发生。”换句话说，计算尺并不具有威胁性。没有人把计算尺称为“机械大脑”。没有人宣称计算尺被赋予了所谓的人工智能。没有关于失控的计算尺夺取宇宙飞船控制权或密谋统治人类的电影。费米、维格纳和沃纳·冯·布劳恩腰带上挂着的计算尺帮助人类创造了第一个核链式反应，并将火箭送入平流层。但计算尺一直被认为只不过是一种工具。它并不比尺子、螺丝刀或任何其他常见的能够扩展人类力量的工具更“智能”。与尺子、螺丝刀等一样，计算尺只是一种无知的机制。

The slide rule was a simple instrument (at least, if you knew how logarithms work). To hear engineers tell it, that simplicity was part of its appeal. “It has a sort of honesty about it,” Jack Kilby told me one day, reaching into the drawer of his desk and pulling out his old K & E. “With the slide rule, there’re no hidden parts. There’s no black box. There’s nothing going on that isn’t right there on the table.” To put it another way, the slide rule was not threatening. Nobody ever called the slide rule a “mechanical brain.” Nobody ever declared that the slide rule was endowed with something called artificial intelligence. There were no movies about runaway slide rules called HAL seizing control of the spaceship or plotting to dominate mankind. The slide rule, hanging at the ready from the belts of Fermi, Wigner, and Wernher von Braun, helped men create the first nuclear chain reaction and send rockets to the stratosphere. But the rule was always recognized as nothing more than a tool. It had no more “intelligence” than a yardstick or a screwdriver or any other familiar tool that extends human power. Like the yardstick, the screwdriver, etc., the slide rule was just an ignorant mechanism.

有一天——鉴于技术发展的步伐加快，可能很快就会有这样的一天——袖珍计算器、手持式计算机、工业机器人、手机和我们这个时代的其他数字奇迹本身将成为博物馆的展品，在名为“原始微电子工具”或类似名称的画廊中展出。当我们和孙辈们一起走过时，我们很可能会对这些曾被认为是革命性的设备露出怀旧的微笑。毫无疑问，孩子们会惊讶地发现，早在 21 世纪初，许多人仍然抵制这些简单的工具，憎恨它们，害怕它们——担心数字计算机、机器人等以及它们所谓的人工智能可能会取代可怜的笨拙人类成为地球上的统治智能。对于我们孙辈来说，这看起来是多么愚蠢！他们会想，为什么有人会害怕这种无知的机制？

Someday—fairly soon, probably, given the accelerated pace of technological development—the pocket calculator, the handheld computer, the industrial robot, the cell phone, and other digital marvels of our day will themselves be museum pieces, on exhibit in a gallery called Primitive Microelectronic Tools or some such. As we file past with our grandchildren, we may well break into nostalgic smiles of fond regard for these devices that used to be considered so revolutionary. The kids, no doubt, will be amazed to learn that back at the turn of the twenty-first century many people still resisted those simple tools, resented them, feared them—feared that digital computers, robots, etc., and their so-called artificial intelligence might replace poor bungling man as the reigning intelligence on earth. To our grandchildren’s generation, how foolish this will seem! Why, they will wonder, would anyone have feared such an ignorant mechanism?

对于今天的我们大多数人来说，即使是最简单的数字设备似乎也难以理解。正如 Jack Kilby 所说，它是一个黑匣子。对于大多数人来说，黑匣子内部发生的事情就像黑魔法。你按下按键，一些难以解决的数学问题的答案就会立即显示在屏幕上。剩下的就是谜了。难怪计算器、计算机等被认为是智能机器；还有什么其他解释呢？事实上，计算机如何获得答案的解释根本不是魔术。黑匣子里的“魔法”实际上涉及一系列数学和逻辑技术，这些技术通过巧妙排列逻辑门中的电子开关来实现。电子脉冲在盲目的物理力量的作用下，通过电子开关迷宫来回移动。

To most of us today, even the simplest digital device seems incomprehensible. It is, as Jack Kilby has suggested, a black box. What goes on inside the black box is, for most people, black magic. You push the keys. The answer to some impossibly difficult math problem shows up on the screen, instantly. The rest is mystery. It’s no wonder that calculators, computers, etc., are thought of as intelligent machines; what other explanation could there be? In fact, the explanation of how the computer gets the answer is not at all magical. The “magic” inside the black box actually involves a series of mathematical and logical techniques carried out by artful arrangements of electronic switches arrayed in logic gates. Electronic impulses are pulled this way and that through the maze of electronic switches by blind physical force.

在计算机芯片中飞速移动的电子就像山上流淌的水一样具有智能。重力拉动水。电——电子电荷的吸引力和排斥力——拉动电子。如果人们以正确的组合建造水闸和灌溉渠道，他们可以让水流向需要灌溉田地的地方。如果人们以正确的模式建造逻辑门和连接导线，他们可以让电子脉冲流向需要解决问题的地方。在每种情况下，机制都会发挥作用，但在每种情况下，它都是一个无知的机制。人类设计师提供了所有的智能。

The electrons racing through a computer chip have as much intelligence as water running down a hill. Gravity pulls the water. Electricity—the attraction and repulsion of electronic charges—pulls the electrons. If people build sluice gates and irrigation canals in the right combinations, they can make water flow where it is needed to water the fields. If people build logic gates and connecting leads in the right patterns, they can make electronic impulses flow where they’re needed to solve a problem. In each case, the mechanism does the work, but in each case, it’s an ignorant mechanism. The human designer provides all the intelligence.

如果你在计算器中输入 3 + 2 的加法任务，计算器会得出答案 5。计算器得出答案并不是因为“人工智能”，而是因为真正的智慧——人类思维——设计了该机制，使其得出正确答案。

If you punch into your calculator the task of adding 3 + 2, the mechanism will produce the answer 5. The calculator gets the answer not because of “artificial intelligence” but rather because a genuine intelligence—the human mind—has designed the mechanism so that it gets the right answer.

制造数字机器的人们利用单片电路（来自基尔比和诺伊斯的头脑）中的晶体管（来自肖克利、巴丁和布拉顿的头脑）实现的开关逻辑（来自乔治布尔和克劳德香农的头脑），设计了一个加法电路，使得当输入二进制 3 和二进制 2 时，表示二进制 5 的脉冲模式是唯一可能的组合。然而，为了从一个完全由开关打开和关闭、关闭和打开组成的机制中得到这个和，人们不得不采取极端措施。对于像计算机这样笨拙的机器来说，要解决 3 + 2 的问题，必须将问题分解为一系列极其详细的指令，这些指令引导机器一步一步地完成任务。如果说袖珍计算器有魔力，那不是机器本身，而是有智慧和耐心对机器进行编程以使其工作的人。

Using switching logic (from the minds of George Boole and Claude Shannon) implemented by transistors (from the minds of Shockley, Bardeen, and Brattain) contained in the monolithic circuit (from the minds of Kilby and Noyce), the humans who build digital machines have designed an addition circuit in such a way that the pattern of pulses representing binary 5 is the only possible combination that can come out when binary 3 and binary 2 are put in. To get that sum, however, out of a mechanism consisting entirely of switches turning on and off, off and on, humans have had to go to some extreme lengths. For a machine as dim-witted as a computer to solve 3 + 2, the problem must be broken down into an absurdly detailed sequence of instructions that lead the machinery through its paces, step by elementary step. If there is magic in the pocket calculator, it is not in the machinery; it is in the humans who had the wit and the patience to program the machine to do its job.

为了说明这一点，我们可以参观一下黑匣子的内部，从内部观察一个典型的数字机制是如何工作的。我们将看一个简单的袖珍计算器——它非常简单，只存在于本书的页面中——称为数字无知机制，型号 I，简称 DIM-I。这里要介绍的 DIM-I 的设计基于常见的四功能计算器，这种计算器在任何地方都可以买到，价格约为 5 美元。不过，在很大程度上，5 美元计算器的基本架构与 50 美元的视频游戏、500 美元的手持电脑、5,000 美元的公司服务器或引导 NASA 火箭穿越宇宙的 500 万美元超级计算机的基本架构相同。更大、更昂贵的机器可以处理更多信息、存储更多结果并处理更多种类的任务，但运作方式是相同的。如果你见过一台数字无知机器在工作，你几乎见过所有的机器。

To bring the point home, we can take a guided tour through the interior of the black box and watch a typical digital mechanism from the inside as it does its stuff. We’ll look at a simple pocket calculator—so simple it exists only in the pages of this book—called the Digital Ignorant Mechanism, Model I, or DIM-I for short. The design of DIM-I to be set forth here is based on the familiar four-function calculator available anywhere for $5 or so. To a considerable extent, though, the basic architecture of a $5 calculator is the same as that in a $50 video game, a $500 handheld computer, a $5,000 corporate server, or the $5 million supercomputers that guide NASA’s rockets through the cosmos. The bigger, more expensive machines can handle more information, store more results, and deal with a larger variety of tasks, but the modus operandi is the same. If you’ve seen one digital ignorant machine at work, you’ve pretty much seen them all.

从外观上看，DIM-I 实际上是黑色塑料盒。盒子上有 18 个键：每个键用于 0 到 9 的数字，另外 8 个用于 +、= 等功能。它有一个显示屏，可以显示最多 8 位数字。它相当轻——最多几盎司——如果你撬开这个黑盒子，你就会明白为什么。里面几乎没有东西。有一个空的空间，里面有一个微型电源——有时是电池，或者太阳能转换器——几根电线，以及一个印刷电路板，上面放着另一个更小的黑盒子。这是一块看起来像人造千足虫的塑料：一个一英寸长的矩形，每边都有一排对称的电线腿。那只千足虫就是芯片——或者更准确地说，是装芯片的塑料包装。两侧的两排腿是将键盘和显示屏连接到芯片的电子引线。

On the outside, DIM-I is in fact a black plastic box. The box has eighteen keys: one each for the digits 0 through 9, and eight others for functions like +, =, etc. It has a display screen that can show numbers up to eight digits long. It’s rather light—a few ounces at most—and if you were to pry open the black box, you’d see why. There’s almost nothing inside. There’s an empty space containing a tiny power source—a battery sometimes, or a solar energy converter—a few wires, and a printed circuit board on which sits another, smaller black box. This one is a piece of plastic that looks like a man-made millipede: an inch-long rectangle with a symmetrical array of wire legs sticking out from each side. That millipede is the chip—or, more precisely, the plastic package that holds the chip. The two rows of legs along the sides are the electronic leads that connect the keyboard and the display screen to the chip.

计算机内部（即使是最小的手持计算机）也包含整排的黑色小千足虫，每个芯片都设计用于特定功能。例如，打开台式计算机的背面，您可以数出大约 200 个独立芯片。内存芯片、逻辑芯片、输入输出芯片和微处理器芯片都排列在各种电路板上。微电子的奇迹之一就是可以将越来越多的独立功能元件压缩到单个芯片中；像 DIM-I 这样的简单药店计算器仅使用一个芯片，该芯片内置了所有必要的功能元件。

Inside a computer—even the smallest handheld computer—are whole platoons of these small black millipedes, each chip designed for a specific function. Open the back of a desktop computer, for example, and you can count about 200 separate chips. There are memory chips, logic chips, input-output chips, and microprocessor chips, all lined up in formation on the various circuit boards. Part of the miracle of microelectronics is that more and more separate functional elements can be squeezed into a single chip; a simple drugstore calculator like DIM-I uses just one chip that has all the necessary functional elements built into it.

为简单起见，我们假设 DIM-I 内部的芯片是 TMS 1000C，这是为小型计算器设计的常见微处理器之一。它有 (1) 一组逻辑门，用于读取键盘上的电子信号并将其“编码”为计算器可以理解的二进制形式。它有 (2) 相对较少的内存单元 - 晶体管链按顺序排列，以便每个晶体管都可以单独寻址。这意味着机器可以随机访问每个内存块，因此这是随机存取存储器或 RAM。它有 (3) 一个算术处理器单元 - 一组排列成门的晶体管，以便它们可以使用布尔逻辑执行简单的数学运算。它有 (4) 一组门，用于将二进制信息“解码”回十进制形式并将其发送到显示屏。换句话说，该芯片具有执行四项操作所需的电路：

Just for simplicity’s sake, we’ll say that the chip inside DIM-I is a TMS 1000C, one of the common microprocessors designed for small calculators. It has (1) a set of logic gates that read electronic signals from the keyboard and “encode” them in binary form that a calculator can understand. It has (2) a relatively small number of memory units—chains of transistors lined up in ordered rows so that each one can be addressed separately. That means the machine can randomly get to each memory block, so this is random-access memory, or RAM. It has (3) an arithmetic processor unit—a group of transistors arranged in gates so that they can use Boolean logic to perform simple math. And it has (4) a set of gates that “decode” binary information back into decimal form and send it to the display screen. In other words, the chip has the necessary circuitry to do four things:

感知输入键盘的数字。

Sense numbers punched into its keyboard.

将它们写在电子便笺簿上。

Write them on an electronic scratch pad.

对它们进行加、减、除、乘。

Add, subtract, divide, and multiply them.

以显示屏上发光数字的形式报告总数。

Report the sum in the form of lighted digits on the display screen.

换句话说，DIM-I 可以执行任何数字设备的四项基本工作：

Which is just another way of saying that DIM-I can carry out the four essential jobs of any digital device:

输入

input

记忆

memory

加工

processing

输出

output

更先进的机器（例如 DIM-II 或 DIM-III）可能能够处理更大的数字、在屏幕上生成图形并在内存中存储更大量的信息。到 DIM-X 或 DIM-XLVII 时，机器可以处理文字和数字，并以无数种方式操纵信息，这些方式超出了我们的小计算器所能想象的最疯狂的梦想。相比之下，DIM-I 做不了什么。但它可以向我们展示基本的计算力学，因为它所做的工作与其他计算器和计算机相同。

A fancier machine—say, DIM-II or DIM-III—might be able to handle larger numbers, produce graphs on the screen, and store greater quantities of information in memory. By the time one gets to DIM-X or DIM-XLVII, the machine can deal with words as well as numbers and manipulate the information in countless ways that are beyond the wildest dreams of our little calculator. DIM-I, by contrast, can’t do much. But it can demonstrate to us the basic computational mechanics, because what it does do it does in the same way as every other calculator and computer.

DIM-I 的处理电路与任何数字设备中的处理电路一样，也具有一组中央逻辑门，称为控制单元。这是一种中央配电盘，它根据需要将电子脉冲从输入端引导到内存、处理器、显示屏等各个地方，以解决问题。控制单元本身又由一个简单而熟悉的设备控制，该设备对任何数字机器的运行都是必不可少的——时钟。

The processing circuitry of DIM-I, like that in any digital device, also has a central set of logic gates called the control unit. This is a sort of central switchboard that busily directs electronic pulses here and there, from input to memory to processor to the display screen, as needed to solve the problem. The control unit is itself controlled, in turn, by a simple, familiar device that is essential to the operation of any digital machine—a clock.

就我们赋予计算机拟人化特征而言，恰当的类比不是说机器有大脑，而是说它有心脏——一个稳定的、脉动的中央节奏仪器，可以协调和控制发生的一切。计算机工程师将中央时钟称为时钟发生器，因为它实际上是一个以完全稳定、不变的速率产生脉冲的电路。时钟之于计算机就像乐队领队之于乐队；它站在那里打着节拍，一二三，一二三，这样每个部分都会以正确的节拍开始。

To the extent that we attribute anthropomorphic characteristics at all to computers, the proper analogy would be not that the machine has a brain, but rather that it has a heart—a steady, pulsing central rhythm instrument that orchestrates and controls everything that happens. The computer engineers call the central clock a clock generator, because it really is a circuit that generates pulses at a perfectly steady, unvarying rate. The clock is to the computer what the bandleader is to the band; it stands there keeping time, ONE-two-three, ONE-two-three, so that each part will come in at the right beat.

DIM-I 内部的时钟每千万分之一秒无变化地跳动一次，也就是说，它每秒发出 100,000 个脉冲，或者每 1/100,000 秒发出一个脉冲。这是廉价、简单的袖珍计算器的相当标准的时钟速率。与大型主机计算机或小型笔记本电脑的运行速度相比，它很慢，但与闪电或眨眼相比，它的速度非常快。眨眼大约需要 0.30 秒；眨眼之间，简单计算器内的时钟将发出 30,000 次脉冲。

The clock inside DIM-I beats, without variation, every ten millionth of a second—that is, it emits 100,000 pulses every second, or one pulse every 1/100,000 second. This is a fairly standard clock rate for cheap, simple pocket calculators. It is slow compared to the operating speed of large mainframe computers—or of small laptop computers, for that matter—but extremely fast compared to, say, a flash of lightning or the blink of an eye. An eye’s blink takes about .30 second; in the blink of an eye, the clock inside a simple calculator will have pulsed 30,000 times.

在由秒、分、时组成的狭小世界中，人类根本无法想象十万分之一秒这样的时间段，更不用说微秒（1,000,000 秒）、纳秒（1,000,000,000 秒）、皮秒（1,000,000,000,000 秒）或飞秒（1,000,000,000,000,000 秒）了。以人类的尺度来看，任何持续时间少于十分之一秒的事件都来不及形成视觉图像，因此是看不见的；如果持续时间少于千分之一秒左右，事件的速度甚至快到潜意识都无法感知，完全超出了人类的范围。微电子事件的速度使它们远离人类的世界；工程师怎么能考虑千分之一秒呢？计算机工程师是务实的人，他们通常不会进行形而上学的推测，他们甚至不会去尝试。正如鲍勃·诺伊斯所说，他们只是“接受”了这样一个观点：他们的机器以难以想象的高速度运行。

There is no way for humans, in our poky world of seconds, minutes, and hours, to conceive of a time period like 1/100,000 second, much less the microsecond (1/1,000,000 second), the nanosecond (1/1,000,000,000 second), the picosecond (1/1,000,000,000,000 second), or the femtosecond (1/1,000,000,000,000,000 second). On the human scale, anything that lasts less than about a tenth of a second passes by too quickly for the brain to form a visual image, and is thus invisible; if the duration is less than a thousandth of a second or so, the event becomes too fast even for subliminal perception and is completely outside the human sphere. The speed of microelectronic events puts them in a world far removed from the human realm; how can an engineer contemplate a thousandth of a thousandth of a second? Computer engineers, practical types not often given to metaphysical speculation, don’t even try. They just become, as Bob Noyce said, “reconciled” to the notion that their machines work at unthinkably high speeds.

难以置信的运行速度之所以能实现，是因为数字机器的“运动部件”是电子脉冲，它们在难以置信的短距离内以难以置信的速度传播。电信号以光速传播，每秒 186,000 英里。这使得传输速度异常快速，即使是跨大陆的距离。

The inconceivable speed of operation comes about because the “moving parts” of a digital machine are electronic pulses that travel inconceivably fast over distances inconceivably small. An electric signal moves at the speed of light, 186,000 miles per second. This makes for extraordinarily rapid transit, even at transcontinental distances.

波士顿的一位棒球迷打开电视观看洛杉矶的这场重要比赛。他看到投球、击球手开始挥棒、球棒击中球。但他无法在比赛发生的那一刻看到这一切。将画面传送到电视的电子信号需要大约 0.016 秒才能从美国西海岸传到东海岸，行程 3,000 英里。因此，观众要等到击球实际发生后约 1/62 秒才能看到球棒击中球。（对于通过互联网以流媒体视频形式观看比赛的球迷来说，场景可能会延迟更多时间——最多延迟半秒——因为软件会将脉冲转换为计算机屏幕上的视频图像。）

A baseball fan in Boston turns on his TV to watch the big game in Los Angeles. He watches the pitch coming in, the hitter start to swing, and the smack of bat against ball. He does not see this at the precise instant it happens, though. The electronic signals carrying the picture to his television take about .016 second to travel the 3,000 miles from America’s West Coast to the East. Thus the viewer will not see the bat hit the ball until about 1/62 second after the impact actually occurs. (For a fan watching the game in the form of streaming video over the Internet, the scene may be delayed even more—as much as half a second more—by the software that converts the impulse to a video image on the computer screen.)

我们计算器内部开关的信号也以光速移动，但它们不必传播 3,000 英里。在包含 10,000 个元件的四分之一英寸见方的集成电路上，单个晶体管的间距只有几万分之一英寸。以光速移动的电子电荷在极短的时间内穿过这些距离。因此，控制芯片周围脉冲调度的时钟发生器可以设置为以极小的间隔滴答作响。

The signals that turn switches on and off inside our calculator also move at the speed of light, but they do not have to travel 3,000 miles. On a quarter-inch square integrated circuit containing 10,000 components, individual transistors are spaced a few ten thousandths of an inch apart. Electronic charges moving at the speed of light traverse those distances in tiny periods of time. Consequently, the clock generator that controls the dispatch of pulses around the chip can be set to tick at tiny intervals.

然而，在设定数字机器的时钟频率时，人类设计者不仅要考虑脉冲从一个晶体管传输到另一个晶体管的传输时间，还要考虑每个晶体管从开到关所需的时间。计算机由一长串晶体管组成；每个晶体管都必须等待其前面的晶体管翻转才能执行任何操作。在大多数现代计算机中，晶体管的切换时间（工程师称为传播延迟）比信号通过电路的传输时间更为严重。

In setting the clock rate for digital machines, however, the human designers have to consider not only the transit time for pulses racing from one transistor to another but also the time it takes for each transistor to switch from on to off. The computer is made of a long, long chain of transistors; each one has to wait for the transistor ahead of it in line to flip one way or the other before it can do anything. In most modern computers, the transistors’ switching time (known to engineers as propagation delay) is a more serious constraint than the travel time for signals moving through the circuit.

“传播延迟”和微电子术语中的许多其他术语一样，是一个简单而熟悉的现象的复杂术语。每天的交通高峰期，高速公路上都会出现传播延迟。如果有 500 辆车紧挨着前行，当第一辆车停下来时，其余车辆也会停下来。当第一辆车的驾驶员将脚放回油门上时，第二辆车的驾驶员会看到前面的刹车灯熄灭，于是她便将脚从刹车换到油门。这个从刹车换到油门的切换动作会沿着车辆链条传递下去。如果每个驾驶员的切换时间只有 1 秒，那么由于交通传输延迟，最后一辆车将不得不等待 500 秒（约 8.5 分钟）。

“Propagation delay,” like many other elements of microelectronic jargon, is a complex term for a simple and familiar phenomenon. Propagation delays occur on the freeway every day at rush hour. If 500 cars are proceeding bumper to bumper and the first car stops, all the others stop as well. When the first driver puts his foot back on the accelerator, the driver in the second car sees the brake lights ahead of her go off, and she, in turn, switches her foot from brake to accelerator. This switching action, from brake to accelerator, is then relayed down the chain of cars. If each driver has a switching time of just one second, the last car will have to wait 500 seconds—about 8½ minutes—because of the propagation delay down the line of traffic.

数字设备中的晶体管从刹车到加速器（从关闭到打开）的切换速度要快一些。在功率最大的机器中，切换时间约为一纳秒（十亿分之一秒）。在使用 Pentium IV 微处理器的当前一代个人计算机中，晶体管的切换时间约为二十亿分之一秒。按照这些标准，像 DIM-I 这样的廉价袖珍计算器就像乌龟一样慢。它的晶体管从打开到关闭大约需要 5 微秒。为了解决这么大的传播延迟并留出一点额外的时间让信号通过芯片上的电路，小型计算器的时钟速率（设置每个操作节奏的时间特征）设置为 10 微秒，或每十万分之一秒一个脉冲。

The transistors inside a digital device go from brake to accelerator—from off to on—somewhat faster. In the most high-powered machines, the switching time is about one nanosecond—one billionth of a second. In the current generation of personal computers, using the Pentium IV microprocessor, the transistors switch in about two billionths of a second. By those standards, a cheap pocket calculator like DIM-I is a tortoise. Its transistors take about 5 microseconds to go from on to off. To account for that much propagation delay and to allow a little additional time for signals to travel through the circuitry on the chip, the clock rate—the time signature that sets the tempo for each operation—in a small calculator is set at 10 microseconds, or one pulse every hundred thousandth of a second.

计算器内部时钟的滴答声调节着一个重复的操作周期——指令周期——只要机器处于开机状态，它就会不断地、一遍又一遍地执行这些操作。指令周期分为两个阶段。

The ticking of the clock inside a calculator computer regulates a repetitive cycle of operations—the instruction cycle—that the machine performs continuously, over and over, as long as it is turned on. The instruction cycle is a two-stage affair.

在第一个时钟脉冲时，计算机的时钟单元（交换台）向内存发送一条消息，请求下一条指令。指令（以二进制电荷模式的形式）闪回到交换台，交换台将其保存到时钟的下一次点击。当下一个时钟脉冲到来时，交换台将指令发送到计算机的相应部分进行执行。执行完一条指令后，控制器等待下一个脉冲。时钟滴答作响，控制器获取下一条指令；时钟再次滴答作响，然后执行该指令。

On the first clock pulse the computer’s clock unit—the switchboard—sends a message to memory, asking for the next instruction. The instruction (in the form of a binary pattern of charges) flashes back to the switchboard, which holds it until the next click of the clock. When the next clock pulse comes, the switchboard sends the instruction on to the appropriate part of the computer for execution. When one instruction has been executed, the controller waits for the next pulse. The clock ticks, the controller fetches the next instruction; the clock ticks again, and that instruction is carried out.

这种两阶段指令周期（取指和执行、取指和执行）是计算机生命的重要节律，与人体的两阶段呼吸周期（吸气和呼气、吸气和呼气）一样基本和恒定。时钟发生器调节该过程，以便每个信号（来自内存、控制单元、键盘或任何地方）在下一个信号开始通过电路之前到达目的地。

This two-stage instruction cycle—fetch and execute, fetch and execute—is the vital rhythm of the computer’s life, as fundamental and as constant as the two-stage respiratory cycle—inhale and exhale, inhale and exhale—of the human body. The clock generator regulates the process so that each signal—from memory, from the control unit, from the keyboard, from anywhere—arrives at its destination before the next signal starts its journey through the circuit.

在 DIM-I 中，与视频游戏和其他简单的数字工具一样，指令序列（程序）在机器制造时永久安装在内存中。这种预编程设备只能执行其设计目的，而不能执行其他任何任务。相比之下，计算机并不局限于内置程序；它的多功能性来自于每个用户可以对其进行编程以执行广泛的任务。这就是“通用”机器（计算机）与“专用”工具（如计算器）之间的区别。（有些袖珍计算器被称为可编程计算器，但从传统意义上讲，这样的机器实际上是计算机，而不是计算器。）购买计算器就像购买火车票；你只能沿着公司的轨道行驶。另一方面，如果你有一台计算机，你必须自己操纵它，但你可以驾驶它去任何你想去的地方。

In DIM-I, as in video games and other simple digital tools, the sequence of instructions—the program—is permanently installed in memory when the machine is built. Such preprogrammed devices can do the exact tasks they were built for, and nothing else. A computer, in contrast, is not restricted to built-in programs; its versatility comes from the fact that it can be programmed by each user to perform a broad range of tasks. This is the difference between a “universal” machine—a computer—and a “dedicated” tool like a calculator. (There are pocket calculators that are called programmable, but in classic terms, machines like that are really computers, not calculators.) Buying a calculator is like buying a ticket on the railroad; you can go only where the company’s tracks will take you. If you have a computer, on the other hand, you have to steer it yourself, but you can drive it wherever you want to go.

无论如何，程序，无论是工厂内置的还是单独提供的，都是驻留在指定内存块中的一长串指令。为了完成任何工作，无论工作多么平凡，机器的中央控制单元都必须从内存中取出单个指令并逐一执行它们。

In any case, the program, whether built in at the factory or provided separately, is a long chain of instructions that reside in a designated block of memory. In order to do any job, no matter how mundane, the machine’s central control unit has to fetch individual instructions from memory and execute them, one at a time, one after another.

基本的提取和执行周期从 DIM-I 开启的瞬间开始。时钟发生器开始产生规则脉冲，每 1/100,000 秒发出一次哔哔声。如果您打开计算器，然后放下它去喝咖啡或接电话，计算器可能看起来好像什么都没做。事实上，它正在疯狂地工作，提取和执行指令 - 一个特殊的指令集，它会不断检查键盘，寻找输入。您的所有数字设备 - 计算器、计算机、寻呼机、传呼机、手机、遥控器等 - 在等待某人过来按下按键时都遵循相同的特殊程序。这种特殊的观察和等待程序称为空闲程序。空闲程序是我们大多数现代工具在大多数时间（未主动使用期间）所做的事情。

The fundamental fetch-and-execute cycle begins the instant DIM-I is turned on. The clock generator starts generating regular pulses, beeping out every 1/100,000 second. If you turn on a calculator and then put it down to sip some coffee or answer the phone, the calculator may look as if it is doing nothing. In fact, it is working furiously away, fetching and executing instructions—a special instruction set that continually checks the keyboard, looking for input. All your digital devices—calculator, computer, beeper, pager, cell phone, remote control, etc.—follow this same special program when they are waiting for somebody to come along and press a key. This special watching-and-waiting program is called the idle routine. The idle routine is what most of our modern tools are doing most of the time, during the periods when they are not in active use.

DIM-I 在开启后 1/100,000 秒内，随着第一个时钟脉冲开始进入空闲程序。滴答。控制单元转到存储指令的存储库中的第一个位置并获取第一条指令：“检查键盘上的‘1’键。”滴答。现在控制器执行该指令。也就是说，它向键盘发送一个电子查询：“最近有人按过‘1’键吗？”电子回复：“没有。”按照这个顺序——第一条指令被获取并执行——第一个指令周期已经完成。

DIM-I starts into its idle routine 1/100,000 second after it is turned on, with the first clock pulse. Tick.
