The control unit goes to the first location in the memory bank where instructions are stored and fetches the first instruction: “Check the ‘1’ key on the keyboard.” Tick. Now the controller executes that instruction. That is, it sends an electronic query to the keyboard: “Has anybody pushed the ‘1’ key lately?” The electronic reply comes back: “No.” With this sequence—the first instruction was fetched and executed—the first instruction cycle has been completed.

滴答。空闲程序继续。控制单元返回内存并获取第二条指令：“检查键盘上的‘2’键。”滴答。获取并收到指令后，控制器现在执行命令。它调用键盘：“最近有人按过‘2’键吗？”电子回复：“没有。”滴答。控制器获取下一条指令：“检查‘3’键。”滴答。控制器查询键盘：“最近有人按过‘3’键吗？”回复：“没有。”

Tick. The idle routine continues. The control unit goes back to memory and fetches the second instruction: “Check the ‘2’ key on the keyboard.” Tick. Having fetched and received an instruction, the controller now executes the order. It calls the keyboard: “Has anybody hit the ‘2’ key lately?” The electronic reply: “No.” Tick. The controller fetches the next instruction: “Check the ‘3’ key.” Tick. The controller queries the keyboard: “Anybody pushed the ‘3’ key lately?” Reply: “No.”

此时，即使是智力最原始的人也会开始意识到，这里的训练是逐一检查所有键，看是否有人按过。小孩子也能猜出接下来的两个步骤是检查“4”和“5”键。然而，DIM-I 比任何孩子都要笨得多。它没有智力；它是一种无知的数字机制。它什么都不知道，只是按照编程机械地遵循不变的获取和执行例程。

At this point, even the most primitive intelligence would start to appreciate that the drill here is to check all the keys seriatim to see if anybody has pushed. A child could figure out that the next two steps will be to check the “4” and the “5” keys. DIM-I, however, is much more stupid than any child. It has no intelligence; it is an ignorant digital mechanism. It knows nothing but the unvarying fetch-and-execute routine it has been programmed to follow mechanically.

滴答。控制器执着地从下一个内存位置获取指令。“检查键盘上的‘4’键。”滴答。执行。滴答。获取。滴答。执行。滴答。这就是计算机的生命。控制单元将逐一检查 DIM-I 的十八个键。如果没有按下任何键，这个机制就只做一件事。它会一遍又一遍地重复整个程序。任何人，事实上任何黑猩猩，任何有智慧的生物，在最初几个重复的循环之后都会心烦意乱。相比之下，数字设备每个工作日都要快速完成数十亿次获取和执行循环，永远不会感到无聊，永远不会疲倦。毕竟，它是一台机器，这就是机器为我们做的事情。它们接管了人类无法管理的繁重或无聊的工作。

Tick. Doggedly, the controller fetches the instruction in the next memory location. “Check the ‘4’ key on the keyboard.” Tick. Execute. Tick. Fetch. Tick. Execute. Tick. This is a computer’s life. One by one, the control unit will check each of DIM-I’s eighteen keys. If none has been pushed, there’s only one thing for this mechanism to do. It runs through the whole routine again, and again, and again. Any human, indeed any chimpanzee, any creature with intelligence would be driven to distraction after the first few repetitive cycles of this. A digital device, in contrast, races its way through billions and billions of fetch-and-execute cycles every working day, never getting bored, never getting tired. It’s a machine, after all, and that’s what machines do for us. They take over the jobs that are too heavy, or too boring, for humans to manage.

在某个时刻，大约每百万或十亿个指令周期，DIM-I 的持续警惕就会得到回报：有人按下了一个键。键盘向控制器报告已按下了一个键。但按下的是哪个键呢？

At some point, every million or billion instruction cycles or so, DIM-I’s unceasing vigilance pays off: Somebody pushes a key. The keyboard reports to the controller that a key has been pushed. But which key?

我们计算器键盘上的每个键都是一个开关，就像墙上的电灯开关一样。当有人轻按墙上的电灯开关时，电流就会流向灯泡。当有人按下键盘上的某个键时，电流就会流向控制单元。这只是一股快速的电流——一团电子——无论按下哪个键，脉冲都是相同的。“1”、“+”、“9”——每个键都发送相同的脉冲。（在 20 世纪 50 年代的仓库大小的计算机中，一些设计师确实试图改变每个信号的电流，这样“9”通过电路发送的电流是“1”的九倍。但这种方法需要大量的电力并产生大量的热量。如果每个键都发送相同的脉冲，事情就会简单得多。唯一的问题是控制单元需要辨别给定的脉冲应该是“1”、“+”还是“9”。这就是时钟的作用所在。）

Each key on the keyboard of our calculator is a switch, just like the light switch on the wall. When somebody flicks the light switch on the wall, it lets current flow to the light bulb. When somebody pushes a key on the keyboard, it lets current flow to the control unit. This is just a quick surge of current—a swarm of electrons—and it is the same pulse no matter which key is hit. The “1,” the “+,” the “9”—every key sends the same pulse. (In those warehouse-size computers of the 1950s, some designers did try to vary the current for each signal, so that a “9” sent a surge nine times as powerful through the circuit as a “1.” But this approach takes huge amounts of power and generates huge amounts of heat. Things are much simpler if you have each key send the same pulse. The only problem is that the control unit needs to discern whether a given pulse is supposed to be a “1,” a “+,” or a “9.” That’s where the clock comes in.)

DIM-I 核心的控制单元就像主货运线上某个偏僻车站的站长。站长知道每天有四趟火车从南方经过：上午 10:00 从塔尔萨出发的火车、中午从纳奇兹出发的火车、下午 2:00 从特克萨卡纳出发的火车以及下午 4:00 从沃斯堡出发的火车。他的工作是观察火车并将每趟火车调到正确的轨道以到达目的地。

The control unit at the heart of DIM-I is like the stationmaster at some isolated depot along the main freight line. The stationmaster knows that four trains come through from the south each day: the 10:00 A.M. from Tulsa, the noon train from Natchez, the 2:00 P.M. from Texarkana, and the 4:00 P.M. from Fort Worth. His job is to watch for the trains and switch each one to the right track to reach its destination.

每天早晨 9 点 45 分左右，站长都会听到远处有一列火车从南方驶来。他看不到火车，而且从远处看所有火车的声音都一样。然而，站务员知道这是从塔尔萨开来的火车。一定是这样，因为这是当时唯一一趟列车。他在日志中勾选了塔尔萨的火车，然后从办公桌抽屉里拿出站长手册，获取应该将火车开到哪条轨道的指示。然后他喝杯咖啡，又回到他闲散的日常工作中。11 点 45 分，他听到另一辆火车引擎的声音，站长也看不到，而且所有火车的声音都一样。但他拿出日志，勾选了从纳奇兹开来的火车。他知道这一定是从纳奇兹开来的火车，因为列车时刻表是这么告诉他的。

Each morning at about 9:45 the stationmaster hears the remote rumble of a train chugging in from the south. He can’t see the train, and all trains sound alike at a distance. Yet, the station man knows that this is the train from Tulsa. It has to be; it’s the only train scheduled for that hour. He checks off the Tulsa train in his logbook; then he reaches in the desk drawer and fetches his stationmaster’s manual to get the instruction for which track he should route it to. Then he gets a cup of coffee and goes back into his idle routine. At 11:45 he hears another engine; the stationmaster can’t see that, either, and all trains sound alike. But he takes out the logbook and checks off the train from Natchez. He knows it has to be the train from Natchez, because the timetable tells him so.

DIM-I 内部的控制单元也是如此。在整个空闲例程中，它一直在逐个查询十八个键。每个键都在特定的时间间隔内进行查询 - 这些间隔由时钟发生器的稳定心跳决定。控制单元只有在寻址特定键时才能接收来自该键的脉冲。如果在控制单元查询“3”键的 2/100,000 秒内从键盘传来脉冲，那么该脉冲就一定是 3。有人刚刚按下了“3”按钮。来自键盘的脉冲，就像远处的火车头一样，听起来都一样。但控制单元知道这个脉冲一定来自“3”键，因为时间表是这样告诉它的。

So it is for the control unit inside DIM-I. All through the idle routine it has been querying each of the eighteen keys, one at a time. Each key is queried at a specific time interval—intervals determined by the steady heartbeat of the clock generator. The control unit can receive a pulse from a given key only when it is addressing that particular key. If a pulse comes in from the keyboard during the 2/100,000 second when the control unit is querying the “3” key, then the pulse had to be a 3. Somebody just pushed the “3” button. Pulses from the keyboard, like locomotives at a distance, all sound alike. But the control unit knows this pulse had to come from the “3” key, because the timetable tells it so.

但还有一种可能性：电流激增可能根本不是来自键盘。它可能只是随机的电子“噪音”。我们的大气层几乎总是充满杂散的电磁脉冲，有些是由大自然产生的，有些是由人类的机器和武器产生的。武器，特别是核武器，是电磁脉冲（用五角大楼的缩写来说，是 EMP）的大量产生者。关于世界核武库的众多未知数之一是原子弹爆炸或试验可能产生的 EMP 数量。人们认为，任何核武器一旦引爆，都有可能释放出如此多的电磁“噪音”，以至于世界计算机的控制单元（包括据称指导全球作战室战略规划的计算机）将被杂散脉冲淹没，并会在终极混乱状态下崩溃。然而，即使在和平时期，也有足够的 EMP 四处漂浮，因此必须对每个数字设备进行编程以检查传入的信号。因此，在 DIM-I 的控制单元真正确定它从键盘收到信号之前，它会再返回“3”键几次以确保该键确实被按下。这相当简单，因为在手指按下该键一次的时间里，计算器将经历数万个指令周期。

Except that there’s one other possibility: The surge of current may not have come from the keyboard at all. It could have been nothing more than random electronic “noise.” Our atmosphere is almost always noisy with stray electromagnetic pulses, some generated by nature, others by mankind’s machines and weapons. Weapons, particularly nuclear weapons, are prolific producers of electromagnetic pulses, or EMP, to use the Pentagon acronym. One of the many unknowns about the world’s nuclear arsenals is the quantity of EMP that might result from an atomic blast or test. It is considered possible that any nuclear weapon, once triggered, would release so much electromagnetic “noise” that the control units of the world’s computers—including the computers supposedly directing strategic planning in war rooms around the planet—would be flooded with stray pulses and would break down in a state of terminal confusion. Even in time of peace, though, there is enough EMP floating around that every digital device must be programmed to check the signals coming in. Before the control unit of DIM-I can really be sure it got a signal from the keyboard, therefore, it goes back to the “3” key a few more times to make sure the key has actually been pressed. This is fairly simple, because in the time it takes a finger to push that key once, the calculator will go through tens of thousands of instruction cycles.

在确定它感应到的脉冲确实来自“3”键后，控制单元现在按照站长的方式进行操作。首先，它将新到达的“3”输入到日志中，然后将信号发送到正确的目的地。

Having determined that the pulse it sensed did in fact come from the “3” key, the control unit now proceeds the same way the stationmaster did. First it enters the newly arrived “3” in a logbook and then it sends the signal on to its proper destination.

记录键盘信号接收的“日志”是四个晶体管组成的一个链，它们组成一个小型存储单元，称为寄存器。控制单元向一组逻辑门发送一个信号（电流浪涌）。该逻辑电路依次向寄存器发出一组电子脉冲，打开和关闭四个晶体管，使它们像这样排列：

The “logbook” for recording the receipt of a signal from the keyboard is a chain of four transistors constituting a small memory unit known as a register. The control unit sends a signal—a surge of current—to a group of logic gates. This logic circuit, in turn, emits a pattern of electronic pulses to the register, switching the four transistors on and off so that they line up like this:

关 关 开 开

OFF OFF ON ON

此模式是二进制数的电子版本

This pattern is the electronic version of the binary number

0 0 1 1

0 0 1 1

从右边读，这意味着一个 1 加一个 2 加没有 4 加没有 8。将它们全部加起来 — 1 + 2 + 0 + 0 — 0011 是十进制数 3 的二进制版本。它现在存储在 DIM-I 的临时内存寄存器中。

Reading from the right, this means one 1 plus one 2 plus no 4’s plus no 8’s. Add it all up—1 + 2 + 0 + 0—and 0011 is the binary version of the decimal number 3. And it is now stored in DIM-I’s temporary memory register.

处理完这些之后，需要将 3 从临时寄存器发送到其实际目的地 — 在本例中是计算器的显示屏。DIM-I 将把键盘“输入”转换为显示屏“输出”。也就是说，它已准备好将 3 显示在屏幕上。

With that taken care of, the 3 has to be sent from the temporary register to its real destination—in this case, the calculator’s display screen. DIM-I is going to turn the keyboard “input” into display screen “output.” That is, it’s ready to put the 3 on the screen.

控制单元至少和愚笨的站长一样笨，如果不查阅指令，它甚至无法开始执行此操作。它会跳转到存储已编程步骤序列的内存位置，这些步骤将在屏幕上的第一位显示一个数字。计算器现在将以精确的节奏和时钟的滴答声获取并执行操作“输出解码器”电路的指令——一系列逻辑门将把存储在寄存器中的二进制 0011 转换为显示屏上的数字 3。

Being at least as dumb as a dull-witted stationmaster, the control unit can’t even begin to do this without looking up the instructions. It jumps ahead to the memory location that stores the programmed sequence of steps that will display a number in the first digit position on the screen. The calculator will now fetch and execute, in precise rhythm with the ticking of the clock, the instructions to operate the “output decoder” circuitry—the series of logic gates that will transform the binary 0011 that has been stored in the register into the digit 3 on the display screen.

小型数字设备（手表、计算器、手机、汽车导航系统等）可以使用各种显示技术。任何特定机器的选择都取决于许多考虑因素，包括可用电量、需要显示的信息类型、图像变化的速度等。对于像 DIM-I 这样的廉价小型手持计算器，只有两种现实的可能性（因为它们使用电池供电即可正常工作），即发光二极管和液晶显示器。发光二极管（工程师称为 LED）系统采用一组由特殊半导体材料制成的小二极管，其工作原理类似于标准灯泡。当电流流过时，它们会发出明亮的光芒（红色、黄色、绿色、橙色或白色，具体取决于所用的材料）。然而，与灯泡不同，LED 可以用微量的电流发光；而且由于它没有灯丝需要加热，所以 LED 发光时不会产生热量。 （虽然与本章关系不大，但我还是忍不住要指出，在二十一世纪初，爱迪生在十九世纪发明的发光灯丝灯泡最终将被取代。工程师们一直在开发更亮、更白的 LED；很快白色 LED 将取代我们熟悉的玻璃灯泡成为标准家用照明光源。这些新灯的耗电量要少得多，不会发热，也永远不会烧坏。所以不要买任何灯泡存货。）低功耗设备的另一种标准显示设备是液晶显示器 (LCD)，它是一种乳灰色液体，其工作原理与灯泡相反：当通电时，液晶会阻挡电流的流动，从而变黑。结果是，每当您看电子表时，您都会看到熟悉的黑色数字漂浮在灰色背景上。不管它使用 LED 还是 LCD，显示屏都会显示特有的方形数字，这些数字已经成为微电子时代不可或缺的一部分，从时钟、计算器、记分牌和秤的数字读数，随处可见。

Small digital devices—watches, calculators, cell phones, car navigation systems, etc.—can use any of a variety of display techniques. The choice in any particular machine is dictated by a number of considerations—the amount of power available, the type of information that needs to be displayed, the speed at which the image will change, etc. For a cheap little handheld calculator like DIM-I, the only two realistic possibilities—because they work fine on battery power—are light-emitting diodes and liquid crystal displays. The light-emitting diode (known to engineers as LED) system employs a group of small diodes made of a special semiconductor material that work something like a standard light bulb. They give off a bright glow—red, yellow, green, orange, or white, depending on the material used—when current flows through. Unlike a light bulb, though, an LED can be made to glow with a minute amount of current; and since it has no filament to heat up, the LED gives off light without heat. (Although it doesn’t have much to do with this chapter, I can’t resist pointing out that, early in the twenty-first century, the glowing-filament light bulb that Edison invented in the nineteenth century will finally be replaced. Engineers have been developing brighter and whiter LEDs; soon a white LED will replace the familiar glass light bulb as the standard home lighting source. These new lights will use far less power, they won’t get hot, and they’ll never burn out. So don’t buy any light bulb stock.) The other standard display device for low-powered devices is the liquid crystal display (LCD), a creamy gray liquid that works the opposite of a light bulb: When current is applied, the liquid crystal blocks the flow of current and thus turns black. The result is the familiar black digit floating on a gray background that you see whenever you look at your digital watch. Whether it uses LED or LCD, though, the display produces the characteristic squared-off digits that have become part and parcel of the microelectronic age, staring out at us everywhere from the digital readouts of clocks and calculators, scoreboards and scales.

从 0 到 9 的十个数字中的每一个，以及一些其他标准符号（例如表示负数的减号），都可以从包含七个独立二极管的矩形簇以熟悉的方形样式创建，排列方式如下：

Each of the ten digits from 0 to 9, together with a few other standard symbols such as the minus sign for negative numbers, can be created in the familiar squared-off style from a rectangular cluster containing seven separate diodes, arranged this way:

仅使用这些部件绘制所有数字就变成了一种高科技版本的令人抓狂的小谜题，要求您用四块形状怪异的塑料片拼成一个“T”。在七段显示器中，有些形状比其他形状更容易制作。要制作数字“8”，所有七个二极管段都会亮起。“1”由仅点亮段 b 和 c 组成。“5”可以用段 a、f、g、c 和 d 组成：

Drawing all the digits using just these pieces turns into a sort of high-tech version of the maddening little puzzles that ask you to form a “T” out of four weirdly shaped pieces of plastic. In a seven-segment display, some shapes are simpler to make than others. To make a number “8,” all seven diode segments would be lighted. A “1” is formed by lighting only segments b and c. A “5” can be made with segments a, f, g, c, and d:

如果在簇中添加第八个二极管（形状像句点），则该第八个段可以表示小数点：

If an eighth diode, shaped like a period, is added to the cluster, this eighth segment can represent a decimal point:

计算器的输出电路必须解决这个难题：它必须绘制代表控制单元发送的任何数字的十进制数字。输出单元由一组逻辑门组成，这些逻辑门向显示屏的选定部分发送信号模式。在本例中，二进制模式 0011 从控制单元流向输出门。门依次打开段 a、b、g、c、d 和 h，但不打开段 e 和 f。因此，显示屏会像这​​样亮起：

The calculator’s output circuit has to solve the puzzle: it has to draw the decimal digit representing whatever number the control unit sends along. The output unit consists of a group of logic gates that sends out a pattern of signals to selected segments of the display. In the case at hand, the binary pattern 0011 flows from the control unit to the output gates. The gates, in turn, will turn on segments a, b, g, c, d, and h, but not segments e and f. The display, consequently, lights up like this:

将“3”从键盘移到显示屏上——并在此过程中将其写入寄存器——需要数百或数千个指令周期。如果机器只花一秒钟来获取和执行每条指令，那么我们要等待十到十五分钟才能让显示屏亮起来。任何使用标准电话线上网的人都知道坐着等待屏幕上显示某些东西是什么感觉，但我们的小计算器不会让任何人等待。DIM-I 的时钟每十万分之一秒滴答一次，它运行所有指令并在大约 0.005 秒内完成工作。以人类的尺度来看，这实际上是瞬间完成的：我们按下按键的瞬间，数字似乎就出现在显示屏上。计算器比眼睛更快，尽管它将每一项任务都变成了一系列极其复杂的获取和执行操作。

Moving the “3” from the keyboard to the display screen—and writing it down in a register along the way—has taken hundreds or thousands of instruction cycles. If the machine took just one second to fetch and execute each instruction, we would have waited ten or fifteen minutes for the display to light up. Anybody who has surfed the Internet using a standard telephone line knows what it feels like to sit around waiting for something to show up on the screen, but our little calculator doesn’t make anybody wait. With its clock ticking every hundred thousandth of a second, DIM-I runs through all the instructions and completes the job in a total time of about .005 second. On the human scale, this is effectively instantaneous: the digit appears to hit the display screen the instant we push the key. The calculator is quicker than the eye, even though it turns every task into a ridiculously complicated series of fetch-and-execute operations.

它也比手快。据推测，人类操作员很快就会按下更多键。但即使是异常敏捷的人类手指，在两次按键之间也要花费十分之二或三秒的时间——这在微电子尺度上几乎是永恒的时间。因此，即使以我们 10 微秒计算器的从容不迫（以微电子标准为准）的速度，控制单元也有足够的时间检查 EMP，将“3”写入寄存器，将其发送到输出电路，然后返回到其熟悉的消遣——空闲程序——然后手指才能继续移动。事实上，在人类手指两次按键之间的间隔内，计算器将检查键盘数千次。

It’s also quicker than the hand. Presumably, the human operator will soon be punching some more keys. But even an unusually nimble human finger will take two or three tenths of a second between keys—virtually eons of time on the microelectronic scale. Thus the control unit, even at the unhurried (by microelectronic standards) pace of our 10-microsecond calculator, has more than enough time to check for EMP, write the “3” in the register, send it on to the output circuitry, and return to its old familiar pastime—the idle routine—before the finger can move on. Indeed, a calculator will check the keyboard thousands of times in the interval when the human finger is between two key punches.

因此，在接下来几千次向键盘发出查询时，控制中心可能会发现手指仍停留在“3”键上。这种人类迟钝的表现需要一整套新的空闲例行指令，以便 DIM-I 能够弄清楚用户真正想做什么：她只是在慢慢地输入那个 3，还是真的想输入一个数字，比如 33 或 333333？事实上，程序员之间对于控制单元应该等待多长时间才能决定“3”键上的手指是否发送了一个新的 3 存在着无休止的争论。同样的问题也出现在手机键盘上。有些人，尤其是那些用手机发送无数短信的青少年，在那个小键盘上打字速度惊人。手机必须经过编程，才能同时处理神童般的速度和慢吞吞的成年人，后者输入每个新数字的速度都很慢、很慢、很慢。

On its next few thousand queries to the keyboard, consequently, control will probably find a finger still resting on the “3” key. This manifestation of human torpidity requires a whole new subgroup of idle routine instructions so that DIM-I can figure out what the user really has in mind: was she just taking her time about punching that 3, or is she really trying to enter a number like 33, or 333333? Among programmers, in fact, there’s endless dispute about how long a control unit should wait before deciding that the finger on the “3” key is sending a new 3. The same problem shows up on cellular phone keyboards. Some people, particularly teenagers who send endless text messages on their phones, have become amazingly fast typists on that tiny keyboard. The phone has to be programmed to deal with both whiz-kid speedsters and slow-poke adults who punch out each new number slowly, slowly, slowly.

一旦控制系统算出要输入多少个 3，它就可以回到站长职责：观察按键，对照时间表检查它感应到的每个脉冲，记录下来，并向电路的各个部分发送适当的信号。它可能会将脉冲切换到通向主存储单元、临时存储寄存器或显示屏的线路上。

Once control figures out how many 3’s were intended, it can go back to its stationmaster duties: watching the keys, checking each pulse it senses against the timetable, logging it in, and sending the appropriate signals to various parts of the circuitry. It may switch the pulse onto a wire leading to the main memory unit, to a temporary memory register, or to the display screen.

有时，它会将信号发送到任何数字机器中最重要的目的地。这是实际进行计算的复杂逻辑门嵌套。它有各种名称：算术逻辑单元、加法器-减法器等。无论它叫什么，这个中央算术电路都是计算机进行计算的地方。

And occasionally it sends the signals on to the most important destination in any digital machine. This is the complex nest of logic gates that actually does the calculating. It is known by various names: arithmetic-logic unit, adder-subtracter, etc. Whatever it’s called, this central arithmetic circuitry is the place where a computer does its computing.

例如，假设按下 DIM-I 的“3”键的人开始输入加法问题：3 + 2 = 。正如我们所见，第一次击键导致一系列复杂的操作，将 0011（二进制 3）留在内存寄存器中，并在屏幕上显示“3”。对于接下来的两次击键，当 DIM-I 消化“+”和“2”时，将再次遵循相同的一般序列，其复杂性令人眼花缭乱。

Let’s assume, for example, that the person who pushed DIM-I’s “3” key was starting to punch in an addition problem: 3 + 2 = . As we have seen, the first keystroke resulted in a byzantine sequence of operations that left 0011 (binary 3) in a memory register and displayed a “3” on the screen. For the next two keystrokes, the same general sequences are followed again, in all their labyrinthine complexity, as DIM-I digests the “+” and the “2.”

当脉冲从“=”键传来时，事情变得更加复杂。该脉冲是行动的召唤。一旦控制系统检测到有人触摸了该键，它就会跳转到一组新指令，将数字和加号发送到算术单元。任何数字设备最复杂的部分都是该单元的电路。所有开关和所有线路都必须布置好，以便无论输入什么二进制脉冲，都只能输出正确的答案。正是因为人类已经弄清楚了如何构建算术逻辑电路，一个无知的工具才可以执行逻辑和算术运算。

Things become even more complicated when the pulse comes in from the “=” key. That pulse is the call to action. As soon as control senses that someone has touched that key, it jumps to a new set of instructions that dispatches the number and the plus sign to the arithmetic unit. The most complicated part of any digital device is the circuitry for that unit. All the switches and all the wiring must be arranged so that no matter what binary pulses are fed in, only the correct answer can come out. It is only because humans have figured out how to build arithmethic-logic circuitry that an ignorant tool can perform logical and arithmetic operations.

任何数字工具（无论大小）中的运算电路的基本构件都是克劳德·香农（Claude Shannon）于 1937 年首次提出的标准逻辑门。香农当时表明，各种开关组合可以与几个电阻器和电容器连接在一起，以执行乔治·布尔（George Boole）提出的基本逻辑运算。这些逻辑电路称为门；门根据既定规则接收和发送脉冲。这些逻辑门中最简单的电路称为非门 - 一组开关，其输出始终与输入相反。也就是说，如果电流流入非门，电流就不会流出。当没有电流流入时，电流就会流出。

The basic building blocks of the arithmetic circuit in any digital tool, big or small, are the standard logic gates that Claude Shannon first proposed in 1937. As Shannon showed then, various combinations of switches can be wired together with a few resistors and capacitors to carry out the basic logical operations that George Boole had formulated. These logic circuits are called gates; the gates take in and send out impulses according to established rules. The simplest of these logic gates is the circuit called a NOT gate—a set of switches with an output that is always the opposite of the input. That is, if current flows into the NOT gate, current does not flow out. When current is not flowing in, current does flow out.

将其转换为二进制数学，输入“1”的非门将输出“0”，反之亦然。这个小而简单的电路的完整操作可以在一个小而简单的逻辑表中列出：

Translating this to binary math, a NOT gate that takes in a “1” will send out a “0,” and vice versa. The complete operation of this small, simple circuit can be set forth in a small, simple logic table:

由于该电路的运行是基本物理力的函数，因此除了表中所示的结果外，不可能有其他结果。因此，计算机工程师将此类表格称为真值表。

Because the operation of this circuit is a function of fundamental physical forces, there can be no other results than those shown in the table. Accordingly, a table like this is known to computer engineers as a truth table.

电路设计的标准方法是准备提供所需结果的真值表，然后使用香农技术构建一个产生与表匹配结果的电路。例如，生成布尔 AND 运算的真值表非常简单。正如我们在第 6 章中看到的，AND 运算的规则（以昏昏欲睡的通勤者为代表，如果时钟显示现在是早上 8:00 并且日历显示今天是工作日，他必须早上起床）是，只有当条件 A 和条件 B 都为真时，结果才为是。要用 DIM-I 可以理解的二进制术语来陈述该逻辑规则，只有当输入 A 和输入 B 都为 1 时，输出才为 1。如果任一输入不为 1，则 AND 门必须输出 0。将其写在真值表中，AND 运算如下所示：

The standard approach to circuit design is to prepare the truth table that provides the desired result and then, using Shannon’s techniques, build a circuit that produces a result to match the table. It is simple enough, for example, to produce the truth table for the Boolean AND operation. As we saw in Chapter 6, the rule of the AND operation—typified by the sleepy commuter who has to get out of bed in the morning if the clock says it is 8:00 A.M. AND the calendar says it is a workday—is that the result is yes only if condition A AND condition B are both true. To state that logical rule in the binary terms that DIM-I can understand, the output is 1 only if input A AND input B are both 1. If either input is not 1, then the AND gate has to emit a 0. Set it down in a truth table, and the AND operation looks like this:

该表比我们刚刚看到的简单 NOT 表稍微复杂一些。而且这些事情可能会变得更加复杂。例如，AND 运算可能有三个、四个或八个不同的输入。基本的逻辑 AND 规则是相同的 - 只有当输入 A AND 输入 B AND 输入 C AND 输入 D 等都为 1 时，输出才为 1 - 但绘制真值表并在电路中复制时会变得更加复杂。

That table is a little more complicated than the simple NOT table we just saw. And it is possible for these things to become a whole lot more complicated. An AND operation, for example, could have three or four or eight different inputs. The basic logical AND rule is the same—the output is 1 only if input A AND input B AND input C AND input D, etc., are all 1—but the truth table gets more complicated to draw and to replicate in electric circuitry.

此外，不同的逻辑门可以以不同的组合方式串联起来，以实现不同的逻辑结果。在常见情况下，NOT 门连接到 AND 门的输出，这样 AND 运算的结果就会直接反转。NOT 加 AND 的组合创建了一种称为 NAND 门的新逻辑门。出于各种原因，这已成为许多计算机设计师最喜欢的构建块。

Further, different logic gates can be chained one after another in different combinations to achieve different logical results. In a common instance, a NOT gate is wired to the output of an AND gate, so that the result of the AND operation is directly reversed. This combination of NOT plus AND creates a new logic gate called a NAND gate. For various reasons, this has become the most popular building block of all for many computer designers.

为了使像 DIM-I 这样一台没有思维的机器每次都能将两位数字相加并得出正确答案，电路设计师首先要为双输入加法问题绘制真值表。由于数字机器以二进制数进行算术运算，因此真值表涵盖了二进制加法的所有规则：

To make a mindless machine like DIM-I add two digits and come up with the right answer every time, then, the circuit designer first draws up the truth table for a two-input addition problem. Since digital machines do their arithmetic in binary numbers, the truth table encompasses all the rules for binary addition:

（10 读作“一零”，是 2 的二进制版本。）

(The 10, which is read “one-zero,” is the binary version of 2.)

自从人们开始制造数字计算设备以来，标准电路已经得到开发，可以复制每个必要的逻辑门和每个必要的数学运算。工程师们已经完善了几种不同的电路，可以精确地产生这种二进制结果。必要的开关模式内置于执行逻辑和算术运算的微处理器芯片的一角。由于 DIM-I 是一种非常简单的设备，它使用最简单的加法电路，由大约十几个标准门构成。电子脉冲以代表要相加的二进制数字的模式流入门。产生的是代表这两个数字之和的脉冲模式——如果需要，还会有一个进位数字，以结转到下一列。

Since people started building digital computational devices, standard circuits have been developed to replicate every necessary logic gate and every necessary mathematical operation. Engineers have perfected several different circuits that will produce precisely this binary result. The necessary patterns of switches are built into the corner of a microprocessor chip that does logic and arithmetic. Since DIM-I is such a simple device, it uses the simplest addition circuit there is, constructed with about a dozen standard gates. The electronic pulses flow into the gates in patterns representing the binary digits to be added. What comes out is a pattern of pulses representing the sum of those two digits—and a carry digit, if necessary, to be carried over to the next column.

当 DIM-I 内部的控制单元注意到有人按下了“=”键时，该电路就会开始使用。现在，控制单元会返回到其临时存储寄存器，查找之前的按键点击情况，以便进行计算。寄存器记录了有人按下了“3”、“+”和“2”键。因此，DIM-I 现在面临着一项艰巨的任务：将 3 + 2 相加并求和。为此，控制单元将 3 和 2（当然是二进制形式）逐列输入加法电路：

And this circuitry comes into use when the control unit inside DIM-I notices that somebody has pushed the “=” key. Control now goes back to its temporary storage registers to find what the previous key clicks were so that it can do the computation. The registers record that somebody pushed the keys “3,” “+,” and “2.” So DIM-I now faces the formidable task of adding 3 + 2 and finding the sum. To do so, control feeds the 3 and the 2 (in binary form, of course) into an addition circuit, one column at a time:

从右列（二进制数的 1 列）开始，每对数字进入逻辑门。由于门的接线方式，可能出现的脉冲模式只有一种：

Starting with the right-hand column (the 1’s column of the binary number), each pair of digits enters the logic gates. Because of the way the gates are wired, there is only one pattern of pulses that can possibly emerge:

0 1 0 1

0 1 0 1

（当然，这是二进制 5。）

(That’s a binary 5, of course.)

现在加法电路已经给出了答案，控制单元重新开始工作。它向输出电路发送一个信号：“准备显示答案。”二进制脉冲流入；电流沿着选定的导线流出，通向显示器。选定的段亮起，屏幕上问题的二进制答案 0101 被转换成十进制等价值：

Now that the addition circuitry has emitted an answer, the control unit gets back into the act. It sends a signal to the output circuitry: “Get ready to display the answer.” The binary pulses flow in; current flows out along selected wires leading to the display. The chosen segments light up, and the binary answer to the problem, 0101, is translated on the screen to its decimal equivalent:

太棒了！以最迂回的方式，DIM-I 确实解决了一个问题。在微处理器的细致分步方式下，看似简单的 3 + 2 加法任务变成了塞西尔·B·德米尔 (Cecil B. DeMille) 的作品，成千上万的临时演员严格按照导演的指示行事。任何人的头脑都能在一瞬间解决的问题都必须在计算器上分解成成千上万条单独的指令，这些指令引导机器完成其工作。

Ta da! In the most roundabout conceivable fashion, DIM-I has actually solved a problem. In the minute step-by-step manner of the microprocessor, the seemingly simple task of adding 3 + 2 has become a Cecil B. DeMille production, with thousands of extras following the director’s instructions to the letter. A problem any human mind could work in a flash had to be broken down for the calculator into thousands and thousands of individual instructions that led the machine by the nose through its paces.

看到计算机必须查阅极其详细的使用手册来检查其所做的每件事，让我想起了披头士乐队的电影《救命！》中两个邪恶科学家的精彩场景。一位身穿白大褂的科学家犯了一个错误，惹怒了他的老板。“从现在开始，”老板咆哮道，“不先跟我核实就不要做任何事情。”“是的，老板，”下属回答。现在老板说，“好的，过来！”下属开始穿过房间。然后他想起了必须先跟老板核实所有事情的规则。“我可以移动左脚吗？”他问。“我可以移动右脚吗？”等等。自然，这让老板更加不耐烦。

Watching the way a computer has to go back to the ridiculously detailed instruction manual to check on everything it does reminds me of that wonderful scene with the two evil scientists in the Beatles’ movie Help! One white-coated scientist makes a mistake, infuriating his boss. “From now on,” the boss roars, “don’t do anything without checking first with me.” “Yes, boss,” the underling replies. Now the boss says, “Okay, come over here!” The underling starts to walk across the room. Then he remembers the rule that he has to check everything first with the boss. “Can I move my left foot?” he asks. “Can I move my right foot?” And so on. Naturally, this makes the boss even more impatient.

但当然，DIM-I 太无知了，无法耐心等待或不耐心等待。它是一种工具，就像锤子或螺丝刀一样，它做任何事情的唯一方法就是遵循人类给它的精确指令，直到最细微的程度。这就是为什么两个数字相加需要所有这些获取和执行。这是一个只有无意识的机器才会喜欢的过程。这是一个只有强大的智慧才能发明的过程。但是，数字机制是由地球上最强大的计算机——人类大脑发明的。

But of course, DIM-I is too ignorant to be patient or impatient. It is a tool, like a hammer or a screwdriver, and the only way it can do anything is to follow the precise instructions humans have given it, to the most minute degree. That’s why adding two numbers takes all those fetches and all those executes. It is a process that only a mindless mechanism could love. It is a process that only a powerful intelligence could have invented. But then, digital mechanisms were invented by the most powerful computer on earth—the human mind.

10

10

日落，日出

SUNSET, SUNRISE

1974 年 6 月 27 日上午，一份极具洛可可风格特色的官方文件出现在杰克·基尔比 (Jack Kilby) 在达拉斯的邮箱中。这份文件用鲜红色的丝带装饰，上面贴着闪闪发光的金箔封条，上面镌刻着华丽的草书字体，并配有精美的蚀刻版画，上面描绘了美国鹰、星条旗、各种机器和美国商务部总部大楼等。这份文件以丰富的法律行文表达了其信息：

A spectacularly rococo official document showed up in Jack Kilby’s mailbox in Dallas on the morning of June 27, 1974. Framed in a silken strip of bright red ribbon, affixed with a gleaming gold foil seal, engraved in a florid cursive script, and illustrated with an ornate etching that depicted, among much else, the American eagle, the stars and stripes, assorted machinery, and the headquarters building of the U.S. Department of Commerce, the document poured forth its message in a rich flood of legalistic prose:

致所有收受此礼物的人：鉴于 Jack S. Kilby、Jerry D. Merryman 和 James H. Van Tassel，均来自德克萨斯州达拉斯……向专利局局长提交了一份请愿书，请求授予一项所谓的新型实用发明的专利证书，该发明的名称和说明已包含在说明书中，说明书的副本随附于此并作为本请愿书的一部分……且鉴于经适当审查，上述申请人被判定有权根据法律获得专利：因此，现在授予这些专利证书……自授予之日起，有效期为十七年。

TO ALL TO WHOM THESE PRESENTS SHALL COME: WHEREAS Jack S. Kilby; Jerry D. Merryman; James H. Van Tassel, all of Dallas, Texas . . . presented to the COMMISSIONER OF PATENTS a petition praying for the grant of LETTERS PATENT for an alleged new and useful invention the title and a description of which are contained in the specification of which a copy is hereunto annexed and made part hereof . . . and WHEREAS upon due examination made the said Claimants are adjudged to be justly entitled to a patent under the law: Now therefore these LETTERS PATENT are to grant . . . for the term of SEVENTEEN years from the date of this grant.

附在其中并成为其一部分的说明书实际上是德州仪器在几年前 Kilby 和他的“加州理工学院”团队成功开发出第一台袖珍计算器时提交的专利申请。在正式获得专利后，TI 现在可以将其袖珍计算器上的“专利申请中”字样替换为官方专利号：US Pat. 3,819,921 — 至今，这个标志仍印在德州仪器和其他获得其许可复制 Kilby 基本架构的公司生产的计算器的塑料外壳上。

The specification thereunto annexed and made part thereof was, in fact, the patent application that Texas Instruments had sent off years earlier when Kilby and his “Cal Tech” team had successfully developed the first pocket calculator. With the formal receipt of the patent, TI could now replace the words “Patent pending” on its pocket calculators with the official patent number: U.S. Pat. 3,819,921—a legend that is still being molded today into the plastic cases of calculators turned out by Texas Instruments and other firms it has licensed to copy the basic Kilby architecture.

与围绕集成电路的长期法律斗争形成鲜明对比的是，手持计算器的专利问题一直没有争议。每个人都承认 Kilby、Merryman 和 Van Tassel 有权获得这项荣誉。然而，到专利发布时，这项荣誉几乎就是它的全部。到 1974 年中期，很明显德州仪器以及所有其他美国制造商都失去了对计算器业务的控制权。这项革命性的产品——在美国德克萨斯州构思、诞生和培育——正成为日本的专利。

In sharp contrast to the long legal struggle over the integrated circuit, there had been no contest about the patent for the handheld calculator. Everyone recognized that Kilby, Merryman, and Van Tassel were entitled to the honor. By the time the patent was issued, however, the honor of the thing was just about all it stood for. By the middle of 1974, it was clear that Texas Instruments, and for that matter all other American manufacturers, had lost control of the calculator business. This revolutionary product—conceived, born, and bred in Texas, U.S.A.—was becoming a Japanese preserve.

鉴于日本在消费电子行业其他领域的主导地位，卡西欧和松下等公司赶上并超越美国竞争对手并不令人意外。但这仍是一个苦涩的讽刺。日本电子公司凭借袖珍计算器的成功，为当代美国商业史上较为愉快的篇章之一增添了酸涩的色彩。

Given the Japanese dominance of other facets of the consumer electronics business, it was not altogether surprising that firms like Casio and Panasonic had caught and passed their American competitors. But it was still a bitter irony. By succeeding with the pocket calculator, the Japanese electronics firms had added a sour twist to one of the happier chapters in contemporary American business history.

自 20 世纪 30 年代首次面世以来，办公计算器就被全世界公认为美国产品。尽管面临来自欧洲公司的激烈竞争，但美国制造商仍占据了市场主导地位。随后，在 20 世纪 60 年代，当“计算器”仍是一种笨重、昂贵的台式设备时，日本制造商已进入美国市场，并完全压倒了传统的美国办公机器公司。日本的市场主导地位稳步提升，而美国方面的形势一直不容乐观，直到 1971 年 Jack Kilby 的第一台手持计算器上市。微电子技术在计算器业务中的应用彻底扭转了局面。基于芯片的计算器比任何日本产品都更小、更便宜、更高效，让美国品牌重新占据了主导地位。

Since its first appearance in the 1930s, the office calculator had been recognized worldwide as an American product. Despite impressive competition from European firms, U.S. manufacturers dominated the market. Then, in the 1960s, when a “calculator” was still a hefty, expensive, desktop apparatus, Japanese manufacturers had moved into the U.S. market and simply overwhelmed the traditional American office-machine firms. Japan’s market dominance increased steadily, and the situation was bleak for the American side until the day in 1971 when Jack Kilby’s first handheld calculator went on the market. The application of microelectronics to the calculator business completely turned the tables. The chip-based calculator—smaller, cheaper, and more efficient than any Japanese product—put American labels back on top.

这一逆转是如此引人注目，以致美国商务部发布了一份关于美国胜利的详细报告：“凭借创新产品和激进定价政策以及高产量效率，美国公司迅速从其主要竞争对手日本手中夺回了美国计算器市场的控制权。”报告接着说，这一转变“极好地说明了自由竞争的工业体系如何为消费者带来利益”，也是其他美国行业在与外国竞争者的斗争中可以效仿的典范。

This reversal was so dramatic that the Commerce Department issued a detailed report on the American triumph: “With innovative products and aggressive pricing policies backed by high volume production efficiencies, U.S. firms rapidly regained control of the U.S. calculator market from their chief competitors, the Japanese.” The report went on to say that this turnabout was “an excellent illustration of the way a free and competitive industrial system can provide benefits to the consumer,” and a model that other U.S. industries could emulate in their struggles against foreign competition.

不幸的是，美国并不是唯一一个拥有自由竞争的工业体系的地方，美国公司也不是计算器行业中唯一知道如何实施激进定价和提高生产效率的公司。当 Jack Kilby 获得专利证书时，日本制造商已经获得了制造自己的手持计算器所需的信息。他们部分开发了自己的计算器技术；但主要还是借用美国技术，要么购买要么盗用美国公司的专利工艺。（TI 于 1982 年起诉卡西欧侵犯 Kilby 计算器专利；该案以卡西欧支付一大笔钱和解。）

Unfortunately, the United States was not the only place with a free and competitive industrial system, and American firms were not the only ones in the calculator business that knew how to practice aggressive pricing and production efficiencies. By the time Jack Kilby received his letters patent, Japanese manufacturers had obtained the information they needed to make handheld calculators of their own. In part, they developed their own calculator know-how; mainly, though, they borrowed American techniques, either buying or appropriating patented processes from U.S. firms. (TI sued Casio in 1982 for infringement of the Kilby calculator patent; the case was settled with Casio paying a considerable sum.)

无论如何，来自日本的竞争如此激烈，如此成功，以至于在最初的计算器报告发布两年后，美国商务部不得不发布一份令人不快的更新报告：“自 1974 年以来，情况再次发生逆转……美国公司继续退出计算器行业……日本原产计算器进口再次成为这种下降趋势的主要因素。” 1977 年撰写这份报告时，日本制造的计算器占美国销售的计算器的 45%。到 20 世纪 80 年代初，日本公司在美国市场的份额（以美元价值计算）超过 70%。（到 21 世纪初，日本和美国制造商都转向生产附加值更高的产品，大多数袖珍计算器来自中国或东南亚。）

In any case, the competition from Japan was so intense and so successful that, two years after its original calculator report, the Commerce Department had no choice but to issue an unhappy update: “Since 1974, the situation has once again been reversed. . . . The departure of U.S. firms from the calculator industry continues. . . . Japanese-origin calculator imports have again been a major factor in this downward trend.” When that was written, in 1977, the Japanese made about 45 percent of the calculators sold in the United States. By the early 1980s, Japanese firms’ share of the U.S. market, in dollar value, was above 70 percent. (By the turn of the century, both Japanese and American manufacturers had moved on to higher value-added products, and most pocket calculators came from China or Southeast Asia.)

正如美国商务部所指出的，70 年代日本公司在美国从汽车到拉链等各个市场都取得了同样成功的进军，任何看过日本公司进军美国市场的人，都不会忘记日本公司在 70 年代占领计算器市场的模式。日本公司首先进入了低价市场​​，生产出简单的“普通”计算器，这些计算器为消费者提供了更多选择、同等或更好的可靠性以及比美国同类品牌更低的价格。在低端市场站稳脚跟后，入侵者开始扩大其地盘。“他们所做的就是拿走我们的产品，并添加一堆花哨的东西，”一位美国制造商抱怨道。但这些花哨的东西——更不用说卡路里计数器、货币转换器、万年历、占星表、生物节律图以及东京营销人员构想的其他各种附加功能——卖出了数百万台计算器。在进攻的第三阶段，日本人将目光投向了利润率最高的更复杂、价格更高的型号。美国商务部的第二份报告指出：“这种市场活动模式在电视机等其他产品上也能看到。”

As the Commerce Department noted, the pattern of conquest in calculators in the seventies was familiar to anyone who had watched Japanese firms make equally successful forays into U.S. markets ranging from automobiles to zippers. The Japanese had first moved into the low-priced segment of the business, turning out simple, “plain vanilla” calculators that offered the consumer greater variety, equal or better reliability, and lower prices than comparable U.S.-made brands. Having established a beachhead at the low end of the market, the invaders moved to broaden their territory. “All they did was take our product and add a bunch of bells and whistles,” a U.S. manufacturer complained. But the bells and whistles—not to mention the calorie counters, currency converters, perpetual calendars, astrology tables, biorhythm charts, and assorted other add-ons dreamed up by the marketing men in Tokyo—sold calculators by the millions. In the third stage of their assault, the Japanese set their sights on more sophisticated, higher-priced models that provided the highest profit margins. “This pattern of market activity,” the Commerce Department’s second report said, “has been observed for other products, such as television sets.”

电视机与美国电子行业的任何一位从业者相比，都令人心生恐惧。电视机是现代电子领域国际竞争的典型案例，但对于美国工业家来说，这绝不是一个令人愉快的典型案例。电视机发展中几乎每一项重大进步都来自美国。然而，日本人凭借自己的生产和营销技能，屡屡击败了美国的创新天才。

The comparison to television sets had to be a frightening one for anybody in the U.S. electronics industry. Television was the paradigm case of international competition in modern electronics, but it is hardly a pleasant paradigm for American industrialists to ponder. Just about every significant advance in the development of television has come from the United States. Yet the Japanese repeatedly trumped the American genius for innovation with their own skills at production and marketing.

电视机的起源可以追溯到 19 世纪晚期几位欧洲物理学家的工作，他们开发并完善了阴极射线管。现代电视机是这种设备的直系后代，这一血统反映在俚语“tube”和“boob tube”中。阴极射线管最初是作为实验室设备制造的，它是一种长长的封闭玻璃管，内部有一个装置，可以沿管子长度发射“阴极射线”——JJ Thomson 确定为电子流的神秘能量束。管子另一端的玻璃涂有磷光体。从阴极枪发射的电子沿管子向下移动，击中远端的磷光玻璃。电子击中的地方，磷光体就会发出明亮的光点。

The ancestry of the television set can be traced to the work of several late-nineteenth-century European physicists who developed and perfected the cathode ray tube. The modern TV is a direct descendant of this device, a lineage reflected in the slang terms “tube” and “boob tube.” The cathode ray tube, originally built strictly as a laboratory apparatus, was a long, closed glass tube with a mechanism inside that shot a “cathode ray”—the mysterious beam of energy that J. J. Thomson determined to be a stream of electrons—down the length of the tube. At the opposite end of the tube the glass was coated with phosphor. An electron shot from the cathode gun raced down the tube and struck the phosphorescent glass at the far end. Precisely where the electron hit, the phosphor would glow with a bright point of light.

1908 年，英国物理学家 AA Campbell-Swinton 在凝视阴极射线管上有趣的发光点图案时，突然想到了电视的基本概念：玻璃管上的光点可以形成点画法图像，即电视图像。（如果您放下这本书，仔细观察电视屏幕，您会发现玻璃上的图像实际上是由数千个单独的光点组成的，就像法国点画派画家 Georges Seurat 的作品一样。）Campbell-Swinton 将他的想法命名为“远距离电子视觉”；“电视”一词显然是由法国人创造的。苏格兰高地的每个小学生都知道，苏格兰人 John Logie Baird 曾成功实现过这个想法。但电视的真正发明是在 20 世纪 20 年代，由一对相互竞争的发明家管理的美国实验室中诞生的，他们激烈地竞争，希望成为第一个完善这一概念的人。

Peering at an interesting pattern of glowing dots on a cathode ray tube in 1908, the British physicist A. A. Campbell-Swinton hit upon the fundamental idea of television: the dots of light on the glass tube could form a pointillistic picture—the television image. (If you put down this book for a moment and look closely, very closely, at a television screen, you will see that the picture on the glass is actually composed of thousands of individual points of light, à la the French pointillist painter Georges Seurat.) Campbell-Swinton named his idea “Distant Electrical Vision”; the term “television” was apparently coined by the French. As every schoolchild in the Highlands knows, the Scotsman John Logie Baird pursued the idea with some success. But the real invention of television came about in the 1920s in a pair of American laboratories run by a pair of competing inventors who battled furiously to be first to perfect the concept.

一边是弗拉基米尔·兹沃里金，他是沙皇军队的一名军官，在 1917 年革命期间逃离俄罗斯，最终进入纽约 RCA 的戴维·萨诺夫实验室。另一边是菲洛·T·法恩斯沃思，他是来自爱达荷州的一位非常独立的农场男孩，他不会与任何大型电子公司签约，不得不不断四处寻找资金来支持他的研究。（经过多年的工作，在即将取得成功之际，法恩斯沃思在 34 岁时退休回到农场——典型的精疲力竭的例子。）

In one corner was Vladimir Zworykin, an officer in the tsar’s army who had fled Russia during the 1917 revolution and eventually landed in David Sarnoff’s laboratory at RCA in New York. In the other was Philo T. Farnsworth, a fiercely independent farm boy from Idaho who would not sign on with any of the major electronics firms and was forced to scrounge constantly for money to support his research. (After years of work, and just on the verge of final success, Farnsworth retired back to the farm at the age of thirty-four—a classic burnt-out case.)

在竞争的鞭策下，兹沃里金和法恩斯沃思迅速超越了贝尔德和其他欧洲人的努力，到 1929 年，他们共同开发出了一种可以将视觉图像转换为电子信号的照相机，以及一种可以将这些信号转换回视觉图像的显像管。兹沃里金/法恩斯沃思电视机（以及当今几乎所有电视机）的核心是一个阴极，它向磷光屏发射移动的电子束。电子枪在屏幕上喷射图像的方式就像喷漆在地铁墙上喷涂图像一样。当然，涂鸦会永远留在墙上；相比之下，电视显像管每秒在屏幕上喷射新图像 60 次，从而产生运动图像的幻觉。

Spurred on by the whip of competition with each other, Zworykin and Farnsworth rapidly surpassed the efforts of Baird and other Europeans, and by 1929 they had developed, between them, a camera that could convert a visual image into electronic signals and a picture tube that could translate these signals back into the visual image. The heart of the Zworykin/Farnsworth TV—and of almost all television sets today—is a cathode that fires a moving beam of electrons toward the phosphorescent screen. The electron gun sprays a picture on the screen the way an aerosol paint can sprays pictures on the subway wall. The graffiti, of course, is on the wall for good; the television tube, in contrast, sprays a new image on the screen sixty times each second, creating the illusion of a moving picture.

电视的真正商业化发展一直被推迟到二战后，当时美国政府终于开始颁布频率、带宽等技术法规，以便所有电视台都能播放相同的标准信号。战后第一年，美国售出了 6,000 台电视机。1948 年，美国人购买了 100 万台电视机；两年后，购买量增加到 700 万台。电视机市场开始繁荣。由于美国技术领先，美国标准在世界各地被采用，只是略有不同。

Serious commercial development of television was delayed until after World War II, when the U.S. government finally got around to issuing technical regulations for frequencies, bandwidths, and the like, so that all stations could broadcast the same standard signal. In the first year after the war, 6,000 television sets were sold in the United States. In 1948, Americans bought 1 million sets; two years later, 7 million. The boom was on. Because American technology set the pace, the U.S. standards were adopted, with minor variations, around the world.

随着销量的飙升，美国电视制造商开发了一种与美国另一项蓬勃发展的行业——汽车业——类似的营销结构。主要的电视制造商——Admiral、DuMont、Sylvania 等——通过特许经销商销售产品，这些经销商通常只经销一个品牌。经销商提供工厂授权维修，这在当时是一项重要的职能，因为家庭电视可能和家庭汽车一样频繁地进店维修。他们尽职尽责地推销大型控制台型号，为制造商带来最大的利润率。

As their sales skyrocketed, U.S. television manufacturers developed a marketing structure not unlike that of another booming American business, the automobile industry. The major television makers—Admiral, DuMont, Sylvania, etc.—sold their products through franchise dealerships that generally handled only one brand. The dealers provided factory-authorized repair, an important function at a time when the family TV was likely to be in the shop as often as the family car. And they dutifully pushed the large console models that brought manufacturers the largest profit margins.

这种零售结构使得新公司（尤其是海外制造商）进入美国市场变得异常困难。美国是迄今为止最大、利润最高的电视市场，但外来者无法进入由国内大公司控制的经销商体系。此外，如果没有零件仓库网络和经过工厂培训的维修人员，海外竞争对手如何保证其电视机正常运行？

This retail structure made it doubly hard for new firms, particularly overseas manufacturers, to move into the U.S. market. It was the biggest and most lucrative television market by far, but there was no way for an outsider to break into the dealership system, which was controlled by the big domestic firms. Further, without a network of parts depots and factory-trained repairmen, how could an overseas competitor keep his sets in working order?

这些问题迫使欧洲主要电子公司留在国内。但在政府官员急于增加出口的推动下，日本制造商在 20 世纪 60 年代初对美国进行了长期观察并决定尝试。在技术方面，日本最初抄袭了其他人的做法。这些公司从美国和欧洲公司购买了 400 多项专利权，并通常等待其他人取得重大突破。然而，在生产和营销方面，日本进行了创新。

These problems persuaded the major European electronics firms to stay home. But the Japanese manufacturers, prodded by government officials eager to increase exports, took a long look at the United States in the early 1960s and decided to give it a try. On technical matters, the Japanese initially copied what others had done. The firms purchased the rights to more than 400 patents from U.S. and European firms and generally waited for others to make the important breakthroughs. In production and marketing, however, Japan did the innovating.

日本电视公司向美国市场推出了比许多国内制造商更多样化的机型，包括一系列小型台式电视机和首批便携式电视机。通过瞄准低价市场，他们能够通过快速增长的折扣连锁店销售电视机，从而绕过传统的经销商网络。为了解决缺乏训练有素的维修人员的问题，日本人取消了维修需求。他们在工厂中培养了一支纪律严明的劳动力，并引入了广泛的质量控制机制，这样日本电视机就可以可靠地运行，而无需经常维护。

Japanese television firms approached the U.S. market with a wider variety of models than many domestic makers offered, including a line of smaller table-model sets and the first portables. By targeting the low-price segment of the market, they were able to sell their sets through the fast-growing discount chains, circumventing the traditional dealer network. To deal with the lack of trained repairmen, the Japanese eliminated the need for repair. They honed a highly disciplined labor force in their factories and introduced extensive quality-control mechanisms, so that Japanese television sets would work reliably without constant maintenance.

结果是惊人的。1961 年，这六家日本制造商的黑白电视机销量加起来还不到美国黑白电视机销量的 0.5%。1962 年，他们的市场份额上升到 2%，1965 年上升到 13%；此后，这一比例逐年上升。

The results were dramatic. In 1961 the six Japanese manufacturers combined sold less than one half of one percent of the black-and-white television sets purchased in the United States. They moved up to 2 percent of the market in 1962 and 13 percent in 1965; thereafter, the percentage kept going up, year after year.

美国制造商对这一挑战不以为然。到 60 年代中期，他们集中精力研发更热门的新产品——彩色电视，美国在彩色电视领域的技术遥遥领先于世界。但彩色电视市场却重演了黑白电视的辉煌。日本积极购买西方的专利许可。他们比美国公司晚几年进入市场，但凭借其熟悉的品种齐全、价格低廉和质量上乘的结合弥补了起步的迟缓。到 1976 年，日本已成为世界领先的彩色电视生产国，占据了美国 35% 的市场份额。

American manufacturers shrugged off this challenge. By the mid-sixties, they were concentrating on an even hotter new product—color television, in which U.S. technology led the world by a large margin. But the color TV market turned into a rerun of the monochrome story. The Japanese aggressively purchased patent licenses in the West. They entered the fray a few years behind the American firms but made up for the late start with their familiar combination of extensive variety, low prices, and high quality. By 1976, Japan was the world’s leading producer of color television sets and had 35 percent of the U.S. market.

在这一关头，一些美国公司干脆放弃了。Admiral 退出了电视业务。摩托罗拉将其电视业务出售给了松下。其他公司则在市场和华盛顿进行了反击。美国制造商指控一些日本竞争对手以掠夺性的价格向美国“倾销”电视机；根据法律，这可能导致日本公司被处以数百万美元的罚款，但出于外交考虑，这一结果没有发生。相反，日本和美国政府于 1977 年达成了一项“有序营销协议”——这是进口配额的外交术语。这些年度协议为国内制造商保留了近 80% 的美国市场（在这种情况下，“国内”一词包括在美国生产电视机的日本公司）。最终，是外交手段，而不是技术或商业头脑，让美国在其开拓的市场中保留了一部分行动。

At this juncture, some U.S. firms simply gave up. Admiral quit the business. Motorola sold its television operation to Matsushita. Others fought back, both in the market and in Washington. U.S. manufacturers charged that some Japanese competitors were “dumping” TV sets in the United States at predatory prices; under the law, this could have resulted in multimillion-dollar fines for the Japanese firms, but diplomatic considerations prevented that result. Instead, the governments of Japan and the United States in 1977 negotiated an “orderly marketing agreement”—the diplomatic term for an import quota. Those yearly agreements preserved almost 80 percent of the U.S. market for domestic makers (the term “domestic,” in this context, included Japanese firms building sets in the United States). In the end, it was diplomacy, not technology or business acumen, that saved the United States a piece of the action in a market it had pioneered.

从美国的角度来看，电视传奇故事会令人不安，即使它是这种突然工业失败的唯一例子。但在消费电子产品中，就像汽车和钢铁一样，刚刚讲述的历史是常态，而不是例外。在二十世纪的最后几十年里，美国公司被日本制造商所超越，日本制造商提供一系列具有广泛吸引力的产品，这些产品兼具优质品质和有竞争力的价格。

The television saga would be an unsettling one from the American point of view even if it were the sole instance of such an abrupt industrial defeat. But in consumer electronics, as in automobiles and steel, the history just related was the rule, not the exception. Throughout the final decades of the twentieth century, American firms were overtaken by Japanese manufacturers offering a broadly appealing range of products that combined premium quality with competitive prices.

美国商务部表现出官僚主义对数字和表格的普遍渴求，于 1980 年发布了一项研究报告，将整个令人遗憾的状况简化为一张图表：

The Commerce Department, displaying the universal bureaucratic yen for numbers and tables, issued a study in 1980 that reduced the whole sorry state of affairs to a single chart:

在每种情况下，产品都是在美国构思和开发的；在每种情况下，日本人（有时随后是其他国家的生产商，例如台湾、韩国，以及最近的中国）都借用了该技术，然后席卷美国市场。

In each case, the product was conceived and developed in the United States; in each case, the Japanese (sometimes followed by producers from other nations, such as Taiwan, South Korea, and, more recently, China) borrowed the technology and then swept into the American market.

在杰克·基尔比和鲍勃·诺伊斯提出单片机概念后的第一个十年，美国半导体行业蓬勃发展，可以放心地将消费电子产品的这些发展视为无关紧要。在芯片方面，美国先驱者在技术上远远领先于欧洲或亚洲各地的外国竞争对手。无论日本在消费电子产品方面多么令人生畏，芯片都是另一回事。事实证明，日本人善于进入相对稳定的技术领域，产品设计已经确定，并以合理的价格生产大量产品。但集成电路行业在其最初的 25 年里从来都不稳定。改进来得如此之快，以至于实际上并不存在所谓的固定设计；价格沿着学习曲线迅速下降，以至于外国竞争对手的低价竞争并不构成严重威胁。

The American semiconductor industry, during the first booming decade after Jack Kilby and Bob Noyce hit upon the monolithic idea, could safely look upon these developments in consumer electronics as irrelevant. In chips, the American pioneers had an enormous technological lead over foreign competitors everywhere, European or Asian. And however daunting the Japanese might be in consumer electronic goods, the chip was a different animal. The Japanese had proven adept at moving into relatively stable technological fields, where the design of the product was settled, and producing large volumes of goods at reasonable prices. But the integrated circuit business, in its first quarter century, was never stable. Improvements came so rapidly that there was no such thing, really, as a settled design; prices fell so rapidly along the learning curve that undercutting from foreign competitors did not loom as a serious threat.

不过，在 20 世纪 60 年代和 70 年代初，有迹象表明日本人对半导体行业有着共同的关注。日本大型电子公司（如富士通、日本电气公司 (NEC)、日立和索尼）开始购买他们能找到的每一项美国半导体专利的许可；1964 年至 1970 年间，日本支付的美国半导体专利使用费增长了 10 倍，从每年 260 万美元增加到 2500 万美元。对于一些美国公司，尤其是仙童公司来说，这成为一项重要的无风险收入来源。布鲁金斯学会经济学家约翰·蒂尔顿报告称：“美国公司通常非常合作。除了少数例外，他们愿意向日本和其他外国公司授予许可，并帮助他们吸收新的半导体技术，即使在此过程中他们正在帮助建立潜在的竞争对手。”

Still, there were signs during the 1960s and early 1970s that the Japanese had a collective eye on the semiconductor business. The big Japanese electronics firms—outfits like Fujitsu, Nippon Electric Company (NEC), Hitachi, and Sony—began buying licenses for every U.S. semiconductor patent they could find; between 1964 and 1970, royalty payments from Japan on U.S. semiconductor patents rose by a factor of ten, from $2.6 million to $25 million per year. For some U.S. firms, particularly Fairchild, this became an important source of no-risk income. “American firms have generally been very cooperative,” a Brookings Institution economist, John Tilton, reported. “With few exceptions, they have been willing to license Japanese as well as other foreign firms and aid them in assimilating new semiconductor technologies, even though in the process they are helping establish potential rivals.”

只有一家大型美国公司拒绝合作：德州仪器。德州仪器拒绝支付专利使用费，并对其半导体专利设定了更高的价格：除非日本政府允许德州仪器在日本设立制造工厂，否则任何日本公司都不能使用这些专利。这一要求让东京陷入了严重的困境。日本人决心将高科技领域的大多数外国竞争对手排除在本国之外。但为了生产集成电路，日本公司需要同时获得仙童公司的 Noyce 专利和德州仪器的 Kilby 专利。仙童公司愿意出售其技术，日本制造商每赚 1 美元芯片，仙童公司就需要支付 4.5 美分的专利使用费。但德州仪器坚持己见。1968 年，经过几年的报价和反报价，这家达拉斯公司最终获准在日本开设工厂，条件是获得 Kilby 专利许可。此后十多年来，德州仪器是唯一一家在日本有重大销售业绩的美国半导体生产商。直到 20 世纪 80 年代末，里根政府最终对日本存储芯片实施进口禁令，英特尔和其他美国公司才设法在日本开设工厂和设计设施。

There was only one major U.S. firm that refused to cooperate: Texas Instruments. TI spurned royalty payments and set a more ambitious price on its semiconductor patents: no Japanese firm could use them unless the Japanese government permitted TI to set up manufacturing operations in Japan. This demand posed a serious dilemma in Tokyo. The Japanese were determined to exclude most foreign competition in high-tech fields from their country. But in order to produce integrated circuits, the Japanese firms would need access to both the Noyce patent from Fairchild and the Kilby patent from Texas Instruments. Fairchild was willing to sell its technology, for a royalty of 4.5 cents on every dollar the Japanese makers earned on chips. But the Texans hung tough. In 1968, after several years of offers and counteroffers, the Dallas firm was finally permitted—in return for a license to the Kilby patent—to open a Japanese plant. For more than a decade thereafter, TI was the only U.S. semiconductor producer with any significant sales in Japan. Not until the late 1980s, when the Reagan administration finally slapped an import ban on Japanese memory chips, did Intel and other U.S. firms manage to open plants and design facilities in Japan.

无论美国公司是否意识到这一点，大力争取美国专利权和排除美国竞争对手都是日本政府为赢得芯片领域的全球领先地位而制定的宏伟战略的一部分。半导体业务是日本国际贸易和工业部 (MITI) 重点发展的几个高科技行业之一。在其 20 世纪 80 年代的十年计划或“愿景”中，MITI 认为微电子技术非常适合这个岛国，因为它需要大量的人力资源，例如高级工程师和勤奋的工人，而日本拥有丰富的人力资源，但只需要少量的能源和自然资源，而日本缺乏这些资源。

Whether or not the American firms were aware of it, both the vigorous pursuit of U.S. patent rights and the exclusion of U.S. competition were part of a grand strategy devised by the Japanese government to win that nation global preeminence in chips. The semiconductor business was one of several high-tech industries targeted by the Japanese Ministry of International Trade and Industry (MITI) for intensive development. In its ten-year plan, or “vision,” for the 1980s, MITI concluded that microelectronics was perfect for the island nation, because it required large quantities of human resources, such as advanced engineering and diligent workers, which Japan has in abundance, but only small amounts of energy and natural resources, which Japan lacks.

从官方角度看，通产省关于什么对日本工业有利的决定只不过是“行政指导”，企业可以依法自由地忽略这些指导。但有些企业确实忽略了。例如，在 20 世纪 50 年代，通产省的某个人敏锐地洞察到欧洲人和美国人永远不会花钱购买印有本田或丰田等品牌的汽车。通产省发布了“指导意见”，要求一群汽车制造商联合起来设计一款代表整个日本工业的“人民汽车”，面向全球。本田、丰田、日产等拒绝了这个想法，并在全球范围内取得了令人震惊的成果。当通产省在 20 世纪 60 年代与电子行业合作，计划日本进军美国低价电视市场时，索尼这家制造商拒绝了普遍的看法，并找到了自己的利润丰厚的利基市场，即高端品牌。

Officially, MITI’s decisions about what was good for Japanese industry constituted nothing more than “administrative guidance, ” which companies were legally free to ignore. Some did. In the 1950s, for example, someone at MITI had the brilliant insight that Europeans and Americans would never shell out their money for cars bearing names like Honda or Toyota. MITI issued “guidance” telling a group of automakers to get together and design a single “people’s car” that would represent the entire Japanese industry around the world. Honda, Toyota, Nissan, etc., rejected this idea, with stunning worldwide results. When MITI worked with its electronics industry in the sixties to plan Japan’s foray into the low-priced end of the U.S. television market, one manufacturer, Sony, spurned the consensus view and found a lucrative niche of its own, as a prestige upper-bracket label.

但一般来说，通商产业省的政策往往会成为行业惯例。半导体行业当然如此。正如通商产业省所计划的那样，日本电子公司在 20 世纪 60 年代中期获得了开始制造集成电路所需的美国技术。正如通商产业省所计划的那样，这些公司能够依靠向日本国内计算机和电信公司销售产品（除了德州仪器外，没有其他美国公司的竞争）来获得进军全球芯片市场所需的财务缓冲。正如通商产业省所提议的那样，五家最大的电子公司在 20 世纪 70 年代初联合起来开展一项合作研究，部分资金由政府资助，部分资金由公司资助，旨在开发超大规模集成电路 (VLSI) 芯片的制造技术。

As a rule, though, MITI’s policies tend to become industrial practice. They certainly did in semiconductors. Just as MITI planned it, Japanese electronics firms acquired the U.S. technology required to get started in the manufacture of integrated circuits in the mid-sixties. Just as MITI planned it, these firms were able to rely on sales to domestic Japanese computer and telecommunications firms—free of competition from any U.S. firm except Texas Instruments—to provide the financial cushion necessary for an assault on the world market for chips. And just as MITI proposed, the five largest electronics firms banded together in the early 1970s for a cooperative research endeavor—funded partly by the government and partly by the companies—to develop manufacturing techniques for very-large-scale integrated (VLSI) chips.

然而，尽管付出了这么多努力，日本电子行业在微电子领域的大多数领域仍然远远落后于美国公司。日本占据了相当市场份额的产品是随机存取存储器（RAM）芯片。1968 年，罗伯特·诺伊斯和戈登·摩尔在英特尔公司率先发明了内存电路，这种产品与日本的优势非常契合：简单且相对稳定的产品，全球计算机制造商大量使用。然而，即使在 RAM 市场，美国的主导地位也直到 20 世纪 70 年代中期才受到挑战。后来，美国工业给了日本机会。

For all this effort, however, the Japanese electronics industry still lagged far behind American firms in most areas of microelectronics. The one product in which the Japanese took any significant market share was random-access memory, or RAM, chips. The memory circuit, pioneered by Robert Noyce and Gordon Moore at Intel in 1968, was nicely suited to the Japanese strengths: a simple and relatively stable product that was consumed in huge quantities by computer manufacturers around the world. Even in the RAM market, though, U.S. dominance was unchallenged until the middle of the 1970s. Then the American industry gave Japan its chance.

在 1973 年石油禁运之后的长期经济衰退期间，美国半导体公司采取了与美国制造商应对经济衰退通常相同的方式：他们裁员、关闭工厂，并普遍保持低调以等待经济复苏。1976 年，当经济强劲复苏时，计算机公司对当时最先进的内存芯片的需求激增：16K RAM，能够存储大约 16,000 位信息。美国公司无法快速重建以满足需求。他们的客户去寻找 RAM 芯片的替代来源——并在日本找到了。

During the prolonged recession following the 1973 oil embargo, American semiconductor firms reacted the way American manufacturers normally react to recessions: they laid off workers, closed plants, and generally hunkered down to await an upturn. In 1976, when the economy came roaring back, there was an enormous burst of demand from computer firms for what was then the most advanced memory chip: the 16K RAM, capable of storing some 16,000 bits of information. The U.S. firms could not rebuild fast enough to meet the need. Their customers went shopping for an alternate source of RAM chips—and found it in Japan.

按照日本工业惯例，日本大型电子公司在经济衰退期间维持了劳动力和生产能力。它们在经济不景气时承担了充分就业的成本，因为它们认为，投资于训练有素、忠诚的员工队伍，当形势好转时，就会获得回报。因此，当 16K RAM 市场在 20 世纪 70 年代中期起飞时，它们处于有利地位。硅谷无法满足需求，这给了日本一个向世界展示其能力的绝佳机会，日本公司抓住了这个机会。他们开始向世界各地发送高质量、价格具有竞争力的芯片。到 1980 年，日本占据了全球 42% 的内存芯片市场份额，而这一市场曾经由美国公司拥有。

Following standard Japanese industrial practice, the big Japanese electronics firms had maintained their work force and their production capacity during the recession. They absorbed the costs of full employment during slack times on the theory that the investment in keeping a trained, loyal work force on the job would pay off when things turned up. They were, accordingly, in the catbird seat when the market for 16K RAMs took off in the mid-1970s. Silicon Valley’s inability to meet demand gave Japan a golden opportunity to show the world what it could do, and Japanese firms leaped at the chance. They began dispatching high-quality, competitively priced chips around the world. By 1980 the Japanese had 42 percent of the world market in memory chips, a market that American firms had once owned.

更重要的是，当 20 世纪 70 年代末开发出下一代内存芯片 64K RAM 时，日本公司已经处于完美的竞争地位。这一次，日本公司无需担心技术落后，而且他们已经在各地建立了内存芯片市场。经过两年的激烈竞争，日本公司终于超越了美国公司。到 1983 年，他们控制了全球 64K RAM 市场的一半以上。

More important, Japanese firms had put themselves in perfect position to compete when the next generation of memory chips, the 64K RAM, was developed in the late 1970s. This time Japanese firms had no technological lag to worry about, and this time they had established markets everywhere for their memory chips. After two years of nip-and-tuck competition, Japanese firms finally eclipsed the Americans. By 1983 they controlled well over half the world market for 64K RAMs.

日本在这一产品线上的成功在美国引起了各种形式的心痛——远远超过了实际情况的需要。RAM 内存芯片是半导体市场的一个重要组成部分，但并不是特别重要或有利可图的。以美元计算，RAM 芯片可能占半导体年销售额的 5% 到 10%。美国人在几乎所有其他类型的集成电路上都占据主导地位。硅谷担心日本、韩国或台湾的内存芯片销售，就像通用汽车公司为一家在火花塞业务上表现良好的小公司而睡不着觉一样。

The Japanese success in this one product line prompted all manner of distressed breast-beating in the United States—far more than the situation actually warranted. The RAM memory chips constitute a high-volume part of the semiconductor market but not a particularly important or remunerative one. In dollar terms RAM chips probably represent somewhere between 5 and 10 percent of annual semiconductor sales. Americans have maintained supremacy in virtually every other type of integrated circuit. For Silicon Valley to worry about Japanese or Korean or Taiwanese sales of memory chips is like General Motors losing sleep over a smaller company that has done well in the spark plug business.

但许多美国人都很担心。国会委员会报告称，日本在芯片领域的进军“表明美国公司在半导体技术创新和传播方面可能不可逆转地失去世界领导地位。”硅谷公司非常警惕，成立了一个行业组织，即半导体行业协会，专门用于抵御外国挑战。“当日本占据 20% 的市场份额时，电视行业人士才醒悟过来，而当日本占据 40% 的市场份额时，他们又向政府求助，”该组织的执行董事告诉《纽约时报》。 “这有点晚了。”

But many Americans were worried. The Japanese inroads in chips, a congressional committee reported, “indicate the potential for an irreversible loss of world leadership by U.S. firms in the innovation and diffusion of semiconductor technology.” The Silicon Valley firms were sufficiently alarmed to form a trade group, the Semiconductor Industry Association, specifically to fight off the foreign challenge. “The television people woke up when the Japanese had 20 percent of the market, and went to the government when the Japanese had 40 percent,” the group’s executive director told The New York Times. “That’s a little late.”

半导体行业协会开始陆续发布研究报告、宣传册和广告，并向各政府委员会和机构提交请愿书，声称来自日本的竞争是不公平的。半导体行业协会指出，通产省决心将美国公司排除在日本市场之外。它抱怨日本政府对这项超大规模集成研发项目的资助——超过 1 亿美元。它指出，日本公司从日本银行获得的贷款利率远低于任何一家美国电子公司所能期望的利率，这部分是由于该国的工业结构，部分是由于通产省的支持。

The Semiconductor Industry Association began turning out a steady flow of studies and brochures and advertisements, along with petitions to various government commissions and agencies, asserting that the competition from Japan was unfair. The SIA cited MITI’s determination to keep U.S. companies out of the Japanese market. It complained about Japanese government contributions—something over $100 million—to the very-large-scale integration research and development venture. It pointed out that the Japanese firms, partly because of that nation’s industrial structure and partly because of support from MITI, received loans from Japanese banks at much lower interest rates than any electronics firms could hope for in the United States.

“我只是不想假装自己在公平竞争。事实并非如此，”Advanced Micro Devices 董事长杰里·桑德斯 (Jerry Sanders) 在一份明确 SIA 立场的声明中写道。“你知道日本人是如何获得动态 RAM 业务的吗？他们买下了它。（如果我有他们的交易，我也会买下它。）他们支付 6% 或 7% 的资本金。我支付 18% 的利润，运气好的时候……他们每年都会从政府那里获得数亿美元的免费研发资金，以此开始每个产品开发周期。这对他们来说是一件好事。但随后他们的零件如洪水般涌入这里。”

“I just don’t want to pretend I’m in a fair fight. I’m not,” wrote Jerry Sanders, chairman of Advanced Micro Devices, in a statement that crystallized the SIA position. “Do you know how the Japanese got the dynamic RAM business? They bought it. (If I had their deal, I’d have bought it too.) They pay 6 percent, maybe 7 percent, for capital. I pay 18 percent on a good day. . . . They start every product development cycle with hundreds of millions of dollars of free R&D every year, paid for by their government. Good for them. But then their parts arrive here in a flood.”

然而，还有另一种观点，德州仪器等公司持有这种观点，但该公司从未找到加入半导体行业协会的理由。持不同意见的人指出，尽管日本努力排除外国竞争对手，但美国公司在日本半导体市场的份额一直比日本在美国获得的份额大。他们认为，美国半导体行业是在政府融资的浪潮下发展起来的，每年仍从五角大楼获得数千万美元用于研发，几乎没有资格对通产省向日本公司提供的补助挑剔。半导体行业协会的美国批评者还回忆说，硅谷公司在 1976 年繁荣之前出售专利并削减产能，这在一定程度上促成了日本的成功。德州仪器总裁弗雷德·布西在半导体行业协会成立后表示：“西海岸的那些家伙有点精神分裂。他们和我们有同样的筹码……但他们处理专利问题的方式非常短视。”

There was, however, another point of view—a view held, among other places, at Texas Instruments, which never found reason to become a member of the Semiconductor Industry Association. The dissenters pointed out that despite Japan’s efforts to exclude foreign competitors, American firms had always had a larger share of the Japanese semiconductor market than the Japanese had gained in the United States. They argued that the American semiconductor industry, launched on a wave of government financing and still receiving tens of millions of dollars annually from the Pentagon for research and development, was hardly in a position to carp at MITI’s grants to Japanese firms. The SIA’s American critics also recalled that the Silicon Valley firms, by selling their patents and by cutting capacity just before the 1976 boom, were themselves partly responsible for the Japanese success. “Those fellows on the West Coast sort of have schizophrenia,” Fred Bucy, the president of Texas Instruments, said after the SIA was founded. “They had the same leverage as we did. . . . But they were very shortsighted in the way they handled the patent situation.”

日本在 RAM 内存芯片领域取得成功还有另外一个因素，但美国贸易团体并不愿意谈论这个因素。这个因素对美国人而言并不陌生，因为他们曾目睹过日本在电视、照相机和汽车领域取得的成功——质量因素。

There was one other factor, too, fueling the Japanese success in RAM memory chips, but it was something that American trade groups were not eager to talk about. It was a familiar factor to Americans who had observed the Japanese success in television, in cameras, in automobiles—the quality factor.

20 世纪 70 年代中期，当日本电子公司首次成功打入美国半导体市场时，购买进口内存电路安装到计算机中的美国公司开始注意到一个有趣的现象：日本芯片更胜一筹。性能上没有明显差异，因为所有内存芯片的工作原理都相同。但可靠性方面却存在明显差异。日本制造的芯片故障率低于美国产品。

In the middle 1970s, when the Japanese electronics firms first managed to break into the American semiconductor market, U.S. companies buying imported memory circuits for installation in their computers began to notice something interesting: Japanese chips were better. There was no discernible difference in performance, because all memory chips are built to work the same way. But there was a marked difference in reliability. Chips made in Japan were less likely to fail than the American product.

起初，日本在质量方面的优势是硅谷的肮脏小秘密。几乎没有人谈论它，当这个话题被提起时，美国制造商激烈地否认日本公司生产的芯片更可靠。1980 年 3 月的一个早晨，情况发生了改变，当时一位名叫理查德·W·安德森 (Richard W. Anderson) 的美国计算机高管在华盛顿特区举行的一次行业会议上站起来，发表了一篇后来被称为“安德森重磅炸弹”的论文。

At first, the Japanese edge in quality was the dirty little secret of Silicon Valley. Hardly anybody talked about it, and when the subject did come up, American manufacturers heatedly denied that Japanese firms were turning out more reliable chips. That changed one morning in March 1980 when an American computer executive named Richard W. Anderson stood up at an industry meeting in Washington, D.C., and delivered a paper that came to be known as “The Anderson Bombshell.”

安德森是惠普公司的一名部门经理。惠普公司是加利福尼亚州一家大型电子仪器和计算机制造商，也是世界上最大的集成电路消费者之一。正是他决定开始为惠普计算机购买日本内存芯片，尽管当时他有些不情愿，但在华盛顿的会议上，他讲述了自己的经历。

Anderson was a division manager at Hewlett-Packard, a giant California-based manufacturer of electronics instruments and computers that is one of the world’s biggest consumers of integrated circuits. It was he who had decided, rather reluctantly, to start buying Japanese memory chips for Hewlett-Packard computers, and at the Washington meeting he told his story.

1974 年，我们首次在计算机中引入半导体内存。所有内存均来自美国供应商。1977 年，16K（即 16 千位）RAM 开始面世。我所熟悉的第一批产品来自美国供应商，我们急忙将这种设计应用到我们的产品线中……

We first introduced semiconductor memory in our computers in 1974. We got all our memory from United States suppliers. Then in 1977 the 16K, or 16 thousand-bit, RAM began to make its appearance. The first introductions that I was familiar with came from U.S. suppliers, and we hurried to implement this design into our product line. . . .

然而，在推出几个月后，我们一直合作的美国供应商发现他们无法满足我们的数量需求，原因要么是产量问题，要么是产能问题，这让我们陷入了进退维谷的境地。因此，经过一番苦恼之后，我们决定与一家日本公司进行沟通，这家公司一段时间以来一直向我们打电话讲述他们的记忆。我想首先说明的是，我们采取了非常谨慎的态度，因为我们清楚地记得二战后日本产品的印象，即它们价格低廉、成本低、质量低劣。因此，我们的工程师通过了非常严格的资格认证计划，我们很高兴地发现他们通过了认证。

However, some months after introduction, the U.S. suppliers that we had been working with found themselves unable to meet our quantity demands, either due to yield or capacity problems, and this left us between the proverbial rock and a hard spot. So, after much anguish, we decided to talk to a Japanese company who had been calling on us telling us of their memory for some time. And I would like to state at the outset we took a very cautious approach because we remembered well the impressions from post–World War II Japanese products; namely, that they were cheap, low cost, and low quality. And so our engineers went through a very rigorous qualification program; and we were pleasantly surprised to find they qualified.

安德森接着说，随着时间的推移，他从这家日本公司购买的芯片越来越多。他说，尽管这一事实并不是立即显而易见的，但惠普逐渐开始意识到日本内存电路存在显著差异。“我们在进货检验中遇到的故障更少；我们在生产周期中遇到的故障更少；我们在客户手中看到的产品故障更少……不仅质量好，而且实际上比我们与国内供应商合作的经验要好。

Anderson went on to say that, over time, he bought more and more chips from the Japanese firm. Although the fact was not immediately obvious, he said, Hewlett-Packard gradually began to realize that there was a significant difference in the Japanese memory circuits. “We had fewer failures in incoming inspection; we had fewer failures during production cycle; we saw fewer failures of products in customers’ hands. . . . Not only was the quality good, but [it] was actually superior to what had been our experience with the domestic suppliers.

“然后到了 1979 年，”安德森继续说道，“一场真正的市场危机打击了内存供应商，特别是美国制造商……我们发现供应不足。所以我们回到日本，又为我负责的产品线找到了两家合格的日本供应商。再次获得同样的经验：质量卓越。”安德森补充说，最终，惠普编制了约 300,000 个内存芯片的性能记录，其中一半来自日本供应商，一半来自美国制造商。最终排名显示，这三家日本公司提供的产品质量都高于最好的美国制造商。“所以这是一组了不起的，我认为对美国供应商来说，也许是一组令人恐惧的统计数据，”安德森说。

“Then came 1979,” Anderson went on, “and a real market crunch hit the memory suppliers, particularly the U.S. manufacturers . . . and we found ourselves in short supply. So we went back to Japan and qualified two more Japanese suppliers for the product line that I’m responsible for. And again the same experience: excellent quality.” Eventually, Anderson added, Hewlett-Packard compiled performance records on some 300,000 memory chips, of which half came from the Japanese suppliers and half from American makers. The final standings showed that all three Japanese firms were delivering higher quality goods than the best American manufacturer. “So that’s a remarkable, and I would think to American suppliers, perhaps a frightening set of statistics,” Anderson said.

这当然是令人恐惧的。外国竞争对手在半导体领域的表现优于美国，而半导体是美国技术领先地位的象征，这一消息无疑是一记不容忽视的耳光。安德森爆炸性新闻得到了广泛报道，并得到了其他一些计算机公司的证实，这使得美国公司再也无法否认质量差异的存在。相反，他们开始学习日本是如何做到这一点的。1981 年《华尔街 日报》的头条新闻是：“美国微电子公司研究日本的质量和生产率秘诀” 。20 世纪 80 年代初出现的大量赞美日本管理实践的书籍成为半导体行业的必读书目。美国电子协会举办的关于日本质量控制的研讨会生意兴隆。各公司派出调查小组前往东京，揭开日本质量的秘密。

Frightening it certainly was. The message that foreign competitors were outperforming the United States in semiconductors, the symbol of American technical preeminence, was a slap in the face that could not be ignored. The Anderson Bombshell, widely reported and corroborated by some other computer firms, made it impossible for American firms to deny any longer that there was a quality difference. Instead, they set out to learn how the Japanese had attained it. “U.S. Microelectronics Firms Study Japan for Secrets of Quality and Productivity,” read a headline in The Wall Street Journal in 1981. The spate of books that appeared in the early 1980s extolling Japanese management practices became required reading in the semiconductor business. The American Electronics Association did a booming trade in seminars on Japanese quality control. Companies dispatched fact-finding teams to Tokyo to uncover the Japanese quality secret.

这种反应带有强烈的讽刺意味。日本人非常清楚，他们的质量机制几乎不是什么秘密，尤其是对美国人来说。毕竟，日本几乎所有关于质量控制的知识都是从美国人那里学来的。这位老师是一位联邦官僚，一个默默无闻的人，在他的祖国默默无闻，但在日本列岛却受到认可和尊重。他和杰克·基尔比和罗伯特·诺伊斯一样，都是草原之子。

There was a strong streak of irony in this reaction. As the Japanese knew perfectly well, their quality mechanisms were hardly secret, particularly to Americans. After all, Japan had learned virtually all it knew about quality control from an American. The teacher was a federal bureaucrat, an obscure fellow, unknown in his homeland but recognized and respected throughout the Japanese islands. He was, like Jack Kilby and Robert Noyce, a son of the prairie.

W. Edwards Deming 于 1900 年出生于爱荷华州苏城。在草原上长大的 Deming 和许多才华横溢的年轻人一样，在数学和音乐方面都表现出了天赋。最终，数学和科学的诱惑占了上风，在怀俄明大学读本科时，Deming 专注于数学、物理和工程学。他继续在科罗拉多矿业学院和耶鲁大学攻读研究生，并于 1928 年在耶鲁大学获得物理学博士学位。随后，Deming 博士开始了漫长的联邦服务生涯，先是美国农业部土壤局的科学家，后来，当统计学成为他的主要职业兴趣时，他进入了人口普查局。最终，他离开了联邦服务部门，开始了一项异常活跃的演讲和咨询业务，他在华盛顿家中杂乱的地下室里经营着这项业务。

W. Edwards Deming was born in Sioux City, Iowa, in 1900. Growing up on the prairie, young Deming, like many intellectually gifted youngsters, displayed talent both in mathematics and music. Eventually, the lure of math and science prevailed, and as an undergraduate at the University of Wyoming, Deming concentrated on math, physics, and engineering. He went on to graduate work at the Colorado School of Mines and at Yale, where he took a Ph.D. in physics in 1928. Dr. Deming then began a long career in federal service, first as a scientist in the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s Bureau of Soils and later, when statistics became his dominant professional interest, at the Census Bureau. Eventually he left the federal service and began an extraordinarily vigorous lecturing and consulting business that he ran from the cluttered basement of his Washington home.

我第一次见到戴明博士时，他已经过了 80 岁生日，每年出差约 300 天，足迹遍布欧洲、亚洲和美国的各个角落。他身材高大、脾气暴躁、气势不凡，留着蓬松的白色平头，戴着眼镜，鼻子突出，看起来像一只在龟壳外探来探去的乌龟。他告诉我，他已经开发出一种在一天工作日中挤出两天时间的方法：他会工作到下午 3 点左右，午睡到晚上 8 点半，然后再起床工作几个小时。他自然会抽出时间听音乐——和妻子洛拉·舒佩·戴明以及他们的孩子和孙辈一起弹钢琴。他创作了礼拜音乐；戴明的作品包括两部弥撒和一些颂歌。除此之外，他一心一意做生意。我问过他——当时他 83 岁——他是否休过假。 “嗯，接下来的几个小时我什么都不做。”他粗鲁地回答道。

When I first met Dr. Deming he was past his eightieth birthday and traveling on business about 300 days per year, to Europe, Asia, and various corners of the United States. He was a tall, crusty, imposing gentleman with a fluffy white crew cut, spectacles, and a jutting nose that gave him the look of a tortoise poking around outside the shell. He told me that he had developed a method of squeezing two workdays out of one: he would work until midafternoon, nap until eight-thirty at night, and then rise for several more hours of business. He found time, naturally, for music—sessions at the piano with his wife, Lola Shupe Deming, and their children and grandchildren. He composed liturgical music; the Deming oeuvre includes two masses and a number of canticles. Otherwise, he was all business. I asked him once—he was eighty-three at the time—if he ever took a vacation. “Well, I’m not doing anything for the next few hours,” came the gruff reply.

戴明向其咨询客户提供了一份长达九页的“主要论文清单”，反映了他多年来兴趣的转变。他的前十几篇出版物（许多都由 W. Edwards Deming 和 Lola Shupe 共同署名）涉及物理和化学：“等势面电子作为堆积效应的解释”；“关于低压气体热容量的注释”。但从 20 世纪 30 年代中期开始，这些标题开始显示出他对概率和统计学的兴趣：“关于逆概率的频率解释”；“关于在已知预期边际总数的情况下对抽样频率表的最小二乘调整”；“关于在 1940 年人口普查中消除未知年龄”。

A nine-page “list of principal papers” that Deming provided his consulting clients reflects the changing focus of his interests over the years. The first dozen or so of his publications—many signed jointly by W. Edwards Deming and Lola Shupe—deal with physics and chemistry: “Equipotential surface electrons as an explanation of the packing effect”; “Note on the heat capacity of gases at low pressure.” But midway through the 1930s the titles begin to reveal a developing interest in probability and statistics: “On the frequency interpretation of inverse probability”; “On a least squares adjustment of a sampled frequency table when the expected marginal totals are known”; “On the elimination of unknown ages in the 1940 population census.”

戴明学术成果的这种转变源于他越来越意识到统计学的巨大威力，它可以精确解释任何重复过程（包括商业商品的大规模生产）中发生的事情。戴明了解到，当工业操作出现问题时，统计学家可以充当熟练的侦探，搜索数据以查明问题并消除它。他将这个想法写在了一本开创性的专著中，该专著于 1934 年撰写，此后不断更新，名为“论统计误差理论”。戴明对沃尔特·休哈特博士思想的阐述，休哈特博士是美国数学家，他首先将统计方法应用于工厂运营的控制。戴明致力于成为休哈特福音的传播者，他认为仔细的统计记录是制造业质量始终如一的关键。

This shift in Deming’s scholarly output resulted from his growing appreciation for the enormous power of statistics to explain precisely what was going on in any repetitive process, including mass production of commercial goods. Deming learned that the statistician could act as a skilled detective when things went wrong in an industrial operation, searching his data to pinpoint the problem and eliminate it. He put this idea on paper in a seminal monograph, written in 1934 and updated thereafter, titled “On the Statistical Theory of Errors.” The “Theory of Errors” was Deming’s explication of the ideas of Dr. Walter Shewhart, the American mathematician who first applied statistical methods to the control of factory operations. Deming set out to be the evangelist of the Shewhart gospel, which held that careful statistical records were the essential key to consistent quality in manufacturing.

戴明在世界各地发表的演讲以及他的基本教材《质量、生产力和竞争地位》中，不断宣扬他在 1934 年提出的“错误理论”中提出的教训。他强调，质量和生产力源于对某些基本规则的认真遵守——他将这些规则汇总成一张“14 点”表格——所有这些规则都可以归纳为一条应该指导所有工作的黄金法则：“第一次就把事情做好。”

In the lectures he delivered around the world, and in his basic text, Quality, Productivity, and Competitive Position, Deming kept on preaching the lessons he had set forth back in 1934 in the “Theory of Errors.” He stressed that quality and productivity result from diligent observance of certain fundamental rules—he has gathered them into a table of “14 points”—all of which can be summarized in a single, golden rule that should govern all work: “Do it right the first time.”

总结起来，戴明的讯息显而易见，这是这位教授从不忘记强调的一点。“这很简单，”他在讲座中说道。“这很明显。”但要实现这个显而易见的讯息需要细致的努力。为了实现始终如一的质量，从制造半导体到管理棒球队，任何操作的参与者都必须保持“统计控制”——即仔细、定期地测量工作的各个方面。戴明说：“通过用统计方法准确描述所做的工作，这种方法可以找到问题所在，并引导创新来解决问题。”当制造问题发生时，质量控制官员应该像夏洛克·福尔摩斯在谋杀现场探查尸体一样探查统计数据。

Reduced to those six words, the Deming message seems obvious—a point the professor never failed to drive home. “It’s so simple,” he said in his lectures. “It’s so obvious.” But to carry out the obvious required detailed effort.
