To achieve consistent quality, those involved in any operation, from manufacturing semiconductors to managing a baseball team, must maintain “statistical control”—that is, careful, regular measurement of all aspects of the job. “By describing statistically exactly what is done,” Deming said, “the method locates your problems and leads to innovations that solve them.” When a manufacturing problem occurs, the quality control officer should probe the statistics like Sherlock Holmes probing the body at a murder scene.

例如，有一次，一家鞋业公司聘请了戴明，该公司遇到了成本高昂但又莫名其妙的生产延误。管理层感到困惑；同一家工厂的同一批工人突然生产率远远落后于正常水平。戴明仔细查看了工时卡、维护图表、采购记录等，发现有人最近订购了一种新品牌的缝纫线。现在一切都变得如此明显。新的、更便宜的缝纫线不断断线，迫使工人们一次又一次地停下缝纫机重新穿线。“为了节省每卷缝纫线 15 美分，他们每小时要花 150 美元重新穿线，”他解释说。购买了更好的缝纫线后，问题就解决了。

One time, for example, Deming was retained by a shoe company that had run into costly but inexplicable manufacturing delays. Management was baffled; the same work force in the same factory had suddenly fallen far behind its normal production rate. Poring over time cards, maintenance charts, purchasing records, and the like, Deming found that someone had recently ordered a new brand of thread. Now it was all so obvious. The new, cheaper thread kept breaking, forcing workers to stop and rethread their sewing machines time and again. “To save 15 cents per spool they were losing $150 per hour rethreading the stuff,” he explained. Better thread was purchased and the problem disappeared.

戴明尖锐地指出，统计控制是唯一合理的质量控制手段。“所有这些公司都在电视上做广告，宣传他们的检查员非常严格，”他嗤之以鼻。“检查太晚了，你看不出来吗？这太明显了。等到产品送到检查员手中时，质量，无论是好是坏，都已经出来了。你是想把面包烤焦了再刮掉，烤焦了再刮掉——还是想在送到检查员手中之前做好面包？”

Deming argued pointedly that statistical control is the only sensible means of quality control. “All these companies are running advertisements on the TV about their rigorous inspectors,” he snorted. “Inspection is too late, don’t you see? It’s so obvious. By the time the product gets to an inspector, the quality, either good or bad, is already in. Do you want to burn the toast and scrape it, burn the toast and scrape it—or do you want to make the toast right before it gets to your inspectors?”

根据戴明法则，烤面包的正确方法需要仔细观察整个过程的每个环节——市场上面包的质量、厨房的光线、烤面包机的线路和定时器、将面包放入槽中的方法以及取出烤好的面包的方法。如果在统计控制图上跟踪所有这些变量，经理就能知道任何一片面包被烤焦时发生了什么。问题可以很快得到纠正。与检查和刮擦每一片面包相比，控制过程更有效率，也更有利于提高工人的士气。

The right way to make toast, under the Deming rules, would involve careful observation of every element of the process—the quality of the bread in the market, the level of light in the kitchen, the wiring and the timer in the toaster, the methods of inserting the bread into the slot and of taking the finished toast out. If all these variables were tracked on statistical control charts, a manager could see just what had happened when any piece was burned. The problem could be corrected quickly. The control process would be more efficient and better for workers’ morale than inspecting and scraping every piece of toast.

此外，这也是戴明提高生产率的途径，统计控制更便宜。烤好一片面包的成本总是低于烤焦一片、检查、拒收，然后再烤好另一片的成本。“生产和处理有缺陷产品的总成本超过了生产好产品的成本，”教授在课文中说道。一旦烤面包的质量达到了可预测的水平，之前花在检查和刮掉烤焦面包上的时间和金钱就可以用于更有生产力的目标——烤更多的面包。

Moreover—and this is the Deming route to enhanced productivity—statistical control is cheaper. It will always cost less to make one piece of toast right than to burn one piece, inspect it, reject it, and then make another piece the right way. “The total cost to produce and dispose of a defective item exceeds the cost to produce a good one,” the professor’s text says. The time and money previously spent to inspect and scrape burnt toast can be directed to a more productive goal—making more toast—once a predictable level of toast-making quality is achieved.

20 世纪末，随着日本和其他外国竞争对手的挑战日趋严峻，美国工业界从惨痛经历中认识到，必须遵守戴明规则。然而，在 20 世纪 30 年代，情况却截然不同；当 WE 戴明讲话时，没有人听。第二次世界大战开始时，人们对统计质量控制的兴趣曾短暂高涨，当时产品质量成为国家生存的大事。军火工厂的工程师被请来向戴明教授学习，陆军部也在工厂里开设课程。戴明后来以他一贯尖刻的风格写道：“出色的应用烧毁、熄灭、失败，最后消亡。质量控制部门应运而生。他们绘制图表，查看图表，并归档。他们从其他人手中夺走了质量控制权，这当然是完全错误的，因为质量控制是每个人的工作。”

As the challenge from Japan and other foreign competitors became acute, late in the twentieth century, American industry learned the hard way that the Deming rules should be heeded. In the 1930s, though, things were sharply different; when W. E. Deming talked, nobody listened. There was a brief spurt of interest in statistical quality control at the start of World War II, when quality of production became a matter of national survival. Engineers from munitions plants were brought in to learn from Professor Deming, and the War Department gave courses in factories. “Brilliant applications burned, sputtered, fizzled, and died out,” Deming wrote later in his typically acerbic fashion. “Quality control departments sprouted. They plotted charts, looked at them, and filed them. They took quality control away from everybody else, which was of course entirely wrong, as quality control is everyone’s job.”

戴明不是轻易放弃的人，但战争经历让他专注于统计学的其他应用，包括人口统计学。在战争结束后的全球重建中，他成为了人口统计学的流动大使。他是 1946 年希腊选举的官方观察员，之后又前往德里为印度人口普查提供建议。最终，在战后美国占领日本期间，他被道格拉斯·麦克阿瑟将军召往日本，协助开展各种人口和住房研究。在那里，戴明终于找到了一群关心质量控制的听众。

Deming was not a man to give up easily, but the wartime experience led him to focus on other applications of statistics, including demographics. In the global reconstruction at the end of the war, he became a sort of roving ambassador of demographics. He was an official observer at the Greek elections in 1946, and from there went to Delhi to advise on the Indian census. Eventually he was summoned to Japan by General Douglas MacArthur during the postwar American occupation to assist in various population and housing studies. And there, at long last, Deming found an audience that cared about quality control.

熟悉“错误理论”的日本统计学家 E.E.西堀博士偶然发现，这篇富有洞察力的论文的作者就在日本。西堀博士找到了戴明，问他这个美国人是否有兴趣在日本科学与工程联合会的质量控制研讨会上发言？戴明表示有兴趣。他确实这么做了。研讨会一个接一个。有人安排戴明在东京的日本工业俱乐部发表演讲，这是一个商业圆桌会议，其成员包括日本所有主要制造业企业的高级管理人员。1950 年 7 月 26 日，戴明在演讲中宣布，日本的质量很快就会成为世界上最好的，令日本听众感到惊讶。

A Japanese statistician, Dr. E. E. Nishibori, who was familiar with the “Theory of Errors,” discovered more or less by accident that the author of that insightful paper was in Japan. Nishibori tracked Deming down: would the American be interested in speaking at a quality control workshop for the Union of Japanese Science and Engineering? He would. He did. Another workshop followed, and another. Someone else arranged for Deming to speak in Tokyo at the Industry Club of Japan, a business round-table whose membership included senior management of every major Japanese manufacturing concern. In that speech, on July 26, 1950, Deming declared, to the astonishment of his Japanese audience, that Japanese quality would soon be the best in the world.

三十年后，戴明兴致勃勃地回忆道：“我曾预言，日本制造商将主宰世界市场，而他们的竞争对手将哭着寻求保护。当时，我是世界上唯一相信这一点的人……但这很简单。你可以看到，这个社会很容易接受对质量和生产力必不可少的理念。”

“I predicted,” Deming recalled with great relish three decades later, “that Japanese manufacturers would come to dominate world markets and have their competitors crying for protection. At that time I was the only person in the world who believed that. . . . But it was so simple. You could see that this society was receptive to the ideas that are necessary for quality and productivity.”

这次演讲起到了决定性的作用。戴明总是说：“一旦你说服高层管理人员相信这会带来改变，最困难的工作就完成了。”日本就是他最好的例证。日本人对他们所听到的内容深信不疑，以至于在占领结束后，他们年复一年地邀请戴明回到东京传播他的福音。日本科学与工程联盟分发了数百万本他的书籍和小册子。数以万计的日本工厂工人、工程师和高管在常规课堂上学习他的教诲（他们至今仍在这样做）。这些勤奋的学生将他的思想付诸实践，其影响震惊了世界。

That speech turned out to be decisive. “Once you convince senior management that this will make a difference, the hardest job is done,” Deming always said, and Japan was Exhibit A for him. The Japanese were so convinced by what they heard that they invited Deming back to Tokyo year after year long after the occupation had ended to spread his gospel. The Union of Japanese Science and Engineering distributed millions of copies of his books and pamphlets. Tens of thousands of Japanese factory workers, engineers, and executives studied his teachings at regular classes (they still do so today). These diligent students put his ideas into practice, with consequences that shook the world.

当戴明来到战后残破不堪的东京时，日本商品在任何地方都被认为是用廉价劣质材料制成的廉价劣质产品。到了 20 世纪 70 年代，曾经引以为豪的美国汽车业购买了电视广告，吹嘘其产品是按照日本方式制造的。“日本制造”标签代表了从钢铁、汽车、重型机械到照相机、科学仪器和消费电子产品等产品的世界质量标准。

When Deming arrived in the shattered remnants of postwar Tokyo, Japanese goods were everywhere considered cheap, shoddy products made from cheap, shoddy materials. By the 1970s, the once-proud American automobile industry bought television advertising to boast that its products were made the Japanese way. The label “Made in Japan” came to represent the world standard of quality for products ranging from steel, automobiles, and heavy machinery to cameras, scientific instruments, and consumer electronic gear.

日本战后的经济奇迹没有单一的解释，但日本人至少将很大一部分功劳归功于他们的美国老师。戴明是少数获得日本最高皇室荣誉的二等圣宝章的外国人之一。他的名字和简介出现在戴明奖上，这是一项年度工业奖，其地位堪比美国普利策奖，该奖项以奥斯卡奖的形式颁发，每年向全国直播。戴明这个名字几乎已成为家喻户晓的词。

There is no single explanation for Japan’s postwar economic miracle, but the Japanese, at least, have given a good deal of the credit to their American teacher. Deming was one of the few foreigners ever to receive the Second Order of the Sacred Treasure, Japan’s premier imperial honor. His name and profile adorn the Demingu Shō (the Deming Prize), an annual industrial award carrying the stature of the American Pulitzer Prizes, which is awarded, Oscar style, in an annual presentation telecast live to the entire nation. The name “Demingu” has become virtually a household word.

五十年后，“戴明”这个名字在其他国家也开始有了意义——甚至在美国也是如此。日本和其他竞争对手使得美国管理层迟迟不注意这位土生土长的卡桑德拉；如果不是这样，戴明就不必把两个工作日挤成一个工作日。在他七十五岁到八十岁生日之间，戴明成为了所谓的第三次工业化浪潮的领袖，继工业革命开始时的第一次浪潮和席卷而来的大规模生产技术的第二波浪潮之后。第三次浪潮适合于一个标准更高、对极限认识更清晰的世界，它关注尽可能高效地利用资源来生产具有可预测可靠性和质量的产品。

And then, fifty years late, the name “Deming” came to have meaning in other countries as well—even in the United States. The Japanese and other competitors led American management to pay tardy heed to the native-born Cassandra; if it were not so, Deming would not have had to squeeze two workdays into one. Sometime between his seventy-fifth and eightieth birthdays, Deming emerged as the guru of what was called the Third Wave of industrialization, following the First Wave at the start of the Industrial Revolution and the Second Wave, which swept in with techniques of mass production. The Third Wave, suited to a world with higher standards and a clearer recognition of limits, focuses on the most efficient possible uses of resources to produce goods of predictable reliability and quality.

戴明博士喜欢提醒人们，他早在同胞们意识到之前就预见到了新浪潮的到来。“在国际经济中竞争的方法是提高效率，生产出比其他人更好的产品，”他说。“这很简单。很明显。”

Dr. Deming loved to remind people that he saw the new wave coming long before his countrymen caught on. “The way to compete in an international economy is to promote efficiency, to produce better quality than the other people are producing,” he would say. “It’s so simple. It’s so obvious.”

直到日本在内存芯片领域取得的惊人成功让美国半导体行业意识到了这一点，美国才真正意识到了这一点。美国人对此深有体会。半导体公司将质量控制（不仅仅是检查，而是真正的控制）作为一项高度优先的挑战。这产生了影响。惠普高管理查德·安德森在发布这一重磅消息两年后的一次采访中表示，他的公司发现来自美国供应商的内存芯片质量有了显著改善；事实上，他说，美国的质量标准已经赶上日本了。这一变化帮助美国公司从日本手中夺回了 64K 随机存取内存芯片全球市场的一小部分份额。

The point was somewhat less than obvious to the American semiconductor industry until the startling Japanese success in memory chips brought the message home quite clearly. The Americans took it to heart. The semiconductor firms made quality control—not just inspection but genuine control—a high-priority challenge. It made a difference. In an interview two years after he released his bombshell, Richard Anderson, the Hewlett-Packard executive, said his firm had found marked improvement in the quality of memory chips coming from American suppliers; in fact, he said, the Americans had matched the Japanese on quality standards. This change helped U.S. firms take back a small share of the world market for 64K random-access memory chips from the Japanese.

美国国会 1982 年发布的一项研究报告指出：“在与日本展开质量竞争之前，美国制造商一直心照不宣地认为，快速、大批量生产以及通过零部件测试来弥补制造过程中的缺陷比高质量更重要。”“日本人则专注于完善生产流程，以提供更高质量的设备。随着美国公司重组和扩大产能，他们显然一直在‘调整’生产流程，以提供更高质量的设备。因此，日本人以质量作为渗透策略的能力很可能不会延续到下一轮竞争中。”

“U.S. manufacturers, until the advent of Japanese competition over quality, had made a tacit decision that fast, volume output with component testing to cover imperfections in the manufacturing process was more important than high quality,” reported a study published by Congress in 1982. “The Japanese instead concentrated on perfecting their production process to deliver higher quality devices. As U.S. firms retool and expand capacity, they have apparently been ‘tweaking’ their production process to deliver higher quality devices. It may well be, then, that the Japanese ability to use quality as a penetration strategy will not carry over to the next round of competition.”

但美国人并没有“调整”质量标准，以抵御日本的挑战。到 20 世纪 80 年代中期，硅谷的夕阳似乎已开始消逝。日本的半导体巨头已成为世界半导体市场的主导力量。尽管集成电路的两位发明者在美国市场中令人鼓舞，但美国在整体市场份额上落后得越来越远。日本在内存芯片领域领先最大，而内存芯片正是日本的优势，可以生产出可靠、高质量的经过测试的产品。但日立、富士通和日本电气等公司也开始在某些逻辑芯片和模拟芯片领域占据市场领先地位，而这些产品领域一直由美国主导。有一段时间，日本电气 (NEC) 甚至与英特尔在个人电脑微处理器业务上展开竞争，直到专利侵权诉讼的威胁导致日本退出该市场。

But the Americans did not “tweak” their quality standards enough to head off the Japanese challenge. By the mid-1980s, the sun seemed to be setting on Silicon Valley. Japan’s semiconductor giants had become the dominant force in the world semiconductor market. Despite the inspiring presence of the two inventors of the integrated circuit in its midst, the United States fell further and further behind in overall market share. The Japanese lead was greatest in the field of memory chips, a product that played precisely to Japanese strengths for dependable, high-quality production of a tested product. But firms like Hitachi, Fujitsu, and Nippon Denki also began to take the market lead in certain logic chips and analog chips—product areas where the United States had always been dominant. For a while, Nippon Denki (NEC) even competed with Intel in the microprocessor business for personal computers, until the threat of a patent infringement lawsuit led the Japanese to drop out of that market.

每年 1 月，硅谷研究公司 DataQuest 和 VLSI Research 都会发布年度市场份额调查报告，这对美国芯片制造商来说是一件令人沮丧的事情。年复一年，日本在全球半导体市场以及大多数细分市场的份额中都遥遥领先。除此之外，日本机床制造商在半导体制造机市场上也领先于美国。制造机械领域的领先地位在某种程度上更加令人不安。如果日本机床制造商在推出每种新型号时都让日本客户优先购买，那么日本芯片公司将比美国竞争对手拥有另一个优势。

The annual market share surveys put out by Silicon Valley research firms like DataQuest and VLSI Research, announced in January each year, became a somber event for American chip makers. Year after year, Japan had a clear lead in global market share for semiconductors overall, and in most distinct market segments. Beyond that, Japanese machine-tool makers pulled ahead of the Americans in the market for semiconductor fabricating machines. The lead in fabricating machinery was, in a way, even more disturbing. If Japanese machine-tool makers gave their Japanese customers first call on each new model, then the Japanese chip companies would have another advantage over their U.S. competition.

半导体行业协会曾经是全球领导者的骄傲代言人，但现在却开始变得像以前屈服于日本竞争的钢铁制造商、汽车制造商和电视制造商一样。半导体行业协会开始向政府求助，以阻止亚洲侵略者。

The Semiconductor Industry Association, once the proud voice of a global leader, now began to sound very much like the steelmakers and carmakers and television makers that had earlier succumbed to Japanese competition. The SIA began badgering the government for help to stave off the Asian invaders.

为了发出日本人即将到来这一警告，硅谷人选出了他们自己的一位资深业内人士，他似乎非常适合这个角色。这位指定的发言人口齿伶俐、聪明睿智，给人留下了深刻的印象。他抱怨日本人在作弊，利用他们在封闭的国内市场的垄断地位为国外市场的掠夺性定价提供资金。这位发言人告诉国会委员会：“日本的许多做法都是我们认为不公平、非法或其他什么的。……我们或许可以希望日本人遵守我们的游戏规则，但我看不出他们有任何这样做的动机，因为他们认为使用目前的策略他们会赢。事实上，他们可能会赢。”

To deliver its warning that the Japanese were coming, the men of Silicon Valley selected one of their own—a senior statesman of the industry who seemed perfectly suited to the role. The designated spokesman was articulate, intelligent, and immediately impressive. He complained that the Japanese were cheating, using their monopoly in the closed domestic market to fund predatory pricing in foreign markets. “Many of the Japanese practices are practices that we would see as unfair, illegal, or whatever,” the spokesman told a congressional committee. “. . . It may be that we can hope the Japanese will play by the rules of our game, but I don’t see any motivation for them to do so whatsoever, since they perceive that they are winning using the current strategy. And, indeed, they may win.”

这位悲痛欲绝的发言人在全国各地的听证会、研讨会、大会和新闻发布会上，每周都向政府提出同样的请求。他似乎一生都在做这项工作，但事实并非如此。这位发言人曾是物理学家，后来成为发明家，然后成为公司经理和风险投资家——他把所有这些工作都做得同样出色。这位发言人就是罗伯特·诺伊斯。

The spokesman who offered this mournful plaint presented the same plea for government help week after week at hearings, seminars, conventions, and press conferences all over the country. He performed the job as if he had been doing it all his life, but he had not. The spokesman had been a physicist, then an inventor, then a corporate manager and a venture capitalist—and had performed all those jobs with equal facility. The spokesman was Robert N. Noyce.

在本书的第一版中，这一章在美国半导体行业的不幸时刻结束了。鲍勃·诺伊斯成为该行业的代言人正值半导体公司陷入绝望之际。到 1985 年左右，人们有一种感觉，美国已经输掉了这场比赛，英特尔、摩托罗拉和 IBM 等美国工业冠军注定会被日本微芯片巨头甩在后面。

In the first edition of this book, this chapter came to an end at that unhappy juncture for the American semiconductor industry. Bob Noyce’s emergence as spokesman for the industry came at a time of desperation among semiconductor firms. There was a feeling, by 1985 or so, that the United States had already lost the race, that American industrial champions like Intel, Motorola, and IBM were bound to be left behind by the Japanese microchip juggernaut.

在某种程度上，美国半导体行业在危机时刻必然会转向其创始人诺伊斯。作为微芯片的共同发明者，他拥有无人能否认的技术资质。但他作为管理者、企业家、演讲者和倡导者也拥有出色的记录。诺伊斯所触及的几乎所有事情都变成了金子；现在他被要求恢复美国竞争力的黯淡光彩。

It was inevitable, in a way, that the U.S. semiconductor community would turn back to its founding father, Noyce, in time of crisis. As the co-inventor of the microchip, he had technical credentials that nobody could gainsay. But he also had a stellar record as a manager, entrepreneur, speaker, and advocate. Almost everything Noyce ever touched had turned to gold; now he was being asked to restore the tarnished luster of American competitiveness.

起初，该行业的推动者与钢铁、汽车、轮胎、玻璃、音像等老行业一样，都曾与强大的日本竞争对手发生过冲突。半导体行业协会是诺伊斯在创立过程中发挥了重要作用的一个行业组织，它聘请了一些曾在其他受到威胁的行业工作过的经济学家和说客。在这些专家的敦促下，芯片制造商纷纷向华盛顿寻求帮助。作为半导体行业协会的负责人，诺伊斯出席了国会，并忠实地宣读了标​​准稿，将问题归咎于邪恶的亚洲人——“不公平、非法或其他什么”。该行业敦促联邦政府提供帮助，里根政府做出了回应。1986 年，日本政府签署了一项“自愿贸易协定”，但实际上它既不是自愿的，也不是协议。这是华盛顿单方面强加的，威胁要关闭美国市场，禁止日本进口半导体以外的许多领域。日本公司承诺限制其内存芯片和多种逻辑芯片的出口。这是纯粹的配额制度。但它为美国工业提供了喘息的空间和重建的机会。

At first, the movers and shakers of the industry headed off in the same direction as older industries—steel, autos, tires, glass, audio-video, etc.—that had run up against formidable Japanese competitors. The Semiconductor Industry Association, a trade group that Noyce had been instrumental in starting, hired some of the same economists and lobbyists who had worked for other threatened industries. At the urging of these experts, the chip makers ran to Washington for help. As head of the SIA, Noyce appeared before Congress and dutifully read from the standard script, which blamed the problem on the nefarious Asians—“unfair, illegal, or whatever.” The industry pressed the federal government to help, and the Reagan administration responded. In 1986 the Japanese government signed a “voluntary trade agreement,” which was actually not voluntary and not an agreement. It was imposed unilaterally by Washington on threat of closing U.S. markets to Japanese imports in many areas beyond semiconductors. Japanese companies committed to limit their exports of memory chips and many kinds of logic chips. It was a quota system, pure and simple. But it gave the U.S. industry some breathing space and a chance to rebuild.

然而，鲍勃·诺伊斯从未真正接受过这种针对行业问题的保护主义反应，也从未接受过自己在导致这种反应中所扮演的角色。自从在 Philco 担任初级工程师以来，诺伊斯就对与政府勾结的企业怀有本能的厌恶。事实上，他认为与政府的私下交易是导致该行业萎靡不振的原因之一：“价格在美国太空计划中并不是一个主要问题，这可能培养了一代设计工程师将成本排除在外，”他写道，对于一位美国半导体高管在 1988 年做出这样的承认，这是一个相当大胆的承认。

Bob Noyce, however, was never really comfortable with this protectionist response to the industry’s problems, or with his role in bringing it about. Ever since his days as a junior engineer at Philco, Noyce had nourished a visceral dislike for businesses that got into bed with government. In fact, he believed that sweetheart deals with government were one of the causes of the industry’s malaise: “Price wasn’t much of an object in the American space program, and that may have trained a generation of design engineers to leave cost out of the equation,” he wrote, a rather daring admission for an American semiconductor executive to make in 1988.

然而，诺伊斯面临的更大问题是一种挥之不去的感觉，即他的行业正在陷入泥潭。诺伊斯在整个职业生涯中都坚持认为解决问题的最糟糕的方式是“用别人的方法解决问题”。现在，半导体行业正走上与所有其他行业相同的道路，这些行业都曾遭遇过日本的激烈竞争。诺伊斯太诚实了，他不会说向华盛顿寻求贸易保护就能解决困扰硅谷的基本问题。“这些问题主要是我们自己造成的，所以我们必须自己解决问题，”他说。“我们需要回到设计的前沿，我们需要在制造方面做得更好。”

The bigger problem for Noyce, though, was a nagging sense that his industry was falling into a rut. All his professional life, Noyce had insisted that the worst way to reach a solution was “to approach the problem the way everybody else has.” And now the semiconductor industry was going down the same road as every other industry that had run up against stiff Japanese competition. Noyce was simply too honest to argue that running to Washington for trade protection could solve the basic problems troubling Silicon Valley. “The problems are primarily of our own making, so we have to make our own solution,” he said. “We need to get back to the leading edge of design, and we need to get better at manufacturing.”

于是，鲍勃·诺伊斯成为了一个全行业联盟 Sematech（该名称源于半导体技术）的首席架构师和首任首席执行官。为了吸引德州仪器（达拉斯）、摩托罗拉（菲尼克斯）和 IBM（阿蒙克）等加州以外的公司加入，Sematech 的创始人同意新组织不会设在硅谷。因此，1987 年，诺伊斯离开了他心爱的硅谷，搬到了德克萨斯州奥斯汀的植被较少的地区，试图挽救他的行业。他有些不情愿地同意 Sematech 将接受政府的财政援助——每年约 1 亿美元——但他坚持要求企业成员必须贡献更大的数额，以便 Sematech 成为一家主要的私营企业。

Thus it was that Bob Noyce became the chief architect, and the first CEO, of an industry-wide consortium called Sematech (a name carved out of semiconductor technology). To induce the non-California companies like Texas Instruments (Dallas), Motorola (Phoenix), and IBM (Armonk) to sign on, the founders of Sematech agreed that the new organization would not be located in Silicon Valley. And so in 1987, Noyce left his beloved valley and moved to the less verdant precincts of Austin, Texas, to try to save his industry. Somewhat reluctantly, he agreed that Sematech would take government financial help—about $100 million per year—but he insisted that the corporate members must contribute an even larger figure so that Sematech would be a primarily private undertaking.

从一开始，诺伊斯就意识到 Sematech 不必太担心美国人在半导体物理、电路设计或创新方面的技能。美国在这些领域已经处于世界领先地位。相反，该联盟专注于更平凡的生产问题。诺伊斯说，目标是确保美国芯片制造商能够在制造速度和质量上赶上甚至超过日本。联盟的做法是，让来自全国各地的公司和大学共同合作，以帮助处于技术前沿的相对较小的美国公司（如 Cyrix、Xilinx、Micron 和 Zilog 等公司）在微芯片制造领域与 NEC、日立和东芝等巨头竞争。诺伊斯认为，实现这一目标的方法是让“制造业”成为一个充满活力且确实光彩夺目的领域，供聪明的美国人追求。诺伊斯告诉《财富》杂志，美国最需要的是“母亲们自豪地说，‘我的儿子，制造工程师。’”

From the first, Noyce realized that Sematech need not worry much about American skills in semiconductor physics, circuit design, or innovation. The United States already led the world in those fields. Rather, the consortium focused on the more mundane problem of production. The goal, Noyce said, was to see to it that American chip makers could match or exceed the Japanese in speed and quality of manufacturing. The consortium approach, with companies and universities from all over the country working together, was designed to help the relatively small U.S. firms at the forefront of technology—outfits with names like Cyrix, Xilinx, Micron, and Zilog—compete with behemoths like NEC, Hitachi, and Toshiba in microchip manufacture. And the way to do it, Noyce argued, was to make “manufacturing” a dynamic and indeed glamorous field for bright Americans to pursue. The main thing America needed, Noyce told Fortune magazine, was “mothers who say proudly, ‘My son, the manufacturing engineer.’”

当诺伊斯埋头于这项意义重大但并不十分吸引人的任务时，许多美国专家对半导体制造技术联盟的概念嗤之以鼻。他们认为，真正的问题不只是一两个陷入困境的行业，而是一个更广泛的问题，即美国相对于东亚新兴工业强国的“衰落”。从这个角度来看，日本及其工业化的“侄子”如台湾、韩国和中国，代表着“新经济”的朝阳，而老式的美国资本主义则在黑暗的地平线下垂头丧气。一位杰出的亚洲学者詹姆斯·法洛斯在他的论文《仰望太阳》中提出了这一理论。法洛斯以一章冗长而令人不安的篇章作为开篇，讲述了日本人如何从落后中赶超美国工业，在关键的半导体领域取得胜利。法洛斯写道，这是一个“日本胜利而美国失败”的故事。

While Noyce hunkered down to this significant but not very sexy task, many U.S. experts sneered at the Sematech concept. The real issue, they argued, was not just one or two troubled industries, but rather a broader problem of American “decline” visà-vis the emerging industrial powerhouses of East Asia. In this view, Japan, and its industrial nephews like Taiwan, South Korea, and China, represented the rising sun of a “new economics” while old-fashioned U.S. capitalism was drooping beneath a dark horizon. A distinguished student of Asia, James Fallows, set forth the theory in his treatise Looking at the Sun. Fallows opened the book with a long, disturbing chapter relating how the Japanese had come from far behind to trump American industry in the crucial field of semiconductors. It was a tale, Fallows wrote, of “Japanese triumph and American failure.”

但是法洛斯和他那些记录美国衰落的同行们没有考虑到鲍勃·诺伊斯的惊人才华和精力。诺伊斯周游全国，训斥同事，不断督促研究人员、工程师和公司董事长更加努力、更加高效地工作，他花了四年时间推动美国工业收复失地。他成功了。1993 年初（就在《看着太阳》在书店上架时），全球半导体市场份额的年度数据公布了。十几年来，日本首次位居第二；美国工业赶上并超过了它的宿敌。领先优势并不大——1992 年美国公司占据了全球 44% 的市场份额，而日本占 43%，欧洲制造商占 8%，其他亚洲国家占 5%——但这标志着一个惊人的逆转。“从彻底的灾难变成了美国的胜利，”VLSI 研究公司总裁 G. Dan Hutcheson 说。 “这表明，只要有创造力、努力工作以及政府的帮助，你就可以扭转一个行业的局面。”

But Fallows and his fellow chroniclers of American decline had not counted on the formidable talents and energy of Bob Noyce. Traveling the country, hectoring his colleagues, constantly pushing researchers, engineers, and corporate chairmen to work harder and faster, Noyce spent four hard years driving the American industry to make up for lost ground. And he succeeded. Early in 1993 (just as Looking at the Sun was hitting the bookstores), the annual figures for global market share in semiconductors were released. For the first time in a dozen years, Japan was number two; the American industry had caught up with and passed its nemesis. The lead wasn’t huge—U.S. companies had 44 percent of the global market in 1992, to 43 percent for the Japanese, 8 percent for European makers, and 5 percent for other Asian countries—but it marked a stunning reversal. “It’s gone from total disaster to an American triumph,” said G. Dan Hutcheson, president of VLSI Research. “This shows that you can turn an industry around with creativity, hard work, and help from the government.”

在接下来的几年里，美国巩固了其领导地位。到 21 世纪初，美国占据了全球 45% 的市场份额，而日本的市场份额则下降到 40% 左右，一些存储芯片市场份额被其较小的亚洲邻国夺走。20 世纪 90 年代末，为了特别赞扬 Sematech 的成就，美国半导体制造设备制造商再次在全球市场份额中占据领先地位。

In the following years, Americans cemented their leadership position. By the turn of the twenty-first century, the United States claimed a comfortable 45 percent of global markets, while Japan dropped to about 40 percent, losing some market share in memory chips to its smaller Asian neighbors. In the late 1990s, in a particular tribute to Sematech’s achievement, U.S. makers of semiconductor manufacturing equipment once again took the lead in global market share.

尽管美国工业已步入世界领先地位，但这一成就却蒙上了一层阴影。鲍勃·诺伊斯（Bob Noyce）——对美国复兴贡献最大的人——却未能亲眼见证这一成就。

While the American industry marched forward into the broad, sunlit uplands of world leadership, though, there was one shadow over the achievement. Bob Noyce, the man who was probably more responsible for the U.S. renaissance than anyone else, was not there to see it.

11

11

族长

THE PATRIARCHS

罗伯特·诺伊斯从公司经理到行业发言人的转变是逐渐发生的，也是不可避免的，就像他早先从发明家到经理的转变一样。这种转变并不是他计划好的；“我只是随波逐流，”他说。但是，如果诺伊斯的生活按照他最初计划的那样发展，他的大部分时间都会在某个物理实验室里度过，愉快地沉迷于对事物运作方式的好奇心，并撰写专著来解释固态物理的有趣现象。

Robert Noyce’s metamorphosis from corporate manager to industry spokesman had come about as gradually, and as inevitably, as his earlier transition from inventor to manager. The change was not something he had planned; “I just sort of drifted into it,” he said. But then, if Noyce’s life had turned out the way he originally planned, he would have spent most of it in a physics lab somewhere, happily indulging his curiosity about the way things work and turning out monographs explicating interesting phenomena of solid-state physics.

事实上，诺伊斯的职业生涯早在 1959 年 1 月就已开始走出实验室，当时他突然想到了单片机的理念。这是他最重要的工程突破，从实际意义上讲，也是他最后的突破。诺伊斯身上有一种特质——一种基本的自信和一种令人信服的存在感——促使人们向他寻求领导。1956 年，在肖克利半导体公司工作的物理学家、化学家和工程师必须——这是威廉·肖克利独特的管理风格的一部分——互相提供成绩单。在成绩统计出来后，诺伊斯成为该团队技术总监的一致人选。因此，当“八叛徒”于 1957 年离开肖克利去创立仙童半导体公司时，该团队在意识到需要有人担任经理时就转向了诺伊斯。他的同事戈登·摩尔回忆说：“鲍勃是每个人的选择。他是天生的领导者。”

In fact, Noyce’s career had already begun to move out of the lab by January 1959, when he hit upon the monolithic idea. That was his most important engineering breakthough, and it was also, for all practical purposes, his last. There was something about Noyce—a fundamental confidence matched with a compelling sense of presence—that prompted people to look to him for leadership. The physicists, chemists, and engineers working at Shockley Semiconductor in 1956 were required—it was part of William Shockley’s unique management style—to give one another report cards. When the grades were tabulated, Noyce emerged as the consensus choice to be the group’s technical director. Accordingly, when the “traitorous eight” left Shockley in 1957 to found Fairchild Semiconductor, the group turned to Noyce as soon as it became clear that somebody was going to have to act as a manager. His colleague Gordon Moore recalled that “Bob was everybody’s choice. He was the natural leader.”

无论如何，这是一个令人满意的发展，尤其是因为它为人类提供了一个全新的学习世界。“进入管理层是一件非常令人兴奋的事情，”诺伊斯几年后回忆道。“因为，首先，我对此一无所知，所以你的学习速度非常非常快。但其次，管理层确实成为组织中所有信息的焦点。好吧，拥有信息的人就拥有权力……这是一件非常令人满意的事情，特别是你来自一个只见树木不见森林的狭窄领域。突然间，你坐在气球上，从一个分支往下看……你第一次看到了整体。”

In any case, it was a satisfying development, not least because it provided a whole new world of human endeavor to learn about. “Getting into management was just enormously exciting,” Noyce recalled a few years later. “Because, first of all, I didn’t know a damn thing about it, so that your learning rate goes up very, very rapidly. But secondly, management does become the focal point for all the information in the organization. Well, the guy who has the information has the power. . . . It’s a very satisfying thing, particularly coming from a place where you’re looking at a narrow field so you don’t see the forest for the trees. And suddenly you’re sitting in a balloon looking down from branch to branch and . . . for the first time you can see the whole.”

更重要的是，让一名技术专家来管理一家高科技公司感觉很正确——这完全符合诺伊斯不断发展的企业领导理论。“美国企业真正的问题之一，”他辩称，“是这种观念，即你可以接受管理培训，接受某种通用的管理形式，然后你就可以管理任何业务。但这在技术情况下绝对行不通。经理必须对在特定情况下应该做什么有直觉，如果你没有技术背景，如果你没有亲自参与，你就没有这种直觉。”

More important, it just felt right—it fitted precisely with Noyce’s evolving theory of corporate leadership—to have a technologist running a high-tech company. “One of the real problems with American business,” he argued, “is this notion that you can be trained in management, in some kind of generic form of management, and then you can manage any operation. But that absolutely does not work in a technical situation. The manager has to have an intuitive gut feel for what ought to be done in a particular situation, and if you don’t have the technical background, if you haven’t participated personally, you don’t have that.”

在很大程度上，美国半导体行业是由技术人员建立和运营的，对诺伊斯来说，这是该行业取得爆炸性成功的关键原因。“他们说我们很幸运，”他解释道。“好吧，你可以说你在世界大赛最后一场比赛第九局两人出局时很幸运地上场击球，碰巧击出了本垒打。但真正的重点是你必须当时上场击球。基本上，你必须参与其中，并有直觉知道可以做什么。”

For the most part, the American semiconductor industry has been built and run by technologists, and to Noyce this was a key reason for its explosive success. “They say we were lucky,” he explained. “Well, you can say you were lucky being up at bat in the World Series with two out in the ninth inning in the final game of the series and you happen to hit the home run. But the real point is that you have to be at bat at that time. Basically, you have to be in there participating and have the gut feel for what can be done.”

诺伊斯在仙童半导体公司的第一个管理职位是研发总监，这个职位比听起来要重要得多，因为在第一年左右，公司只做研发工作。随着研究发展成为重要产品——平面工艺和集成电路——新兴的半导体部门成为整个仙童照相机和仪器公司的主要利润中心之一。

Noyce’s first management position at Fairchild Semiconductor was director of research and development, a position considerably more important than it might sound because, for the first year or so, the firm was doing nothing but research and development. As the research developed into important products—the planar process and the integrated circuit—the upstart semiconductor division became one of the leading profit centers in the whole of Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation.

仙童公司东部的董事们以传统方式奖励诺伊斯：他先是被任命为部门总经理，然后是副总裁，职位基本相同，只是头衔更花哨，然后是集团副总裁，职位仍然相同，但更加花哨。他的薪水开始攀升，接近运动员、演艺人员和大公司高层管理人员的薪资水平。但在 1959 年之后，当他和七位联合创始人以每人 25 万美元的价格将价值 500 美元的股票卖给母公司时，薪水就不再是那么重要了。

Fairchild’s directors back east rewarded Noyce in the traditional ways: he was named general manager of the division, then vice president, which was basically the same job with a fancier title, then group vice president, which was still the same job but even fancier. His salary began to climb toward the exalted levels reserved for athletes, entertainers, and the top management of large corporations. But after 1959, when he and his seven cofounders sold their $500 worth of stock to the parent company for a quarter million dollars each, salary was not so important a concern.

然而，到了 20 世纪 60 年代中期，诺伊斯变得越来越不适应。仙童公司的董事们想按照自己的方式经营新的利润中心，这与鲍勃·诺伊斯和戈登·摩尔的想法大相径庭。正如诺伊斯所说，这两位技术专家“敢于承担风险”，无论是技术风险还是财务风险。而东部总部的普通经理们只对安全、稳妥的商业行为感到满意。后来回想起来，诺伊斯发现分歧是不可避免的。1967 年，东部高层管理人员的一次失误更替让加州团队感到厌恶。这为 1968 年的最终决裂铺平了道路，当时诺伊斯和摩尔决定——与当代企业智慧形成鲜明对比——通过在半导体芯片上构建计算机内存电路可以赚钱。在硅谷领先的风险投资家亚瑟·罗克的帮助下，两人离开了仙童公司，成立了英特尔公司。他们安排好一切，让技术人员掌控一切。该公司总裁是罗伯特·诺伊斯，董事长是戈登·摩尔。诺伊斯解释说，英特尔的管理方式不是市场调查和财务分析，而是“直觉”。

And yet, through the mid-1960s, Noyce was becoming more and more uncomfortable. Fairchild’s directors wanted to run the new profit center their way, and this was something quite removed from what Bob Noyce and Gordon Moore had in mind. The two technologists were, as Noyce put it, “comfortable with risk,” be it technical or financial. The generic managers back east at the home office were comfortable only with security, with the safe business play. Looking back later, Noyce could see that a fissure was inevitable. A bungled turnover among top management back east in 1967 left the California group shaking their heads in disgust. That paved the way for the final break, in 1968, when Noyce and Moore decided—in sharp contrast to contemporary corporate wisdom—that money could be made by building computer memory circuits on a semiconductor chip. With the help of Silicon Valley’s leading venture capitalist, Arthur Rock, the pair left Fairchild and founded Intel Corporation. They arranged things so that technologists would be in control. The firm’s president was Robert Noyce; its chairman was Gordon Moore. Intel was to be governed, Noyce explained, not by market surveys and financial analyses, but rather by “intuitive gut feel.”

有一天，诺伊斯在英特尔总部的办公室里讲述了这一切。英特尔总部是一座不起眼的长方形建筑，位于圣克拉拉中央高速公路旁，距离大美洲主题公园不远。不过，将诺伊斯的办公室称为办公室，未免有些牵强。更好的说法是“工作空间”。这位创始人的工作空间，就像英特尔分配给其他所有人的空间一样，实际上只是一个被四个白色金属隔板围起来的小隔间。英特尔过去和现在都没有提供巨大的高管办公室。诺伊斯在外面停车场的停车位是他上班时碰巧有空位的。英特尔不为高层提供预留停车位。如果诺伊斯在早上 8 点（工作日的正式开始时间）之后才到办公室，他的名字就会像其他懒汉一样被列入迟到名单。英特尔不允许高层领导有例外。虽然英特尔周边那些远不如英特尔成功的公司初级主管经常乘坐豪华轿车前往旧金山，在昂贵的小酒馆享用豪华午餐，但鲍勃·诺伊斯经常去英特尔的自助餐厅就餐。“土豆沙拉很不错，”他边吃托盘边告诉我。

Noyce related all this one day in his office at Intel’s headquarters, a sprawling rectangle of nondescript architecture alongside the Central Expressway in Santa Clara, just shouting distance from an enormous amusement park named Great America. To call Noyce’s office an office, though, is to stretch the language. The better term would be “work space.” The founder’s work space, like the spaces allotted to everyone else at Intel, was really just a small cubicle bounded by four white metal partitions. Intel did not, and to this day does not, provide huge executive offices. Noyce’s parking space in the lot outside was whatever space happened to be free when he arrived at work. Intel does not provide reserved parking for the brass. If Noyce arrived at the office later than 8:00 A.M., the official start of the workday, his name went on the late list like all other dawdlers. Intel does not permit exceptions for those at the top. While junior executives of neighboring companies far less successful than Intel routinely rode their limousines to San Francisco for lavish expense-account lunches at exorbitant bistros, Bob Noyce’s routine lunchroom was the Intel cafeteria. “The potato salad’s pretty good,” he told me over his tray.

所有这些都直接体现了诺伊斯、摩尔和另一位仙童公司难民安德鲁·格鲁夫为公司量身定制的民主、任人唯贤和刻意去等级化的管理风格。他们希望在英特尔培养一种“这里除了我们工程师之外没有其他人”的感觉——一种公司只是一群技术人员共同努力解决技术问题并领先竞争对手两步的感觉。重点是让员工中的每位科学家、工程师和数学家都有能力——也有责任——在行业的前沿工作。这种管理理念在安德鲁·格鲁夫的《只有偏执狂才能生存》一书中阐述，专门为一家充满聪明、好奇和干劲十足的超级成就者的公司而设计——简而言之，一家充满诺伊斯的公司。

All of which was a direct reflection of the democratic, meritocratic, and studiously nonhierarchical management style that Noyce, Moore, and another Fairchild refugee, Andrew Grove, custom-designed for their company. They wanted to nurture at Intel a feeling of “nobody here but us engineers”—a sense that the company was just a bunch of technologists working together to solve technical problems and keep two hops ahead of the competition. The thrust was to give each scientist, engineer, and mathematician on the staff the ability—and the responsibility—to work at the leading edge of the industry. This management philosophy, laid out in Andrew Grove’s book Only the Paranoid Survive, was specifically designed for a company full of bright, curious, and driven superachievers—in short, for a company full of Noyces.

这也是一种行之有效的理念。《华尔街日报》在英特尔成立十周年之际报道称：“英特尔成为硅谷的技术旗舰”，这要归功于它在半导体存储器和微处理器方面的开创性发展。英特尔与业内其他公司一样，经历了低迷时期，但总体而言，其公司历史一直是一个惊人的增长故事。在开业不到十五年后，英特尔从没有产品、只有几十名员工，发展成为一家价值 10 亿美元的公司。2000 年，其销售额突破 320 亿美元，在全球四十多个国家拥有 85,000 名员工。

It was also a philosophy that worked. “Intel became Silicon Valley’s technology flagship,” The Wall Street Journal reported on the firm’s tenth anniversary, thanks to its pioneering development of semiconductor memory and the microprocessor. Intel struggled through downturns with the rest of the industry, but overall its corporate history has been a story of stupendous growth. A little less than fifteen years after it opened for business with no product and a few dozen employees, Intel became a billion-dollar company. In the year 2000, its sales topped $32 billion and there were 85,000 people on the payroll in four dozen countries around the world.

英特尔公司的成功也为其创始人带来了非凡的经济成功。1969 年，41 岁的诺伊斯凭借仙童公司股票的 25 万美元利润，变得相当富裕。然而，在英特尔诞生和快速发展之后，他进入了超级富豪的行列。1971 年，英特尔股票上市当天——开盘价为每股 23.50 美元——诺伊斯的净资产达到了八位数。

Intel’s corporate success was accompanied by extraordinary financial success for its founders. In 1969, at the age of forty-one, Noyce had become reasonably well-to-do with the quarter-million-dollar profit on his Fairchild stock. After the birth and rapid growth of Intel, though, he moved into the category of the seriously rich. On the day in 1971 when Intel’s stock went public—at an opening price of $23.50 per share—Noyce’s net worth went into the eight-digit range.

当一个自称“敢于承担风险”的人发现自己手头宽裕时，几乎可以肯定他会将一部分资金投入金融投资。罗伯特·诺伊斯在创办英特尔时曾向风险投资家求助，现在他已成为高科技领域最活跃的风险投资家之一。他的投资组合中充斥着“diasonics”和“单克隆抗体”等名称。当然，他将大部分资金投入了半导体和计算机行业。但即使在投资自己开创的领域时，他也乐于承认自己的投资决策并非总是最明智的。他的妻子曾问过他库比蒂诺附近有一家初创公司正在寻找投资者。诺伊斯研究了前景并警告她远离它；那里没有未来。这家“没有未来”的公司就是苹果电脑，它后来成为个人电脑行业财务成功的象征。 （幸运的是，诺伊斯太太明智地忽略了丈夫的建议。）鲍勃自己也投资了一家看似可靠的公司，名为奥斯本电脑。该公司有一个充满活力的产品理念——世界上第一台便携式个人电脑。不幸的是，奥斯本产品太重太笨重，以至于它后来被称为“便携式”而不是“可携带”。这家公司最终破产，诺伊斯的钱也随之消失。

When a man whose self-description included the phrase “comfortable with risk” finds himself dripping with money, it is almost axiomatic that he is going to risk some of it on financial ventures. Robert Noyce, who had gone pleading to venture capitalists when he started Intel, now became one of the more active venture capitalists in the high-tech sector. His portfolio was studded with names like “diasonics” and “monoclonal antibodies.” Naturally, he put a good part of his money into the semiconductor and computer industries. But even when investing in the fields he pioneered, he cheerfully admitted that his investment decisions have not always been the wisest. His wife asked him once about a start-up company down the road in Cupertino that was looking for investors. Noyce studied the prospects and warned her to stay away; no future there. The “no-future” company was Apple Computer, which went on to become the very symbol of financial success in the personal computer industry. (Fortunately, Mrs. Noyce had the good sense to ignore her husband’s advice.) Bob himself put some money into a seemingly solid outfit called Osborne Computer. It had a dynamic product idea—the world’s first portable personal computer. Unfortunately, the Osborne product was so heavy and cumbersome that it came to be known not as a “portable” but as a “luggable.” The firm lurched into bankruptcy, taking Noyce’s money with it.

然而，诺伊斯的投资记录中，英特尔公司的投资比奥斯本公司还多。1987 年，当他离开英特尔前往奥斯汀时，这位来自爱荷华州丹麦的部长之子已经拥有数十亿美元的资产。（他的母校格林内尔学院也身家不菲。诺伊斯安排该校在英特尔首次公开募股时购买大量股票，这项投资使格林内尔学院成为世界上最富有的小型学院之一。）诺伊斯用这笔钱来追求他对新体验的无限渴望。他驾驶自己的喷气式飞机到阿斯彭的公寓滑雪度假。他驾驶自己的水上飞机到北加州的湖泊划船度假。他喜欢在工作和娱乐中冒险，因此他开始滑翔、悬挂式滑翔、滑翔伞、水肺潜水和其他各种运动，只是为了好玩。在阿斯本，他每天下午工作，早上则在阿贾克斯山上最难爬的山坡上飞驰。有一次我问他阿斯本最喜欢的滑雪道是什么，他毫不犹豫地说：“Face of Bell”。当我跋涉过去看这条滑雪道时，我发现那是一处陡峭的悬崖，上面标有双黑菱形和一个红色的标志：“小心：仅限专家。”他买了越来越豪华的汽车，开得越来越快。他开始品尝上等葡萄酒，毫不奇怪地成为了葡萄酒酿造学专家。只要他住在硅谷，他就住在洛斯加托斯舒适但并不豪华的房子里，他和他的第一任妻子（1974 年离婚，一年后再婚）在那里抚养了四个孩子。但现在房子周围环绕着越来越奢华的花园——四十五岁左右的诺伊斯对园艺产生了浓厚的兴趣——配备了网球场和游泳池。搬到奥斯汀后，他在新家建了一个花园和游泳池，并利用工作之余的一点空闲时间培养对德克萨斯州本土植物的了解。“他的生活非常精彩，”迈克尔·马龙写道，他在半导体行业工作时，诺伊斯是该行业最著名的公民。“在硅谷，我们所有人都想为戴夫·帕卡德（惠普公司）工作，但我们所有人都想成为鲍勃·诺伊斯。”

There were, however, more Intels than Osbornes in Noyce’s investment record. By the time he left Intel for Austin in 1987, the minister’s son from Denmark, Iowa, was counting his assets in the billions of dollars. (His alma mater, Grinnell, was also in the chips. Noyce had arranged for the school to buy a hunk of stock at Intel’s initial public offering, an investment that made Grinnell one of the richest small colleges in the world.) Noyce used the money to pursue his unbounded appetite for new experiences. He flew his own jet to skiing vacations at his condominium in Aspen. He flew his own seaplane to boating vacations on the lakes of northern California. Comfortable with risk at play as well as work, he took up gliding, hang gliding, paragliding, scuba diving, and assorted other sports, just for the hell of it. At Aspen, he arranged his day so that he worked in the afternoon and spent the mornings racing down Ajax, the toughest slope on the mountain. I asked him once to name his favorite run at Aspen, and he didn’t hesitate a minute: “Face of Bell,” he said. When I trekked over to see this run, it turned out to be a precipitous cliff marked with double black diamonds and a sign in red letters: “Caution: Experts Only.” He bought ever fancier cars and drove them ever faster. He took up fine wines, not surprisingly becoming an expert in enology. As long as he lived in Silicon Valley, he stayed at the comfortable but hardly fancy house in Los Gatos where he and his first wife (he was divorced in 1974 and remarried a year later) raised their four children. But the house was now surrounded by increasingly lavish gardens—in his mid-forties, Noyce became intensely interested in gardening—accoutered with tennis court and swimming pool. When he moved to Austin, he put in a garden and pool at his new home there, and spent what little time he had outside of work developing an expertise in native Texas flora. “He had one helluva life,” wrote Michael Malone, who worked in the semiconductor industry when Noyce was its most famous citizen. “In Silicon Valley, all of us wanted to work for Dave Packard [of Hewlett-Packard], but all of us wanted to be Bob Noyce.”

诺伊斯充满活力的运动生涯、广泛的个人兴趣以及在英特尔的管理工作足以填满大多数人的日常生活。然而，对于诺伊斯来说，年逾五十的他开始将目光投向英特尔小隔间之外。除此之外，他开始思考不仅是自己公司的未来，而且是整个半导体行业的未来——以及整个美国工业的未来。他是硅谷高管们共同成立的半导体行业协会的领导人之一，当然也是董事会的创始成员。当记者来到加州调查芯片行业时，诺伊斯的办公室成了他们的必经之地。从很多方面来看，他都是完美的发言人——一位深思熟虑、口齿伶俐的开国元勋，既可以讨论精确的技术问题，也可以讨论广泛的工业政策问题。

The combination of Noyce’s vigorous athletic life, his far-flung personal interests, and his management work at Intel would have been sufficient to fill the days of most men. For Noyce, though, his late fifties found him looking beyond the low partition in his cubicle at Intel. Among much else, he started thinking about the future not only of his own company but also of the entire semiconductor industry—and of American industry as a whole. He was among the leaders of a group of Silicon Valley executives who got together to form the Semiconductor Industry Association, and was, of course, a charter member of the board. When journalists came to California to look into the chip business, Noyce’s office became a regular stop. He was, in many ways, the perfect spokesman—a thoughtful, articulate founding father who could discuss both precise technical questions and broad issues of industrial policy.

到 1978 年，诺伊斯在会议、研讨会和国会听证会上发言的时间已经和他在英特尔一样多了。他放弃了日常管理工作，将公司交给了他的老朋友兼顾问戈登·摩尔 (Gordon Moore)，以便可以投入更多时间处理整个行业的事务。他是硅谷的元老，一位同事称他为“科学家兼魅力人物”，是该行业的官方代言人。他成为半导体行业协会主席，并领导该协会抵御日本挑战。他对日本的保护主义做法感到不耐烦，因此开始思考振兴他所开创的行业的其他方法。这导致了 Sematech 的成立。诺伊斯是呼吁成立全行业联盟的主要声音之一，当 14 家大公司同意向 Sematech 投资时，诺伊斯加入了为联合运营寻找首席执行官的委员会。他们联系了通常的猎头公司，面试了几位履历出色的人选。但在遴选委员会的最后一次会议上，其他成员发起了一场小规模的反抗。他们扔掉了候选人名单，转而选择了从一开始就被认为是最佳人选的人：鲍勃·诺伊斯。

By 1978, Noyce was spending as much time speaking at conferences, seminars, and congressional hearings as he was at Intel. He stepped aside from day-to-day management—turning the firm over to his old friend and sounding board, Gordon Moore—so that he could devote more time to industry-wide concerns. He was the elder statesman of Silicon Valley, the “scientist-cum-charmer,” as a colleague put it—the official voice of his industry. He became chairman of the Semiconductor Industry Association and the leader of its battle to stave off the challenge from Japan. It was his impatience with the protectionist approach to the Japanese challenge that got him thinking about other ways to revitalize the industry that he had started. That led to the formation of Sematech. Noyce was one of the key voices calling for an industry-wide consortium, and when fourteen major companies agreed to put money into Sematech, Noyce served on the committee set up to find a CEO for the joint operation. The usual headhunter firms were contacted, and several people with stellar résumés were interviewed for the job. At the final meeting of the selection committee, though, the other members staged a mini-revolt. They threw out the list of candidates and turned to the man who had been the obvious choice from the beginning: Bob Noyce.

在 Sematech，诺伊斯成为了芯片业务生产端的专家——这种精密的光刻机可以将厚度不到百万分之一英寸的线路“打印”到薄如刀片的硅片上。他涉足了新领域，这些领域很可能被标记为“警告：仅限专家”。现在，他正在处理冶金学、激光投影、亚微米光学和其他复杂领域，而这些领域诺伊斯通常留给英特尔的其他人。他的目标是雄心勃勃，但至少很明确，那就是确保美国制造的半导体制造机器是世界上最先进的。他打赌，如果美国能够重新夺回微芯片贸易制造端的领先地位，它将再次成为世界领先的供应商。到那时，来自硅谷的骄傲的技术人员将不再需要向国会乞求保护以免受外国竞争。

At Sematech, Noyce turned himself into an expert on the production end of the chip business—the incredibly precise photolithographic machinery that “prints” wires less than a millionth of an inch thick onto razor-thin wafers of silicon. He took excursions into new terrain that might well have been marked “Caution: Experts Only.” Now he was dealing with metallurgy, laser projection, submicron optics, and other complex areas that Noyce had generally left to others at Intel. His goal, ambitious but at least clear, was to see to it that American-made semiconductor fabrication machinery was the most advanced in the world. His bet was that if the United States could regain its lead in the manufacturing end of the microchip trade, it would once again become the world’s leading supplier. Then, proud technologists from Silicon Valley would no longer have to crawl to Congress begging for protection from foreign competition.

1990 年春天，当我见到鲍勃·诺伊斯时，这个目标还遥不可及。他像往常一样友好但又很严肃，抽着烟，像往常一样语速飞快。但他也很自信。“这个任务比我想象的还要艰巨，”他说。“但我认为我们会做到的。我认为我们已经找到了正确的解决方案，我们绝对有才能和意志来实现它。日本人是优秀的制造商和严肃的竞争对手。但他们自己也有一些问题。所以我认为我们会实现目标。”

The goal was still some ways off when I saw Bob Noyce in the spring of 1990. He was friendly but intense, as usual, smoking like mad and talking at his normal super-fast pace. But he was also confident. “This was a bigger job than even I thought it was going to be,” he said. “But I think we’re going to do it. We’ve identified the right solution, I think, and we definitely have the talent and the will to achieve it. The Japanese are excellent manufacturers and serious competitors. But they have some problems of their own. So I think we’re going to get there.”

然而，仅仅两年后，当美国半导体行业真的发展到这个地步时，鲍勃·诺伊斯却没能亲眼见证。1990 年 6 月的一个星期天早上，他在奥斯汀的家中早早起床，跳进游泳池进行日常游泳。几乎就在那一刻，他的心跳停止了。人们把他从水里捞出来，送往医院，但不到一小时他就死了。他是一位草原之子，在 62 年的人生中取得了巨大的成就。但他没能到达职业生涯的终点。

When the U.S. semiconductor industry did get there, though, just two years later, Bob Noyce was not around to see it. On a Sunday morning in June 1990, he got up early at the house in Austin and dove into the pool for his daily laps. Almost immediately, his heart stopped. They fished him out of the water and got him to a hospital, but within an hour he was dead. He was a son of the prairie who had gone enormously far in his sixty-two years. But he didn’t get to arrive at his final professional destination.

杰克·圣克莱尔·基尔比 (Jack St. Clair Kilby) 是悼念这位美国工程巨人的人之一。杰克告诉记者，他对诺伊斯的成就充满钦佩，无论是作为发明家还是作为业界的官方代言人。然后，他坐在达拉斯北部边缘的杂乱办公室里，很高兴能成为自己的官方代言人。从那时起，他一直呆在那里，非常愿意与偶尔到访的记者或历史学家交谈，但大部分时间他都在默默地、创造性地从事他最喜欢的事业：发明。

Among those who mourned the passing of this giant of American engineering was Jack St. Clair Kilby. Jack told the reporters who called that he was filled with admiration for Noyce’s accomplishments, both as an inventor and as the official voice of the industry. Then he sat back in his cluttered office at the northern edge of Dallas, quite happy to be the official voice of no one but himself. He has remained there pretty much ever since, perfectly willing to talk to the occasional reporter or historian who stops in, but for the most part tacitly and creatively engaged in the business he has always liked best: inventing.

在完成 Pocketronic 计算器后的几年里，杰克·基尔比似乎也或多或少不可避免地进入了管理层。德州仪器公司急于让杰克知道他的开创性工作得到了赞赏，因此给杰克提供了源源不断的加薪、奖金、股票期权和晋升。对于一个从事发明工作的人来说，晋升意味着升至管理其他发明者的管理职位；最终，他成为德州仪器研发实验室的二号人物，那里的最高职位唾手可得。到 1970 年，当他前往白宫领取国家科学奖章时，他已成为德州仪器最受尊敬的工程师；只要他留在公司，他似乎就能获得更多的奖金、更多的加薪和更多的晋升。

For a while, in the years after he finished the Pocketronic calculator, Jack Kilby, too, seemed to be moving more or less inevitably into management. Eager to let him know that his groundbreaking work was appreciated, Texas Instruments rewarded Jack with a steady flow of raises, bonuses, stock options, and promotions. Promotion, for a man whose job was inventing, involved moving up to a management position supervising other inventors; eventually he became the number two man in the hierarchy at TI’s research and development lab, and the top job there was easily within reach. By 1970, when he went to the White House to receive the National Medal of Science, he was TI’s most respected engineer; he seemed assured of more bonuses, more raises, and more promotions as long as he stayed at the company.

然后，他于1970年11月离开了。

And then, in November 1970, he left.

多年来，杰克一直在思考他最喜爱的工作：发明这项要求高、富有创造性、最终回报丰厚的工作。他越来越清楚地认识到，真正的创造力，无论是艺术的还是技术的，都需要真正的自由——这种自由与政府或企业的官僚机构格格不入。公司的整个组织结构开始变得不协调。“发明家和大公司之间存在着根本的不相容性，”杰克在一次关于这个主题的演讲中写道。“大公司拥有完善的规划机制，需要在开始一个新项目时就知道要花多少钱、需要多长时间，最重要的是，要做什么。这些答案对发明家来说可能都不是显而易见的。”基尔比继续说，如果爱迪生在一家大公司工作，可能就不会有爱迪生灯泡，因为公司的目标可能与发明家的目标不符。当杰克思考爱迪生、贝尔和其他自由发明家的工作时——这些人自己定义问题并自己找到解决方案——他开始意识到自由职业者可能确实更乐于助人。事实上，他在德州仪器享有相当大的自由，但即使在那里，官僚主义也开始侵犯他。他的目标一直是为重要问题找到“不明显的”解决方案；但任何不明显的解决方案对公司规划师和会计师来说都是诅咒。

Over the years, Jack had been thinking a great deal about the work he loved most: the demanding, creative, and ultimately rewarding job of inventing. It became more and more apparent to him that real creativity, artistic or technical, demanded real freedom—the kind of freedom that did not mesh with bureaucracies, governmental or corporate. The whole organizational structure of the corporation was beginning to chafe. “There is a basic incompatibility of the inventor and the large corporation,” Jack wrote in a lecture on the subject. “Large companies have well-developed planning mechanisms which need to know at the beginning of a new project how much it will cost, how long it will take, and above all, what it’s going to do. None of these answers may be apparent to the inventor.” If Edison had worked for a big corporation, Kilby went on, there might have been no Edison light bulb, because the company’s goals might not have matched the inventor’s. As he contemplated the work of Edison and Bell and other freelance inventors—men who had defined the problems on their own and worked out their own solutions—Jack began to perceive that the grass might indeed be greener on the freelance side of the fence. He had, as a matter of fact, enjoyed considerable freedom at Texas Instruments, but even there bureaucracy was beginning to infringe. His goal had always been to find “nonobvious” solutions to important problems; but anything nonobvious was anathema to corporate planners and accountants.

通过大量阅读，杰克整理出两份清单，比较了大公司和个人的重大发明。公司发明家的清单包括透明胶带、电视和尼龙等，更不用说集成电路了。个人发明家的清单包括空调、青霉素、静电复印和拉链等。如今回想起来，基尔比无法解释这两份清单之间的任何重大差异。然而，当时，当他仔细阅读这两份清单时，它们似乎在某种程度上证明了一个观点。今天他意识到，这个观点在他心中已经基本确定了。自由职业才是出路。

From his voluminous reading, Jack had put together a pair of lists comparing major inventions produced by large corporations to those made by individuals. The corporate inventors’ list included, among other things, Scotch tape, television, and nylon—not to mention the integrated circuit. The individual inventor was credited with, among other things, air-conditioning, penicillin, xerography, and the zipper. Looking back on it today, Kilby is at a loss to explain any significant difference between the two lists. At the time, though, as he perused the two lists, they somehow seemed to prove a point. Today he realizes that the point had already been largely settled in his own mind. Freelance was the way to go.

于是，他收拾好书籍、文件和他最喜欢的老式 Log-Log Decitrig 计算尺，搬到了北达拉斯 LBJ 高速公路旁一栋低层办公楼里，距离德州仪器约两英里。在那里，他可以按照自己的节奏解决自己选择的问题。“设定自己的目标，自由地做自己认为重要的事情，而不是追随别人的日程安排，这会带来一定的满足感，”他说。“自由，这就是我对此感兴趣的地方。”

And so he packed up his books, his papers, and his favorite old Log-Log Decitrig slide rule and moved out to a place of his own in a low-rise office building off the LBJ Freeway in North Dallas, about two miles from TI. There he could work at his own pace on problems of his own choosing. “There’s a certain amount of satisfaction,” he said, “in setting your own goals, in being free to do what you decide is important, and not pursue somebody else’s schedule. The freedom, that’s what interests me about this.”

他坦言，从经济角度来看，选择自由并不是特别明智。“不，这几乎是愚蠢的。经济回报相当有限。”

He admitted readily that the choice of freedom was not a particularly wise one in financial terms. “No, it was pretty damn close to stupid. The economic rewards have been pretty marginal.”

杰克·基尔比 (Jack Kilby) 获得的经济回报从未达到罗伯特·诺伊斯 (Robert Noyce) 积累的巨额财富，基尔比从哲学角度接受了这一事实。“基本上，公司聘请工程师就是为了做这种工作，”他说。“我不会从所有售出的产品中获得 5% 的价值，或者诸如此类的东西……但我因在集成电路方面的工作而从 TI 获得了相当丰厚的回报。”他在 TI 的回报使他的年薪稳稳地达到六位数，这笔收入让杰克、芭芭拉和他们的两个女儿过上了舒适的中上阶层生活。这也让他们有足够的积蓄来维持杰克刚开始独立时的艰苦岁月。杰克最终从德州仪器的咨询工作和德州农工大学固态电子研究所的兼职教员那里获得了一些收入，他从 1978 年到 1984 年一直担任该职位。随着时间的推移，杰克因发起微电子革命而获得的奖金也开始大量涌入；1993 年，他因获得日本京都奖而获得了 40 万美元，2000 年因获得诺贝尔奖而获得了近 50 万美元。但他把这些钱大部分捐了出去。杰克·基尔比从来都不在意有钱与否。

The economic rewards for Jack Kilby have never approached the vast wealth accumulated by Robert Noyce, a fact that Kilby accepted philosophically. “Basically, engineers are hired by companies to do that kind of work,” he said. “I don’t get five percent of the value of everything that is ever sold, or anything of that sort . . . but I was rather well rewarded by TI for my work on the integrated circuit.” His rewards at TI put his yearly salary safely into the six-figure range, an income that permitted Jack and Barbara and their two daughters to live in comfortable upper-middle-class style. It also permitted them to save enough to maintain their way of life during the lean years when Jack first set out on his own. Jack would eventually draw some income for consulting work at Texas Instruments and as a faculty member at Texas A&M’s Institute of Solid-State Electronics, a part-time appointment he held from 1978 to 1984. Over time, as well, considerable money started pouring in from prizes Jack was given for launching the microelectronic revolution; he got $400,000 for winning Japan’s Kyoto Prize in 1993, and just under a half million for the Nobel Prize in 2000. But much of that money he gave away. Being rich never mattered much to Jack Kilby.

作为一名独立发明家，杰克已经获得了大约十几项专利，这些专利反映了他自独立以来创意范围的广泛性。在妻子的建议下，杰克开始研究一种“电子拦截”装置，这种装置可以阻止您的电话响铃，除非该电话是您想要接听的。经过三年的摸索，他获得了专利号 3,955,354，“禁用来电的系统”。这个小玩意儿运行完美，但迄今为止在市场上表现不佳。然后是专利号 4,001,947，“教学系统”，这是一种小型计算器式装置，可以在教授数学、拼写和其他科目时与学生交谈。这个想法也很好，但在这种情况下，基尔比被德州仪器生产的竞争产品 Speak 'n Spell 抢先了。 Kilby 的“电子支票打印机”专利号为 3,920,979，由一家日本消费电子公司授权，但至今还未赚到第一分钱，这一描述也适用于专利号为 3,944,724 的“带有可选择性启动的袖珍打印机的分页系统”。

As an independent inventor, Jack has received about a dozen patents, and they reflect the considerably wider scope of his ideas since he went out on his own. At his wife’s suggestion, Jack started working on an “electronic intercept” device that keeps your telephone from ringing unless the call is one you want to take. Three years of tinkering resulted in Patent No. 3,955,354, “System for disabling incoming telephone calls.” The gadget works perfectly but so far has been a dud in the market. Then there was Patent No. 4,001,947, “Teaching system,” a small calculatorlike device that talks to a student as it teaches math, spelling, and other subjects. That idea, too, worked fine, but in this case Kilby was scooped by a competing product known as Speak ’n Spell—produced by Texas Instruments. The Kilby “Electronic check writer,” Patent No. 3,920,979, was licensed by a Japanese consumer electronics firm but has yet to earn its first dime, a description that also holds true for Patent No. 3,944,724, “Paging system with selectively actuable pocket printers.”

在自由职业生涯的最初几年里，基尔比沉浸在新获得的自由中，随着精神的指引，从一个想法转向另一个想法。一如既往，他仍然是工程师，而不是科学家。他的目标是解决问题，现在他有机会选择自己要解决的问题。“发明家可以满足大量实际需求，”他在关于发明的演讲中说道。“个人可以自由选择他认为可以满足的需求…… 问题的定义成为创新的主要部分”（基尔比强调）。

For the first few years or so of his freelance career, Kilby reveled in his new freedom, moving from one idea to the next as the spirit took him. As always, he remained an engineer, not a scientist. His goal was to solve problems, and he now had the opportunity to choose which problems he would work on. “There are a large number of real needs which the inventor can address,” he said in his lecture on inventing. “The individual is free to choose a need that he thinks he may be able to satisfy . . . . The definition of the problem becomes a major part of the innovation” (Kilby’s emphasis).

多年来，他一直致力于解决一个重大问题：国家能源供应。20 世纪 70 年代的石油危机之后，人们逐渐达成共识，认为根本需要其他能源——一种地球上每个人都可以使用的能源，一种取之不尽、用之不竭的能源，一种不需要排放温室气体的巨型烟囱的能源。事实上，这种能源已经存在——太阳。问题是如何将阳光转化为电能。这对杰克来说是个好问题，因为就像数字暴政一样，它显然可以用半导体，特别是硅来解决。这里的基本思想被称为光伏效应，是半导体物理学最早的发现之一。一个多世纪以来，物理学家们就知道，如果用光照射半导体材料条带（如硅），电子就会开始从条带的一端移动到另一端。正如 JJ Thomson 所解释的那样，电子的流动就是电流。杰克将问题定义为建造一个适合普通房屋的半导体材料太阳能电池，并产生足够的电力来满足该房屋的日常需求。这不是一个容易的问题。“我不能说这项工作没有结果，”杰克说。“但结果并不多。”

For several years, he worked on a problem of major importance: the nation’s energy supply. After the oil shocks of the 1970s, a consensus grew that there was a fundamental need for some other source of power—a source that was available to everyone on earth, a source that was unlimited, a source that didn’t require huge smokestacks emitting greenhouse gases. In fact, this power source already existed—the sun. The problem was how to turn sunshine into electricity. It was a good problem for Jack, because, like the tyranny of numbers, it is one that apparently can be solved with semiconductors, particularly silicon. The basic idea here, known as the photovoltaic effect, was one of the earliest discoveries of semiconductor physics. Physicists have known for more than a century that if you shine light on a strip of semiconductor material, such as silicon, electrons will start to move from one end of the strip to the other. The flow of electrons, as J. J. Thomson explained, is an electric current. Jack defined the problem as building a solar cell of semiconductor material that would fit in an average house and generate enough power to meet the daily needs of that house. It was not an easy problem. “I can’t say exactly that nothing came of that work,” Jack said. “But not a hell of a lot came of it.”

渐渐地，基尔比发现自己又回到了企业界。他对德州仪器怀有忠诚之心，当德州仪器请他为这个问题或那个问题提供咨询时，杰克都很乐意效劳。他加入了两家较小的半导体公司的董事会，并为其他多家公司和研究中心的项目提供咨询。他还不断改进自己的发明。

Gradually, Kilby found himself drawn back toward the corporate world. He felt a loyalty to Texas Instruments, and when TI asked him to consult on this problem or that one, Jack was happy to oblige. He joined the board of directors of two smaller semiconductor companies, and consulted on projects at various other firms and research centers. And he kept tinkering away at his inventions.

对于一个认为抓住一个有趣的问题并解决它就是天堂的人来说，杰克·基尔比的命运是幸福的。如今，他已年近八十，过着平静、深思熟虑、令人满意的生活。他的妻子于 20 世纪 80 年代初去世，当时他们刚结婚 33 周年。但他的妹妹简住在离家不远的达拉斯，和杰克一样健谈，照顾着家里的实际事务。当杰克的眼镜和助听器不见时，她能找到它们。他经常见到他的两个女儿安和珍妮特以及五个孙女。他一生中最大的乐趣之一就是带着家人去世界各地参加颁奖典礼。“当我告诉校长我要休假一周，因为我的爷爷获得了诺贝尔奖时，你应该看看她眼中的表情，”安·基尔比的女儿卡特里娜说。

For a man whose notion of heaven is to seize an interesting problem and solve it, Jack Kilby’s lot has been a happy one. Today, in his late seventies, he leads a quiet, thoughtful, and satisfying life. His wife died in the early 1980s, shortly after the couple’s thirty-third anniversary. But his sister Jane, as talkative as Jack is quiet, lives in Dallas, not far away, and watches after practical matters. She’s the one who can find Jack’s glasses and hearing aid when they disappear. He sees his two daughters, Ann and Janet, and five granddaughters often. One of the great pleasures of his life has been taking his family with him around the world to award ceremonies. “You should have seen the look in the principal’s eye,” said Ann Kilby’s daughter, Katrina, “when I told her I was going to take a week off school because my granddad won the Nobel Prize.”

大多数星期五，杰克都会拿出他旧的 TI 员工徽章，前往德州仪器的研发实验室（现在位于一座名为 Kilby Center 的崭新设施中）与他的工程师同事们一起闲逛。德州仪器的新闻稿将此称为“常规顾问角色”。杰克对此的描述略有不同：“我四处闲逛并与人们交谈。”

Most Fridays, Jack digs out his old TI employee badge and heads over to the R&D lab at Texas Instruments—now located in a sparkling new facility known as Kilby Center—to hang out with his fellow engineers. Texas Instruments’ press releases refer to this as a “regular consultative role.” Jack described it a little differently: “I kinda wander around and talk to people.”

他仍然花很多时间思考。“杰克是个思想家，”他的同事、退休人员 Willis Adcock 说，这位精力充沛的工程师在 25 年前将 Kilby 带到了达拉斯，以解决数字的暴政。“我想说杰克有很好的创造性意识，他有这一点，但我雇用他的另一点是，他是一个坚持不懈的人。他会从头到尾思考问题，不断努力，直到解决问题。你知道，你可以看到结果。”

And he still spends a lot of time thinking. “Jack is a thinker,” said his fellow retiree Willis Adcock, the sprightly engineer who brought Kilby to Dallas a quarter century ago to tackle the tyranny of numbers. “I would say Jack’s got a good creative sense, he’s got that, but the other thing that I liked when I hired him is that he is a persister. He just thinks a problem all the way through, works it through, and he doesn’t stop until he’s got it worked out. And you know, you can see the results.”

您可以在任何地方看到这种结果，因为 Kilby-Noyce 微芯片已成为现代生活中无处不在的现实和必需品。正如 1931 年为了纪念托马斯·爱迪生而关闭世界上所有的灯泡两分钟是不切实际的一样，现在任何人提出关闭世界上所有的集成电路以纪念其发明者都是不可想象的。首先，您无法找到它们。数十亿个微芯片在世界各地的家庭、汽车、口袋、人造器官、办公室、医院和工厂中发挥作用。这种整体理念催生了数千家公司和数以万计的新产品。

You can see the results anywhere, because the Kilby-Noyce microchip has become an ever-present reality, and necessity, of modern life. Just as it proved impractical back in 1931 to turn off all the world’s light bulbs for two minutes as a memorial to Thomas Edison, it would be unthinkable for anybody now to suggest shutting down all the world’s integrated circuits in tribute to its inventors. For one thing, you couldn’t find them all. Microchips by the billions are at work in homes, cars, pockets, artificial organs, offices, hospitals, and factories around the world. The monolithic idea has spawned thousands of companies and tens of thousands of new products.

它也为 Jack Kilby 和 Robert Noyce 赢得了大量奖项、奖牌、奖金和表彰。

It has also spawned a veritable flood of awards, plaques, prizes, and citations for Jack Kilby and Robert Noyce.

事实上，专业技术奖项变得如此普遍，以至于在发明 25 周年之际，当收到新奖项的消息时，诺伊斯和基尔比都没有太在意。然而，1982 年的一天，杰克·基尔比获得了对他来说真正重要的荣誉，因为这证明他在自己选择的行业中取得了成功。他被选入国家发明家名人堂，当时这个堂皇的团体只有 50 多人，其中包括爱迪生、贝尔、福特、肖克利和莱特兄弟。

The professional and technical awards became so common, in fact, that by the twenty-fifth anniversary of their invention, neither Noyce nor Kilby paid much attention when word of a new one came in the mail. One day in 1982, though, Jack Kilby received an honor that really mattered to him, because it was proof he had succeeded at his chosen trade. He was inducted into the National Inventors Hall of Fame, an august group of just five dozen people at the time—among them Edison, Bell, Ford, Shockley, and the Wright brothers.

一个阳光明媚的冬日星期天，一群人聚集在专利局大厅，与华盛顿纪念碑隔波托马克河相望，参加名人堂入选仪式。当年获奖的五位发明家中，只有两位还活着——基尔比和马克斯·蒂什勒，后者于 1941 年通过合成维生素 B2 开创了维生素行业。两人都出席了。当商务部长叫到蒂什勒的名字时，这位年迈的化学家站起来，发表了一段长篇演讲，讲述了他如何得到这个想法以及这个想法的意义。然后轮到杰克·基尔比了。他站了一会儿，羞涩地环顾四周的观众，轻声说：“谢谢。”

On a sunny winter Sunday, a group of people gathered in the lobby of the Patent Office, just across the Potomac from the Washington Monument, for the Hall of Fame induction ceremony. Of the five inventors honored that year, only two—Kilby and Max Tishler, who started the vitamin industry in 1941 by synthesizing vitamin B2—were still alive. Both were present. When the secretary of commerce called out Tishler’s name, the aging chemist stood up and gave a long speech about how he got his idea and what it had meant. Then it was Jack Kilby’s turn. He stood up for the briefest moment, looked around shyly at the audience, and quietly said, “Thank you.”

全国各地的多家报纸都刊登了一篇简短的报道，介绍那次颁奖典礼以及杰克·基尔比作为数字电路之父的角色。一年后，当罗伯特·诺伊斯因在芯片发明中所发挥的作用而被选入同一名人堂时，几家报纸又用几英寸的篇幅报道了这一主题。此后，诺伊斯经常以硅谷发言人的身份出现在报纸或商业杂志上。但诺伊斯和基尔比都没有得到足够的媒体关注，以至于他们的名字只为极少数的同胞所熟知。事实上，在他们提出引发微电子革命的想法近半个世纪后，罗伯特·诺伊斯和杰克·基尔比仍然默默无闻。

A scattering of newspapers around the country ran a brief story on that ceremony and on Jack Kilby’s role as the patriarch of digital circuitry. A year later, when Robert Noyce was inducted into the same Hall of Fame for his part in the creation of the chip, a few papers again devoted a few inches of space to the subject. Thereafter, Noyce used to show up in newspapers or business magazines in his role as the spokesman for Silicon Valley. But neither Noyce nor Kilby ever received enough attention in the press to make their names familiar to any more than a minute fraction of their countrymen. Indeed, nearly half a century after they came up with an idea that launched the microelectronics revolution, both Robert Noyce and Jack Kilby remain cloaked in obscurity.

这是时代的标志。几代人之前，像爱迪生、贝尔、福特和固特异这样的人，他们的发明影响了每个人的生活，催生了巨大的产业，他们被赋予了巨大的声望。虽然当时对这些事情的研究不像现在这样仔细，但可以相当肯定地说，托马斯·爱迪生在发明电灯泡后的十年内，是这个国家，甚至可能是世界上最著名的人。（1890 年，世界上最著名的人几乎肯定是维多利亚女王，她的肖像挂在世界上最庞大帝国的墙上；但爱迪生才是最著名的人。）作为门洛帕克的奇才，“科学界的拿破仑”，他在1922 年《纽约时报》的一项调查中仍然被评为“最受尊敬的美国人”，当时他已经 75 岁，早已退休。亚历山大·格雷厄姆·贝尔凭借他的发明家喻户晓，早在全国范围内的贝尔系统建立之前。亨利·福特和他的“Tin Lizzie”成为了神话，并立即被世界各地视为汽车时代的象征。

It’s a sign of the times. A few generations ago, men of this ilk—men like Edison and Bell, Ford and Goodyear, whose inventions touched every life and spawned giant industries—were accorded enormous prominence. Although such things were not surveyed as carefully then as they are now, it seems fairly safe to assert that Thomas Edison was the best-known man in the country, and probably on earth, within ten years after he perfected the light bulb. (The best-known person on earth in 1890 was almost certainly Queen Victoria, whose portrait hung on walls throughout the world’s vastest empire; but Edison was the best-known man.) The Wizard of Menlo Park, the “Napoleon of Science,” he still ranked as the “Most Admired American” in a New York Times survey taken in 1922, when he was seventy-five years old and long finished with productive work. Alexander Graham Bell was a household name on the basis of his invention long before the nationwide Bell System was in place. Henry Ford and his Tin Lizzie became the stuff of myth, instantly recognized around the world as the symbols of the automobile age.

芯片对世界的改变与电话和汽车一样具有决定性的意义。与许多现代发明不同，我们清楚地知道是谁发明了芯片。但在微电子时代，杰克·基尔比和鲍勃·诺伊斯所代表的，如果真有什么的话，也只是现代人对机器背后的人缺乏兴趣。几乎一万个美国人中只有一个人能说出发明集成电路并发起数字革命的两位同胞的名字。他们并不是当代美国社会塑造英雄的典型人物。

The chip has changed the world as decisively as did the telephone and the automobile. And unlike many modern inventions, we know exactly who gave it to us. But in the microelectronic age, Jack Kilby and Bob Noyce symbolize, if anything, only the modern lack of interest in the humans behind the machines. Barely one American in ten thousand could name the two countrymen who invented the integrated circuit and launched the digital revolution. They are not the stuff of which heroes are made in contemporary American society.

是因为人们真的相信计算机包含“电子大脑”——因此不关心使这些机制成为可能的人类智力吗？是因为我们已经接受了奥威尔式的观念，认为数字技术是一种残酷的、专制的力量——因此我们不想尊敬甚至不了解发明它的人吗？是因为我们已经习惯了大型企业和政府企业的新想法，以至于我们不再承认个人发明吗？是因为那些在我们同时代人中传播名声和认可的媒体——《人物》、 奥普拉、拉里·金、《早安美国》等——不相信他们的观众会欣赏真正的智力成就吗？或者是因为在选择我们社会所尊敬的人时，财富比成就更重要。比尔·盖茨是一位成就卓著、富有创新精神的程序员，他开创了全球个人电脑软件行业；但直到他以“世界首富”的身份出现在《人物》杂志上之前，谁听说过他？ 《时代》杂志在鲍勃·诺伊斯去世前不久刊登了一篇关于他的文章，主要关注他的投资收益，并将他描述为“金融精灵”——这是一个典型的忽略真正要点的案例。

Is it because people really believe that computers contain “electronic brains”—and thus don’t care to know about the human brainpower that made these mechanisms possible? Is it because we have swallowed the Orwellian notion that digital technology is a brutalizing, tyrannical force—and thus we don’t want to honor, or even know, the men who made it? Is it because we have grown so accustomed to new ideas coming out of huge corporate and governmental enterprises that we no longer recognize individual invention? Is it because the media that purvey fame and recognition among our contemporaries —People, Oprah, Larry King, Good Morning America, and the like—don’t trust their audiences to appreciate genuine intellectual accomplishment? Or maybe it’s because wealth matters more than achievement when it comes to choosing the people our society will look up to. Bill Gates was an accomplished and innovative programmer who launched the global industry of personal computer software; but who had ever heard of him until he showed up in People magazine as “the richest man in the world”? A Time magazine story about Bob Noyce shortly before his death focused on his investment earnings and described him as a “financial genie”—a classic case of missing the real point.

当今世界“最受尊敬”人物名单——由盖洛普民意调查这一精密调查机构每年汇总的名单——表明，目前美国人对政治人物的崇拜之风盛行，偶尔也会崇拜牧师或艺人。几十年来，乔治·盖洛普和他的组织一直在要求美国人说出他们最崇拜的两个人。答案每年都差不多。教皇和葛培理经常出现在名单上。鲍勃·霍普和沃尔特·克朗凯特偶尔会出现。其他名字往往来自政府；罗纳德·里根、比尔·克林顿和科林·鲍威尔都是这个花园中经久不衰的常客。正如盖洛普组织在其调查的附加说明中指出的那样，这项民意调查“倾向于支持那些目前在新闻中的人”。因此，从事科学和工程领域的男女往往被排除在外也就不足为奇了，因为这些人一般不被视为新闻——除非他们成为狂热的自我推销者（就像爱迪生和福特那样），或者除非他们像威廉·肖克利那样，放弃技术工作，开始为政治目的进行宣传。

The list of the “most admired” in today’s world—a list assembled annually by the sophisticated surveying apparatus of the Gallup poll—suggests that the current vogue in admiration among Americans runs heavily to political figures, with an occasional clergyman or entertainer thrown in. For decades George Gallup and his organization have been asking Americans to name the two people they admire most. The answers vary little from year to year. The pope and Billy Graham are often on the list. Bob Hope and Walter Cronkite show up occasionally. The other names tend to be drawn from government; Ronald Reagan, Bill Clinton, and Colin Powell are among the hardy perennials in this garden. As the Gallup organization points out in a caveat accompanying its survey, the poll “tends to favor those who are currently in the news.” It’s hardly surprising, then, that men and women engaged in science and engineering tend to be left out, for such people are generally not treated as news—unless they become avid self-promoters (as Edison and Ford were) or unless, like William Shockley, they set aside their technical work and begin proselytizing for political causes.

因此，在这个每个人都应该成名十五分钟的时代，杰克·基尔比和鲍勃·诺伊斯从未在规定的十五分钟内出现过。报纸和杂志上偶尔会报道他们的故事，尤其是达拉斯和硅谷的当地媒体。事实上，在达拉斯，杰克·基尔比几乎是一个小明星，主要是因为人们对这个表现出色的家乡男孩感到由衷的自豪。当地媒体称他为“德克萨斯爱迪生”。在杰克首次写下这一巨大想法的实验室所在地，有一块官方的德克萨斯历史标记。德州仪器公司对其队伍中的这位杰出发明家特别感到自豪，这提高了杰克在达拉斯的地位。当该公司于 1997 年开设新的基尔比中心时，它在大楼的墙上挂了一张巨大的帆布海报，每个在 I-635 上疾驰而过的通勤者都可以看到：“杰克制造的芯片改变了世界。”当一群达拉斯市民设立一个年度奖项，奖励那些通过科学为人类幸福做出贡献的人们时——获奖者包括医生、化学家、植物学家等——他们给这个奖项起了他们能想到的最合适的名字：基尔比奖。

And so, in an era when everybody is supposed to be famous for fifteen minutes, Jack Kilby and Bob Noyce have never come into their allotted quarter hour. There have been occasional stories about them in newspapers and magazines, particularly in the local media of Dallas and Silicon Valley. In Dallas, as a matter of fact, Jack Kilby is almost a minor-league celebrity, largely because of genuine pride in the hometown boy who did well. The local media call him the “Texas Edison.” There’s an official Texas Historical Marker on the site of the lab where Jack first wrote down the monolithic idea. Texas Instruments is particularly proud of the eminent inventor in its ranks, and that has increased Jack’s stature in Dallas. When the company opened its new Kilby Center in 1997, it hung a massive canvas poster on the wall of the building, visible to every commuter whizzing by on I-635: “The Chip That Jack Built Changed the World.” When a group of Dallas citizens created an annual award for people who contribute to human happiness through science—the laureates include physicians, chemists, botanists, etc.—they gave their prize the most appropriate name they could think of: the Kilby Awards.

除了达拉斯之外，“杰克·基尔比”这个名字被广泛认可的地方就是日本。这个国家不仅纪念爱德华兹·戴明，还纪念微芯片的发明者，微芯片帮助日本在 20 世纪 80 年代在全球工业领域占据了重要地位。部分原因是杰克的名字在日本成为热门新闻长达近二十年，而德州仪器当时正与日本半导体公司争夺专利许可费。德州仪器最初的集成电路专利在日本被称为“Ki-ru-bee tokkyoken”——即“基尔比专利”——因此这个名字多年来一直是日本头版的常用词。除此之外，杰克·基尔比正是日本倾向于崇拜的那种人。索尼创始人盛田昭夫是另一位在日本取得英雄地位的技术专家，他说，他的岛国经济成功的真正关键在于“我们是一个尊重工程师的社会”。因此，日本人自然会尊重一位改变一切的工程师。

Next to Dallas, the one place where the name “Jack Kilby” is fairly broadly recognized is Japan. The country that honors W. Edwards Deming also honors the inventor of the microchip, a product that helped lift the Japanese to global industrial prominence in the 1980s. This is partly because Jack’s name was a hot news item in Japan for almost two decades while Texas Instruments was battling Japanese semiconductor firms for patent license fees. The original TI patent for the integrated circuit is known in Japan as the “Ki-ru-bee tokkyoken”—that is, the “Kilby patent”—and thus the name was for years a common term on Japanese front pages. Beyond that, Jack Kilby is exactly the kind of person that Japan tends to admire. The founder of Sony, Akio Morita, another technologist who achieved heroic stature in Japan, said that the real key to his island country’s economic success was that “we are a society that honors engineers.” So it is natural that the Japanese would honor an engineer who changed everything.

因此，杰克经常从德克萨斯州前往东京，那里的媒体排起了长队，等待采访他。当德州仪器在日本“科学城”筑波开设一家大型新工程中心时，该公司当然派出了其最著名的工程师来主持剪彩仪式。剪彩仪式以典型的日本风格进行，不留任何侥幸心理。杰克和许多日本官员都戴着白手套，拿着金色剪刀，上面装饰着白色、红色和紫色的丝带。他们被带到新大楼入口处的指定位置，一名播音员指示他们：“用右手握住彩带，用左手握住剪刀，将彩带移到刀片上，在镜头前停留十秒钟，现在——剪！”彩带成功剪断后，播音员激动地重播了刚刚发生的事情。“我们深感荣幸，”他最后说，“一位赢得全日本尊敬的工程师今天能加入我们，为我们简陋的中心剪彩。”

Accordingly, Jack has traveled regularly from Texas to Tokyo, where the media literally line up for interviews with him. When Texas Instruments opened a big new engineering center in the “science city” of Tsukuba, Japan, the company, of course, sent its best-known engineer to do the honors. The ribbon-cutting ceremony was performed in characteristic leave-nothing-to-chance Japanese style. Jack and a host of Japanese officials were each given white gloves and golden scissors festooned with white, red, and purple streamers. They were directed to their assigned places at the entrance of the new building, and an announcer instructed them: “Hold the ribbon in your right hand, hold the scissors in your left, bring the ribbon up to the blade, pause ten seconds for the cameras, and now—CUT!” With the ribbon successfully cut, the announcer offered a breathless replay of what had just happened. “We are deeply honored,” he ended, “that an engineer who has won the esteem of all Japan could join us today to open our humble center.”

在国内，杰克无法获得全美国的尊重。但也有过这样的时刻。杰克的第一块集成电路被赠送给史密森学会，与 Keuffel & Esser 的最后一块计算尺不同，它被永久陈列在美国国家历史博物馆。美国邮政局发行了 33 美分的邮票以纪念这项发明（但没有包括发明这项发明的两位美国人的名字）。在杰克·基尔比加入福特和爱迪生的发明名人堂后不久，黛安·索耶飞往达拉斯，为哥伦比亚广播公司的 晨间新闻采访他。采访持续了大约三百秒，索耶提出了一些活泼的问题，杰克则以他缓慢、简洁的方式回答。

Back home, Jack could not quite claim the esteem of all America. But there were moments. Jack’s first integrated circuit was presented to the Smithsonian Institution, where—unlike Keuffel & Esser’s last slide rule—it is on permanent display in the National Museum of American History. The U.S. Postal Service issued a 33-cent stamp honoring the invention (but did not include the names of the two Americans who invented it). And shortly after Jack Kilby joined Ford and Edison in the Inventors Hall of Fame, Diane Sawyer flew to Dallas to interview him for the CBS Morning News. The segment lasted about three hundred seconds, with Sawyer tossing out peppy questions and Jack responding in his slow, laconic way.

“我的意思是，如果要说有什么让美国一直处于技术前沿的话，”索耶说，“那一定是你的发明。”基尔比停顿了一下，思虑再三。“嗯，我还没想过这个问题，”他平静地说。“你从这项发明中赚到钱了吗？”索耶问道。“是的，赚了一些钱，”基尔比回答道。事情开始变得有趣起来，索耶收到了导演的信号：该继续了。她迅速转向镜头说：“一会儿，杰瑞·布罗迪博士将告诉你如何处理宠物的死亡。”杰克·基尔比的辉煌时刻结束了。

“I mean, if you have to think of one thing that kept the United States at the forefront of technology,” Sawyer said, “it was really your invention.” Kilby paused, stewing it over. “Well, I hadn’t thought of it in those terms,” he said quietly. “Have you made money from this invention?” Sawyer asked. “Some, yeah,” Kilby replied. Things were just starting to get interesting when Sawyer got a signal from the director: time to move on. She turned quickly to the camera and said, “Coming up in a moment, Dr. Jerry Brodie on how to handle the death of a pet.” Jack Kilby’s moment in the sun was over.

当然，如果杰克在阳光下呆的时间更长，他可能就会跑到阴凉处。杰克非常脚踏实地，非常谦虚，所以当人们对他的发明感到兴奋时，他似乎很不自在。杰克不但不鼓励人们对他的成就感兴趣，反而倾向于淡化它们。德州仪器开设基尔比中心时，公司杂志采访了，或者至少试图采访该中心的创始人，询问他这个庞大的想法及其后果。杰克被问到：“你有没有想过你会对每个人的日常生活产生如此深远的影响？”“嗯，”他回答说，“我不知道我是否因他们的深远影响而受到赞扬……你今天看到的可能是数万名世界上最优秀的工程师的工作成果，他们都专注于改进产品、降低成本等。”采访者坚持问道：“知道你为德州仪器的今天做出了最重要的贡献之一，你是不是很高兴？”杰克对此并不认同：“好吧，从那时起，已经发生了很多事情，”他说，“很难将今天的 TI 直接归功于任何人。”

Of course, if Jack had remained in the sun much longer, he probably would have been running toward the shade. The man is so down-to-earth, so genuinely modest, that he seems uncomfortable when people get wound up about his inventions. Far from encouraging interest in his achievements, Jack tends to play them down. When Texas Instruments opened its Kilby Center, the company magazine interviewed, or at least tried to interview, the center’s namesake about the monolithic idea and its consequences. “Did you have any idea that you were going to have such a profound effect on everybody’s daily life?” Jack was asked. “Well,” he replied, “I don’t know that I get credit for their profound effect. . . . What you see today is the work of probably tens of thousands of the world’s best engineers, all concentrating on improving the product, reducing the cost, things of that sort.” The interviewer persisted: “Is it nice to know that you made one of the most major contributions in making Texas Instruments what it is today?” Jack was having none of it: “Well, there’s a lot of water under the dam since that time,” he said, “and it’s hard to take any direct credit for the TI of today.”
